abstract: The "E.D. Morgan Artillery Company" carried the name of the Governor of the State and the American flag at the head of the column. This was followed by the Twentieth-Ward Artillery Company and their respective bands. The Ninth-Ward Wide-Awake associations, numbering some two hundred, followed, and after them came the Wide-Awakes of Hartford, New-Haven, and other Connecticut towns, a prominent place being assigned to them, as to Hartford belongs the honor of having originated the Wide-Awake organizations. New-Haven, Bridgeport, West Haven, Hartford, Meriden, Norwalk and Danbury, Connecticut, had about one thousand in the line. Marching as an escort of these Companies were the Sixteenth and Twenty-first Ward Wide-Awakes. Rhode Island followed Connecticut, Providence having about 300, and Newport 50. The Eighth Ward, of New-York, formed the escort. The delegation from Portland, Me., numbered about sixty men.

abstract: Yesterday, one of the finest double team trots which has been witnessed in this vicinity for a long time, came off on the Union Course, for $1,000 a side. The horses are what is termed "crack roadsters," and belong respectively to Mr. H.D. FELTER, a wine merchant on Broadway, and a Mr. MEAD. Mr. FELTER's horses were a splendid pair of light bays, driven by HORACE F. JONES. Mr. MEAD's horses were a black horse and sorrel mare, driven by SAM MCLAUGHLIN. The race was attended by about 200 persons, and seemed to afford great satisfaction to the spectators in every particular. The betting was about 100 to 60 on Mr. FELTER's team at the onset, but after scoring several times, and when it was discovered MCLAUAGHYLIN's horses could not foot with them, it went down to 100 to 10.

abstract: By the steamer Osceola, which arrived yesterday at Batabano from Truxillo, we have received letters which give us an account of the tragical end of the great fillibuster. we insert them below; and it is highly satisfactory to note the Christian death of the celebrated fillibuster. It is a great pity that a man capable of such sentiments should have led a life during which he caused so many disasters to humanity.

abstract: WHO WILL SECEDE. -- The Breckinridge organs and orators, excepting those in the Gulf States, will not admit, categorically, that they are in favor of disunion, in the event of Mr. LINCOLN's election, but all their appeals to the people in behalf of their candidates assume that a Republican triumph will be the signal for instant secession. Now it becomes an interesting question, Who will secede? We know that the Bell and Everett Party will not, because they have no other avowed principle than adherence to the Union, no matter who shall be chosen President by a constitutional majority of the people. It is equally certain that the Douglas Party will not secede, for their leader, in his speech at Norfolk, pledged himself to support Mr. LINCOLN in the execution of the laws. We have also the pledge of the Breckinridge Party, as far down as the thirty-fifth parallel of latitude, to adhere to the Union.
lead_paragraph: WHO WILL SECEDE. -- The Breckinridge organs and orators, excepting those in the Gulf States, will not admit, categorically, that they are in favor of disunion, in the event of Mr. LINCOLN's election, but all their appeals to the people in behalf of their candidates assume that a Republican triumph will be the signal for instant secession. Now it becomes an interesting question, Who will secede? We know that the Bell and Everett Party will not, because they have no other avowed principle than adherence to the Union, no matter who shall be chosen President by a constitutional majority of the people. It is equally certain that the Douglas Party will not secede, for their leader, in his speech at Norfolk, pledged himself to support Mr. LINCOLN in the execution of the laws. We have also the pledge of the Breckinridge Party, as far down as the thirty-fifth parallel of latitude, to adhere to the Union.

abstract: Contiguous to the New-York Hotel, the largest possible crowd of humanity was crammed into the smallest possible space, in the general anxiety to be near one of the most interesting points of view. The proximity of the Central Campaign Club Head-quarters, and the fact of the recent disturbance with the Wide-Awakes in this vicinity, attracted rather a motley gathering of the friends of all the Presidential candidates. The mutual anxiety to out-do one another in cheering for their respective candidates, while it tended greatly to enliven the scene, was at the same time strongly suggestive of bronchitis, sore throats, hoarseness, and cough remedies.

abstract: THOMAS E. MUNDY AGAIN IN CUSTODY. -- Yesterday morning Recorder BARNARD was to have sentenced THOMAS E. MUNDY for the offence to which some weeks ago he had pleaded guilty, of having committed an indecent assault upon a little girl, daughter of a policeman in the Twenty-second Ward. MUNDY had been sauntering about the vestibule of the Court during the morning, but when his name was called he failed to present himself, and consequently his bail was declared forfeited and a bench-warrant was issued for his arrest. Among those who went in search of the fugitive was Capt. DOWLING, of the Sixth Precinct, who heard, at a late hour in the afternoon, that he had concealed himself in Hoboken, and he therefore went over there, and found him. MUNDY stated that he would return without the formality of a requisition being made for his surrender, and he accordingly was brought over, and lodged in a cell in the Sixth Ward Station-house for the night. He expressed great contrition for having forfeited his bail, particularly as he had broken his faith with Mr. WILLIAM MINER, the Register, who had been his bondsman, and who would be a loser by his folly. With reference to his offence, he stated that it was the result of drunkenness, and he seemed to feel very keenly the disgrace which his imprisonment will reflect upon his family.

abstract: The People ex rel. Pettigrew vs. The Street Commissions. -- Motion for mandamus to compel the Street Commissioner to give certificate that the relator is entitled to $32,000 for work done in regulating and grading Third-avenue, from Eighty-sixth to One Hundred and Tenth streets. The case was before Justice LEONARD of the Supreme Court. It appeared from the papers before the Court that a resolution was adopted by the Common Council in 1855 and 1856, by different Boards, in different years. The Street Commissioner advertised for proposals, and awarded the contract to one Fromin, the lowest bidder. This award was confirmed by the Common Council. Fromin entered upon the work. His sureties turned out to be irresponsible, and Taylor, then Street Commissioner, gave the contract to the relator, but did not inform the Common Council, nor did they confirm his action till in 1858, after the Charter of 1857 had come into effect. Mr. Cooper having been appointed Street Commissioner, notified Mr. Pettigrew that he had no contract that would be recognized by his Department. Mr. Pettigrew then got a resolution passed by the Common Council recognizing his contract; but the Street Commissioner showed him that he had still no claim. Mr. Pettigrew then, last Winter, got a bill through the Legislature legalizing the first resolution of the Common Council. He now moves for a mandamus to get his assessment bonds.
lead_paragraph: The People ex rel. Pettigrew vs. The Street Commissions. -- Motion for mandamus to compel the Street Commissioner to give certificate that the relator is entitled to $32,000 for work done in regulating and grading Third-avenue, from Eighty-sixth to One Hundred and Tenth streets. The case was before Justice LEONARD of the Supreme Court. It appeared from the papers before the Court that a resolution was adopted by the Common Council in 1855 and 1856, by different Boards, in different years. The Street Commissioner advertised for proposals, and awarded the contract to one Fromin, the lowest bidder. This award was confirmed by the Common Council. Fromin entered upon the work. His sureties turned out to be irresponsible, and Taylor, then Street Commissioner, gave the contract to the relator, but did not inform the Common Council, nor did they confirm his action till in 1858, after the Charter of 1857 had come into effect. Mr. Cooper having been appointed Street Commissioner, notified Mr. Pettigrew that he had no contract that would be recognized by his Department. Mr. Pettigrew then got a resolution passed by the Common Council recognizing his contract; but the Street Commissioner showed him that he had still no claim. Mr. Pettigrew then, last Winter, got a bill through the Legislature legalizing the first resolution of the Common Council. He now moves for a mandamus to get his assessment bonds.

abstract: European advices two days later are received by the Connaught, which arrived at St. Johns, N.F., yesterday morning. The political news, however, is extremely brief. It is announced that VICTOR EMANUEL had determined to go to Naples. The Sardinian ships had bombarded Ancona for nine hours; and the bombardment had been replied to in a spirited, manner. The action, however, had been suspended for a conference, which would doubtless result in the capitulation of the city. No new movement had been made by GARIBALDI, whose troops were concentrated near Voltera. The Sardinian Ambassador had quitted Paris, leaving the business of the Legation to the Secretary. Queen VICTORIA had embarked for Prussia, accompanied by Lord JOHN RUSSELL, who, it is said, will have a polttical conference with the Prussian Minister of Foreign Affairs. Some additional advices are also received by the Niagara, which reached Halifax yesterday, though nothing of special importance. The steamships Saxonia and Arago, the one from Hamburg and the other from Havre, and both from Southampton on the 19th ult., arrived at this port yesterday. Their news has been anticipated by telegraphic advices of three days later date, but we receive details of considerable interest. The Sardinian memorandum explaining VICTOR EMANUEL's reasons for invading the Pontifical dominions, and the Constitutionnel's semi-official exposition of the recall of the French Minister from Turin, will be found among our extracts. GARIBALDI has issued an important proclamation to the Sicilians, announcing his positive refusal to allow the annexation of the Island to Piedmont at the present time. The Dictator declares that the union of all Italy will only be proclaimed at Rome, by which he is supposed to mean that Venice must first be detached from Austrian authority. We shall have to wait a week or ten days before we can receive full particulars of the late Sardinian victories in the Roman States. The great demonstration of the Wide-Awakes came off last night, and was literally one of the most brilliant affairs in the annals of our political history. By actual count there were more than eleven thousand five hundred torches in procession, and this without including numerous small Clubs detailed to rouse up and awaken the public in portions of the City not traversed by the main Republican army. A very full and detailed report of the whole proceedings will be found on our first page.

abstract: There must have been an "irrepressible conflict" between the political sympathies of the male and female guests of the St. Nicholas Hotel last evening, for while the former ranged themselves on the sidewalk in front of the hotel, and there, almost to a man, manifested in various ways their dislike and disgust at the whole Wide-Awake procession as it passed in review before them, the former presented their beautiful faces, like clusters of roses, at each of the 150 windows that look out on Broadway from the upper stories, and by constant smiles and waving of handkerchiefs testified their delight and approbation of the whole affair. So unanimous and hearty was the Wide-Awake demonstration on the part of the ladies, that one of the male guests on the sidewalk, on looking up and beholding the extent of the fluttering linen overhead, declared that "he'd be d_____d if he didn't believe the St. Nicholas was tinctured with Black Republicanism, and he reckoned he'd change his quarters to-morrow." The procession reached the St. Nicholas about 8 1/2 o'clock, and its approach was the signal for a general outburst of groans, hisses, cat-yawls and sheep-blats, from the aforesaid gentlemen on the walks, all of which was more than counteracted by the quiet and graceful demonstration of delight from the fair faces above them. The Wide-Awakes took no notice of the animal noises on the walk, but lifting their eyes to the angels overhead, returned their salutations by raising their hats and cheering them as they passed. Counter cheers were gotten up by the sidewalk guests for all sorts of persons and things. There were cheers for BRECKINRIDGE, cheers for DOUGLAS, cheers for HOUSTON, cheers for BELL, and one enthusiastic Southerner proposed "Three cheers for more Slave States." which sentiment was heartily responded to. This gentleman, who was said to be a Georgian, appeared to be the spokesman of the Southern portion of the sidewalk, and did pretty much all the talking for the whole crowd in front of the hotel. He was blessed with a pair of lungs scarcely inferior to those of a Durham bull, and his voice could be heard at least two squares above the din of the music, and all the other concomitant noises of the procession. He proposed the sentiments, started the counter cheers, initiated the groans, and in fact led off in all the opposition demonstrations of the sidewalk. Besides leading the opposition forces, he kept up a running fire at the procession on his own hook, in the way of verbal commentary, for about an hour, when he subsided, declared he was going into the hotel to take a drink, and was seen no more. In the beginning of his commentary he exhibited considerable anger, and appeared anxious for a fight, but he soon got better natured, and before he left was quite humorous. When the procession first hove in sight, he led off in something like the following strain: "You're a pretty lot of suckers. Where did you get your cloaks from? You can shoulder your lamps now, but we'll make you shoulder muskets before next Spring. How would you like that? Do you think you can fight, eh?"

abstract: The Lafarge House is about as representative a hotel in its way as any in the City. The proprietor is strongly Democratic in his political proclivities, and the guests are mostly of a Southern stripe. It will readily be inferred that the "Wide-Awakes" were not likely to receive many floral favors while passing this institution. They would naturally expect more hoots to fall upon them than bouquets. And yet the "Slaves of the Lamp" were permitted to pass without any overt demonstrations of the disfavor in which they were held. The curses heaped upon them en passant were not loud, but deep. A Georgian, carried away by the enthusiasm of the moment, lamented in the hearing of our reporter, that he did not have his rifle with him. He said it would afford him especial pleasure to pick off the leaders of the battalions singly; -- against one portly Captain, in particular, he seemed to entertain a singular prejudice, stating that he would experience a grim satisfaction in perforating his abdomen with a leaden bullet. He inclined to regard the "Wide-Awakes" as an organization designed to coerce the South into obedience and quell the first rising symptom of rebellion. They were burning cotton upon the shrine of Republicanism, lighting the path of LINCOLN with the flames of the great Southern staple, and this he very properly viewed as a decided instance of insult added to injury. The smoke of the lamps was an unplesant stench in his nostrils -- as indeed it was in the nostrils of all who leaned from windows or hung themselves out upon balconies. However, the "Wide-Awakes" may have resembled angels of light in the abstract, they certainly smelt like a detachment from the left wing of the Pit in the concrete, and this their most ardent admirers must concede. But the thing that most troubled the Georgian was the perfection of military drill which they exhibited. The command to shoulder candles was obeyed with such promptness and precision, the candles were carried with such an air of bayonet determination, as to excite unpleasant apprehensions in his mind in regard to the consequences should they change with those candles upon a Southern haystack or a cut-and-dried cotton crop. As they wound their way down the street, terrible as an army with lanterns, these contingencies suggested themselves to the Georgian's mind and he trembled. And in a brave man's tremor there is something very difficult from the rattling of a coward's knee-pans.

abstract: The United States Mail steamship Cahawba, J. W. abstract: At a recent meeting of the legislative wisdom of the City, a resolution was passed, directing the erection of a well and pump in one of the far up-town streets, which is deprived of the blessing of the Croton water. The resolution was very brief and very mandatory -- but previous surveys have proven that the grounds in the vicinity named, though treacherously soft to outward tread, are infested with immense boulders beneath, and the Croton Department, to whom the mandate is directed, is in a dilemma. The erection of a pump is the simplest thing in the world, but the digging of a well embraces many difficulties. The resolution of the Common Council prescribes no depth, and if the Croton Board should be compelled to resort to the Artesian process, and bore through some hundred feet of rock, who would foot the bill? The necessity for explicit directions, where removal for cause is threatened, is abundantly exemplified in this case. Parties assessed for benefit would not tamely submit, and if the City was called upon to pay, it is scarcely questionable whether an Engineer, who could be guilty of such an extravagant construction of plain directions, might fairly expect to be impeached for "ignorance and incapacity." The question now is, "What is a well ?"

abstract: It was thought that the pickpockets would improve the occasion which the immense crowd offered to labor in their peculiar way. The Detective Police accordingly were on the qui v[???]ive to arrest the operations of well-known rogu[???]es, but in spite of their utmost vigilance, not more than seven of this class of offenders were found. Ordinarily on the occurrence of large processions or celebrations, the number of pickpockets taken in to be kept out of "harm's way" has at least reached fifty; and the only way in which the decrease can be accounted for is in the fact that the recent stringent law passed against them has rendered their pursuit so hazardous as to be unprofitable. None of those arrest[???]d last evening were caught in the commission of offence, but their apprehension was effected to keep them beyond the reach of temptation; and when the procession had been dismissed they were set at liberty.

abstract: "Le roi s'amuse: the sovereigns enjoy themselves," was the observation of a swarthy mild-eyed man, who stood in the portico of the Metropolitan, as he saw the sky begin to glow with the countless torches of the advancing columns of the Wide-Awake hosts. "Oh, yes," retorted a person at his elbow, whose accent betrayed his New-England origin, "Them's boys, Sir, as is to do the business. I rather guess we're going to open the eyes of the Democratic Party this time." "Perhaps you may," said the Southron, but you know the old Latin poet's declaration: 'Hic nam plebecula gaudet?" "Ach, now, yer honor, said an Irish waiter, who was standing on tip-toe, striving to peer through the human mass that blocked up the entrance, "sure that manes something, anyhow?" He winked significantly as he spoke, and with an air of familiarity that indicated a former acquaintanceship. "Yes, JIMMY," was the response, "it means that such displays as this which have for their design to influence the public sentiment of the country in a great political crisis, betray the inherent weakness of the party who has recourse to them, and furnish melancholy evidence of the growing degeneracy of Northern politics. "Excuse, me, Sir," said a polite Republican; "I think differently. No display of popular enthusiasm in behalf of a great cause, can be taken as indicative of degeneracy, and we only wish to secure aid in the struggle to promote our principles by appealing to the popular sympathy with all great movements, when those movements are, as it were, physically embodied -- when their power is made obvious to the sense. There is an immense inchoate force in a great public exhibition. The orator, in his most exquisite apostrophes and most powerful addresses to the passions, speaks to one man, and awakens criticism; he speaks to a multitude, and elicits thunders of approving cheers. The same may be said of the effect of an imposing multitude on an admiring multitude; admiration rises, first, into sympathy, and then into conviction."

abstract: On the evening of Thursday, should the weather prove favorable, a grand display of fireworks will be given on the grounds south of the President's Mansion in honor of Lord RENFREW and his suite. This exhibition, we understand, will exceed anything which has ever been presented before the public in this country. The various pieces have been arranged and designed by that efficient and skillful officer, Maj. GEO. D. RAMSAY, Commandant at the U.S. Arsenal, and prepared by Mr. THOMAS B. BROWN, chief pyrotechnist, who has always met with remarkable success in his displays of pyrotechnic works. The Marine Band will be in attendance in the President's grounds, and add to the interest of the occasion by the rendition of many of our most patriotic and stirring airs.

The Marine Band will be in attendance in the President's grounds, and add to the interest of the occasion by the rendition of many of our most patriotic and stirring airs.

abstract: Every available position was occupied at the windows, and on the steps of the Astor House, long before the how for the procession to arrive, as this was considered the most eligible point from which to view the pageant throughout its entire length. The sidewalk was densely packed. If there were Southerners in this particular crowd, or others opposed to the Republicans, they generally restrained the expression of their feelings, and there was little exhibition of spleen or ill-will noticed, while from all the windows and from many on the sidewalk there were cheers, waving of handkerchiefs, and other friendly greetings. From the windows and balconies of POWERS & LOVEJOY's Hotel, on Park-row, the good-natured multitude waved; and cheered in response to the salutes from the procession. The ladies were particularly earnest in these demonstrations of good will.
lead_paragraph: Every available position was occupied at the windows, and on the steps of the Astor House, long before the how for the procession to arrive, as this was considered the most eligible point from which to view the pageant throughout its entire length. abstract: The will of Edward B. Murray was admitted to probate, yesterday, before the Surrogate, Hon. EDW. C. WEST. The deceased was a member of the firm of McGrath, Tweed & Co. He died worth about $20,000. His entire estate is bequeathed to his wife, to revert in equal shares to his two children at her death. To each of his sisters the testator bequeathed $1,000, and a like amount to his brother. These bequests are conditional that the estate nets $10,000 after paying debts and expenses.
lead_paragraph: The will of Edward B. Murray was admitted to probate, yesterday, before the Surrogate, Hon. EDW. C. WEST. The deceased was a member of the firm of McGrath, Tweed & Co. abstract: - The news we receive from Oregon is not flattering to the home and fireside popularity of Gen. Jo. LANE. Oregon has abandoned the service of the Slavery propagandists; and a majority of its Legislature, composed of friends of DOUGLAS and LINCOLN, has determined to substitute for such worthless instruments of secession as the present Senator, men of more decided character and more liberal opinions. The geographical paradox of a Southern State in the extreme North-west is therefore extinguished. Oregon is henceforth a free-labor State.

abstract: By the steamship City of Baltimore, which passed Cape Race yesterday, we have European advices to the 27th ult., two days' later. The Sardinian forces continued their advance into the Papal States, and had captured the fortress of Santo Leo. The bombardment of Ancona by sea and land continued. GARIBALDI had concentrated his troops on the heights of Valtoona, preparatory to attacking the Neapolitans.
lead_paragraph: By the steamship City of Baltimore, which passed Cape Race yesterday, we have European advices to the 27th ult., two days' later. The Sardinian forces continued their advance into the Papal States, and had captured the fortress of Santo Leo. The bombardment of Ancona by sea and land continued. GARIBALDI had concentrated his troops on the heights of Valtoona, preparatory to attacking the Neapolitans. The Dictator had issued a fresh proclamation, indicating that he would join the Sardinian troops at Rome and begin a march against Venice. The official journal at Rome contains the note of Cardinal ANTONELLI, claiming the assistance of the Catholic Powers. Some addittional European news is also received by the Connaught, whose arrival at St. Johns was announced in yesterday's TIMES. The breach between GARIBALDI and the Count DE CAVOUR threatens to be a serious obstacle to the complete success of the revolution. It is reported that VICTOR EMANUEL will go to Naples for a personal incourse with GARIBALDI. Further details of LAMORICIERE's defeat near Ancona show that 600 prisoners were taken by the Sardinians, and that 4,000 of the Papal troops capitulated. The mails by the Canadian steamship North American reached this City yesterday. They include Paris and London journals of the 20th ult. -- one day later than those brought by the Arago -- and furnish us with interesting particulars of intelligence previously received. The Glasgow also arrived at this port last night. Her advices have been anticipated. The telegraph lines of the New-York and Newfoundland Telegraph Company, extending from Port Hood to St. Johns and Cape Race, N.F., and from Sackville, N.B., to Charlottetown, P.E.I., -in all about eight or nine hundred miles in extent -have been leased for a term of years by the New-York Associated Press, and the services of Mr. A.M. MACKAY, the past and present excellent General Superintendent of the lines, have been retained. The new arrangement goes into effect on the 1st of November next. Much more extended arrangements are being made to intercept the European steamers off Cape Race, with every prospect of obtaining news from a large proportion of the passing steamers, which now number about two hundred per annum from Europe. Arrangements are also in progress by which the commercial public will have greatly increased and more reliable facilities for transacting European and other business over the Newfoundland line.

abstract: BOYS FOR THE WEST. -- A company of boys and girls from the Children's Aid Society will leave the City for homes in the West on Wednesday, the 10th inst. Parents who are too poor to provide for their children, as they would desire, will do well to take this opportunity of securing their welfare in good places in the country. Many a poor father and mother who have made application for their children on seeing former notices of this kind, have had their hearts gladdened with happy news from the little ones in their new homes. Information may be had at the Newsboys' Lodging-house, No. 128 Fulton-street, Sun Building.

abstract: On Wednesday, as we stated, Mr. Thomas J. Monday, late member of Assembly, who had pleaded guilty to an indecent assault in a former term of this Court, before Recorder BARNARD, and who was then remanded for sentence, until such time as inquiry could be made into his state of mind, and other matters incident to the cage, was to have been sentenced by the Recorder, such inquiries having been made, ...
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, as we stated, Mr. Thomas J. Monday, late member of Assembly, who had pleaded guilty to an indecent assault in a former term of this Court, before Recorder BARNARD, and who was then remanded for sentence, until such time as inquiry could be made into his state of mind, and other matters incident to the cage, was to have been sentenced by the Recorder, such inquiries having been made, and the result proven to be unsatisfactory. But as we have said, Mr. Munday did not choose to appear, and by order of the Recorder his bail was forfeited, his bondsman being Mr. William Miner, the City Register. On Wednesday night, being discovered at Hoboken by Capt. Dowling, he accompanied him back to the City, and was confined in the Sixth Ward Station-house, Yesterday morning he was brought into Court, and placed at the bar for sentence.

abstract: JAMES F. DWIGHT, Esq., late Assistant United States District Attorney, has been appointed Special Commissioner to take the testimony of ISAAC V. FOWLER, the former Postmaster of this City -- in the suit of the United States vs. GEO. LAW and CONOVER, FOWLEE's sureties on his official bond. The Commission was granted some days ago, and on Wednesday, by the consent of the parties, Judge BETTS appointed Mr. DWIGHT, who leaves to-day in the Quaker City for Havana, where it is understood FOWLER is at present.

abstract: The principal speaker was Hon. F.P. STANTON, Gov. WALKER'S Secretary, and at one time Governor of Kansas. He took occasion to review the effect of what some called the "dead question" of Slavery upon Mr. BUCHANAN'S Administration.
lead_paragraph: The principal speaker was Hon. F.P. STANTON, Gov. WALKER'S Secretary, and at one time Governor of Kansas. He took occasion to review the effect of what some called the "dead question" of Slavery upon Mr. BUCHANAN'S Administration. He showedhow, commencing with the confidence of the people, Mr. BUCHANAN had concluded by distracting his party, violating his pledges, and losing the esteem of honest men. He reviewed the course of events in Kansas, pointed out how the President had violated his plighted faith and the avowed intent of the Kansas-Nebraska bill, and ruthlessly sacrificed all former friends who refused to participate in his guilt. As a representative of the largest slave district in Tennessee, he had voted for that bill, and knew that the construction upon it by the Administration was quite the reverse of that held by the supporters of the bill. He depicted in forcible language the burning wrongs inflicted upon Kansas by unprincipled minorities under the protection of the Administration, and insisted that the retribution visited was just.

abstract: This regiment, which has (by official permission) occupied Bedloe's Island for the past week as an encampment and practice ground, returned yesterday to the City, well embrowned, well wearied, and evidently well exercised during their week of duty. The Fifth, under the command of Col. SCHWARTZWAELDER, reflected high credit upon themselves and their commander, proving that the week passed on the Island had not been lost. Their marching was so steady and compact as to draw forth plaudits from the large crowd assembled to witness their evolutions.

abstract: A Turin letter gives the following particulars respecting the taking of Perugia by Gen. FANTI: "The town was defended by about 3,000 men, who fought with great resolution. The garrison had raised barricades in all parts of the town, and occupied the houses from which they fired upon the Sardinians. Every street was the scene of a conflict; but the assistance afforded to Gen. FANTI by the inhabitants made the struggle much shorter than it would otherwise have been. A considerable portion of the Pontifical carbineers contrived to escape out of the town -- the others retired to the citadel, which could not hold out long. Towards evening the fort capitulated, and the whole of the garrison, consisting of 1,600 men, were made prisoners, as well as Gen. SCHMIDT, who commanded them. He is the worthy chief of the adventurers whom the Italians so cordially detest. Switzerland refuses to acknowledge him. He was one of the heroes of that impious war of the Sonderbund, which caused much bloodshed in the Swiss canons. He was subsequently exiled, and if he is again set at liberty he certainly will not find a refuge in Switzerland."

abstract: John Richardson et. al. vs. The Schooner G.H. Montague. This is a libel filed in the U.S. Circuit Court, Judge NELSON presiding, to recover the possession of the schooner by the owners. The proofs are very voluminous and complicated, embracing some nine hundred folios in manuscript.
lead_paragraph: John Richardson et. al. vs. The Schooner G.H. Montague. This is a libel filed in the U.S. Circuit Court, Judge NELSON presiding, to recover the possession of the schooner by the owners. The proofs are very voluminous and complicated, embracing some nine hundred folios in manuscript. It is not denied but that the libelants were the original owners of the vessel, nor but that the claimant is a bona fide purchaser for value. The question in the case is, whether or not Atwater, who sold and conveyed her to the claimant, had, at the time of the conveyance, obtained the title of the libelants. We agree, if he possessed the title at the time, though obtained through fraud and covin, the claimant being a bona fide purchaser, is to be protected. And hence the libelants are bound to show that they have not parted with the title, or in other words, that Atwater had not acquired it. It is quite clear, if the question was simply between the libelants and Atwater, or between Mix and them, from whom Atwater derived the possession, there could be no great difficulty in disposing of it, as Mix took possession professedly for the benefit of the libelants, and the proofs show that Atwater is chargeable with notice of the circumstances, and acted in the sale to the claimant in collusion with Mix.

abstract: The first meeting of this society since the summer vacation, was held at Clinton Hall, last evening, the President, Dr. F.L. HANKS, in the chair. Owing to the small number of persons in attendance, consequent upon the inclement weather, and the fact that due notice of the meeting had not been served upon the members, Judge DALY moved that the reading of the paper upon Syria, by Rev. Dr. J.P. THOMPSON, which was to have been the feature of the evening, be postponed to the next meeting of the society, to be held on the 25th inst.

abstract: It is announced with a flourish of trumpets that Fusion has at last been effected, that an electoral ticket has been nominated for which the Breckinridge and the Douglas Democrats and the Bell and Everett men of this State are expected to vote.
lead_paragraph: It is announced with a flourish of trumpets that Fusion has at last been effected, that an electoral ticket has been nominated for which the Breckinridge and the Douglas Democrats and the Bell and Everett men of this State are expected to vote. The utmost which this arrangement can effect is the defeat of LINCOLN. No one of its friends expects anything more from it. Nobody anticipates for a moment that either of the other candidates can possibly be elected by the people. The Fusionists will have accomplished all they hope for if they can defeat a choice by the people and throw the election into the House of Representatives. No such result has followed a Presidential election since 1824, and the people, consequently, are in the main ignorant of what will be the workings of an election by the House.

abstract: Gen. BARROW, of Tennessee, a very near neighbor of Hon. JOHN BELL, and once a member of Congress, made a speech last night to the Young Men's National Union Club, who hold forth at No. 654 Broadway. The General was decidedly dilatory. He was to have been on hand at 7 1/2 o'clock; it was 9, if not more than 9, when he entered the hall, and many of his embryotic admirers began to entertain grave fears about him. At length he presented himself, and a very presentable man he is, indeed: he stands about 6 feet 3 in his stocking soles; is proportionately built, wears a genial, rotund face, and combines in his person all the physical characteristics of a fine old Kentucky gentleman.

abstract: Richard C. Dean, alias Dunn, alias Andrews, alias a dozen other names, was yesterday apprehended by Officer Anderson, of the Eleventh Precinct, on suspicion of having stolen a case of cloth caps, on Monday last, from the store No. 70 Broadway. The case had been lowered to the sidewalk from one of the upper stories of the building, but when the porter came down to look for it, he found it was a "case of mysterious disappearance." The prisoner at the time of his arrest had with him a carpet-bag full of caps answering the description of those which had been stolen, and he was peddling them at a suspiciously low figure. When taken to the Station-house a bunch of skeleton keys was found upon him, and altogether circumstances were so much against him that Justice BRENNAN, before whom he was taken, held him for trial.

abstract: The New-York Associated Press has leased the New foundland Telegraph lines for five years. This step has been taken by the members of the Association to protect themselves against the hostility with which they are men  aced by the American Telegraph Company.
lead_paragraph: The New-York Associated Press has leased the New foundland Telegraph lines for five years. This step has been taken by the members of the Association to protect themselves against the hostility with which they are men aced by the American Telegraph Company. Since this corporation obtained control of all the seaboard Telegraph lines, it has been aiming steadily and vigorously to perfect the monopoly thus established, and to obtain absolute and unrestricted control of news from every part of the world. The Executive Committee, in several pamphlets they have issued, avow their determination to break up the New-York Press Association, and to start rival news agencies for the supply of telegraphic intelligence to the newspapers. What they seek to accomplish by this, according to their own statement, is to compel the newspapers to expend more money on the telegraph. Instead of having one dispatch used by seven or eight papers, who divide the expense among them, the committee think that a separate dispatch should come, and be paid for by each separate newspaper, -- so that the company's receipts for each item of news might be multiplied sevenfold. This is their idea of the relations that ought to exist between the Telegraph and the Press; and, since the consolidation of their lines, they have been lending all their energy and ingenuity, and using the funds of the Company, to the realization of this scheme.
headline: {'main': 'The Press and the Telegraph.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Press and the Telegraph.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We are in a state of actual war. It is on our Tuscan border, and the popular heart here is beating with new pulsations. It is not purely and simply the war of revolution, such as GARIBALDI has been leading so gallantly in the South, but a war declared by one State against another by a regular proclamation.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Friday, Sept. 14, 1860.

abstract: The concluding race of the Fall meeting on the Fashion Race Course, took place yesterday, and was as fine a contest as could be desired. About fifteen hundred persons witnessed the race. The credit of the race yesterday, is due to the proprietors of the course, who offered a purse of $700 for a three-mileheat race, to make up for the disappointment to the...
lead_paragraph: The concluding race of the Fall meeting on the Fashion Race Course, took place yesterday, and was as fine a contest as could be desired. About fifteen hundred persons witnessed the race. The credit of the race yesterday, is due to the proprietors of the course, who offered a purse of $700 for a three-mileheat race, to make up for the disappointment to the subscribers to the Fall meeting, which arose from Daniel Boone's withdrawal from the great four-mile race, and the forfeiture of Prophet to Oysterman in the four-mile race for $10,000. For the race yesterday, four horses were entered: Throggs Neck, Muddy Coon, Nicholas I., and Oysterman. Nicholas and Oysterman were all that started, and the track was rather dead and unfavorable for fast time. Nicholas, who had run splendidly with Daniel Boone on his trial trips, was, it was said, slightly lame, and in consequence the betting ran currently at 100 to 60 on Oysterman, previous to the start.

abstract: We have been compelled so often to comment in terms of censure upon the manner in which criminal justice is administered in this City that we cannot but rejoice at the occurrence of a single instance of righteous judgment against a criminal whose escape from the penalty of retributive justice the public had begun to expect, or at least to fear.
lead_paragraph: We have been compelled so often to comment in terms of censure upon the manner in which criminal justice is administered in this City that we cannot but rejoice at the occurrence of a single instance of righteous judgment against a criminal whose escape from the penalty of retributive justice the public had begun to expect, or at least to fear. It will be remembered that last Spring, THOMAS J. MUNDAY, a man who has been a member of the Legislature, and has occupied, at various times, other offices in the gift of this City, was brought before Recorder BARNARD on a charge of most disgusting attempts to corrupt the morals of some little girls on their way to school. To this charge the prisoner pleaded guilty, and was discharged upon bail to await the sentence of the Court.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- This evening Miss CUSHMAN will take her first benefit in the United States, since her last engagement, nearly four years ago. She will play Bianca, in MILMAN's tragedy of "Fazio," in which she appeared on Wednesday night and on last night. Those who have seen her in that character must wish to see her again -- those who have not, should not lose the opportunity. What lover of the drama of the present generation would not be proud to have seen Mrs. SIDDONS in her palmy days? Let such enthusiasts not neglect Miss CUSHMAN. We never saw her play with more vigor than in her present engagement.

abstract: The whole country awaits with intense interest the result of next Tuesday's election in Pennsylvania. It will go very far towards deciding the contest. It is true FOSTER is the candidate of both wings of the Democratic Party, and his success will not, therefore, imply the defeat of LINCOLN in November. Still the moral effect of a Democratic victory now would be very great, not only in Pennsylvania itself, but in this State. It would give increased courage and hope to the Fusion movement. The election of CURTIN, the Republican candidate for Governor, on the contrary, would render the vote of Pennsylvania very certain for LINCOLN, and would be widely regarded as deciding the Presidential contest.
lead_paragraph: The whole country awaits with intense interest the result of next Tuesday's election in Pennsylvania. It will go very far towards deciding the contest. abstract: AMERICAN BIBLE SOCIETY. -- At the meeting of the Board of Managers of the Bible Society, last Thursday, communications were received from agents, giving an account of the work in their several fields: From JASON W. STONE, Para, South America, giving an account of distribution of the Scriptures up the Amazon and Madeira Rivers; from Rev. Mr. BLACKFORD, Rio Janeiro, acknowledging the receipt of books from this Society, and giving encouraging accounts as to the prospect for circulating the Scriptures in Brazil; from Mr. JAMES OLIVER, Fray Bentos, in regard to distribution of the Scriptures in Uruguay; [???] Col. TRONCHIN, Geneva, sending an account of the labor of Bible distributors in Italy, and requesting further appropriations; from Rev. J.G. BALDWIN, Fuh Chau, in regard to versions of the Holy Scriptures to China; from the Secretary of the Netherlands Bible Society, with a donation for the Library of valuable books relating to the Indian Archipelago, and giving a statement of the distribution of the Holy Scriptures by that Society. Grants of books were made to the American Tract Society; to the New-York Colonization Society, for recaptured Africans in Liberia; German Bibles for distribution in Canada; Bibles and Testaments in various languages for Rio Janeiro, for Ceylon, and the region of the Uruguay River, S.A., and Bogota; with several grants to needy Sunday Schools where there are no auxiliaries, and for distribution in Kansas, Texas, and California, in places where there are no societies; and eighteen volumes in raised letters for the blind.

abstract: Broadway is not merely a great "institution" itself an institution which all the world may well be excused for determining once in its life to see. It is also a sort of Banyan tree, continually sending out tributary "institutions," which swell the interest of the "mighty parent" with a thousand new and various interests of their own. In Broadway all merchants become princely, all trades palatial. The old
lead_paragraph: Broadway is not merely a great "institution" itself an institution which all the world may well be excused for determining once in its life to see. It is also a sort of Banyan tree, continually sending out tributary "institutions," which swell the interest of the "mighty parent" with a thousand new and various interests of their own. In Broadway all merchants become princely, all trades palatial. The old contempt which wholesale commerce traditionally entertains for its more homely and familiar brother, commerce by retail, threatens to become ridiculous in the natural progress of Broadway. When ladies buy their laces and their ribbons under frescoed ceilings and within marble porches, and seamstresses may buy their wedding-rings in ornamental halls, it is absurd to pooh-pooh the mercer and the goldsmith in favor of the Indian magnate or the China shipper. The day is not far distant when every branch of human industry will have its representative palace along the line of our great thoroughfare; and scarce a month passes over one's head that we are not called upon to chronicle some new effervescence of the magnificent enterprise which is doing for New-York what CAESAR AUGUSTUS did for Rome.

abstract: If Italy were but half as safe from her friends as she is from her foes, we might look upon the sternest crisis of her history as already past. True, the Pope still lingers at the Vatican, perhaps unwilling to inflict upon his French defenders the extreme anguish of seeing him depart from the dominions which they have so painfully preserved for him, -- perhaps, too, a trifle uncertain as to whether he could more oblige his enemies than by taking himself comfortably out of their way.
lead_paragraph: If Italy were but half as safe from her friends as she is from her foes, we might look upon the sternest crisis of her history as already past. abstract: INTERESTING TO GAS CONSUMERS. -- JESSE C. ROWEN formerly occupied a hired house and took gas from the Brooklyn Gas-light Company, making the usual deposit of $5 as security. Last Spring he moved into a house of his own, and receiving gas from the same company, permitted the original deposit to remain. Recently, Mr. ROWEN withdrew his deposit, it not being the practice of the company to demand security of parties owning the house supplied. The Company paid him interest on the deposit up to the time he occupied his own house, but refused to pay interest after that. Mr. ROWEN sued the Company for the balance of interest to test the question in Justice VOORHIES' Court, but the Company, rather than stand the test, paid the demand in full.
lead_paragraph: INTERESTING TO GAS CONSUMERS. -- JESSE C. ROWEN formerly occupied a hired house and took gas from the Brooklyn Gas-light Company, making the usual deposit of $5 as security. abstract: Miss PATTI is certainly the most prompt and peremptory little prima donna in the world. On Wednesnesday evening she essayed the role, perfectly new for her, of Violetta, in "La Traviata," and achieved a decided vocal triumph. One new part in a week might well content an ordinary singer -- but Miss PATTI is no ordinary singer; on the contrary, she is an extraordinarily willful little siren. She chose to sing two new parts in a week, and as the proverb tells us, Ce que femme vent, Dieu le vent, Miss PATTI last night attacked part number two, and conquered it. The character of Linda belongs, both musically and dramatically, to the natural repertoire of Miss PATTI. Her emotions never rise into even the semblance of passionate melodrama, save in that scena of the second act, in which the venerable parent of Linda, horrified, rejects the gold which he supposes to be the wages of his daughter's shame. And as the strength of this scene lies with the paternal baritone, the filial soprano having little to do but to lament and be musically miserable, Miss PATTI was equal to its requirements. For the rest of the opera she sang it with a fluency and grace worthy of all praise. FERRI performed his part, too, with unusual spirit, and earned honest plaudits for the dramatic energy and musical fire which he threw into his representation of the Savoyard father.
lead_paragraph: Miss PATTI is certainly the most prompt and peremptory little prima donna in the world. abstract: Important advices reach us from Mexico, by way of New-Orleans. The report of the final condemnation and confiscation of the Spanish bark Maria Concepcion is confirmed. The Spanish Commodore threatened to bombard the city in retaliation, and would probably have put his threat in execution, but Capt. JARVIS, of the American squadron, interfered and condemned such a course, and the whole Spainsh squadron, with the exception of one vessel, thereupon left for Havana.
lead_paragraph: Important advices reach us from Mexico, by way of New-Orleans. The report of the final condemnation and confiscation of the Spanish bark Maria Concepcion is confirmed. The Spanish Commodore threatened to bombard the city in retaliation, and would probably have put his threat in execution, but Capt. JARVIS, of the American squadron, interfered and condemned such a course, and the whole Spainsh squadron, with the exception of one vessel, thereupon left for Havana. The Liberals, meantime, had come into the possession of sundry sinews of war, with which the demonstration against the Capital was to be prosecuted with vigor. DEGOLLADO had seized a conducla with $1,200,000, and DOBLADO had effected a loan of $600,000 -- whether in the same honest manner is not stated. The vanguard of the Liberal army had reached Tacubaya.

abstract: The only real danger which now menaces the peace of the Southern States, results from the studied, persistent and extravagant misrepresentations of the principles and purposes of the Republican, Party, by Democratic demagogues. It seems to be the chief vocation of these political desperadoes to impute the most diabolical aims to the great party, which under
lead_paragraph: The only real danger which now menaces the peace of the Southern States, results from the studied, persistent and extravagant misrepresentations of the principles and purposes of the Republican, Party, by Democratic demagogues. It seems to be the chief vocation of these political desperadoes to impute the most diabolical aims to the great party, which under the forms of the Constitution, is about to assume the administration of the Federal Government. According to their enemies, the Republican Party aims at nothing less than the immediate destruction of Slavery in the States; and to effect this object, the Constitution is to be trampled under the unhallowed feet of Abolition incendiaries, the sovereignty of the States is to be overthrown, and the Government of the Union is to become a consolidated despotism. If we are to believe the same authorities, the negroes of the South are not only to be made free by an act of Congress, or by the habeas corpus, but they are to be made in all respects the political and social equals of the whites, if, indeed, the latter class is not to be forced into subjection to their slaves.

abstract: Elmira seems destined to a hard fate in Fair times, for the last State Exhibition here, five years ago, was attended with a severe storm, which did much damage to many articles, and the two first days of this week were rainy, cold and uncomfortable. Though cloudy this morning, it cleared up by 10 o'clock, and a dense mass of humanity poured through each of the four entrance gates.

abstract: The first sod of the new Theatre on Thirteenth-street and Broadway is to be turned, this morning, by the veteran WALLACK himself, surrounded by all the beauties of his Court. For the lot, 150 by 75, which he has taken on a lease of ten years, he pays Mr. GIBSON an annual rent of $10,000 a year, and all taxes, the rent to commence from to-day. In addition, he is to pay $2,500 for the entrance on Broadway, for the first five years, and $3,500 for the remaining five. Mr. WALLACK lodges with Mr. GIBSON $5,000 as security for the erection of the building, which sum, on its completion, is to be allowed in the first payment of rent. The Theatre is estimated to cost, in erection and fittings, &c., $30,000, and at the close of the ten years passes into Mr. GIBSON's hands. Mr. TRIMBLE is preparing the plan. Besides Mr. WALLACK's, there have been numerous other offers for the site. The French Company, the HANLON BROS., and Mr. WILLARD, on the part of Mr. CHARLES THORNE, have been in the field.

abstract: The positions occupied by the contending parties in Italy is at this moment as striking in strategical as in political points of view. If a triangle be drawn on the map with its base extending along a line a few minutes westward of, but parallel to, the fourteenth meridian, it would have at its southernmost point Gaeta, and at the northernmost, Ancona.
lead_paragraph: The positions occupied by the contending parties in Italy is at this moment as striking in strategical as in political points of view. If a triangle be drawn on the map with its base extending along a line a few minutes westward of, but parallel to, the fourteenth meridian, it would have at its southernmost point Gaeta, and at the northernmost, Ancona. The shorter sides would converge from those points at Rome. At Gaeta, upon a spur of rock projecting into the Mediterranean, just as Ancona projects into the Adriatic, is the King of Naples, in all probability inclosed just now by the land and sea forces of GARIBALDI. At Ancona, LAMORICIERE, with the relics, and doubtless the better portion of his troops, is shut up by a Sardinian fleet and army; while the intervening territory is either occupied by the liberating armies or in a state of sympathetic revolt. Rome, and its immediate vicinage, is in the hands of the French, in number sufficiently strong to resist any force likely to be brought against it; and there the Pope lingers, weighing the temptation to security in flight, against the duty of contending yet longer for the fragments of his temporal authority.

lead_paragraph: Between 1 and 2 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, a woman named HESTER FINLEY, residing somewhere in First-avenue, near Eleventh-street, was murdered by her husband, DANIEL FINLEY, while she was visiting at the tenement house No. 199 East Fourteenth-street. The circumstances of the case, as narrated by the police of the Eighteenth Ward, are as follows: Deceased and her husband, in consequence of their intemperate habits, had lived miserably together for a long time. Frequently the woman would spend days in dissipation, and but a day or two since she was. imprisoned for drunkenness.

abstract: The steamship Northern Light, the delay in the arrival of which had begun to cause some apprehensions as to her safety, reached this port last night. She brings no mails, passengers or treasure from California, the John L. Stephens, the  steamer on the Pacific side, having failed to reach Panama up to the 30th ult., the day on which the Northern Light left Aspinwall.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Northern Light, the delay in the arrival of which had begun to cause some apprehensions as to her safety, reached this port last night. She brings no mails, passengers or treasure from California, the John L. Stephens, the steamer on the Pacific side, having failed to reach Panama up to the 30th ult., the day on which the Northern Light left Aspinwall. The detention of the Stephens, which is known to have left San Francisco on the regular day, is supposed to have been caused by some accident to her machinery in a gale. She has but one engine, the disabling of which would cause a serious delay. The Northern Light brings highly interesting intelligence from Central and South America.

abstract: REOPENING OF CALVARY CHURCH.--This beautiful Episcopal Church, on the corner of Twentieth-street and Fourth-avenue, was re-opened yesterday for divine service, after having been closed for several weeks to allow repairs and alterations to be made, which have added much to the beauty and ornament of the edifice and the comfort of the congregation.
lead_paragraph: REOPENING OF CALVARY CHURCH.--This beautiful Episcopal Church, on the corner of Twentieth-street and Fourth-avenue, was re-opened yesterday for divine service, after having been closed for several weeks to allow repairs and alterations to be made, which have added much to the beauty and ornament of the edifice and the comfort of the congregation. The church has undergone a thorough renovation, and the panneling of the building has been painted in imitation of black walnut. A new study has been built for the pastor, in the rear of the vestry-room, and other additions have been made throughout. The church was densely crowded yesterday, to listen to the services, which were conducted by Rev. Dr. HAWKS, assisted by Rev. Messrs. EIGENBRODT and FROSH. The chanting by the choir was excellent. One of the attractive features of the church, on Sabbath-days, is the appearance of some thirty neally-dressed German children, varying in age from 6 to 14 years, who are clothed and educated by the Church, They are always seated in front of the chancel.

abstract: We are gratified to witness the vigor with which the Bell and Everett and Douglas parties South press upon their adversaries of the Breckinridge school the charge of disunion, and demand a categorical response to it. This fact shows, at least, that the union feeling is predominant, and that the spirit of disunion is exceptional. This is true even in Georgia, while all the Slave-States north of it are firm in their attachment to the Union. In view of this highly gratifying state of things in the Southern States, it is surprising that the President's organ gives unmistakable evidence of its sympathies with the disunionists. That journal published, a few days ago, the latest disunion manifesto of Mr. KEITT, of South Carolina, with the faintest possible expression of its dissent from some portions of it. The official organ omits to inform us whether Mr. KEITT falls below or goes beyond its ideal of a true disunionist. But the South Carolinian talks of nothing but disunion, and the organ only declares that it cannot indorse all that he says, while commending the letter, to the attention of its readers.

abstract: On Saturday the Woman's Library was crowded with ladies, and the pleasure and satisfaction they seemed to feel in having a handsome institution of this kind for themselves, were not only plainly apparent, but eagerly expressed. Among the books called for during the day were: Dewitt's Practical Ethics, Ruskin's Seven Lamps of Architecture, and Arnold's Elementary Greek Grammar, proving beyond a doubt that women intend to make use of their library to some purpose. For a circulating library of its kind, where the books have been selected with care, it is the cheapest in the world -- the yearly subscription fee being but $1. The Library, as our lady readers are aware, is in the New-York University, on Washington-square, and the location is a peculiarly pleasant one for such an institution. It is open from 9 in the morning until 8 in the evening.

abstract: It will be seen from our law-reports that no Receiver has yet been appointed by the Supreme Court in the case of the Artisans' Bank; and from the course which the proceedings have taken, it must be evident that certain of the Directors in that institution now entertain a desire to retrace their steps, deny the hitherto conceded insolvency of their concern, and thus withdraw its affairs from that rigid and honest investigation with which it is threatened by Judge LEONARD.

abstract: A mass meeting is to be held this evening at the Cooper Institute to ratify the Fusion electoral ticket. It will be large and enthusiastic, for instead of being addressed to the members of any one political party, it invites all of every party who are opposed to the election of a President by the American people, and in favor of throwing the election into the House of Representatives.

abstract: Mr. H.J. RAYMOND made a speech on Friday night at the Republican Head-quarters of the Sixth Ward, in Brooklyn, to a large and intelligent meeting, upon the perils and prospects of the pending Presidential canvass. A considerable portion of his remarks were devoted to a critical analysis of the attempted Coalition of the three parties opposed to LINCOLN in this State, -- and a presentation of the danger which this Coalition, if successful, threatens to bring upon the country. As this topic just now engrosses a large share of public attention, we publish below an extended report of that part of Mr. RAYMOND's speech.
lead_paragraph: Mr. H.J. abstract: A very general and profound interest is felt in the State elections which take place tomorrow, especially those in Pennsylvania and Ohio. The result in these States will have a very decided effect on the sentiment of the public and the action of parties concerning the Presidential contest in November.
lead_paragraph: A very general and profound interest is felt in the State elections which take place tomorrow, especially those in Pennsylvania and Ohio. The result in these States will have a very decided effect on the sentiment of the public and the action of parties concerning the Presidential contest in November. The October election in Pennsylvania is always regarded as an indication of the succeeding contest, and although it has not always proved to be accurate, yet it generally affords a very good basis for estimating the result in November.

abstract: The United States District Attorney yesterday examined the alleged captain and mates of the slaver Erie. Lieut. DUNNINGTON, prize-master, was the only witness called. His testimony merely reaffirmed the particulars of the capture of the ship, which have already been published. The three officers were remanded to Eldridge-street prison, in the custody of Officer O'KEEFE.

abstract: The Central Park concerts richly merit their name; they are Citizens' in every acceptation of the term. The concert-room is of almost unlimited capacity and free to all. There is no reservation of front seats, and no distinction of pit and parquette, gallery and dress-circle, exists. Seats are provided for a few, standing-places for the many, and either are the property of the first comer, no matter what his rank. The barriers and hedges of society for the time being are let down; -- unfortunately, also, a few of its decencies are forgotten. A gentleman in a seedy coat stands at your elbow and blows the smoke of a villainously flavored cigar in your face, as composedly as though he sat beneath the shade and shelter of his own vine and fig-tree; on your other hand you are very likely to have some one who will make a spittoon of your outer-coat pocket. And when the crowd around the music-stand is dense, the air of the Park does not find its way to your lungs pure and undefiled. Here stands a German, redolent of Schweitzer and the too, too tonic beverage; there rustles a lady from whose person little ripples of musk go circling through the ambient air. The queerest contrasts in dress and manners are visible. Rival beauties and rival fashions jostle each other, and the rival reds -- Magenta and Solferino -- stream like opposing banners from the fair wearers' shoulders. Such a patchwork of an audience, such a mosaic of classes and colors, cannot elsewhere be obtained.
lead_paragraph: The Central Park concerts richly merit their name; they are Citizens' in every acceptation of the term. The concert-room is of almost unlimited capacity and free to all. abstract: It would not be easy to exaggerate the importance of a bountiful supply of pure water to the general health and comfort of cities and large towns. But no sooner does this first principle of civilization assume the practical shape of costly water works, suited to the prospective wants of our growing towns, than lo! the reservoirs are but half full, and the engineers are threatening us with new reservoirs, aqueducts, engines -- and taxation. It is only a few years ago that New-York celebrated the introduction of the copious and inexhaustible Croton; what is the hydraulic condition of its streets and houses to-day? Fountains as dry as the desert -- hydrants that were to throw their full streams to warehouse tops, scarcely able to expand a hose; penurious drippings in the second stories of dwellings, and the dry whistle of air entering a vacuum, in the upper rooms; manufacturers taxed for water to an amount almost equal to the rent of their buildings; news columns filled with appeals to good citizens to refrain from the excessive use of water; official reports acknowledging the utter inability of the Department to check the enormous drain on the reservoirs. More than ten years ago we were told that the maximum capacity of the works was exhausted -- works designed for a much larger population -- and that suffering would inevitably follow an interruption of the water supply. And at this time we are paying for a reservoir of enormous cost and magnitude, to be drained like the rest, by the remorseless demand for water -- a demand which increases with the supply -- a thirst which the Father of Waters could scarcely quench.

abstract: Some wag, no doubt disappointed in his hopes of shining among the starry elect of New-York at the coming ball to the coming Prince, has perpetrated a very unjustifiable hoax upon his more fortunate competitors.
lead_paragraph: Some wag, no doubt disappointed in his hopes of shining among the starry elect of New-York at the coming ball to the coming Prince, has perpetrated a very unjustifiable hoax upon his more fortunate competitors. He has contrived (probably through the assistance of some mercenary yellow-plush) to insinuate a quizzical paper prepared by himself into the same envelopes with the "invitations" issued to the General Committee, the tenor of which is so cruelly insulting to the flower of our fashion, that we should not be at all surprised, in case the author shall be discovered, to hear of his being beaten to death with mauve-colored gloves, or strangled with perfumed pocket-handkerchiefs. In this document our anonymous Theodore Hook avails himself of the opportunity to snub all female Gotham by stating that all the ladies who propose coming to the Prince's Ball must understand that "under no consideration can they be admitted with bonnets." He then goes on to inform all gentlemen "not entitled to wear uniforms, "that they will be expected to appear in evening dress, viz.: black trowsers, black dress-coat, black waistcoat and white cravat, or white waistcoat and black cravat, (the former preferable,) and light colored kid gloves." Now, this would be a very good joke, perhaps, at the right time and in the right place. It is possible that a generous and microscopic mind might discern some faint quality of fun in a lesson on costume, delivered by a Broadway tailor to an audience of the townsmen of Hardscrabble, bent on a Royal ball. But when a man's humor or ill-humor leads him to publish such a sermon on the toilette to the whole world, as a fit and proper and necessary preparation of the "elite of New-York" for a ball given exclusively by invitation to less than one numerical third of the traditional "upper ten thousand," the thing ceases to be even approximately witty, and subsides into an uncertainty over which one hardly knows whether to laugh or to use strong language.

abstract: The New-Orleans Picayene, of Friday, gives a verbal report that Capt. JARVIS passed a note to the Spanish Commodore, in which he not only condemned his threats to bombard Vera Cruz in case the Maria Concepcion was not restored and demages paid, but declared he would consider the first shot fired upon Vera Cruz as a shot upon the American squadron. In consequence of this note, further action in this matter was suspended.

abstract: Those who have the good of the sailor at heart, who have an appreciation of his merits, love him for his real worth, admire him for his self-sacrificing endurance of privation, have an excellent opportunity of testifying to the same by contributing books, etc., to the seaman's library of the U.S. Hospital in Brooklyn. The increase of this library is dependent entirely upon the voluntary contributions of individuals, there being no provision made by the Government for its sustenance. If it be commendable to give a drop of water to the disciple, surely they who minister to the comfort and happiness of the sick mariner will not want for a reward.

abstract: State of New-York City and County of NewYork, ss : 1, John Cook, of the said City, Counselor at Law, being duly sworn, doth depose and say that I have read in the NEW-YORK TIMES of this day, Monday, October the 8th, 1860, an article headed, "Whitewashing by the City Judge," which article RUSSELL, acting in conjuction with a firm of Solicitors.
lead_paragraph: State of New-York City and County of NewYork, ss : 1, John Cook, of the said City, Counselor at Law, being duly sworn, doth depose and say that I have read in the NEW-YORK TIMES of this day, Monday, October the 8th, 1860, an article headed, "Whitewashing by the City Judge," which article RUSSELL, acting in conjuction with a firm of Solicitors named Cook & Co., through the mediumship of a Mr. Shafer, Judge RUSSELL's private partner have engaged in the business of whitewashing all debtors who either cannot or do not choose to pay their debts, and that the said persons named have reduced this business to the level of an exact science; which said article also further charges and alleges that the City Judge has the power of discharging Insolvents from their debts who appear before him either in custody or on judgment, provided they can show the consent to such discharge of creditors, representing two-thirds of the entire indebtedness. Said article then states and says: "here is a little gold mine, or rather a very big one it will be seen at once, and this 'placer' has been worked to enormous profit." The said article then suppresses the case of a profligate or fraudulent debtor, owing two or three thousand dollars to honest creditors, who know him to possess the means of payment, or desire to punish him for the false representations on which he obtained their trust. Judgment is obtained against him, and the man is seized; he is sent to Eldridge-street prison, and that is the first step towards his release. Locked up there, one of the ready turnkeys will not fail to advise him to trust his case to Cook & Co., who are the legal practitioners most largely engaged in this business. The man then finds out that he owes about ten thousand dollars to some gentleman named Jones, or Brown, or some two gentlemen named Robinson and Jenkins; whereupon the second step towards liberation has been taken.

abstract: The early hour at which the Prince took hip departure from Richmond prevented his becoming further initiated into a knowledge of the peculiarities of the denizens of the sunny South. A short ride on horseback, a breakfast, an endurance of popular regard during his ride to the depot, and a telescopic view of the country from the roof of the ear-house comprise the list of his operations at the city of Richmond.

abstract: Another monster Fusion meeting was held inside and outside of the Cooper Institute last evening. Upon the nomination of WILSON G. HUNT, Hon. JOHN A. DIX, Postmaster of this City, was called upon to preside. Mr. JOSHUA J. HENRY, on behalf of the Fusion Committee, reported the Union Electoral ticket agreed upon, which was unanimously ratified by the meeting, and the Committee continued for the purpose of advancing the interests of the ticket. Strong Union speeches were made by JAMES W. GERARD, SAMUEL J. TILDEN, CHARLES O'CONOR, JOHN COCHRANE, HIRAM WALBRIDGE, THEODORE E. TOMLINSON, and others. The demonstration outside was one of the largest yet held in the vicinity.

abstract: The most intense anxiety prevails as to the result of the Pennsylvania election to-day. We shall without doubt be able to announce it in to-morrow's TIMES. It is generally felt to be decisive of the Presidential contest, especially if it results in a Republican victory.
lead_paragraph: The most intense anxiety prevails as to the result of the Pennsylvania election to-day. We shall without doubt be able to announce it in to-morrow's TIMES. It is generally felt to be decisive of the Presidential contest, especially if it results in a Republican victory. The main contest is for Governor. The Republican candidate is Mr. CURTIN, -- and his opponent, Col. FOSTER, is supported by a coalition of the Breckinridge and Douglas Democrats with the Bell and Everett Party. If the latter is beaten, therefore, it will seem reasonably certain that the Republicans have the State, especially as there is no such fusion now, nor will any be possible in that event on the Presidential ticket. If FOSTER should be elected, on the other hand, it will be claimed by the Republicans that this is no fair indication of the result in November, inasmuch as there will be no such fusion then.

abstract: At the Broadway Tabernacle, on Sunday evening, Rev. Dr. JOSEPH P. THOMPSON, the pastor, delivered a sermon -- the occasion being the jubilee of the American Board of Foreign Missions. He took as his text Zechariah iv., 10, in the course of which he gave a sketch of the origin, in 1810, and progress of the work of foreign missions. He forcibly marked the contrast between its first efforts, by which $999 99 were raised and four missionaries sent forth, and its present labors, with its $430,000 contributed in the past year and its 1,300 representatives in the field. The calls of Divine Providence on the one hand, and the outrageous outbreaks of human wickedness upon the other demanded renewed energy and faith and consecration for the missionary service. Along with the wonderful openings of Providence for good there were outgrowths of human wickedness, which showed that Satan was not idle, and that the conflict for the ascendency of truth and righteousness must yet be severe. The wild, fierce tragedy of fanaticism in Lebanon, which had sent a thrill of horror through the whole world, and the audacious demand here that Slavery should be recognized as a Christian institution, and inaugurated as a part of our national policy, were proofs that the Devil was not yet chained up. When the American Board war organized, everybody looked for the speedy cessation of Slavery itself, as an iniquity that must die out before the light of freedom and Christianity. Yet now men calling themselves Christians, who gave largely for foreign missions, pretended to doubt whether it was wise, and safe, and patriotic to talk against Slavery as a system of iniquity, and to vote against its extension. The most serious obstacle to their missionary operations at the Gaboon was the Slave-trade, conducted by Americans. He was informed by returned missionaries that they saw men flourishing here in Broadway who at the Gaboon had been engaged in the Slave-trade. This City was interested in the traffic to an increasing and alarming extent. The half-century that had elapsed since the American Board was established had not been wholly one of progress in righteousness. Iniquity, too, had grown. Their jubilee did not proclaim liberty throughout all the land, to all the inhabitants thereof.

abstract: FIRE. At about 8 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out in the second story of building No. 99 Fulton-street, which extends through to Main-street, and before the fire could be extinguished property valued at $4,000 was destroyed by fire and water, belonging to the several occupants as follows : GEORGE AYERS, confectioner, No. 99 Main-street, loss on stock $700, on furniture $400 insured for $1,500 in the Williamsburgh Fire Insurance Company.
lead_paragraph: FIRE. At about 8 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out in the second story of building No. 99 Fulton-street, which extends through to Main-street, and before the fire could be extinguished property valued at $4,000 was destroyed by fire and water, belonging to the several occupants as follows : GEORGE AYERS, confectioner, No. 99 Main-street, loss on stock $700, on furniture $400 insured for $1,500 in the Williamsburgh Fire Insurance Company. JOHN MEEHAN, who occupied a room on the third floor, lost $50 worth of clothing -- no insurance. Miss DOUGLAS, gentlemen's furnishing goods, who occupied the Main-street front, No. 94, lost $1,000 -- insured in the Atlantic Insurance Company of Brooklyn for $800. PETER REID, confectioner, No. 92 Main-street, lost $700 -- insured for $1,000 in the Artisans' Insurance Company, New-York. H. CRANE, boot and shoe dealer, No. 92 Main-street, lost $50 -- not insured. Mr. AYRES, while attempting to save some of his property, was severely but not dangerously burned. The fire originated in a wardrobe, but from what cause is not known.

abstract: A communication was received from the Mayor, last evening, informing the Board that it having been definitely settled that H.R.H. the Prince of Wales would arrive in this City about 1 P.M. on Thursday, the Common Council were invited to aid in his reception on that occasion, and were requested to be present at the Governor's Room at 12 M. on that day and join in the reception. A motion to lay on the table was at first declared carried, but, oh the Yeas and Nays being called, the invitation was accepted -- Yeas 7, Nays 6.
