abstract: Few that favor Fusion failed to be present at the mass meeting at the Cooper Institute last evening; at least the hall was crowded to its utmost capacity, and around the building thousands of people were gathered. Many and lengthy speeches were delivered, urging a combination for any of the opposing candidates that could defeat the Republicans. Resolutions, declaring its propriety, and a report announcing that it had been effected, were adopted. Processions of Ward Clubs bearing banners with "Fusion" writ upon them paraded the streets; and none were to be met with in the immediate vicinity of Astor-place who would willingly then and there have called loudly for cheers for the party then and there reviled.

abstract: IMPROVEMENTS IN BROADWAY DEMOLITION OF AN ENTIRE BLOCK. Pedestrians in Broadway were not a little astonished yesterday at beholding in sudden and active progress the wholesale destructions of the entire block of buildings between Ninth and Tenth streets, on the east side. Early in the morning an army of some three hundred men appeared on the ground and commenced the work of demolition.
lead_paragraph: IMPROVEMENTS IN BROADWAY DEMOLITION OF AN ENTIRE BLOCK. Pedestrians in Broadway were not a little astonished yesterday at beholding in sudden and active progress the wholesale destructions of the entire block of buildings between Ninth and Tenth streets, on the east side. Early in the morning an army of some three hundred men appeared on the ground and commenced the work of demolition. On inquiry the fact was learned that Mr. A.T. STEWART, the dry goods millionare, had purchased the entire block bounded by Broadway and Fourth-avenue and Ninth and Tenth streets, which was to be wholly swept away, and a score of magnificent marble stores erected on its site. That portion of the block fronting on Broadway is to be immediately demolished, but the Fourth-avenue side will not be torn down before Spring. The whole block[???]s eventually to be covered by a series of magnificent stores of novel and uniform pattern, designed by the well-known architects Messrs. KELLUM & SON, to whom the City is already indebted for so many of its beautiful structures.

abstract: Coroner GAFFNEY, of Jersey City, was notified yesterday to hold an inquest upon the body of a man found floating in the East River, on Sunday afternoon, which was subsequently identified as that of RICHARD C. KELLY, Captain of the schooner Catharine Margaret, of West Farms, Westchester County, NEW-YORK.
lead_paragraph: Coroner GAFFNEY, of Jersey City, was notified yesterday to hold an inquest upon the body of a man found floating in the East River, on Sunday afternoon, which was subsequently identified as that of RICHARD C. KELLY, Captain of the schooner Catharine Margaret, of West Farms, Westchester County, NEW-YORK. The general impression of the friends of deceased, as well as all others acquainted with the facts, ic that the Captain came to his death by foul play. On Sunday forenoon, the 30th of September, the Catharine Margaret was discovered lying at anchor about 100 yards from the Hoboken Ferry, loaded with brick, with her signal-light burning, and the vessel in a sinking condition. Several persons went out in small boats to render assistance, and on arriving at the vessel, found no person on board. In the cabin was found a piece of fresh beef, some potatoes, cabbages, &c., and a bottle of gin, and apparently these articles had been brought on board very recently. The vessel was towed on to the flats, where it shortly after sunk. Since that time the friends of the Captain have been on the look-out to ascertain the cause of his mysterious disappearance without success, until the finding of his body on Sunday. Justice WHITLEY, of Hoboken, viewed the body, and it is stated, without taking any evidence, gave permission to the friends to remove it to Westchester County. A young man named WILLIAM HOOPER was the only person employed on board the schooner, and he, together with the yawl-boat, have been missing since that time. About 11 o'clock on the night previous to the finding of the schooner in a sinking condition, two young men belonging on board the yacht Zinga discovered a yawl-boat floating down the river, and upon rowing out to it, saw a man in it with his head over one side of the boat, apparently intoxicated. His general appearance answered somewhat to the description of HOOPER, who is a tail, very dark-complexioned man, with black hair, small black whiskers and black eyes. The men at the time supposed him to be a colored man, but could not be positive on account of the darkness. Capt. KELLY's face was considerably eaten away, but several marks were discovered upon the head, and particularly a severe cut was discovered over the left eye.

abstract: Capt. DEGROOT, well-known as a popular steamboat commander, and not unknown as a marine engineer, has recently completed two small screw-steamers, called the Resolute and Reliance. These vessels are exactly alike in all particulars; the models are good and appropriate, without being remarkably sharp. They are 100 feet keel by 17 feet beam, and
lead_paragraph: Capt. DEGROOT, well-known as a popular steamboat commander, and not unknown as a marine engineer, has recently completed two small screw-steamers, called the Resolute and Reliance. These vessels are exactly alike in all particulars; the models are good and appropriate, without being remarkably sharp. They are 100 feet keel by 17 feet beam, and 9 feet depth; and, without deviating extremely in any particular from the ordinary construction, the hulls, engines, boilers and propellers have been so well adapted, one to another, that the practical results are remarkable -- indeed they are unprecedented for this class of boats. The more minute details of these fine little vessels are as follow: The hulls, built by B.C. TERRY, of Keyport, N.J., are of wood, strapped diagonally with heavy iron, within and without the frames; entirely "copper and galvanized" fastened, and ceiled with oak planking 3 1/2 inches thick; an arched hogging frame runs from stem to stern; the stems are protected by the best flange boiler-plate, and the vessels are coppered with unusually heavy sheets, to 20 inches above the water-line -- the top sheets, about 4 feet square, weighing 45 1/2 pounds each. The upper rails are also coppered; the bits and caps are of polished brass; the chocks are lined with brass, and the elects on deck are of iron; the main rails around the boats are protected by heavy wrought-iron bands; the upper works and general appointments of the vessels are superior as to workmanship and material. The joiner work was done by JOHN VAN TASSEL, of this City.

abstract: The meeting of the Coalitionists last night was a very large and imposing demonstration. It was one of the largest political gatherings we have ever seen in this City, and was distinguished by a very marked degree of enthusiasm. It would have Been singular if the meeting had not been large, for it embraced three political parties not only of this City, but of Brooklyn, Staten Island and Jersey City also. As a popular demonstration it was all the most sanguine friends of the movement could have desired.

abstract: ANOTHER ATTEMPT AT WIFE-MURDER. A man named ALBERT LANDER was arrested by Officer HAIL, of the Second Precinct Police, late Monday night, for  attempting to kill his wife at the house of a friend on Hudson-avenue.
lead_paragraph: ANOTHER ATTEMPT AT WIFE-MURDER. A man named ALBERT LANDER was arrested by Officer HAIL, of the Second Precinct Police, late Monday night, for attempting to kill his wife at the house of a friend on Hudson-avenue. The accused was married three years ago, after a very short acquaintance with Mrs. LANDER. Six months after that he was arrested and sent to the Penitentiary for larceny. In his defence she exhausted all of her means, believing him to be innocent, but finding upon the trial that he was really guilty of the charge made against him, she resolved never to live with him again. He has before frequently threatened her with violence unless she returned to live with him, and once he has been bound over to keep the peace towards her. Monday night he sought her at the house of Mrs. MCNEIL, where she was visiting. Forcing himself into her presence be asked her again to live with him. She refused, when he seized her by the hair and drew a bowie-knife across her throat before he could be secured by the other parties present. Fortunately in the excitement of the moment LANDER used the back instead of the sharp edge of the knife, and therefore she was not seriously injured. Before he could make a second attempt he was seized and held until the arrival of an officer. Yesterday LANDER was committed by Justice MORDHOUSE for examination.

abstract: The Brokers and Stock speculators are very busy just now in their vocation. They are determined to make what hay they can while the sun shines. Although they do not believe a syllable of the rigmarole by which reckless demagogues are endeavoring to alarm the public, for their own political purposes, yet they have faith enough in public credulity to belies a that it will produce some effect.
lead_paragraph: The Brokers and Stock speculators are very busy just now in their vocation. They are determined to make what hay they can while the sun shines. Although they do not believe a syllable of the rigmarole by which reckless demagogues are endeavoring to alarm the public, for their own political purposes, yet they have faith enough in public credulity to belies a that it will produce some effect. They join their howlings, therefore, to the croaking of the politicians, in the hope that between the two they may create a temporary panic in Wall-street, and buy in, at a low figure, the poorest of the stocks which they sold at a high one. They are speculating for a fall, -- and are endeavoring to create the fall, without which most of them must "burst." To a disinterested spectator who doesn't own stocks, and doesn't care a straw whether they go up or down, the scene is highly amusing. And decidedly the best place to see the absurd and grotesque features of it, is in the columns of the Herald. It is much funnier than the Wide-Awake torchlight procession, or its Democratic imitation of Monday night. Yesterday's issue of that sheet has a very fine specimen of this solemn gibberish.

abstract: A man named Charles Wilson was brought yesterday before Justice WELSH, at the Tombs, on the complaint of Jacob Nowell, of Hartford County, N. C., whom he is alleged to have defrauded to the extent of $100, under the following circumstances.
lead_paragraph: A man named Charles Wilson was brought yesterday before Justice WELSH, at the Tombs, on the complaint of Jacob Nowell, of Hartford County, N. C., whom he is alleged to have defrauded to the extent of $100, under the following circumstances. On the 2d inst. the complainant went on board the steamships Jamestown, and met the accused, who engaged him in conversation. Wilson represented that he was a merchat at Norfolk, Va., and had come North to make purchases, but was about to return home on the Jamestown, which was about to leave. While they were thus conversing, a third man approached Wilson, and demanded payment of a small bill. Wilson admitted that he owed the money, and produced a bill on the City Trust and Banking Company, which he tendered in payment. The new-comer could not change the bank-note, and after pretending, without success, to get smaller bills for it from the clerk of the boat, Wilson returned to Nowell, and asked him to accommodate him. The latter unhesitatingly assented, and handed the affable Wilson five double eagles for the worthless piece of paper. After the lapse of a few hours the verdant Southerner learned that he had been victimized by a sharper, and, therefore, he adopted measures for his apprehension. Yesterday the accused was taken into custody, and the magistrate committed him for examination.

abstract: DEATH FROM VIOLENCE THE PERPETRATOR UNKNOWN Coroner O'KEEPE was notified, yesterday, that MICHAEL HALEY, residing at No. 38 City Hallplace, had died at the New-York Hospital, in consequence of a terrible wound in the abdomen, received last Saturday night. A lack of evidence precluded the Coroner from proceeding with the inquest, but the matter will be investigated to-day, if the Police are fortunate enough to procure any witnesses in the case.
lead_paragraph: DEATH FROM VIOLENCE THE PERPETRATOR UNKNOWN Coroner O'KEEPE was notified, yesterday, that MICHAEL HALEY, residing at No. 38 City Hallplace, had died at the New-York Hospital, in consequence of a terrible wound in the abdomen, received last Saturday night. A lack of evidence precluded the Coroner from proceeding with the inquest, but the matter will be investigated to-day, if the Police are fortunate enough to procure any witnesses in the case. It is said that HALEY, while intoxicated, went into the drinking-place, corner of Spring and Mott streets, and was ejected by the proprietor because he refused to pay for a drink which he ordered. On the sidewalk the trouble between the parties was renewed, and a crowd collected about the disputants. Suddenly HALEY was stabbed by some of the spectators, after which he went to the corner of Canal and Walker streets, where he fell to the sidewalk exhausted from loss of blood. In this condition he was found by the Police, who took him to the Hospital.

abstract: To the curious in literature, a visit to the late Mr. BURTON'S library offers peculiar inducements. They will find there much to interest, either the student of dramatic literature, or the observer of human character.
lead_paragraph: To the curious in literature, a visit to the late Mr. BURTON'S library offers peculiar inducements. They will find there much to interest, either the student of dramatic literature, or the observer of human character. They will find volumes on all subjects connected with the stage; the history of the theatre in every time and country; the lives of the great actors and actresses; anecdotes of GARRICK and memoranda of TALMA; stories about Mrs. BRACEGIRDLE and scandal about RACHEL. Instructions in gesture and declamation; pictures and prints representing pageants of by-gone days; portraits endeavoring to retain the fleeting expression of those mobile faces that now are still forever; accounts of masques in the time of CHARLES I., and mysteries in those days when the priests were the players, and churches the play-houses. They will find the scores of the earliest operas and the music for some of the latest ballets; they will find old plays that were performed before SHAKESPEARE's were written, and others in manuscript that never were performed at all, and never deserved to be. Those who are curious in costume can turn to volumes in nearly every tongue, illustrated by colored engravings of the ancient and modern styles of dress; chivalric customs, the armor of the Greeks and Romans and of the middle ages, heraldry and its insignia, hawking and hunting, archery and the occult sciences, all are discussed and described. Fancy dresses for a ball can be studied; coronations and funerals, processions and royal programmes and parades to welcome modern princes can be gotten up after resorting to these resources. A perfect museum of literature is this left by the great comedian. Odd and ends of antiquity, scraps of queer and quaint information, celebrated speeches of great orators, copies of the proceedings at famous trials, books of jests, classic poems, theatrical criticisms, and, of course, an infinite quantity of dramas, comedies, tragedies, historical, pastoral, scenes indivisible, and poems unlimited. SENECA is not too heavy nor PLAUTUS too light.

lead_paragraph: In our Afternoon Edition of yesterday we published brief dispatches announcing the burning of the steamship Connaught, the new vessel of the Galway line, running between Galway and New-York and Boston, alternately, vid St. Johns, Newfoundland. On her present trip the Connaught left Galway on Tuesday, the 25th ult., and arrived at St. Johns last Wednesday morning. She left St. Johns the same day for Boston. She sprung aleak on Saturday, and on Sunday morning, when about 140 miles from Boston, she was discovered to be on fire, and it was soon ascertained to be impossible to save her. Measures were immediately taken by Capt. LEITCH to insure the safety of the passengers as far as possible, but a great proportion of them must inevitably have perished had it not been for the assistance of the brig Minnie Schiffer, Capt. WILSON, which received the entire number on board. All the particulars which have yet reached us relative to the disaster, will he found in the following dispatch:

abstract: Early in the Spring of the present year, the English newspapers favored us with occasional paragraphs, wonderfully suggestive but mysterious enough in details, about a remarkable ship to be launched for the Galway line. She was guaranteed to sail 20 knots an hour; she was promised to fulfill the conditions of safety in an extraordinary degree, and she has to outstrip all competitors as to elegance and comfort.
lead_paragraph: Early in the Spring of the present year, the English newspapers favored us with occasional paragraphs, wonderfully suggestive but mysterious enough in details, about a remarkable ship to be launched for the Galway line. She was guaranteed to sail 20 knots an hour; she was promised to fulfill the conditions of safety in an extraordinary degree, and she has to outstrip all competitors as to elegance and comfort. And when the counting-room engineers drank to her prosperity in her spacious and magnificent saloon, and surveyed with delight the exquisite outlines of her hull, what other assurances did they need of her triumphant success. Why should they allay their fond expectations with blacksmith's discussions about the comparative strength of iron and cinder-and-iron plates and the grim details of cheap machinery?

abstract: The merchants interested in the shipping business between this country and England held a meeting last night in the room occupied, by the Geographical Society, in the Hall of the Mercantile Library Association. Their object was to hear an address from Hon. W.S. LINDSAY, a member of the British House of Commons, whose visit to this country has been prompted by a desire to effect such a modification in the navigation laws of both countries as will prove advantageous to the commercial interests of both.

abstract: A correspondent of the Courrier des Etats Unis, writing from Managua, announces the discovery of a new and practicable transit route through Nicaragua. He locates its Atlantic terminus half way up the Mosquito coast, at the mouth of a stream named on the maps "Rio Grande," but which is delineated there as anything but a great river, a mere trace indicating its approach to the sea.
lead_paragraph: A correspondent of the Courrier des Etats Unis, writing from Managua, announces the discovery of a new and practicable transit route through Nicaragua. He locates its Atlantic terminus half way up the Mosquito coast, at the mouth of a stream named on the maps "Rio Grande," but which is delineated there as anything but a great river, a mere trace indicating its approach to the sea. This river is described as admitting an ocean steamer through broad, deep and unfailing waters to a point eighty miles distant from its mouth, where an uninterrupted plain, extending quite to the Pacific, and eminently fitted for the construction of a cheap railway, commences, the intermediate distance being 123 miles. All conditions favorable to the enterprize are declared by this writer to be supplied by this route. Not only is the level of the uniformity indicated, but the climate is less torrid than that of Louisiana, the region being singularly healthful; while the timber necessary to engineering labors, is convenient and abundant. It may be advisable to add that the competence and reliability of the person who makes this statement are vouched for by the Courrier.

abstract: A large mass-meeting of Republicans was held at Stuyvesant Institute, the hall of the Young Men's Republican Union, last evening. CHAS. T. RODGERS, Esq., the chairman, called the meeting to order and the Rocky Mountain Glee Club sung a song.
lead_paragraph: A large mass-meeting of Republicans was held at Stuyvesant Institute, the hall of the Young Men's Republican Union, last evening. CHAS. T. RODGERS, Esq., the chairman, called the meeting to order and the Rocky Mountain Glee Club sung a song. Then Hon. JAMES HUMPHREY, M.C. from Brooklyn, addressed the meeting He did not know that at the close of this eventful day, not so decisive as some supposed, yet of great importance, they could compose their minds to listen to a discussion of political principles. He denied that even the success of the Fusion party in Pennsylvania this day would forshadow the result in November. There was a union there merely for State and local affairs. On the other hand, a Republican victory in Pennsylvania now would be the sure presage of Republican success in November. There were no two parties in the country which disliked each other so cordially as the Douglas and Breckinridge parties. It way because they were not divided in principle, but both were struggling for the spoils, that they so hated each other. Mr. HUMPHREY confined himself to the elucidation of this point. He examined, in the first place, the character of the Bell-Everett Party. However respectable that party might be elsewhere, with its ETHERIDGE and HENRY WINTER DAVIS, [applause,] here in New-York it was venal, consisting of officers without an army, who, wandering about with an auctioneer's flag, had finally sold themselves to the party which had most reviled them. They marched under the flag on which was inscribed "Indifference;" but their leader, Mr. BELL, had made avowals in past time which placed him virtually on the same platform with Mr. BRECKINRIDGE. Next, Mr. HUMPHREY controverted the one idea of the Breckinridge Party -- that Slavery was the normal condition of the black man and a blessing to him, and that everywhere where there is no statutory enactment to the contrary, the white man may hold the black man in bondage. The Douglas Party, to all intents and purposes, held the same principles. The expressions of Mr. DOUGLAS at the North were ostensible, and not real, and they were made with the design of alluring the unwary to the support of the Pro-Slavery ascendency. Mr. HUMPHREY quoted the language of Mr. DOUGLAS on different occasions, to show, that his (Mr. HUMPHREY's) statement in this regard was correct.

abstract: The Directors of the Artisans' Bank, assisted, we may suppose, by those parties who are alleged to have received "political loans" from the defunct institution, are now using every agency and appear willing to make any sacrifice to prevent a legal overhauling and thorough examination of the financial and  other practices in which they have been engaged.
lead_paragraph: The Directors of the Artisans' Bank, assisted, we may suppose, by those parties who are alleged to have received "political loans" from the defunct institution, are now using every agency and appear willing to make any sacrifice to prevent a legal overhauling and thorough examination of the financial and other practices in which they have been engaged. Their present scheme to effect this object takes the shape of a proposition, understood to emanate from Chamberlain PLATT, that the Directors amongst themselves shall raise enough money to pay off all depositors; after which, by an application to the Supreme Court, the affairs of the Bank are to be withdrawn from Judge LEONARD's scrutiny and the stockholders are to trust for justice and their respective dividends to the conscience and commercial honesty of the present Direction.
headline: {'main': "The Artisans' Bank Again.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The Artisans' Bank Again.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: THE SUPPOSED MURDER OF CAPT. KELLY. -- The jury in the case of Capt. RICHARD C. KELLY, of the schooner Catharine Margaret, who is supposed to have been murdered, convened last evening at Hoboken. Coroner GAFFNEY stated that he had no further evidence to offer at present, as the time had been too limited, and accordingly adjourned the case for a few days. FRANCIS MCDONOUGH, Chief of Police of Hoboken, together with Officer KILCAULY of Jersey City, are engaged assisting the Coroner to ferret out this mystery, and every effort will be made to accomplish this purpose, it has already been ascertained that two men answering the description of the Captain and HOOPER, were seen to leave the schooner in a yawl, and after a short time to leave Hoboken again in the boat. Other facts have also come to light which will be developed at the inquest.

abstract: SHANGHAE, Aug. 2. -- There is little important political news. The rebels have taken Nantsieng City, in the silk district. An American named WEST undertook to recapture Singpoo. He failed in the attempt and was wounded. The Allies left for the Peiho on the 26th of July. They were to take the forts before treating with the Chinese. The French and general division are landing simultaneouly at Pehlang. A severe engagement has taken place with pirates; 200 men were slain, and two European leaders captured.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAE, Aug. 2. -- There is little important political news. The rebels have taken Nantsieng City, in the silk district. An American named WEST undertook to recapture Singpoo. He failed in the attempt and was wounded. The Allies left for the Peiho on the 26th of July. They were to take the forts before treating with the Chinese. The French and general division are landing simultaneouly at Pehlang. A severe engagement has taken place with pirates; 200 men were slain, and two European leaders captured.

abstract: The elections in Pennsylvania, Ohio and Indiana, which took place yesterday, have excited this year an attention which they only awaken quadrennially, from their bearing upon the ensuing Presidential contest. The result in all these States appears to favor the hopes of the Republicans. In Pennsylvania Col. CURTIN, the candidate of that party, is elected, his majority over Mr. FOSTER, the candidate of the combined supporters of BELL, BRECKINRIDGE and DOUGLAS, falling very little short of 25,000. Our returns from the Congressional Districts indicate the probable loss of four, and the possible loss of six members on the part of the Republicans -- Mr. E. JOY MORRIS, the People's candidate in the Second District, being among the defeated. The results which reach us up to the moment of going to press may be modified by later dispatches.

abstract: A complaint has recently been lodged before Justice WELSH against LEWIS JOHNSON, a lawyer having an office No. 39 Nassau-street, and CHAS. A. GRIGLETTI, another lawyer, who resides in Jersey City, charging them with having conspired to defraud Mr. J.A. O'REILLY by the transfer of some leasehold property, which the complainant had been in possession of for the past ten years.
lead_paragraph: A complaint has recently been lodged before Justice WELSH against LEWIS JOHNSON, a lawyer having an office No. 39 Nassau-street, and CHAS. A. GRIGLETTI, another lawyer, who resides in Jersey City, charging them with having conspired to defraud Mr. J.A. O'REILLY by the transfer of some leasehold property, which the complainant had been in possession of for the past ten years. The circumstances of the case as developed so far, in the testimony before Justice WELSH, are as follows; In June, 1847, Mr. O'REILLY employed Mr. PHILIP BURROWES, a lawyer, to purchase for him from one GARRETT SHUFELDT the lease of two vacant lots, located on Ninth-avenue. The transaction was completed and SHUFELDT made the assignment to CHARLES A. GRIGLETTI, one of the defendants, who at the time was a clerk in BURROWES' employ. The complainant O'REILLY paid the purchase money, and assumed all the responsibilities, and GRIGLETTI, in accordance with the understanding that existed, reassigned the property to him. The papers in the transaction having been sworn to before a Commissioner of Deeds, and being considered perfected, were then deposited in BURROWES' office for safe keeping. O'REILLY subsequently constructed buildings, valued at $10,000, upon the lots in question, and remained in peaceful possession of the property until the 9th of August last. At that time the discovery was made by JOHNSON or some other person that the assignment from SHUFELDT to GRIGLETTI was valid, as it had been recorded, but that the assignment from the latter to O'REILLY, never having been subjected to that formula, was void. GRIGLETTI was apprised of this, and it is alleged that for a small consideration he was induced to make a second assignment of the property to JOHNSON, who forthwith commenced suits of ejectment against O'REILLY's tenants. This action led O'RIELLY to apply for a writ enjoining further proceedings on the part of JOHNSON, and the matter having been argued, on the 28th ult., before Justice INGRAHAM, the assignment from GRIGLETTI to JOHNSON was declared void. Under these circumstances Mr. O'REILLY instituted criminal proceedings against GRIGLETTI and JOHNSON, the latter of whom was taken before Justice WELSH, and required to furnish bail to appear for examination on a charge of misdeanor, which is to be heard on the 28th inst. GREGLETTI has not yet been arrested.

abstract: The Captain and two mates of the Eric were brought up before United States Commissioner NORVELL, and further examined touching their complicity with the slave voyage of that vessel. Lieut. JOHN W. DUNNINGTON was recalled, and identified certain papers, among which was the clearance from Havana, in which NATHANIEL GORDON was named as master. He also produced a receipt from the United States agent at Monrovia for 867 recaptured Africans, namely; men, 211; women, 130; boys, 366; and girls, 160. Witness explained that the Slave-trade is carried on from the Congo to the Gold Coast, about 5Â° south of the equator. He described the capture of the Erie; there was no resistance; he boarded her alone, and a rope was thrown to him; Mr. GORDON did not refer him to DON EMANUEL or any other man as Captain of the ship; in looking over the charts Capt. GORDON spoke of the course the ship had made out, but did not say it was his work. The prisoner HALL claimed a chest of clothes and a quadrant which was in the chest, and which was used to navigate the ship. The prisoners, by advice of Mr. JOACHIMSSEN, declined to testify on their own behalf or others, until the prosecution against them was dismissed. As this raised an important point in the case, the District-Attorney wished to refer it to Judge BETTS, which was mutually agreed to, and the case was adjourned to Friday, at 12 o'clock.
lead_paragraph: The Captain and two mates of the Eric were brought up before United States Commissioner NORVELL, and further examined touching their complicity with the slave voyage of that vessel. Lieut. JOHN W. DUNNINGTON was recalled, and identified certain papers, among which was the clearance from Havana, in which NATHANIEL GORDON was named as master. He also produced a receipt from the United States agent at Monrovia for 867 recaptured Africans, namely; men, 211; women, 130; boys, 366; and girls, 160. Witness explained that the Slave-trade is carried on from the Congo to the Gold Coast, about 5° south of the equator. He described the capture of the Erie; there was no resistance; he boarded her alone, and a rope was thrown to him; Mr. GORDON did not refer him to DON EMANUEL or any other man as Captain of the ship; in looking over the charts Capt. GORDON spoke of the course the ship had made out, but did not say it was his work. The prisoner HALL claimed a chest of clothes and a quadrant which was in the chest, and which was used to navigate the ship. The prisoners, by advice of Mr. JOACHIMSSEN, declined to testify on their own behalf or others, until the prosecution against them was dismissed. As this raised an important point in the case, the District-Attorney wished to refer it to Judge BETTS, which was mutually agreed to, and the case was adjourned to Friday, at 12 o'clock.

abstract: The screw steamship City of Baltimore, from Liverpool on the 26th and Queenstown on the 27th ult., arrived at this port yesterday morning. abstract: DESTITUTION AND SUICIDE -- A SAD CASE. -- On Tuesday evening Coroner SCHIRMER investigated the circumstances in connection with the decease of MATILDA MARX, a German woman 20 years of age, residing at No. 566 Fourth-street, who intentionally poisoned herself by swallowing a mixture for the destruction of vermin, composed of arsenic and acetate of copper. It was shown by the testimony that deceased about eight months since was married to a young man who followed the trade of a butcher. Several weeks ago her husband was taken sick, and his illness continued until both himself and wife were reduced almost to starvation. The prospect of the invalid's recovery not appearing promising, and the poor woman having utterly failed to procure work, finally became to disheartened that she determined to make away with herself. Accordingly she called at a painter's in Fourth-street, near whose shop she lived, and procured the poison which she took. Returning home she went to her husband's bedside and informed him of what she had cone and the motive which had prompted her action. As soon as possible he made the matter known to the other occupants of the house and a physician was summoned. He arrived too late, however, to be of service, and the miserable woman died. A verdict in accordance with these facts was rendered.
lead_paragraph: DESTITUTION AND SUICIDE -- A SAD CASE. -- On Tuesday evening Coroner SCHIRMER investigated the circumstances in connection with the decease of MATILDA MARX, a German woman 20 years of age, residing at No. 566 Fourth-street, who intentionally poisoned herself by swallowing a mixture for the destruction of vermin, composed of arsenic and acetate of copper. abstract: We have further interesting returns from the State Elections on Tuesday, which swell the popular majorities for the Republican ticket in Pennsylvania, Ohio and Indiana beyond the most sanguine previous calculations of the several State Committees. For members of the next Congress, the Republicans, as anticipated, lose several members from their present great preponderance in the Pennsylvania delegation.
lead_paragraph: We have further interesting returns from the State Elections on Tuesday, which swell the popular majorities for the Republican ticket in Pennsylvania, Ohio and Indiana beyond the most sanguine previous calculations of the several State Committees. For members of the next Congress, the Republicans, as anticipated, lose several members from their present great preponderance in the Pennsylvania delegation. And the latest dispatch from Ohio renders probable a net loss of two members in; that State. The Indiana delegation will probably continue divided, as at present, 8 to 3. The new Legislatures of all three of these States will be Republican, unquestionably, and this result is important: in Pennsylvania and Indiana, as enabling the party to displace United States Senators BIGLER and BRIGHT. In reference to the final popular majority, in Pennsylvania for ANDREW G. CURTIN, Republican, for Governor, over HENRY D. FOSTER, Democrat, we see no reason to change our first estimate of yesterday -- 25,000. In the forty counties heard from, he leads FOSTER about 15,000, with Bradford County, on the Northern line, and several of the heavy Western counties to come in.

abstract: We should be very glad to believe that there are some ten or twenty respectable men in the City of New-York who can spare time enough from the oscillations of Wall-street, the excitement of a merchant's or a landlord' life, the uncertainties of national politics, and the ecstatic anticipations of the Prince of Wales Ball, to read the plain, precise and peremptory letter in which Judge...
lead_paragraph: We should be very glad to believe that there are some ten or twenty respectable men in the City of New-York who can spare time enough from the oscillations of Wall-street, the excitement of a merchant's or a landlord' life, the uncertainties of national politics, and the ecstatic anticipations of the Prince of Wales Ball, to read the plain, precise and peremptory letter in which Judge PIERREPONT resigns his seat upon the Bench of the Superior Court of New-York. The system of the elective judiciary has been frequently attacked, and from different points of view, -- nor have we spared what we regard as its irremediable inherent defects in the columns of the TIMES. But it is a new thing, even under the sun of New-York, to find that in its practical working, one of the results of this system is to compel the few decent and capable men who, from time to time, may fortunately be elevated to the ermine, into making a second election for themselves between the resignation of their office and death by suffocation.

abstract: UNION RATIFICATION MEETING. -- A large meeting of the supporters of the Union ticket was held in City Hall-square last evening. The meeting was called to order at 7 1/2 o'clock by JAMES SHARKEY, when Alderman KALBFLEISCH was elected Chairman, and the usual quantity of Vice-Presidents and Secretaries were selected. GILBERT DEAN, Esq., was the first speaker. He commeneed by saying these were times that tried men's souls. Pennsylvania, the keystone of the arch, is shaken -- Ohio and Indiana have gone for the Republican candidates. But we in New-York say to each other that this is the battle-field, and we will signify our devotion to the Union by rolling up an unprecedented majority for the Union ticket. The burthen of his concluding remarks was to show that the Republicans were not capable of, and were too corrupt to govern a State or the country. Hon. JOHN COCHRANE was the next speaker. Mr. COCHRANE said the differences in the State of New-York had been healed, and the Democracy would march in the old step to victory, though Pennsylvania was shaky and Indiana had proved recreant to her trust. He referred to the Douglas nominations for Sheriff and Congress, and closed by declaring that the people of the South were now united as they never were before, and that New-York was certain to defeat Mr. LINCOLN. Senator SPINOLA at this point arrived on the ground at the head of a band of Hickory Boys. He was called for and took the stand, and made a lengthy speech to show that the real contest was whether the white or black man should rule this country. Shortly after the close of this speech the meeting adjourned.
lead_paragraph: UNION RATIFICATION MEETING. -- A large meeting of the supporters of the Union ticket was held in City Hall-square last evening. But we in New-York say to each other that this is the battle-field, and we will signify our devotion to the Union by rolling up an unprecedented majority for the Union ticket. The burthen of his concluding remarks was to show that the Republicans were not capable of, and were too corrupt to govern a State or the country. Hon. JOHN COCHRANE was the next speaker. Mr. COCHRANE said the differences in the State of New-York had been healed, and the Democracy would march in the old step to victory, though Pennsylvania was shaky and Indiana had proved recreant to her trust. He referred to the Douglas nominations for Sheriff and Congress, and closed by declaring that the people of the South were now united as they never were before, and that New-York was certain to defeat Mr. LINCOLN. Senator SPINOLA at this point arrived on the ground at the head of a band of Hickory Boys. Shortly after the close of this speech the meeting adjourned.

abstract: The attempts of the Fusionists to fuse all the Anti-Lincoln forces of our State in the present contest must very forcibly remind the calm observer of the efforts made by an awkward and impatient schoolboy to unravel into a straight line some hopelessly tangled skein of thread with which he seeks to fly his kite.
lead_paragraph: The attempts of the Fusionists to fuse all the Anti-Lincoln forces of our State in the present contest must very forcibly remind the calm observer of the efforts made by an awkward and impatient schoolboy to unravel into a straight line some hopelessly tangled skein of thread with which he seeks to fly his kite. One yard of the thread is only disengaged at a cost of entangling worse than ever the whole remainder of the line; until finally impatience prevails over judgment, and we see the ingenuous youth tearing madly at the skein, and trampling under foot its inextricable mass of fibres. Very similar to this would seem the fate of the Fusionists, who are now attempting to straighten out into line of political ascendency the tangled and jumbled forces opposed to the election of Mr. LINCOLN -- the Fusion Presidential kite, meanwhile, lying on on the ground, and with but little prospect of ever rising over the White House chimnies.

abstract: A Mr. LINCOLN, of Illinois, familiarly known as "Old Ann," age 51, height six feet seven, by profession Rail-Splitter, is to be our next President. The thing seems pretty sure. Since the Pennsylvania election, everybody concedes it. It becomes a matter of some importance, therefore, to see what is likely to happen in consequence of it. On this point doctors differ. Mr. J.W. GERARD, who talks in italics and deals largely in very poor jokes, thinks Mr. LINCOLN intends to split the Union. Mr. O'CONOR becomes facetious -- very much as a retained and well-bred hyena might be -- andthinks LINCOLN will live on negroes, to save expense of beef, during his Presidential term. Gen. WALBRIDGE waxes strong on statistics and small quotations, and JOHN COCHRANE adopts the balloon style of oratory, with about the same success which attends Prof. LOWE's attempts to cross the Atlantic.

Mr. O'CONOR becomes facetious -- very much as a retained and well-bred hyena might be -- andthinks LINCOLN will live on negroes, to save expense of beef, during his Presidential term. Gen. WALBRIDGE waxes strong on statistics and small quotations, and JOHN COCHRANE adopts the balloon style of oratory, with about the same success which attends Prof. LOWE's attempts to cross the Atlantic.

abstract: We may well admit to-day a passing truce in the conflict of politics, and unite as Americans in recognizing the tribute paid our common country in the visit of the heir of England to the commercial metropolis of the great Empire of the West. It is indeed no slight or insignificant homage which is thus rendered by the future Sovereign of England to the justice of the cause in which our fathers...
lead_paragraph: We may well admit to-day a passing truce in the conflict of politics, and unite as Americans in recognizing the tribute paid our common country in the visit of the heir of England to the commercial metropolis of the great Empire of the West. It is indeed no slight or insignificant homage which is thus rendered by the future Sovereign of England to the justice of the cause in which our fathers contended against the crown which he inherits, as well as to the greatness which the Republic has achieved. However lightly some of our own fellow-countrymen may be inclined to estimate the institutions under which the thirteen colonies of Great Britain have developed into more than thirty sovereign States, it is plain that to them we owe a rank among the nations, and a name in the earth not altogether despicable in the eyes even of those who were once our enemies, and to whom every advance which we make in wealth, in importance and in power, brings a more vivid reminiscence of that elder union with themselves which was severed so long ago by their own suicidal hands.

abstract: To-day let us hope that the pluvious Jupiter who has thus far attended and beset the wandering son of Victoria, will return to rainy Britain to report progress, and leave his royal charge to the sunshine and the smiles of the great American City. Never were our people in a better humor of hospitality than to-day. Some few worthy people, of course, are excited to an inordinate degree of unreflecting enthusiasm by the consideration that they are actually on the point of looking on the face of a live Prince, who, if he lives, will one day be a living King. This is as natural and as cosmopolitan a disease as the measles or the croup, and like them rarely attacks those who are adults in intelligence. But the masses of our population, of all orders, are actuated by a loftier as well as a mere generous feeling. In them a reasonable curiosity to see the Prince as a "distinguished stranger," is warmed and kindled by a hearty good-will towards the nation which he represents, and the royal lady who claims his service and his reverence by a higher than a queenly title. In all directions this mood of the multitude is harmoniously displayed. It appears in the ready response of our military to the summons which make them the ushers of our guest, and in the preparations everywhere visible for thronging the whole line of the Prince's parade to-day, and the whole line of his sojourn among us with the "unbought homage" of a free, prosperous and powerful people. If the event shall but answer to the exordium, the Prince of Wales's visit to New-York may take its place among the most agreeable as well as the most important historical fasti of the current age.

abstract: England and the English people need hardly  question, after yesterdayt's experience, the genuine disposition of America to do hearty justice to all that the mother country honors. A youth of nineteen, yesterday, took by storm of general good will the commercial metropolis of the Western World;
lead_paragraph: England and the English people need hardly question, after yesterdayt's experience, the genuine disposition of America to do hearty justice to all that the mother country honors. A youth of nineteen, yesterday, took by storm of general good will the commercial metropolis of the Western World; an a Colonel of the British army, whose maiden sword has never yet been fleshed in battle, rode in triumph through shouting lanes of a people now grown to imperial estate, when all the veteran troops and war-worn commanders of the British Kingdoms, proved powerless to constrain into an unjust obedience, long years ago, when their numbers were few, their resources small, and their name unknown in the earth. The magnificent courtesies yesterday lavished on the son of VICTORIA by all classes of the population of New-York, were more than courtesies. They spoke with irresistible eloquence, at once, of the power, the wealth, and the political influence which have made America strong enough to be unaffectedly, cordial, and placed her high enough to be generously forgetful; and of the sober second thought, which is obliterating from the English mind the angry memories of long ago, together with the jealousies of more recent years.

abstract: -- Capt. Hinckley, commander of the British steam sloop Gladiator, who was recently assaulted in New-Orleans by one of Walker's desperadoes, is a most gallant and intrepid officer. About a year ago, at imminent peril of his own life, he boarded the American brig St. Mary, dismasted and totally disabled during a heavy gale, to see what assistance he could render. The vessel was in a sinking condition, but, through the exertions of Capt. Hinckley and his men, she was safely towed to the harbor of St. Thomas -- a distance of 800 miles. This gallant service was fully recognized, by the New-York Board of Underwriters, and only recently they presented a very handsome testimonial to the Captain, officers and crew of the Gladiator. It is rather humiliating to think that this act of humanity and that of bringing home a portion of the piratical crew which lately, invaded Honduras should have met with the brutal response that it did. Little else, however, could be expected from men who are professional pirates and freebooters.

abstract: The artists and the dealers in Art are beginning to stir with the general revival of metropolitan life. The rural studies of the Summer will soon be ripening under the City's Autumn sun, and new visions of the "light that never was on land or sea" begin to be evoked from the outlines of mountain and shore under the painter's magical wand. More activity is thus far observ.
lead_paragraph: The artists and the dealers in Art are beginning to stir with the general revival of metropolitan life. The rural studies of the Summer will soon be ripening under the City's Autumn sun, and new visions of the "light that never was on land or sea" begin to be evoked from the outlines of mountain and shore under the painter's magical wand. More activity is thus far observable in the marts than in the ateliers, for the amateurs who buy belong mostly to the class of persons upon whom the festivities attending the Prince of Wales his visit, exert a certain magnetic fascination, while the artists who, if true artists, should have TITIAN's proud sense of peerage with the mightiest, have so much still to attract them in the Autumnal glories of our American nature, that many of them still linger in their leafy studios. CHURCH is unhappily kept prisoner from a projected grand attempt to show us a glimpse of that Arctic world which FRANKLIN braved and KANE conquered, by a most untoward and untimely accident. But delay is only a better assurance of full and final triumph to really gifted workers.

abstract: The organs of the Democratic Party are doing their best to keep their courage up. They try to persuade themselves that all is not lost. They acknowledge the stunning character of the blow they have received, but console themselves with the thought that there is a month left in which they may recover. The Washington Constitution talks about reconquering Pennsylvania; but most of the other organs confess that New-York is their forlorn hope.

abstract: Mr. O'CONOR has practiced at the Bar long enough to know that it is a sign of a weak case, when the lawyer who sums it up is compelled to misrepresent or falsify the evidence. Yet in his speech at the Fusion meeting on Monday night, he was guilty of that very thing to a very remarkable degree. Perhaps he
lead_paragraph: Mr. O'CONOR has practiced at the Bar long enough to know that it is a sign of a weak case, when the lawyer who sums it up is compelled to misrepresent or falsify the evidence. Yet in his speech at the Fusion meeting on Monday night, he was guilty of that very thing to a very remarkable degree. Perhaps he thought that as he was before a jury whose verdict was ascertained beforehand, he was absolved from the usual regard to facts. But even in political speeches it is well, in these days of reporters and newspapers, not to fall into mistakes and misrepresentations so easy to be confuted as those Mr. O'CONOR has made.

abstract: COMMISSIONERS OF CHARITIES AND CORRECTIONS. -- At a regular meeting of the Board held yesterday the weekly statement was presented, which in brief is as follows: Number remaining at last report 7,850; admitted since 1857 -- total, 9,737; died, 51; discharged, 1,505; sent to Blackwell's Island, 379; to State Prison, 2; leaving, 7,800; being a decrease of 50 for the week. The regular report of the Committee of the Whole was read and adopted; the only feature out of the usual course being special report upon the question at issue between the Board and the Commissioners of Emigration as to the amount due for the support of emigrant lunatics for many years. The Commissioners of Charities claim over one hundred thousand dollars, which the Commissioners of Emigration allege that they have overpaid by seven thousand.

abstract: Anthony Lawler, alias Becker, and a multitude of other cognomens, was arrested, Wednesday, by Officer Gallagher, of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, on a charge of swindling. The accused, it is said, has for a long time past been in the habit of obtaining patterns of garments from different merchant tailors, to make up, by representing that he was a journeyman, anx-
lead_paragraph: Anthony Lawler, alias Becker, and a multitude of other cognomens, was arrested, Wednesday, by Officer Gallagher, of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, on a charge of swindling. The accused, it is said, has for a long time past been in the habit of obtaining patterns of garments from different merchant tailors, to make up, by representing that he was a journeyman, anxious for employment, The goods, however, he invariably failed to return, and, by his dishonesty, he is said to have accumulated considerable money. The complainant, in this particular instance, is Mr. Theodore Wilhelm, of No. 63 Fulton-street. who was the loser of a pair of pantaloons by the prisoner's tricks, but Smith Brothers, Sandford & Edgerton, and other well-known clothiers, have also been swindled by him. At the house of the accused, No. 99 Mott-street, a quantity of goods was found, which had been procured in this fraudulent way. Justice KELLY committed the prisoner for trial.

abstract: A long time ago the Common Council made a contract for the removal of the human remains from Potter's Field, on Fourth-avenue, between Fortyninth and Fifty-first streets, to Ward's Island, for the sum of $9,000. The work was subsequently supposed to have been done and the money was paid. Some two years ago, however, human bones were exposed there, and Mayor TIEMANN and Comptroller HAWS had
lead_paragraph: A long time ago the Common Council made a contract for the removal of the human remains from Potter's Field, on Fourth-avenue, between Fortyninth and Fifty-first streets, to Ward's Island, for the sum of $9,000. The work was subsequently supposed to have been done and the money was paid. Some two years ago, however, human bones were exposed there, and Mayor TIEMANN and Comptroller HAWS had them removed, at an expense of $2,900. It was then believed that but few more remained, and the property subsequently was given or leased at the rate of $1 per year, to the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum and Woman's Hospital, by the Common Council, with the understanding that the corporations of those charities were never to search after the scattered human remains supposed to be left in the ground, but to build upon it as it came into their possession. Very recently, however, it has transpired that the Commissioners of Health -- whose secret sessions are hold semi-weekly or oftener, in the private office of the Mayor -- have been going all over the ground again during the past Summer. Complaint was made to the Mayor last Spring that the old Potter's Field was not properly rid of human remains, and upon this complaint CHAS. WIEGAN, a lager-bier saloon keeper on Fifty-second-street, near Potter's Field, and another man in Yorkville, were ordered to resume the job of removing the bones. WIEGAND was permitted to prepare the boxes for the re-interment of the remains in a decent manner, and was allowed fifty cents the load for taking them to the dock. Comptroller HAWS objected to the work as being unnecessary, but as the Commissioners of Health had the power to cause the expenditure, the bill was paid. The work had been under way a long time, when the Comptroller sent one of his clerks to note particulars of its progress, and he reported that eight or ten laborers were engaged in hunting out the remains. WEIGAND's payroll that week was for twenty men a day.

abstract: The Detroit Tribune gives the particulars, as related by Capt. NEWMAN, of the explosion on board the Western Transportation Company's propeller Mount Vernon, by which the boat and cargo were totally destroyed, on Tuesday morning. Capt. NEWMAN says: "The Mount Vernon left Detroit for Buffalo on Sunday evening, at 4 o'clock, with a cargo consisting of [???]19,200 bushels corn, 488 barrels flour, and 150 bags wheat. Before leaving the river she enountered a heavy gale, and was compelled to lie by at Malden all night. Left Monday morning 20 minutes to 4, and ran down 6 miles below Point au Pelle, the wind blowing fresh from northeast, with heavy sea. The storm increasing in violence, ran back for shelter in Pigeon Bay, under the Point, from whence she again got under way, at 1 o'clock this morning. When one-fourth of a mile from the "Dummy," off Point au Pelle, Capt. NEWMAN, observing that she was going slow, went aft to see what steam was on. Looked down from the upper deck, and ascertained that she had fifty pounds, (being capable of carrying seventy pounds.) Went back to the man at the wheel, and ordered him to put the wheel starboard, and keep her cast southeast. Just as he had spoken, the boiler blew up with a terrific explosion, tearing away her after part entire, breaking off both arches, and blowing away the after part of the cabin.

Looked down from the upper deck, and ascertained that she had fifty pounds, (being capable of carrying seventy pounds.) Went back to the man at the wheel, and ordered him to put the wheel starboard, and keep her cast southeast. Just as he had spoken, the boiler blew up with a terrific explosion, tearing away her after part entire, breaking off both arches, and blowing away the after part of the cabin.

abstract: We feel it our duty to call the attention of that jealous guardian of the integrity of the Union, the Richmond Enquirer, to a fact of which it seems to be entirely ignorant. We have reliable information that for some weeks past clubs have been organizing at different points, the members of which style themselves "Little Giants." A short time ago 6,000 of them, as the Argus said, appeared in Albany, at a Democratic meeting, and only yesterday we noticed that a branch of the same association had been discovered in Vicksburgh, Miss. So far as opportunity has been afforded for observation, it appears that these clubs closely imitate the Wide-Awakes. They dress in uniform, carry torches and attempt certain military evolutions. Then they train with that branch of the Democracy whose leader has declared so emphatically in favor of employing force to bring the South to reason if it should attempt to walk out of the Union. To be sure, these "Little Giants" are not as yet so formidable in numbers. Mr. LINCOLN's allies, the Wide-Awakes, but taking into consideration the fact that they have already gained a footing on Southern soil -- just where their services would be needed if such an emergency, should, arise, as was thrust upon Mr. DOUGLAS' consideration some weeks since at Norfolk -- it is strange that the Enquirer has not taken the alarm before this. We can only account for its obtuseness on the supposition that it has been blinded' by the glare of the Wide-Awake torches.

abstract: -- The current number of this illustrated serial contains a fine picture of the late Wide-Awake torchlight procession. The view is taken from Printing-House-square, with the TIMES Office prominently conspicuous, and we need hardly say that no more effective site for it could be selected. There is an independent character about Harper's Weekly that commends itself to all classes of readers. Democratic and Republican demonstrations, whenever their importance entitles them to special notice, are treated with equal fairness, while the conservative and sound moral tone of the Weekly give it high claims as a family journal. Its circulation, we understand, has lately increased -- a proper reward for the enterprise of the publishers.

abstract: From Lousiana and Mississippi we begin to obtain sad accounts of the loss by the gale on Tuesday last. No similar record of large and deplorable losses of buildings and machinery, to say nothing of the growing crops, has been lately experienced.

abstract: The extent to which the extreme Pro-Slavery sentiment which has ruled the South during the last dozen years, is the merely artificial product of Democratic politicians, is made apparent in the facility with which many of those who, a year or two ago, were loud-mouthed preachers of disunion, have become equally
lead_paragraph: The extent to which the extreme Pro-Slavery sentiment which has ruled the South during the last dozen years, is the merely artificial product of Democratic politicians, is made apparent in the facility with which many of those who, a year or two ago, were loud-mouthed preachers of disunion, have become equally extravagant in their devotion to the Union, while the Union-savers of an earlier stage in the controversy, in many instances, now profess themselves ready to unfurl the red banner of treason. These individuals have, for local or personal reasons, changed their political relations, and they, as a matter of course, adopt the political maxims and modes of reasoning which are prevalent among their new political associates. Campaign documents have been made up and widely circulated by the opposition to the Breckinridge Democracy, showing, by extracts from the speeches and writings of its leaders, that the party is for disunion. They retort by getting up a compilation from the speeches and writings of the Southern friends of Mr. DOUGLAS, and of Mr. BELL, in which, within a few years past, a similar spirit of disloyalty to the Union is manifest, and equally violent threats of breaking it up, in certain contingencies, are uttered.

abstract: -- The passengers in a train on the Jackson, La., Railroad, on the 1st inst., had a pleasant time of it. The track had been carried away in some places by the severe storm, which the telegraph has already noticed, but the train succeeded in making its way to within thirty miles of New-Orleans, and there it had to stop in water seven feet deep, for nearly twenty-four hours. The passengers had nothing to eat but the scanty provisions which one of their number fortunately had in a basket. Finally, they were relieved from their unpleasant predicament by a relief train.
lead_paragraph: -- The passengers in a train on the Jackson, La., Railroad, on the 1st inst., had a pleasant time of it. abstract: A gratifying indication of the actual condition of social and intellectual culture in Italy, is offered by Il Politechnico, a monthly magazine of studies, "applied to social prosperity and civilization," printed at Milan. The papers, contributed mainly by the ablest living scholars, savans and engineers of the Peninsula, manifest evidences not only of profound and earnest scholarship, but also of vigorous, original thought,
lead_paragraph: A gratifying indication of the actual condition of social and intellectual culture in Italy, is offered by Il Politechnico, a monthly magazine of studies, "applied to social prosperity and civilization," printed at Milan. The papers, contributed mainly by the ablest living scholars, savans and engineers of the Peninsula, manifest evidences not only of profound and earnest scholarship, but also of vigorous, original thought, and judicious speculation, tending powerfully to the advancement of scientific inquiry. Especially interesting are those treating of commercial and industrial questions affecting that most interesting country, At this period of transition, attention is naturally attracted to all the elements necessary to a comparison of the commercial status of the several States under the protective and despotic systems now passing away, and the immediate future of trade and labor to which Freedom will unquestionably afford a new and energetic stimulus. And of much interest, as bearing upon cotemporary history, are several papers upon military questions; those, for instance, of Col. FOGLIARDI, on the "New Italian Army;" Dr. AGOSTINO BRETANI, on the "Cacciatori of the Alps in 1859, their wounds, and their deaths;" and Signor JACCHI on the "Mode of completing the Italian Army." There are also various contributions upon purely literary topics, exhibiting refined and matured taste. As appendants to the monthly issue, works of permanent value are from time to time published, under the charge of the redaction. Of these, the most recent is a map of Italy, illustrative of the mediaeval conflicts between the various communities, with a highly valuable chronological index. The enterprise is creditable as well to Italian scholarship as to the spirit of the publishers. Messrs. A. RAPETTI & Co., of No. 596 Broadway, are the American agents of the Polytechnic.

abstract: The spectacle presented on Broadway on the evermemorable day of the Japanese reception was fairly outdone yesterday. America triumphed in the weather, which was as bright as October in his best humor could make it, and a feeling more generous than mere curiosity emptied New-York into Broadway. From the Battery to Grace Church the great highway was one vast trough of humanity, animated, glittering, good-natured, and bent on making
lead_paragraph: The spectacle presented on Broadway on the evermemorable day of the Japanese reception was fairly outdone yesterday. America triumphed in the weather, which was as bright as October in his best humor could make it, and a feeling more generous than mere curiosity emptied New-York into Broadway. From the Battery to Grace Church the great highway was one vast trough of humanity, animated, glittering, good-natured, and bent on making the best of all possible greetings to the coming Prince. By common consent everybody's business seemed to be sacrificed to the pleasure of everybody else; stores became theatres for the nonce, and high noon a careless holiday. All stoops, windows and roof-tops were groaning under human freight; all the side streets were blocked with vehicles, and on the roof of every coach or omnibus, with straining necks and staring eye-balls, black swarms of humanity clustered. But to relieve the monotony of this picture, never before have we seen such a surplusage of bunting, such a superfluity of flags, such strange combinations of quasi-national colors and designs, as were protruded on poles out of all the windows and hoisted over all the chimney-tops of aspiring trade. One might have thought that Wednesday had been set apart by law as grand washing day for all the flags on Manhattan Island, and that yesterday was prescribed in the same statute as the day for drying and bleaching them.

abstract: The Democracy, and especially the official portion of the Democracy, in Washington, were never before so thoroughly overwhelmed with a sense of ruin as at the present moment; and the reflection that the blow comes from the old Keystone State adds poignancy to despair. In all former defeats there was still hope of resurrection. But now they sink to rise no more.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Oct. 10, 1860.

abstract: -- The South Brooklyn Republican Association held a large meeting last evening in the Court-street Wigwam, when an address was made by HORACE GREELEY. The Republicans of the Fourth Assembly District met last evening hi Musical Hall to complete arrangements for the campaign. The Republicans of the Third Ward met at the same place to reorganize for the campaign.

abstract: One of the most extraordinary of a long series of excited meetings of the Church of the Puritans was held last evening in the lecture-room of the church. The occasion was the citation of Mr. CHAS. E. ABERNETHY, former Treasurer, and for many years a prominent member and one of the Anti-Cheever Party to appear and answer to certain charges concerning his behavior as a member. Among these
lead_paragraph: One of the most extraordinary of a long series of excited meetings of the Church of the Puritans was held last evening in the lecture-room of the church. The occasion was the citation of Mr. CHAS. E. ABERNETHY, former Treasurer, and for many years a prominent member and one of the Anti-Cheever Party to appear and answer to certain charges concerning his behavior as a member. Among these were allegations that he had accused Dr. CHEEVER wrongfully of illegally manufacturing voters, that he had been guilty of schism in trying to effect the removal of Dr. CHEEVER from the pastorate, and that he had tried to create dissensions. This was the spirit of the charges, if not the letter.

abstract: Yesterday the long looked-for Prince of Wales arrived here and received a welcome such as must have been as gratifying to him and his attendants as it was creditable to the first City of the United States. After 11 O' clock in the morning there was but little business done. Buyers and sellers were alike anxious to see the Prince and aid in the
lead_paragraph: Yesterday the long looked-for Prince of Wales arrived here and received a welcome such as must have been as gratifying to him and his attendants as it was creditable to the first City of the United States. After 11 O' clock in the morning there was but little business done. Buyers and sellers were alike anxious to see the Prince and aid in the demonstration, so many of the stores were closed, and instead of the flaming advertisements which usually embellish the windows and fronts of places of trade, American, English and other flags were hung out, and Broadway, from the Battery to Madison-square, was in holiday dress. Early in the morning the revenue cutter Harriet Lane left her anchorage at the Battery and, with the Committee of Reception, Gen. SCOTT, and a number of guests on board, proceeded to Amboy to receive the Prince and suite. He was there taken on board and conveyed to Castle Garden, where he was again received and welcomed by the Mayor. He then left Castle Garden and reviewed the First Division, which was drawn up in line on the Battery. When the review was over, the Prince and party entered carriages, in waiting for them, and, accompanied by the military, proceeded to the City Hall, in front of which he received a marching salute. The line was then reformed, and the Prince was escorted to his rooms in the Fifth-avenue Hotel. The demonstration was among the very best which has ever been made by the City. During the day there were not less than 200,000 people either looking on or taking active part in the welcome, and yet there was no accident of any moment, nor did anything occur to mar the pleasure of the occasion.

abstract: If one of the good old Burghers, who, in the days when New-York was called New-Amsterdam, and WOUTER VAN TWILLER reigned Governor, were wont to smoke their pipes and discuss English aggressive in open squares, could shake off the sleep of centuries, brush the dust from his shoes, and walk from the Battery to Harlem, it is probable he would scarcely believe his eyes. To find the open spaces he once knew effectually closed by variegated structures of marble and mortar, would convince him he had only awaked to a dream, -- in none of its aspects could he recognize Manhattan. He would find drays ratling where it was once water, and ships moored where it was once land. Disgusted with the changes and innovations, he would probably return to the church-yard, with a request that his rest be not again disturbed.

abstract: The firm of L. Van Hoffman & Co., exchange brokers, doing business in Exchange-place, were heavy losers about two years ago in the purchase of over $100,000 in notes, purporting to be the issue of the Colonial Bank, Barbados, W.I., but which subsequently proved to be forgeries. This worthless paper had been taken by Messrs. Van Hoffman in the course of business transactions with a middle-aged German, named Henry Lowe, who commenced his intercourse with them by bringing genuine bills of the bank in question, to be exchanged. Having formed the acquaintance and acquired the confidence of the firm, Lowe found it an easy matter to palm upon the unsuspecting brokers forged notes to the extent of thousands of dollars. These counterfeits had been carefully prepared from a copy of the genuine bank notes, and the imitation was so good that it appeared to be a perfect fac-simile. With the wealth thus acquired, Lowe purchased a vessel, and in it escaped from the country, but from that time until the present the argus eyes of the detective police have been fixed upon his movements. Recently the officers received information that he had again returned to this country, and therefore a fresh stimulus was added to their desire for his arrest. Having made themselves familiar with the general appearance of the fugitive by means of his portrait and a particular description of his person, for the past week or two many an innocent pedestrian in passing through the streets, whose looks have borne a semblance to that of the fugitive forger, has unconsciously to himself been the subject of police scrutiny. Yesterday the vigilance of Officer Smith, of the Detective force, was rewarded. In passing through Third-avenue, near Eighty-fourth-street, he met the identical man for whom he had been so long in search, and at once arrested him. The prisoner was conducted to headquarters and detained for the night. This morning he will be taken before Justice CONNOLLY and examined with reference to the charge against him.

abstract: The Synods of the Free and United Presbyterian Churches in Canada have just concluded important meetings at Montreal. Although distinctive in name, these bodies have had little else to keep them apart, and for two or three years past negotiations have been pending which had in view their consolidation. The discussions on this subject in the Free Presbyterian Synod culminated in the appointment of a deputation to wait upon the United Synod, to request a conference. The proposition was at once acceded to by the latter body, and the two Synods assembled together in Knox's Church the same afternoon. Some modifications of the basis of Union which had been partially agreed upon were made, and then it was formally adopted. The Synods then met again separately, and each adopted the preamble and the other parts of the basis, and in the evening a meeting was held to discuss the name which should be given the United Church. It was determined, after some debate, to designate the body as the "Canada Presbyterian Church," and, by a vote of 46 to 30, a resolution was adopted to hold a special meeting to consummate the Union at Toronto on the 20th of December next. A number of joint Committees were appointed to complete the necessary preliminaries, and the Synods adjourned. The result seems to be hailed with delight by all parties. The Presbyterians in Nova Scotia, however, have been the leaders In this Union movement. By a singular coincidence, at the time when the preliminaries for the coalition in Canada were under discussion, that in Nova Scotia was in process of consummation, and the celebration of the event occurred at Pictou on the 4th and 5th inst. Addresses were made by a number of prominent clergymen residing in the Province, and the members of the two bodies formally gave one another the hand of fellowship. The two bodies in Canada are now known as "The Synod of the Presbyterian Church of the Lower Provinces.

abstract: The trial of Patrick Hogan was continued yesterday in this Court. Mr. Clinton examined some witnesses for the defence, whose testimony was mainly to the effect that the deceased, Thomas McLaughlin, had made offensive demonstrations to Hogan before the wound was inflicted. The summing-up of counsel, reply of the District-Attorney, and charge of the Judge, occupied the attention of the jury till a late hour. They retired about 4 o'clock, and returned in a short time with a verdict of "Guilty of manslaughter in the third degree." The prisoner was remanded for sentence.

abstract: Then Board met yesterday at 12 M., for the purpose of considering the report of the Committee on Annual taxes, who had in charge the Comptroller's budget for 1860, with the ordinance making appropriations for City and County purposes, and which has already been published at the time of its presentation. The Committee propose only three changes; one inserting the sum of $72,034 26 for the "Commissioners of Record." But this is accompanied by a quasi protest, the Committee stating that they insert the item under the compulsion of a peremptory mandamus from the Supreme Court, and from a desire not to embarrass the various departments by any unnecessary delay; at the same time declaring their belief that the Court has no right to direction independent legislative body what it shall or shall not do. The sum of $43,891 is deducted from the appropriation to the Almshouse Department, that amount having been received and paid over by the Commissioners of Excise, and the sum of $2,300 has been stricken from the amount applied for on account of the Beekman-street extension. The addition and subtractions effect a change of only $28,143 26 from the amounts called for by the comptroller, which foot up now as follows: Total tax to be raised for County purposes, and for the payment of State taxes, $3,568,393 69, and for City purposes the sum of $5,923,852 61, and with the addition of $28,143 26, cause by the charges above noted, making a grand total of $9,520,388 96, to be raised for City and County purposes. The item of $80,000 for the Central Park Commission excited some discussion, Mr. TWEED taking the lead, and asserting, that as the Commissioners who had at first asked $97,500 were now content to put up with $80,000, it was not improbable that if a little more time was given them for reflection, they might conclude that they could got along with $50,000. The item of $72,000 for the Commissioners of Records was swallowed with great difficulty and with awfully wry faces on the part of every member of the Board, but it went down sweetened by the assurance that the law compelled the insertion of the item in the tax levy, not one dollar would' ever reach the pockets of the contractors until the very highest court in the land had decided their right to it. The feeling as to this item was unanimous.

abstract: DESTRUCTION OF A KEROSENE OIL FACTORY BY FIRE. -- At about 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon the Kerosene Oil factory of Messrs. BABROWS & SCOTT, on Conover, corner of Reed-street, Red Hook Point, was discovered to be on fire. The building contained such inflammable material that soon after the fire was discovered all hope of saving anything was abandoned, and the exertions of the firemen were consequently chiefly exerted towards the protection of adjoining property. The fire was caused by the leaking of a kettle of oil while the workmen were at dinner. The building was made of brick and wood, one story high, and spread over a space of 200 feet square. The machinery and all the contents of the building, except about 50 barrels of resin, were destroyed. The loss to the owners is from $15,000 to $20,000. There was no insurance.
lead_paragraph: DESTRUCTION OF A KEROSENE OIL FACTORY BY FIRE. -- At about 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon the Kerosene Oil factory of Messrs.
