abstract: The Prince of Wales and suite yesterday visited the New-York University, the Woman's Library, the Astor Library, the Cooper Institute, and the Free Academy, and then rode to the Central Park, where he assisted at the transplanting of an English oak and an American elm. At most of these places addres
lead_paragraph: The Prince of Wales and suite yesterday visited the New-York University, the Woman's Library, the Astor Library, the Cooper Institute, and the Free Academy, and then rode to the Central Park, where he assisted at the transplanting of an English oak and an American elm. At most of these places addresses were presented to the Prince. At 1 P.M. he lunched at the residence of Mayor WOOD on the Bloomingdale-road, and at 3 1/2 o'clock he was received at the Deaf and Dumb Institution, at Fort Washington. Leaving there, he rode to the foot of Two Hundred and Fifteenth-street, and, embarking in the Trumpeter, sailed through Harlem River, under the High Bridge, past the institutions to the East River, down which he sailed in the Harriet Lane. It was 6 1/2 P.M. when the Royal party landed at the foot of Twenty-second-street, North River, and returned to the Fifth-avenue Hotel. The doings at the grand ball at the Academy, last night, will be found duly chronicled in our columns this morning.

abstract: Mr. JOHN KEEPE, of Williamsburgh, who is employed at the lifting dock located at Pier No. 39 East River, near Pike-street, on reaching his place of business, between 7 and 8 o'clock yesterday morning, found the body of a man floating beneath the pier. He at once called a policeman to assist him in taking the remains from the water; and this having been accomplished, unmistakable evidence was presented that deceased had been the subject of violence, which had resulted in his death. The skull and the upper part of the face were crushed in; the nose had been forced from its position and lay upon the cheek, the eyes were discolored and closed in consequence of contused wounds, and a gash in the throat showed that a sharp instrument -probably an axe -- had been used to inflict it. From this last wound blood still flowed, and the body presented every indication that the murder had been perpetrated during Thursday night, and that it afterwards had been thrown into the river with the object of concealing all traces of the crime. The features of deceased are so shockingly mutilated, that it would seem a matter of much difficulty to establish his identity. Apparently, however, he was a laboring man, probably about 35 years of age, weighing 200 pounds, 5 feet 8 inches in height, and his dress consisted of a pair of blue overalls and white cotton shirt, his feet having neither shoe nor stocking upon them. As soon as the fact became known that the body had been found a crowd of people assembled on the pier to look at it. Among them was Commissioner NICHOLSON, of the Board of Public Charities and Corrections, who identified the blood-stained shirt which deceased had on as similar to those used in the Penitentiary Hospital at Blackwell's Island. This circumstance, in connection with the fact that one of the man's legs was bandaged from the knee to the ancle, afforded ground for the belief that he had been a patient in that institution, who had been recently discharged, and later in [???]hh day, a closer examination of the garment revealed the words "Island Hospital" marked upon it, thus verifying the supposition. Coroner SCHIRMER was notified to investigate the circumstances of the case, and his deputy, Dr. BOUTON, took the body in custody, and had it removed to the Bellevue Hospital dead-house, that an opportunity, might be afforded for its identification. In the absence of any testimony whatever, the Coroner has determined not to enter upon an inquest at present. Meantime, the Seventh Ward Police will devote themselves to the task of solving the mystery.

abstract: -- The progress of Metropolitan journalism keeps pace with the progress of the City itself. The efforts that have been lately made by the Associated Press to improve its news arrangements deserve to be chronicled, and we may be pardoned for alluding to them, as the TIMES is but one among divers journals that have assumed the heavy expenditures which these enterprises entail. The establishment of news yachts at Cape Race and other points, whence intelligence could be forwarded by telegraph, was the first successful attempt of the Association to shorten the distance between Europe and the United States. By this means an important European event is known throughout America within eight days after its occurrence; though, from the absence of similar enterprise on the other side of the Atlantic, the American news in the London papers is always from twelve to fifteen days old. The New-York Association, to make the reception of its European news more certain and reliable, lately purchased the lease of the New-foundland and Prince Edward's Island telegraph lines, and it now proposes to have news yachts stationed off Fire Island and Montauk Point, on Long Island, in order that inward-bound steamers and packets may be intercepted and their news obtained some twenty-four hours in advance of the usual time. These important arrangements cannot be effected without much extra expense; but we feel assured that they will be appreciated by the public, whom they are chiefly designed to serve and accommodate.

abstract: Last evening Broadway was enlivened by theglare of the Wide-Awake torches of our City companies. The parade was an impromptu affair, each Ward and company parading independently, gotten up by way of celebrating the recent Republican triumphs in Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana and Maine, and was well calculated to remind the people that their next President has been indicated by these elections.
lead_paragraph: Last evening Broadway was enlivened by theglare of the Wide-Awake torches of our City companies. abstract: One of the minor but not the least gratifying results of the Republican victories in Pennsylvania and Indiana, is that they consign to private life those inestimable public servants, BIGLER and BRIGHT. As members of the United States Senate, those distinguished men have been as instrumental as any others in raising that dignified legislative body to the level of the old French Parliaments for reg
lead_paragraph: One of the minor but not the least gratifying results of the Republican victories in Pennsylvania and Indiana, is that they consign to private life those inestimable public servants, BIGLER and BRIGHT. As members of the United States Senate, those distinguished men have been as instrumental as any others in raising that dignified legislative body to the level of the old French Parliaments for registering royal decrees, thus converting an independent legislative assembly into, an advisory council, where the will of the Executive was simply legalized. That the Senate, during the last six years, has abandoned its constitutional position as arbiter between popular license and Executive usurpation, and formed a strict offensive league with the White House against the popular branch of Congress, is a fact not only verified by current observation, but solemnly recorded in that legislative Doomsday-book, the Congressional Globe.

abstract: The "Grand Ball in honor of the Prince of Wales" came off, we presume, this morning. It was preceded, however, last night, by a very splendid, crowded, gorgeous and glittering levee, which may well take rank with the most magnificent "jams" of history. In the days of our grandmothers, who used to have their hair dressed two
lead_paragraph: The "Grand Ball in honor of the Prince of Wales" came off, we presume, this morning. It was preceded, however, last night, by a very splendid, crowded, gorgeous and glittering levee, which may well take rank with the most magnificent "jams" of history. In the days of our grandmothers, who used to have their hair dressed two days in advance of one of these festivities, and sit holt upright in powder for forty-eight hours, it was regarded as the height of fashion and the supreme of bliss, to fill a house so full with embroidered beaux and belles that they stood upon one another's silken toes in the passages and stairways. Of our own days it may hereafter be said that the finest thing which "four hundred select committee men" of New-York could do to entertain the Prince of Wales, was to invite to the Academy of Music exactly five hundred people more than the house would hold, amuse them by opening a pitfall in the floor, and crush their toilettes into one undistinguishable mass of splendor.

abstract: -- Of the much very natural surprise excited by the result of the election in Pennsylvania, a large share must be given to the First Congressional District, where the candidate of the People's party proves upon the official count to have a majority of 180. The District has so long been represented by the highly respectable hatter of that name as to be known as Florence's. It embraces the lower Wards of the city, where the population is largely intermixed with foreign elements, where education is at a discount, and the popular morals find expression in street-fights, and other frequent disorderly manifestations. It is no unusual thing for democratic politics to meet with peculiar acceptance in such localities; and that Mr. FLORENCE has succeeded in procuring his return, from 1852 until his present term can hardly be a matter of astonishment, especially in view of the adroit and capital use made in his behalf of the administration influence in the Navy Yard. The fact, that his triumphs have been exactly coordinate with the predominance of his party at Washington might indeed provoke a suspicion that to this specific source his success in extinguishing Know-Nothingism in his district and in repelling the inroads of Republicanism is to be chiefly ascribed. But the decline of this possible influence is only an incident of the decline of all Administration influence, not only in this one spot, but throughout the North. In the Fall of 1856, floating upon the flood-tide which swept Mr. BUCHANAN into office, Mr. FLORENCE was returned to Congress by a majority of 2,220, over an antagonist who was supported by both opposing parties. In 1858, a new party, created by the Administration impolicy in regard to Kansas, had sprung up, and while FLORENCE had a plurality of 331 over the People's, and nearly 5,000 over the Anti-Lecompton candidate, he was in a minority upon the popular vote of more than 2,000. How enormously this deficit has been increased may, in the absence of detailed returns, be conjectured from the majority now obtained by Mr. BUTLER, the People's candidate, notwithstanding the presence in the field of a third contestant put forward by the Bell and Everett Party, attracting about the same vote as that given in the previous contest for the Anti-Lecompton man.

abstract: The steamship De Soto, Capt. JOHNSTON, from New-Orleans on the 5th, and Havana on the 8th inst., arrived at this port last night. Nothing of importance was occurring at Havana. The health of the city remained good.

abstract: -- The public will regret to hear that Mr. MUIR, the popular British Consul at New-Orleans, met, on Thursday, while assisting at the reception of the Prince, with an accident which it is feared will confine him for some time to his room. On entering the carriage to join the procession, after the review, the horses suddenly started, as his foot was review, step, and, in order to escape getting under the wheels, and in the concussion the ligaments and tendons of the foot were ruptured. Though still suffering much pain, he felt easier last night.
lead_paragraph: -- The public will regret to hear that Mr. MUIR, the popular British Consul at New-Orleans, met, on Thursday, while assisting at the reception of the Prince, with an accident which it is feared will confine him for some time to his room. On entering the carriage to join the procession, after the review, the horses suddenly started, as his foot was review, step, and, in order to escape getting under the wheels, and in the concussion the ligaments and tendons of the foot were ruptured. Though still suffering much pain, he felt easier last night.

abstract: Private advices from Sonora report the success Of GANDARA, who has taken Guaymas, and every other town but Hermosilla, where PESQUEIRA is fortifying for a last and desperate battle. The Mexicans in Arizona are going over and joining the successful party in Sonora.

abstract: Having delighted the Prince with a view of our magnificent bay in holiday trim, our citizen soldiery in full ranks, our expansive promenade swarming with enthusiastic citizens, welcoming him to the Ectropolis, and the grand ball of the elite, at the Academy, it is but natural that the demonstrations should culminate in the feu de joie of a firemen's torchlight procession. The firemen have entered into the spirit of the reception, and for weeks have been engaged in the necessary preparations, determined to make a turn-out that shall be a credit to the City and to the Department.
lead_paragraph: Having delighted the Prince with a view of our magnificent bay in holiday trim, our citizen soldiery in full ranks, our expansive promenade swarming with enthusiastic citizens, welcoming him to the Ectropolis, and the grand ball of the elite, at the Academy, it is but natural that the demonstrations should culminate in the feu de joie of a firemen's torchlight procession. The firemen have entered into the spirit of the reception, and for weeks have been engaged in the necessary preparations, determined to make a turn-out that shall be a credit to the City and to the Department.

abstract: By each steamer I have been hoping that I could advise you that the Revolution had ended, and that the Liberal Government had become established in power, but it seems as if the delays are interminable, and that the late fair prospects of peace may now not be realized until some foreign Power interferes openly, and by force of arms.

abstract: Nothing of interest has been heard from WALKER for some time, and all excitement here regarding his invasion has died away. The reinforcement of Government troops ordered to the borders of Nicaragua have been withdrawn, and matters have settled down quietly.
lead_paragraph: LEON, Nicaragua, Thursday, Sept. 27, 1860.

abstract: MORTALITY. -- One hundred and thirty-three deaths were reported to the Health Officer last week, classified as follows: Men 26; women, 24; boys, 49; girls, 34. Adults, 50; children, 83; males, 75; females, 58. The principal diseases were consumption, by which there were 16 deaths; marasmus, (infantile,) 10; fevers 24 -- of which 15 were scarlet; 9 each by congestion of the brain and convulsions, (infantile.) There were also 3 deaths the result of accidents. 1 death by drowning, 1 from suffocation, and 1 from unknown causes. Sixty-nine of the persons who died were under five years of age. Ninety-six were natives of the United States, 3 of England, 1 of France, 7 of Germany, 22 of Ireland, 1 of Italy, 1 of Scotland, and 2 unknown. The deaths were in the several Wards as follows: First Ward, 2; Second Ward, 4; Third Ward, 1; Fourth Ward, 3; Fifth Want, 12; Sixth Ward, 17; Seventh Ward, 3; Eighth Ward, 2; Ninth Ward, 9; Tenth Ward, 16; Eleventh Ward, 19; Twelfth Ward, 11; Thirteenth Ward, 5; Fourteenth Ward, 9; Fifteenth Ward, 8; Sixteenth Ward, 4; Seventeenth Ward, 4; Eighteenth Ward, 1; Nineteenth Ward, 3.

abstract: It has been stated, in one or more of the newspapers, that the members of the Committee on Police and Carriages, at the Ball on Friday evening last, believed that a large number of persons not entitled to cards of invitation had gained admission, and they therefore ordered a count of the tickets received at the doors; also, that charges had been made of collusion on the part of the Committee's door-keepers, and the police -- two of the former and one of the latter -- being stationed at each door. Such opinions or charges were not entertained or expressed by the Committee, but from the reliable character of the persons employed to receive the tickets of admission, they most positively dissented from the opinions expressed that the number present exceeded the legitimate issue of cards of invitation, and they ordered the count only as a precaution to prevent the surmises and meet the openly avowed charges of irregularity or collusion on the part of any persons connected with the issue or collection of tickets. At 2 o'clock, by the request of EDWARD PRIME, Esq., and myself, members of the Committee having the charge of the entrances to the house, the boxes of tickets received for admission were taken to a private room and counted by us. M.B. FIELD, Esq., Secretary of the General Committee, was invited to be present; also Mr. MOSS, who had the personal supervision of the door-keepers; and Mr. KENNEDY, Superintendent of Police. From this, no doubt, originated the report of a supposed collusion on the part of the police, which the members of the Committee most emphatically disavow, as the highest praise is awarded to them for their respectful and efficient, services. Several members of the Press were also present. The boxes were unlocked, the keys having been handed to me before the doors of admission were opened. I announced that the count had proved that 3,025 tickets had been received at the door, besides those admitting musicians and policemen, which were correct. No orders or irregular tickets of any kind were found in the boxes. The result proved that of the whole number of the 3,195 tickets issued by the Committee, only 3,025 were received at the door, and that 170 persons had not availed themselves of the invitations presented. The arrangements made by the Committee prevented any return of tickets at the door, and only a small number of tokens for temporary absence were issued.

abstract: -- THE APPEAL FOR FOREIGN AID. -- We find in the London American a copy of a Protest which has been sent to England by a large number of the members of Dr. CHEEVER's Church, against the application which he is making in Great Britain for pecuniary aid. It will be found in another part of this morning's TIMES. It is entirely temperate in its tone, and places the subject upon a basis which cannot fail to command for it respectful attention and decided influence abroad. The signers deny that the Church as such is in any need of foreign aid, -- and represent the appeal as coming from a few individuals, backed by the Pastor, and as intended for their personal benefit and not at all for the support of the Church. They deny that the appeal has any legitimate connection with the opinions of the Church on the subject of Slavery, and that it is only calculated to misrepresent and greatly damage the Anti-Slavery cause. They appeal to their brethren abroad not to undertake to pronounce judgment on a matter which they cannot fully understand, and upon a one-sided statement.
lead_paragraph: -- THE APPEAL FOR FOREIGN AID. -- We find in the London American a copy of a Protest which has been sent to England by a large number of the members of Dr. CHEEVER's Church, against the application which he is making in Great Britain for pecuniary aid. It will be found in another part of this morning's TIMES. It is entirely temperate in its tone, and places the subject upon a basis which cannot fail to command for it respectful attention and decided influence abroad. The signers deny that the Church as such is in any need of foreign aid, -- and represent the appeal as coming from a few individuals, backed by the Pastor, and as intended for their personal benefit and not at all for the support of the Church. They deny that the appeal has any legitimate connection with the opinions of the Church on the subject of Slavery, and that it is only calculated to misrepresent and greatly damage the Anti-Slavery cause. They appeal to their brethren abroad not to undertake to pronounce judgment on a matter which they cannot fully understand, and upon a one-sided statement.

abstract: It seems that the  Liberal forces in Mexico have resorted to an imitation of some of the worst practices of their opponents. Finding themselves in a very desperate condition, with a large force, and destitute of money for its support or advance, they have seized over a million of dollars belonging to foreign merchants, which was on its way from the capital to Vera Cruz, for shipment. Gen. DECOLLADO, by whom this robbery for it.
lead_paragraph: -- It seems that the Liberal forces in Mexico have resorted to an imitation of some of the worst practices of their opponents. Finding themselves in a very desperate condition, with a large force, and destitute of money for its support or advance, they have seized over a million of dollars belonging to foreign merchants, which was on its way from the capital to Vera Cruz, for shipment. Gen. DECOLLADO, by whom this robbery for it is nothing else -- was perpetrated, has issued a manifesto explaining the necessity which existed for it, and treating the affair as only a temporary loan. He will not, however, easily satisfy those to whom the money belonged, nor foreign nations, of the justice or propriety of his course.

abstract: -- Our Royal visitor has enjoyed one exemption during his stay among us, as creditable to an improving taste as it has doubtless been agreeable to him. We have not bored him by long speeches. We have not thought it necessary to rehearse to him the whole history of the country, or to read him solemn lessons on the nature of our institutions; the achievements of our great men, or the superlative extent to which we surpass all the other nations of the earth. We have paid him the compliment of assuming that he knew something of geography and history, and that if he desired information on any particular point, he knows enough of the language to ask for it. This is quite a novelty. Generally our. functionaries take it for granted that distinguished persons come to see us because they know nothing about us. We are evidently making some progress in this particular, at all events.
lead_paragraph: -- Our Royal visitor has enjoyed one exemption during his stay among us, as creditable to an improving taste as it has doubtless been agreeable to him. We are evidently making some progress in this particular, at all events.

abstract: The steamship North Star, from Aspinwall on the 6th inst., arrived at this port early yesterday morning. Her advices are interesting. The steamer John L. Stephens, which had not arrived at Panama when the previous packet left, had put into Acapulco in distress, -- having, as we apprehended, met with an accident to her machinery, which disabled her. The treasure was transferred to the succeeding mail steamer, and reaches New-York by the North Star, which thus brings two lists -- one of $870,157, and the other of $992,484.
lead_paragraph: The steamship North Star, from Aspinwall on the 6th inst., arrived at this port early yesterday morning. Her advices are interesting. The steamer John L. abstract: The news from Costa Rica is highly important. On the night of the 28th ult., the troops of President MONTEALEGRE, 1,300 strong, under Gen. MAXEMO BLANCO, attacked the fort of Ex-President MORA, at the Augostura, near Punta Arenas. We find the particulars of the affair in the Panama Star and Herold.
lead_paragraph: The news from Costa Rica is highly important. On the night of the 28th ult., the troops of President MONTEALEGRE, 1,300 strong, under Gen. MAXEMO BLANCO, attacked the fort of Ex-President MORA, at the Augostura, near Punta Arenas. We find the particulars of the affair in the Panama Star and Herold. The force of MORA only amounted to about 250 or 300 men that he had armed from among the launch men and other inhabitants of Punta Arenas; of course, they could not resist the attack, and, after twenty minutes' fighting, the attacking party succeeded. At the same time a party of thirty men came down in small boats and took MORA and his staff by surprise at their head-quarters at Punta Arenas. After some resistance the house was taken, but MORA and two others hid themselves under the floor of the adjoining house, where they remained a night and a day. When they came out, they surrendered to Gen. BLANCO, and, without any trial, even by court martial, MORA and ARANCIBIA were shot in the most summary manner on the morning of the 30th. Gen. CANAS, who had command of the fort, fought very bravely; he fired the last gun with his own hands.

abstract: The capture of Ancona by the Sardinians, and the surrender of Gen. DE LAMORICIERE, with his whole force, to the army of VICTOR EMANUEL, could not have come at a more opportune moment for the welfare of Italy and the peace of the world. Annihilating at one blow the whole military power of the Papal Government, this triumph makes
lead_paragraph: The capture of Ancona by the Sardinians, and the surrender of Gen. DE LAMORICIERE, with his whole force, to the army of VICTOR EMANUEL, could not have come at a more opportune moment for the welfare of Italy and the peace of the world. Annihilating at one blow the whole military power of the Papal Government, this triumph makes VICTOR EMANUEL the deliverer of Central Italy, puts Sardinia on a footing of moral equality with GABIBALDI in the actual crisis of Italian affairs; and will give all rational patriots in Sicily and Naples breathing-time to choose between the policy which has thus once more ripened to victory under the leadership of the King, and that which the beaten Revolutionists of 1848 are doing their best to fasten upon GARIBALDI, and through him upon Southern Italy.

abstract: The business of fillibustering encounters dreary discouragements in Central America. Scarcely a month has passed since WALKER gallantly met his fate it must be confessed that nothing in his life so well became him as his leaving of it and we now have word of a similar shooting in Costa Rica, where Ex
lead_paragraph: The business of fillibustering encounters dreary discouragements in Central America. Scarcely a month has passed since WALKER gallantly met his fate it must be confessed that nothing in his life so well became him as his leaving of it and we now have word of a similar shooting in Costa Rica, where Ex-President MORA, with two prominent associates in the cause of revolution, have sacrificed their lives. It was but the other day that MORA was autocrat of that thrifty little State, with apparently so secure a tenure of his place as to insure him at least a life-interest. Enterprising, intelligent, liberal, he gave new impulses to the national industry, and new directions to the national capital; encouraged agriculture and other peaceful ways to wealth, and eschewed warfare, save in defence against the menacing WALKER; and by these and similar strokes of policy, rarely practiced in Spanish-American countries, he placed Costa Rica first of all for prosperity and the social results of national opulence.

abstract: -- A large number of letters were found broken open and scattered about the streets in Galveston, Texas, a few mornings since, and rumors of a robbery were immediately in circulation, but an investigation revealed that two little girls were the authors of the mischief. They saw the boxes full and took out as many as they could conveniently carry, to see what was in them. When found one of the girls was admiring a draft for $1,000. The postmaster who has that office in charge deserves an increase of salary.
lead_paragraph: -- A large number of letters were found broken open and scattered about the streets in Galveston, Texas, a few mornings since, and rumors of a robbery were immediately in circulation, but an investigation revealed that two little girls were the authors of the mischief. abstract: A BOLD ROBBERY. Some time during Friday night, Mr. GAREET DAY'S house was entered and $100 in money, a valuable gold watch, and some wearing apparel, were stolen. The clothing and money was taken from Mr. DAY'S room, and in the morning it was found that the thief had feasted on a broiled chicked, after which he attired himself in a suit of Mr. D.'s clothes, leaving his own behind.

abstract: Is it absolutely impossible for us to do anything well? We do not mean passably but perfectly, just as it should be done, without any drawbacks or breakdowns. We pride ourselves greatly on our practical qualities, and yet it is precisely there that our failures occur. Either from some constitutional defect, or from habit, we half do a great many things, and the instances of complete success are the rare exceptions to the general rule.
lead_paragraph: Is it absolutely impossible for us to do anything well? We do not mean passably but perfectly, just as it should be done, without any drawbacks or breakdowns. abstract: The curtain has fallen on the seat of song for a time. Dancers and fiddlers have desecrated this past week the temple of music, and carpenters' hammers have rung where BRIGNOLI stole forth his soft, delicious strains, and PATTI charmed with her brilliant and unerring execution. When we are to hear them again is a mystery. Rumor points to the secession of Mr. STRAKOSCH from the management, and intimates that Messrs. ULLMAN and MARETZEK intend to put up their steeds in the same stable. In the meantime, the Cortesi Opera Troupe made fiasco at Boston, and in a world where all should be harmony, all is discord. Hitherto Mr. ULLMAN has had to seek artists. For the future he says artists must seek him. And until that happy condition of things arises he remains in a state of masterly inactivity. With the ball and the concert the opera owners or lessees have made a very handsome thing. "Carpe horam" is the motto of the day, and the manager took care not to let slide by so golden an opportunity of redecorating and permanently improving the house at the expense of the compliment to the Prince of Wales.
lead_paragraph: The curtain has fallen on the seat of song for a time. abstract: The schooner B.B. Bean, from Richmond for Rio Janeiro, on the 7th September, when in lon. 77, to the north of the Gulf, with the wind from N.E., and blowing a gale, broke her bowsprit, split sails, and sprang aleak, which induced the Captain to bear up for Bermuda, where he arrived on the 13th. She is now in port, and on survey, it is recommended that she discharge her cargo of 2,100 bbls. flour.

abstract: -- We have already hinted at the possibility of Gov. WISE being at the bottom of the recent insurrection in Princess Anne and Norfolk Counties, Va. Some people, we know, are inclined to regard the statements which have been circulated regarding this emeute as gross exaggerations, while others persist in believing that they were started solely to alarm the conservatives in Pennsylvania, and to keep them from voting for CURTIN.

abstract: -- A terrible and fatal accident occurred, Tuesday morning, at the flouring mill of AUTZ & Co., No. 157 Clay-street. The engineer had, at the usual hour, fired up and got up steam ready for operations; after which he went away, leaving directions, however, that no one should touch the engine during his absence. Shortly after he left JOHN SWARTZ, who was employed as a miller, came in and gave orders to some one about the mill to start the engine, as he know how to manage it. This was done, and SWARTZ went up stairs and was engaged about the hopper, when suddenly the under stone burst, the fragments taking a lateral direction, and destroying whatever they touched. The iron hand which was around the stone, struck Mr. SWARTZ in the groin, crushing all his rils, and literally disemboweling him. He died almost instantly. Mr. SWARTZ, a native of Germany, had been in this country but two or three months. He leaves a wife and three children in his native land. He boarded at the corner of Walnut and Allison streets. An investigation into the causes of the explosion showed that in starting the engine the governor had not been attached. The machinery was of course put under a fearful rate of speed, and with a result which would be anticipated by any one philosophically or practically informed. Considerable damage was done to the mill by the flying fragments of stone. -Cincinnati Commercial.

abstract: A great ball, like a great battle, is not to be dismissed with the telegraphic bulletins of the next morning. We have the Duke of Wellington's authority for comparing the one to the other, and for asserting that the illustrious commander, who shrank from the task of attempting to describe the conflict of Waterloo, would have hesitated over a chronicle of the Duchess of Richmond's dance of the night before, at Brussels. To the one case, as in the other, we only adapt the words of the Iron Duke, and say that the fate of each "depends upon the most trifling and unforeseen incidents." Certainly the Prince of Wales' Ball at the Academy on Friday night illustrated this truth, for though the "breakdown" with which it opened instead of a quadrille was "trilling," in so far that nobody suffered any serious detriment either in person or toilette, and must have been "unforeseen" by everybody except the carpenter who built a floor with unbraced beams four feet apart, yet it unquestionably decided the fate of the entertainment, and threw the gloom of a fiasco over the whole evening. Indeed, but for the Duke of Newcastle, it would probably have reduced the ball of Friday to the condition of "Hamlet" without the part of the Prince, and given the eager thousands of the New-York elite such a Barmecide feast as was offered next day by the enterprising ULLMAN to the uninvited myriads of our population. For the Prince of Wales was decidedly disposed to retreat from the scene, no doubt, having been thoroughly inoculated with the notion that we Americans act on Mr. HAWTHORNE's theory, and build in tents, with no eye to anything beyond the immediate hour, and no care for the limbs and lives of our felLow-creatures. The Duke, however, interposed his calmer view of things, and saved the fortunes of the night.

abstract: -- By an article which we copy from the Albany evening Journal, it will be seen that, according to a decision just pronounced in the Court of Appeals, we have no law in this State for punishing murder in the first degree at all! The law of last Winter having abolished the only statute which defined the mode of punishment, no Court or other tribunal has any right to prescribe that mode. This seems to be a very curious and purely technical construction. But it comes from the Court of last resort, and is, of course, final and decisive.
lead_paragraph: -- By an article which we copy from the Albany evening Journal, it will be seen that, according to a decision just pronounced in the Court of Appeals, we have no law in this State for punishing murder in the first degree at all! abstract: THE LATE MURDER CASE A MISTAKE. Coroner SCHIRMER yesterday held an inquest upon the body of as Irishman which was found on Friday morning last beneath Pier No. 39, East River. From the fact that the remains were shockingly mutilated the face be
lead_paragraph: THE LATE MURDER CASE A MISTAKE. Coroner SCHIRMER yesterday held an inquest upon the body of as Irishman which was found on Friday morning last beneath Pier No. 39, East River. From the fact that the remains were shockingly mutilated the face being crushed in and the skull broken -- it was supposed that the man had been murdered, but from the testimony adduced at the inquest, the jury declared that he had been drowned. JOHN O'BRIEN, keeper of the dead-house at Bellevue Hospital, deposed that the body was identified on Saturday last by one of the boatmen of the Island Hospital, as that of ANDREW MEEHAN. Deceased had been an inmate of the Hospital, and about ten days ago he attempted to escape from the Island by swimming the river. He was not again seen alive. Dr. GEORGE B. BOUTON deposed that he had made a post-mortem examination of the body, and that he had found the nasal bones fractured, and the cartilage broken from its attachments and flattened to the right; on the left side of the nose was an incised wound, three-quarters of an inch long, and another extending from the base of the nose to the left supra orbital notch; an incised and lacerated wound extending two inches from a joint to the right of the symphysis of the lower mascilia at its interior border across the throat. These wounds, in the Doctor's opinion, were all inflicted after death. There were also wounds on the neck and temples, and the brains, lungs and viscera were much congested. Dr. BOUTON added that he had no doubt that death had been caused by drowning. A verdict in accordance with this opinion was rendered. It is probable that the body while floating in the river was struck by the flange of a propeller, or the paddles of a steamer, and that the wounds were given in that way.

abstract: Gordon  Crosman and three other casts vs. The Artisans' Bank. E.S. Van Winkle, Esq., now appeared on behalf of the plaintiffs in all the suits now commenced against the Artisans' Bank, and submitted to his Honor Justice LEONARD, sitting at Chambers, consents of all parties to a further ad
lead_paragraph: Gordon Crosman and three other casts vs. The Artisans' Bank. E.S. Van Winkle, Esq., now appeared on behalf of the plaintiffs in all the suits now commenced against the Artisans' Bank, and submitted to his Honor Justice LEONARD, sitting at Chambers, consents of all parties to a further adjournment of the proceedings until Wednesday next. Mr. Van Winkle stated that these consents were based upon the prospect that before that date the Bank would be able to meet the demands of all it creditors, and in that case there would be no necessity for further proceedings at all. No one opposing, the motion was so adjourned. Subsequently, however, a gentleman of the Jewish order appealed, and stated to his Honor that he was a poor man, and had $420 in the Bank, of which he stood in great need. He could do nothing with his account. -could not sell it nor dispose of it in any manner to relieve himself. He had a family to take care of, and must have his money.

abstract: Our obituary column to-day announces the death at Belchertown, Mass., on the 4th inst., of Dr. Horatio Thomson, aged 57. Dr. Thomson was a well known and most valued citizen of the section of the country in which he had lung resided, and was justly celebrated as a medical practitioner of marked ability, for his many exalted virtues as a man, and for the high moral and pure Christian character he always maintained through life. He was a son of the well-known and eminent physician, the late Dr. Furdon Thomson, of Connecticut, and brother of our worthy friend and fellow-citizen. Col. George F. Thomson, for several years editor of the Daily News, and now in the office of the Mayor; of Dr. Chas. 8. Thomson, of New-Haven, Conn., and of Samuel Thomson, formerly of Utica, in this State, and now of San Francisco. Besides these, he has left many warmly attached friends to mourn his sad demise, and none more than in the wide field of his long and successful practice. -- Daily News.

abstract: COMMON COUNCIL. The Board of Aldermen last evening received a communication from the Brooklyn City Railroad Company, asking that the petition for permission to lay rail tracks and run horse-ears through Hicks-street to Fulton Ferry, be referred to a Committee, so that they may protect their rights. The communication was laid on the table. After the transaction of some further business the Board adjourned.

abstract: FATAL STREET ENCOUNTER On Saturday evening JAMES ROBINSON, a young man residing at No.135 Eighth-street, went out with two of his friends to see the great procession of firemen.All of them had been drinking together, and the effect of ROBINSON'S potations was manifested in boisterous behavior. Reaching the corner of Prince-street and Broadway he became involved in a dispute with two strangers, one of whom finally struck him a heavy blow on the head.
lead_paragraph: FATAL STREET ENCOUNTER On Saturday evening JAMES ROBINSON, a young man residing at No.135 Eighth-street, went out with two of his friends to see the great procession of firemen.All of them had been drinking together, and the effect of ROBINSON'S potations was manifested in boisterous behavior. Reaching the corner of Prince-street and Broadway he became involved in a dispute with two strangers, one of whom finally struck him a heavy blow on the head. He fell to the pavement, the blow having rendered him insensible, and his friends as soon as possible had him taken to his residence, where a physician was called to see him. The measures adopted to restore him, however, did not prove successful, and on Sunday evening, at [???] 1/2 o'clock, he died. Coroner SCHIRMER yesterday held an inquest upon the body, and a post-mortem examination by Dr. BOSTON showed that death had resulted from compression of the brain, superinduced by a fracture of the skull. No evidence could be procured by which the identity of the man who had inflicted the injury could be established, and the jury therefore rendered a verdict of death by violence at the hands of some person unknown. Deceased was a native of this City, 23 years of age.

abstract: We publish this morning a curious and instructive article, from the Charleston Mercury, upon the results of Southern submission to Mr. LINCOLN'S election. It sets forth the manner in which a Republican administration of the General Government may be expected to operate injuriously upon Southern interests.
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning a curious and instructive article, from the Charleston Mercury, upon the results of Southern submission to Mr. LINCOLN'S election. It sets forth the manner in which a Republican administration of the General Government may be expected to operate injuriously upon Southern interests. It is important, because it treats of an important subject, and comes from a quarter entitled to respect. The Mercury is a steady, frank and able advocate of secession; -- it is worth while, therefore, to ascertain what such an organ regards as justifiable occasions for such a movement.

abstract: The hour for the departure of the Prince of Wales and his party, was fixed at 9 o'clock A.M. Accordingly, thousands who had been disappointed of a view of the illustrious stranger, availed themselves of the only remaining chance to see him as he left the Fifth-avenue Hotel. Here crowds gathered at an early hour, and remained patiently awaiting his appearance. At 9 3/4 o'clock the Royal party entered their carriages, and amidst the cheering of the assembled multitude drove rapidly to the revenue cutter.

abstract: Our Own Correspondent, writing from Panama on the 6th inst., says: "MORA bore his fate manfully. The file of men drawn up for his execution stood with their muskets not ten feet from him, and yet the five balls in his body did not kill him. 'Give me another shot, gentlemen,' he said, 'and finish me!" He refused to be blindfolded, but stood calmly facing his executioners. His body, as well as that of CANAS, was thrown into a hole in the sand, both with the clothes on in which they were murdered. CANAS was striking fire with his steel and flint to relight his cigarito at the moment he felt the lead at his heart. He was shot at the foot of the monument erected to his honor for his many services to Costa Rica, in the Plaza at Punta Arenas.

abstract: European advices one week later reach us by the Arabia, which passed Cape Race at noon on Sunday. She left Liverpool on the 6th inst., and Queenstown on the 7th. Two dispatches from Naples are published one vid Genoa and the other via Turin stating that GARIBALDI had gained another important success over the Ex-King's troops.
lead_paragraph: European advices one week later reach us by the Arabia, which passed Cape Race at noon on Sunday. She left Liverpool on the 6th inst., and Queenstown on the 7th. Two dispatches from Naples are published one vid Genoa and the other via Turin stating that GARIBALDI had gained another important success over the Ex-King's troops. An attack, it seems, was made upon the position of the Dictator at Caserta, but the King's forces were repulsed and surrounded, and finally lost two thousand men, taken prisoners. No particulars are given, and the news requires confirmation; but its truth is rendered more probable by the fact that it comes in two different directions. A report was also current that GARIBALDI had invited VICTOR EMANUEL to assume authority in Naples, when he would retire to his home. A summary of the Pope's allocution had been published. He condemns, of course, in the strongest terms, the "detestable" and "sacrilegious" attack of the King of Sardinia, and protests fervently against the doctrine of non-intervention, as promulgated by the Emperor of the French and other Catholic sovereigns. VICTOR EMANUEL had issued an address of thanks to his army at Ancona, and had promised to take the command in person. The Spanish Government had demanded a Congress of the Catholic Powers, with a view to guaranteeing the integrity of the States of the Church; but the French Cabinet, while admitting its expediency, declared that the matter of territorial changes could come properly only before a European Congress. There is later news from India, but nothing of importance.

abstract: The pretence that a legislative oversight has left murder without punishment, is sustained by the decision of the Court of Appeals. The Legislature, inexpert in legal niceties, fancied that in repealing a previous statute relative to capital punishment, the common law penalties of the crime resumed full vigor.
lead_paragraph: The pretence that a legislative oversight has left murder without punishment, is sustained by the decision of the Court of Appeals. The Legislature, inexpert in legal niceties, fancied that in repealing a previous statute relative to capital punishment, the common law penalties of the crime resumed full vigor. The Court decides otherwise. It finds the power of the criminal tribunal to end with the sentence of death. The time for inflicting the sentence, after a certain probationary period, and the mode of execution, are left to the Executive; and the Bench declares this uncertainty to be fatal to justice, seeing that the convict has none of that assurance of punishment which is the essence and force of penal inflictions. And we learn from various sources that judges decline to try offenders, because of the novel and startling provisions and omissions of the law.

abstract: A summary of the Pope's allocation at the Consistory of the 28th, is published. He reproves, and condemned in the strongest terms, the detestable and sacrilegious attack of the King and Government of Piedmont. He protested, and would not cease to protest, against their acts, which he declared null and of no effect. He eulogised and blessed his defenders,
lead_paragraph: A summary of the Pope's allocation at the Consistory of the 28th, is published. He reproves, and condemned in the strongest terms, the detestable and sacrilegious attack of the King and Government of Piedmont. He protested, and would not cease to protest, against their acts, which he declared null and of no effect. He eulogised and blessed his defenders, and called the European Powers for assistance. He deplored the disastrous and pernicious policy of non-intervention, and called on the Powers to examine seriously into its dangerous effects; and concluded by expressing his conviction that the Catholic Princes and people would yet come to the assistance of the Father of the Faithful, who is attacked by the parricidal arms of a degenerate son.

abstract: With the desire to satisfy the insatiable demand, for the issues, of the NEW-YORK TIMES, containing the record from day to day of the Prince of Wales in New-York, the entire account has been reproduced from our daily impressions in the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES of this morning. It embraces the visit of the Royal guest to our various Institutions and Public Places the Grand Ball at the Academy of Music; his calls at BRADY's, BARNUM's and BALL, BLACK & COMPANY's; the superb display of our Firemen, in Torchlight Procession; the Religious Services at Trinity Church on Sunday; the Departure of the Prince from New-York, and his Reception at West Point.
lead_paragraph: With the desire to satisfy the insatiable demand, for the issues, of the NEW-YORK TIMES, containing the record from day to day of the Prince of Wales in New-York, the entire account has been reproduced from our daily impressions in the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES of this morning. abstract: The citizens of New-York are threatened with a peril of the most serious character in the forthcoming local elections; they are threatened with no less an evil than the corruption of Justice, at its fountain head, by the elevation to the Bench of men whose antecedents condemn them as utterly unfit for any office of Judicial or other trust. We speak under a solemn sense of responsibility and from positive knowledge, demanding that each good citizen shall investigate and decide upon this matter for himself. Let him, in the absence of personal knowledge, go to any lawyer in whom he may place confidence, and ask for an opinion as to the moral or professional fitness of certain candidates now placed before the people for posts of Judicial preferment.

abstract: We are gratified to learn, as we do from our Washington Correspondent, that President BUCHANAN has no apprehensions that the Union will be dissolved in consequence of Mr. LINCOLN's election. He appreciates, with a great deal of justice and accuracy, the true character of the menaces that are uttered at the South, and has no hesitation in saying that, "though there may be a little noise and agitation, nothing will come of it."

abstract: As late as a fortnight ago GARIBALDI was still the hero of the Parisians; the famous "Rodolphe" of the Mysteries of Paris was never a greater. The daily doings of the hero of EUGENE SUN were not looked for with more anxiety by the public than were those of the hero of Varesa. But  to-day all this is changed. He that was a hero yesterday is to-day but a headstrong and senseless adventurer.
lead_paragraph: From Our Own Correspondent.

abstract: The Board met yesterday afternoon, being their regular day of meeting, and at once suspended the rules in order to complete the list of Inspectors of Registry, to fill vacancies occasioned by resignations, &c. This being completed, the Board then took up the regular business, which amounted only to referring some few bills. The Board then designated by ballot the papers in which the places for holding the polls in the various Wards should be published, and the NEW-YORK TIMES having been selected as one of the official organs, any further allusion to that portion of the proceedings is unnecessary. The Board will meet again at 3 P.M. on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The Board met yesterday afternoon, being their regular day of meeting, and at once suspended the rules in order to complete the list of Inspectors of Registry, to fill vacancies occasioned by resignations, &c. The Board will meet again at 3 P.M. on Thursday.

abstract: ST. THOMAS, Oct. 1 -- The bark Ellen Morrison, Platt, sailed for Caracas on the 29th ult. Her disbursement for repairs amounted to $1,400. The steamer from Porto Rico arrived on the evening of the 29th ult., and brought the information that the Spanish steamer Pajarro del Oceana, was run aground by the pilot in the harbor of the City of St. John's, and that it was doubtful whether they would be able to get her off.
lead_paragraph: ST. THOMAS, Oct. 1 -- The bark Ellen Morrison, Platt, sailed for Caracas on the 29th ult. Her disbursement for repairs amounted to $1,400. abstract: -- We understand that Commodore VANDERBILT is about to build two fast passenger steamers for his transatlantic line. They are to be constructed of wood and braced in the most subtantial manner. Their length is to be 400 feet, beam 55 feet and depth only 17 to 18 feet. There will be no solid bulwarks of the ordinary kind, but the decks will be as thick and solid as the bottom of the ship, and the deck-houses -- instead of being light panel work -- will be constructed like the sides of a ship, with bull's eye lights. These structures will also be sharp, like a ship's bow, to divide the water. The deck and the structures upon it will thus form the upper web of a girder, and will give the vessel great stiffness. The ships will have two beam engines like the Vanderbilt's, with 100-inch cylinders by 16 feet stroke. The paddle-wheels will be 60 feet in diameter by 12 feet bucket. This construction of engine is in accordance with the best practice on the North River, as well as the successful experience of Commodore VANDERBILT's ocean ships. We wish the Commodore would inaugurate a more trustworthy method of constructing iron ships, and then use the best material; both he and the public would be better satisfied in the long run.

We wish the Commodore would inaugurate a more trustworthy method of constructing iron ships, and then use the best material; both he and the public would be better satisfied in the long run.

abstract: Our City Democracy are much exercised in reference to the approaching elections, all efforts yet made to harmonize conflicting interests having proved of no avail. The disorganization of the Democratic Party, which commenced at Charleston in the National Convention, would appear to have spread on all sides with the contagion of a malignant fever. The leaders having quarreled on the Presidency, all discipline has come to an end; and to-day there is every appearance that the Republicans may be enabled to carry four out of the Six Congressional Districts contained in this City. We purpose to give a brief sketch of all the candidates for County, Judicial and Congressional offices, so that our readers may become familiar with the names which will be presented to them on the various tickets next month.

abstract: The annual inspection of the Seventh Regiment will take place at Hamilton-square next Thursday. The men will proceed thither by Companies, and the line will be formed at 10 A.M. At about 4 P.M. the regiment will be at Twenty-seventh-street, conveyed thither by cars, and will proceed to and through Fifth-avenue, Fourteenth-street, Broadway, Canal- street, (perhaps) and up the Bowery to the new drill rooms over Tompkins market, where the men will be dismissed. A great many people who expected to see the fine display which this regiment made on the day of the reception of the Prince of Wales, and were disappointed on account of the delays of that occasion, have since applied at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel where Quartermaster WINCHESTER resides, asking when the Corps would parade again. The encomiums passed upon it by the Prince and Gen. BRUCE have whetted the public appetite for another taste of the quality of the celebrated National Guard, and its line of march next Thursday, when it is probable that there will be 1,000 men in the ranks, will assuredly be fenced in with spectators.

abstract: -- It is vastly amusing to note with what zest our provincial neighbors in Philadelphia and Boston chuckle over what they style the failure of our reception of the Prince. The lofty tone of patronizing condescension with which they chronicle our mishaps, and censure our "ill-breeding," is positively laughable. We certainly do not envy them the enjoyment they derive from this innocent style of criticism. We feel very much like the burly husband who permitted his small and ill-tempered spouse to beat him, because it didn't hurt him, while it did relieve and gratify her.
lead_paragraph: -- It is vastly amusing to note with what zest our provincial neighbors in Philadelphia and Boston chuckle over what they style the failure of our reception of the Prince. abstract: The Prince of Wales has no small reason to rejoice in the opportunity which his visit to New-York afforded him of seeing with his own eyes how easily the principles of order and the instincts of civilization can display themselves, even under the pressure of a great popular excitement, in a country blessed with free institutions. And the people of New-York have grounds as good for remembering proudly the grand ovations which their own good sense and innate decorum clothed with dignity and grace. In this third City of Christendom, the heir of a foreign, and not always friendly empire, unprotected by dynastic bayonets, hedged with no divinity in the popular mind, and with no brother-King to welcome him to a court well-trained in courtly ways, has fairly walked upon the waves of the popular curiosity and the popular interest. Citizen-soldiers left their homes and their business to honor him; myriads of hard-working men and women sacrificed a day's bread, doubtless, to the pleasant hope of seeing him; the noblest body of volunteer firemen in the world gave him their time, their strength, their money, to celebrate the general festival. And all this was done without the command of any central authority, quietly, cordially, successfully, as by one impulse of a thousand different but harmonious wills. It is in no mere outburst of national boasting that we assert the impossibility, utter and absolute, of any similar demonstration in any capital of Europe. We do not believe the lesson will be lost upon the future EDWARD of England; and it would be hardly courteous for us to insist too broadly or too long upon its moral.

abstract: A COLORED GENTLEMAN APPOINTED TO THE GOVERNMENT OF A BRITISH COLONY. -- The British Government appear to be determined to carry into practice the principles of equality set forth in the famous act of emancipation. It is only very lately, however, that English, society in the West Indies has consented to abandon its prejudices against color, and to recognize the Mulatto or the Black as a social as well as political equal. Even yet, in the older Colonies like Barbados, there is a broad line of demarcation between the pure Saxon and the West Indian, who is ever so lightly touched with the mark of African descent, and it would seem to be the policy and desire of the Home authorities to remove altogether a feeling so prejudicial to West Indian interests. Thus, lately, the Mayor of Kingston, Jamaica, was made a Companion of the Bath, and more recently. Mr. SAMUEL COCKBURN, another gentleman of color, and a Creole, of the Island of Granada, has been appointed Administrator of the Government of Montserrat. No loyal subject of the Queen can refuse to recognize as a social equal any one whom she, as the fountain of honor, chooses to appoint to high places in her realm.
lead_paragraph: A COLORED GENTLEMAN APPOINTED TO THE GOVERNMENT OF A BRITISH COLONY. -- The British Government appear to be determined to carry into practice the principles of equality set forth in the famous act of emancipation. abstract: The Republican mass meeting here to-day has been one of the largest demonstrations that has taken place in Central New-York during the canvass. The Wide-Awake procession was large and enthusiastic, and the meeting was one of unusual interest. Nearly ten thousand people were in attendance. Many were disappointed owing to the absence of Gov. SEWARD, but his letter stating the cause gave general satisfaction.

abstract: Senator DOUGLAS arrived here at noon, on a special train, from Detroit. He was met at the depot by an immense crowd, and escorted through the principal streets, followed by a procession two miles in length. An arch was thrown across the street, bearing "Welcome to DOUGLAS," on one side, and "Popular Sovereignty" on the other. 25,000 people are estimated to have been present. There will be a torchlight procession this evening.

abstract: ANNUAL MEETING OF THE ASSOCIATION FOR IMPROVING THE CONDITION OF THE POOR. -- The seventeenth annual meeting of this Society was held on Monday evening, at No. 345 Fulton-street, GEORGE HALL, Esq., in the Chair. The General Superintendent submitted his annual report, from which we gather the following interesting particulars: There was during the year in the voluntary employ of the Society 188 visitors who have made all the collections for the Society, and in addition, many of these visitors have devoted some portion of their time to visiting the sick, the infirm and the poor. The services of seven local or Ward agents were secured during the severity of mid-Winter. Their special duty was to obtain all necessary information in relation to applicants for aid and to furnish the necessary assistance. The receipts and disbursements for the year were as follows:

abstract: The opening match of this newly-organized and important club took place yesterday at Bedford. There was a large muster of the members, who number among them many of the leading base ball players, and a pleasant day's play was much enjoyed by all present. The Club play their Maiden cricket match on Thursday, with the Satellite Club, of Williamsburgh.

abstract: The Sixth Regiment, N.Y.S.M., Col. PINCKNEY commanding, was inspected at Madison-square yesterday. The ranks were not full; there were only 340 men on parade altogether. The Armory Band, of Hartford, accompanied the regiment. Gen. YATES and Staff, of the Second Brigade, reviewed it. Its drill was witnessed and applauded by any quantity of spectators, and it deserved to be. After the inspection, the regiment marched down Broadway and Broome-street to its Armory in Centre Market, where the men were dismissed.

abstract: A very large meeting of delegates and representatives of the various Democratic associations of this and neighboring cities, assembled last evening at their head-quarters, No. 514 Broadway, for the purpose of arranging for the procession on the evening of the 23d inst. A very large number of clubs were represented, and as many claimants appeared and asked for special positions in the line of the procession, a resolution offered by Mr. CHARLES BURDETT, that the entire arrangement and assignment be left to the discretion of the Grand Marshal, was adopted, with directions that each club should report to him on Thursday, with the distinct understanding that every order issued by him should be implicitly obeyed.

abstract: -- Deputy U.S. Marshal MANSON, and seven aids, captured, four fugitive slaves, and two free children from the neighborhood of Sandusky, and returned them by aid of a U.S. Commissioner in this city on Saturday last, to Mason County, Ky., from where the slaves had escaped. The particulars of this exploit are so enveloped in a cloud of glorification and mist, that the facts are not easily obtained. Huge stories are current about these mighty Nimrods being pursued up hill and down dale, through woods and cornfields, over fences and across running waters, by several hundred armed men, who shot at them from every bush and fence corner, yet hit none of the valiant hunters. These were the stories told through the city yesterday, but we fear that the true history of this affair will never reach posterity. -Cincinnati Gazette.
lead_paragraph: -- Deputy U.S. Marshal MANSON, and seven aids, captured, four fugitive slaves, and two free children from the neighborhood of Sandusky, and returned them by aid of a U.S. Commissioner in this city on Saturday last, to Mason County, Ky., from where the slaves had escaped. abstract: The documents which appear at the head of this exposition will inform the public of one of those acts the mere revelation of which is a terrible punishment to men who profess the sacred religion of honor. When from the eminence of that moral scaffold which public opinion will prepare to implacably immolate a name, the eye is turned to the past and there is perceived a life obscure, but without reproach, a consecration to a holy cause without reservation of family, of tranquillity, of pecuniary interests, of personal pride, or of anything that man holds the most dear; and in one instant, by a single chance of fate, it is found with the loss of all, enrolled among criminals, then this punishment becomes more than that of the martyr, for to the martyr remains the generous award of glory.
lead_paragraph: The documents which appear at the head of this exposition will inform the public of one of those acts the mere revelation of which is a terrible punishment to men who profess the sacred religion of honor. abstract: The Registrars met in the various Election Districts, yesterday, to correct the poll list and to register such new names as might be offered. As usual, it was found impossible to make out a perfect list of the voters in the Districts, owing to the ignorance on the part of the Registrars, as to who had changed their residences since the last election. Such as were known to have removed from the district were stricken off, and such new names as presented themselves and proved their qualifications were added. A large proportion of the new names were registered in the evening. The Registrars meet again to-day in those districts containing over 400 voters.
lead_paragraph: The Registrars met in the various Election Districts, yesterday, to correct the poll list and to register such new names as might be offered. abstract: The Journal of Commerce insists, with steadfast earnestness, that the Republican Party is pledged to interfere with the rights and interests of the Slaveholding States. It quotes the oft-repeated and grossly-distorted declarations of Senator SEWARD and Mr. LINCOLN, asserting the fact of a radical hostility between Freedom and Slavery, but lays...
lead_paragraph: The Journal of Commerce insists, with steadfast earnestness, that the Republican Party is pledged to interfere with the rights and interests of the Slaveholding States. It quotes the oft-repeated and grossly-distorted declarations of Senator SEWARD and Mr. LINCOLN, asserting the fact of a radical hostility between Freedom and Slavery, but lays special stress upon a declaration imputed to Senator WILSON, that he trusted the Republican Party would retain and exercise the powers of the Government "till no man on the continent should hold property in another man." The Journal treats this as conclusive of the radical and revolutionary designs of the Republican Party.

abstract: Recorder BARNARD hold Court yesterday. Samuel M. Cracken, a boy, was tried for shooting at and wounding another boy named John Judge with a pistol on the afternoon of July 4. abstract: We shall never see the greatest of magicians, ROBERT HOUDIN, who has taken to common life, the Legion of Honor, and engineering; but perhaps we may console ourselves with the certainty that we already have among us the most brilliant and captivating wonder-work of this illustrious wizard in the person of Mlle. VICTORIA, a young Parisian lady who made her debut at the Bouffes Parisiens Oct. 10, 1855, and March 22, 1858, entered the charmed circle of royalty at the house of the Princess MATHILDE, where she astonished the impressible Empress, and won the applause of the less impressible Emperor of the French.

abstract: The cattle have arrived quite scattering this week, the several lots, instead of being all on hand, were dropping in, one after another, during the whole of yesterday, which caused an unsettled market. Buyers wish to see most of the cattle in the yards, or know about what are to come, before they make extensive purchases. However, a fair business was done yesterday, but generally at lower prices than the previous Tuesday. The cattle were of fair quality, taken as a whole, but included all grades -- first-class, heavy steers, and light, thin cattle, of third and fourth rate. There was a comparative scarcity of fair, smooth steers, of 6 1/2 cwt. to 7 cwt. Prices yesterday ranged from 9c.@9 1/2c. for first quality; 8c. for medium, and 7c.@6c. for poor. In numbers there were about 4,000 head yarded yesterday, and a few additions were expected during the evening, so that there will probably be quite sufficient for the requirements of to-day, which is the chief market day of the week.

abstract: The new Brick Church in Fifth-avenue was nearly filled on Monday evening by the parishioners and friends of Rev. Dr. SPRING, who assembled to witness the presentation of a service of silver by the congregation to their pastor, on the fiftieth anniversary of his pastorate over that church. Dr. SPRING completed the fiftieth anniversary of his ministry over the Brick...
lead_paragraph: The new Brick Church in Fifth-avenue was nearly filled on Monday evening by the parishioners and friends of Rev. Dr. SPRING, who assembled to witness the presentation of a service of silver by the congregation to their pastor, on the fiftieth anniversary of his pastorate over that church. Dr. SPRING completed the fiftieth anniversary of his ministry over the Brick Church on the 6th of August last, at which time the testimonial was to have been presented, but owing to the severe illness of the Rev. Doctor's wife, which subsequently terminated in her death, the presentation was postponed until last evening.

abstract: The Eighth Regiment, (Washington Greys,) Col. LYONS commanding, was inspected at Hamilton-square, yesterday. The weather was fine, the spectators were numerous, and the parade was a highly creditable one. The Regiment has earned a reputation for excellent discipline, and its drill yesterday evinced that it is worthy of the name it bears. The Regimental line was formed at 10 1/2 A.M., and during the morning the corps was exercised in the evolutions prescribed for 1860 by the Adjutant-General. In the afternoon the inspection took place. Of the 508 men that compose the command, there were 411 present, and 97 absent. The numbers were smaller than is usual on inspection day. Doubtless the parade in honor of the Prince of Wales interfered with yesterday's arrangements. The regiment consists mostly of business men, who find it more convenient and less expensive in the long run to pay their fine of $6 for non-attendance on inspection day than to devote two whole days within a single week to military affairs. Gen. HALL and Staff, of the Third Brigade, to which the Eighth Regiment is attached, were inspected with it, and reviewed it during the day. The Washington Grey troops, Capt. VARIAN, was out in full force, and appeared to great advantage, as it always does. The troop was part of the cavalry escort of the Prince of Wales on the day of his reception here.

The first, between Mr. JOSEPH HENRY CLAY MUDD, a violent partisan of Mr. DOUGLAS, and Mr. JOSEPH ROBINSON, of North...
lead_paragraph: The Washington Star tells of four personal encounters which took place in that City on Wednesday evening, in consequence of the excitement growing out of the recent elections. The first, between Mr. JOSEPH HENRY CLAY MUDD, a violent partisan of Mr. DOUGLAS, and Mr. JOSEPH ROBINSON, of North Carolina, now of the Navy Department, and Chairman of the North Carolina Breckinridge Club, began in words and ended with MUDD striking ROBINSON a blow with his fist. A charge of assault and battery was preferred by the latter, Mr. WM.H. COOK, of Mississippi, and Alderman WM. WARD became very much excited over this quarrel, and the former misinterpreting a remark made by the latter, belabored him violently with his cane.

abstract: The Capital Punishment Act of last Winter, having been presented by the Grand Jury yesterday, Judge GOULD, sitting in Oyer and Terminer, seized the occasion to comment at once on the law in question, and upon the Press. To the latter he referred as "claiming to know more about law than the Beneh itself," evidently resenting in this extremely bitter and unsparing way the remarks of the City journals generally upon the course adopted by the Judiciary in regard to the act. How preposterous any such claim on behalf of the Press would be, were the Bench filled with Mansfields and Hardwicks, Marshalls and Kents, it is needless to confess. But it must be owned that some at least of the absurdity vanishes, in days when the elective principle fills the seats of justice with politicians of questionable learning, and when the small emoluments and short tenure of the Bench tend so powerfully to repel the better order of legal talent.

abstract: The Arabia arrived at Halifax yesterday, and a brief dispatch, additional to that forwarded from Cape Race, is given this morning. The statement that BERTANI, late Secretary-General of GARIBALDI, had given orders to oppose by force the entry of the Piedmontese troops into the Neapolitan territory, is denied by BERTANI over his own signature. He also asserts that neither himself nor...
lead_paragraph: The Arabia arrived at Halifax yesterday, and a brief dispatch, additional to that forwarded from Cape Race, is given this morning. The statement that BERTANI, late Secretary-General of GARIBALDI, had given orders to oppose by force the entry of the Piedmontese troops into the Neapolitan territory, is denied by BERTANI over his own signature. He also asserts that neither himself nor GARIBALDI ever had an idea of counseling the immediate occupation of Rome, at the risk of a rupture with France. Further intelligence confirmatory of the report of GARIBALDI's success against the Royal troops at Caserta is received. The Dictator is said to have sent a telegram to Genoa announcing victory along the whole line of operations. The Sardinian army had not yet entered Neapolitan territory, but it was expected soon to do so, with VICTOR EMANUEL himself at the head. A better feeling is reported as existing between GARIBALDI and VICTOR EMANUEL, since the dismissal of BERTANI by the former. The Sardinian Chambers had passed a decree authorizing the King to annex those provinces of Central and Southern Italy which expressed a desire by ballot to become a portion of the Sardinian Constitutional Monarchy.

Kinsman, on the Bahama Keys, and the loss of her cargo, was resumed yesterday, by Justice CONNOLLY, the defendants, HENRY D'ORGUEREE, J.C. PEDRAJAS, OZZA F. DOWWES and DAVID S, MILLS, being present. It is alleged that the vessel was chartered, filled with goods compara-...
lead_paragraph: The hearing in the case of the parties charged with conspiring to defraud several the Marine Insurance Companies of this City, in connection with the wreek of the bark E.A. Kinsman, on the Bahama Keys, and the loss of her cargo, was resumed yesterday, by Justice CONNOLLY, the defendants, HENRY D'ORGUEREE, J.C. PEDRAJAS, OZZA F. DOWWES and DAVID S, MILLS, being present. It is alleged that the vessel was chartered, filled with goods comparatively of little value, upon which policies of insurance to the amount of $60,000 were obtained through the agency of false bills of lading, and that she was dispatched from port with the understanding that she was to be sunk for the purpose of claiming the insurance money. The testimony taken yesterday was mainly corroborative of that which has already been made public. Two additional affidavits, however, were submitted with reference to the sinking of the bark. They are as follows:

Its review and parade will, doubtless, be well worth seeing.

abstract: "In recapitulating these returns, we feel convinced, and we have no doubt so do our readers, that all hope for a speedy arousal of the boasted conservatism of the North is well-nigh vanished. If there be any of it left it is powerless to stop the rushing tide of aggressive fanaticism. With all the perils of disunion staring them in the face; with the almost certain ruin of commerce, and prostration of business, the voters of the Free States have deliberately defied the consequences, and are determined to wage a war upon the South to the bitter end.

abstract: For some time past Messrs. Smith & McDougall, stereotypers, at No. 64 Beekman-street, have missed large quantities of the metal used in casting stereotype plates, and recently they suspected that Robt. Stringer, a lad in their employ, had stolen it. Officer Golden, of the Sixth Precinct, was engaged to investigate the matter, and he yesterday found the lad at the junk-store of John Norton, No. 114 Walker-street, where he had disposed of 1,500 pounds of the metal, at four cents per pound, when its real value is nine cents. Both Stringer and Norton were arrested, and taken before Justice BRENNAN, by whom the former was held for examination on a charge of larceny, and the latter for receiving stolen goods. In addition to the metal which was recovered, Messrs. Smith and McDougall state that 1,000 pounds more have been stolen from them.

abstract: A letter from Springfield (Ill.) to the Chicago Press and Tribune tells how Mr. LINCOLN's friends received the news of the victories in Ohio, Pennsylvania and Indiana. The Wide-Awakes were out early in the evening, and went to Mr. LINCOLN's house. Arriving there they gave three cheers for Mr. LINCOLN, three for Senator TRUMBULL, who chanced to be his guest, and three each for Pennsylvania. Ohio and Indiana. In response to repeated calls Mr. TRUMBULL made a brief speech, predicting that Illinois would follow up the victory in Indiana with a majority of at least 20,000 for Mr. LINCOLN, and then the Wide-Awakes repaired to the wigwam, where addresses were maee by Judge LOGAN and others. During the proceedings an excellent photograph of the cabin in Kentucky in which Mr. LINCOLN was born was presented to the Springfield Wide-Awakes on behalf of Mr. VAN METER, of Kentucky. The enthusiasm could not be repressed until a late hour of the night.

abstract: QUARTERLY MEETING OF THE EXEMPT FIREMAN's ASSOCIATION. -- The quarterly meeting of the Exempt Firemen's Association was held last evening at Firemen's Hall, Mercer-street -- PHILIP W. ENGS occupied the Chair. The President announced that since the last meeting three members had deceased, viz.: ISAAC TICE, Aug. 24, leaving a widow and five children. Unfortunately he was suspended for non-payment of dues on the 18th of October, 1859, and the family, therefore, were not entitled, under the rules, to relief. JOHN NIEL, an old and valued member, died on the 31st of August, aged 68 years, leaving a widow and three children. They were grown up. His widow had been paid her annual allowance of $30 yesterday. CONKLIN TITUS deceased recently, leaving a widow and one child out of 23 of whom he was the parent. All the rest had died. His widow had received the annual allowance. JONAS L. PHILLIPS moved that the sum of $30 be paid to the widow of Mr. TICE. The case was a hard one. Mr. TICE paid his dues until prevented by poverty. The President favored the motion. H.H. HOWARD proposed that the payment, if made, be by subscription of the members, to avoid a departure from the by-laws. The mot on was withdrawn. After some miscellaneous business the meeting adjourned to the third Tuesday in January.
