abstract: -- Mary Conner, an abandoned woman living in Indianapolis, was recently deserted by her paramour, Barger, who married another woman. So enraged was she at his leaving her that she purchased a pound of sulphuric acid at a drug store, and having poured it into a bowl, went Barger's store and threw it into his face. In the confusion which ensued she made her escape. The upper part of Barger's body was made almost entirely raw by the action of the acid, and one of his eyes was destroyed.
lead_paragraph: -- Mary Conner, an abandoned woman living in Indianapolis, was recently deserted by her paramour, Barger, who married another woman. So enraged was she at his leaving her that she purchased a pound of sulphuric acid at a drug store, and having poured it into a bowl, went Barger's store and threw it into his face. In the confusion which ensued she made her escape. The upper part of Barger's body was made almost entirely raw by the action of the acid, and one of his eyes was destroyed.

abstract: Leaving out of view for the present the constitutional problems involved in the question of Disunion, we propose briefly to point out some practical objections to the scheme as a remedy for Southern grievances, real or imaginary. And in the first place there is great reason to doubt whether the sufferings of the North would be so intolerable, inconsequence of the secession of five or six Southern States, as Mr. YANCEY and his disunion friends seem to imagine. By withdrawing from the Union, the politicians of these extreme Southern States seem to suppose that a fatal blow will be struck at the revenue and commerce of the country, and that the commercial and manufacturing cities of the North will at once fall into ruin. But must these terrible consequences necessarily follow from the secession of the cotton States? There is reason for doubt, to say the least.

abstract: -The affairs of the Artisans Bank are being satisfactorily arranged under the management of the new Vice-President, Mr. CHARLES L. FROST, and there is now every prospect of a speedy liquidation of all its debts. The statement made at the creditors' meeting was well received, and a resolution was passed by a large majority to grant the Bank all the indulgence required. We understand the Board have voted to pay 20 per cent. to the depositor and general creditors on the 1st proximo. In view of the liquidations of the Bank, Mr. TOOKER, the Cashier, has resigned, and the future management will devolve upon the President and Vice-President.

abstract: As it is to be presumed that the Prince of Wales and his party came to America to acquire information concerning its people and Government, there will be some desire felt to learn the impression that their visit has left upon their minds. The Queen and people of Great Britain must be highly gratified at the way in which their Prince has been received in the United States, for the enthusiasm and cordiality of the popular greeting have exceeded all the expectations of Americans themselves. It is difficult to believe that any important section of the English people would fail to appreciate the compliment, though we may expect that vulgar parasites of Royalty, who write for Court journals and Morning Posts, will be thrown into despair when they hear that the descendant of a hundred Kings has been an object of such close curiosity to Democratic crowds. This, however, is not the view taken by the Prince or his Minister, of American crowds. They came to this country to move in Democratic crowds; they were as curious to see us as we were curious to see them; both parties were mutually accommodating, and both have separated with the heartiest feelings of friendship and good will.

abstract: To-day we are to hang a man, but probably not one in a hundred of our citizens know it. There has not a reporter been to see him since he was sentenced. Nobody has asked whether he has made a confession. Having requested that none but the priest and the Sisters of Mercy be permitted to visit him, his request has been complied with. We don't work up our sensations, you perceive, artistically.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK JUVENILE ASYLUM. With the general workings of this institution, which ranks among the most beneficent of our benevolent organizations, the public are well acquainted; but a pamphlet which the Managers have just published, embodying extracts from a report of the indenturing Agent, Mr. GEO. H. ALLEN, gives a deeper insight into the thorough manner in which the objects aimed at are accomplished. In July last Mr. ALLEN took a com-...
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK JUVENILE ASYLUM. With the general workings of this institution, which ranks among the most beneficent of our benevolent organizations, the public are well acquainted; but a pamphlet which the Managers have just published, embodying extracts from a report of the indenturing Agent, Mr. GEO. H. ALLEN, gives a deeper insight into the thorough manner in which the objects aimed at are accomplished. In July last Mr. ALLEN took a company of twenty-six boys to homes in the West. Having seen them safely disposed of, he proceeded to an examination of the settlements previously made, visiting the children individually and conversing with them apart from their guardians, in order to ascertain whether they had any cause for complaint in their new quarters, and talking with the guardians apart from their wards, that he might learn what progress the latter were making. Then, too, as far as possible, neighbors were questioned carefully, and every method was taken to remedy the faults which were frequently found to exist on both sides. The pamphlet alluded to gives the results of the third tour of this kind which Mr. ALLEN has made, and, apart from the interest which attaches to each brief record, those who have wisely contributed to this charity may have the satisfaction of knowing that their money has been worthily and prudently expended. It is difficult to see how greater pains could be taken to secure the welfare of the outcasts who have fortunately fallen into the hands of the managers of the New-York Juvenile Asylum.

abstract: We are glad to see that the gallant conduct of Capt. WILSON, of the Minnie Schiffer, has been publicly recognized and rewarded, and that his officers and crew will be likewise rewarded for services rendered to the passengers of the ill-fated steamer Connaught. The courage and ability displayed by Capt. LEITCH, of the Connaught, have been also recognized, but we trust that the recognition will extend beyond a mere resolution of gratitude. To him, under Providence, five hundred shipwrecked passengers owe their lives, and some substantial appreciation of their indebtedness would come gracefully from them, and would be highly valued by the recipient. In the recorded losses of passenger vessels so many valuable lives have been sacrificed through the inefficiency of commanders, that we hail an exception with unusual satisfaction. Capt. LEITCH was, is all probability, a great sufferer by the wreck of the Connaught; but he proved himself to be so thoroughly master of the trying position in which he found himself placed, and so fully competent to command himself and the men under his charge, that he will not long remain in want of a ship. Men of this stamp should be held up as an example for their compeers.

abstract: Preparations are now nearly complete to dispatch from this City and neighboring recruiting offices, the largest number of recruits ever collected at one time within the limits of the Metropolitan District. They are to be divided into the following detachments: 400 men for the Department of California, for the 1st Dragoons and 2d Infantry. 811 men for the Department of Texas, for the 2d Cavalry, 1st Artillery, 1st Infantry, and 3d Infantry. Of these, 950 go by steamer from New-York, and 120 from Carlisle Barracks to Fort Leavenworth, and there take charge of 225 horses for the 1st and 2d Regiments of Cavalry. The recruits for the 1st Infantry go from Newport Barracks to Fort Smith by water, and will march thence to their destition. Thus, in a few weeks, have nearly 1,200 men, more than the field strength of an entire regiment, been accumulated in this district alone.

abstract: By the New-York at this port, and the Arabia'S  mails, we receive details of European news to the 6th inst. A brief synopsis of their purport has been telegraphed from Halifax. Some fresh particulars are obtained of the fall of Ancona. Gen. LAMORICIERE, it seems, has been taken to Turin.
lead_paragraph: By the New-York at this port, and the Arabia'S mails, we receive details of European news to the 6th inst. A brief synopsis of their purport has been telegraphed from Halifax. Some fresh particulars are obtained of the fall of Ancona. Gen. LAMORICIERE, it seems, has been taken to Turin. There is little doubt that France is determined to protect the Pope in Rome, for the French garrison, of the Eternal City has been increased to 25,000 men. It is said that, in case of need, Marshal VAILLANT, the defender of Rome in 1849, will assume the command in chief of the Army of Occupation. The King of Sardinia is about to visit Naples to restore tranquillity and order. In the Sardinian Chambers the project of a law "to annex to Sardinia those Provinces of Central and Southern Italy in which the people freely manifest a wish to form an integral part of its Constitutional Monarchy," was received with great enthusiasm. We continue to furnish details of the progress of the Italian Revolution. No particulars are yet received of GARIBALDI's latest victory at Caserta.

abstract: On Friday morning last, Mrs. JANE AUGUSTA BLAKEMAN, who in years gone by, was a notorious courtesan, known as Fanny White, was found dead in bed at her residence, No.49 West Thirty-fourth-street. On the day previous, apparently in good health, she had been seen in the company of Mr. EDMON BLANKMAN, a lawyer of this City, to whom she is said to...
lead_paragraph: On Friday morning last, Mrs. JANE AUGUSTA BLAKEMAN, who in years gone by, was a notorious courtesan, known as Fanny White, was found dead in bed at her residence, No.49 West Thirty-fourth-street. On the day previous, apparently in good health, she had been seen in the company of Mr. EDMON BLANKMAN, a lawyer of this City, to whom she is said to have been married about two years ago, and together they had witnessed the procession in honor of the Prince of Wales, from a window of Bixby's Hotel, at the corner of Broadway and Tenth-street. The suddenness of her demise therefore occasioned a suspicion on the part of her relatives that she had been poisoned, and the suspicion was not confined to the immediate circle of her acquaintances, but was expressed by many who had been intimate with her when, as proprietress of an elegant house of prostitution in Mercer-street, she attracted to her saloons some who have since become famous in politics and at the bar. That the matter might be satisfactorily determined, Dr. FINNELL, a surgeon of large experience in the conduct of postmortem cases, and Dr. SANDS, Demonstrator of Anatomy at the Twenty-third-street Medical College, were engaged by the brother of deceased to make an autopsy. This was accomplished on Sunday morning last, but it was by no means of a thorough character. Dr. FINNELL confined his investigation to the head, making a particular examination of the brain, while Dr. SANDS pursued his search no further than the thorax, leaving the stomach, intestines, lungs and other organs undisturbed. The medical gentlemen having concluded their operatives, made out a certificate, which, however, was only signed by Dr. SANDS, that Mrs. BLANKMAN had died of apoplexy; and in the afternoon of the same day the remains were interred at Greenwood Cemetery. The fact that a post-mortem examination had been made did not, however, publicly transpire until yesterday, and within a few days the rumor that the woman's death was the result of other than a natural cause, became so general that the authorities were finally induced to take cognizance of it. The matter was brought to the attention of Coroner SC[???]ER on Saturday last by means of an anonymous communication, which was thrust beneath the door-sill of his residence in West Tenth-street, stating that there were circumstances attending Mrs. BLANKMAN's death which demanded a thorough investigation. He, however, declined to notice this unofficial information, believing it to have emanated from some enemy of Mr. BLANKMAN, who had the gratification of his revenge in view. Yesterday morning the Coroner called upon District-Attorney WATERBURY for advice as to his proper course in the present aspect of the case, and an exhumation of the body was determined upon. An order was accordingly made out authorizing Mr. WARD, an undertaker, doing business in Pearl-street, to disinter the remains, which was done, and they were conveyed to Bellevue Hospital. To-day it is the intention of Dr. BOUTON, the Coroner's Deputy, to make a very careful examination, in which he will be assisted by several eminent medical gentlemen, and in this way it is hoped that the suspicions connected with the affair will be removed.

abstract: -The Canadians are rather disappointed that the Prince of Wales has been received with more courtesy in the United States than in British territory. When they reflect over their own disgraceful behavior and lack of hospitality in thrusting political feuds upon their royal guests, they naturally feel ashamed of themselves. The Toronto Globe is bitter upon the subject, and is very much annoyed that the Prince was so delighted with his visit to New-York. Its bitterness is somewhat heightened by the fact that "our own correspondent" could not obtain admission to the ball at the Academy. Of course the mishap that occurred is made the most of, and is balm to our cotemporary's wounded spirit. But our Provincial cousins have now learnt a lesson from New-York in the matter of public receptions, and the next time they invite Princes to visit them they will know how to treat them

abstract: On Saturday last, Oct. 13, the steamer Daniel Drew left her wharf at the foot of Jay-street at 7 o'clock A.M., and ran to Poughkeepsie in 3 hours 25 minutes, including two landings -- the running time being 3 hours 14 minutes. The run to Hudson was made in 5 1/2 hours actual time, and 5 hours 5 minutes running time. She arrived at Albany at 2:20 o'clock P.M., having made the 150 miles in 7 hours 20 minutes, including five stops, or in 6 hours 50 minutes actual time. The average speed per hour throughout the whole trip was, therefore 21.9, or nearly 22 miles, or 19 knots per hour. On other trips we have observed the slip of the paddle wheel to be 18 per cent. Supposing it to be the same on this trip, the number of revolutions per minute would have averaged about 25; they are not stated, but since the engine has been known to make 27, it is not improbable that the actual time of the trip has been fairly given, and that the remarkable speed of 22 miles per hour has been maintained for 150 miles, which is a very different thing from running half a dozen miles at the rate of 22 miles per hour.

abstract: The sale of the library of the late Mr. BURTON is approaching its close. The books have brought good prices, and there is reason to believe have gone largely to swell the public collections of the country, where they will be accessible to the student. This result is always to be coveted.
lead_paragraph: The sale of the library of the late Mr. BURTON is approaching its close. The books have brought good prices, and there is reason to believe have gone largely to swell the public collections of the country, where they will be accessible to the student. This result is always to be coveted. The private collector, so long as he retains the fruits of his industry within his own cabinet, and for the use of himself or an immediate circle of friends, is a sad monopolist, and justly incurs the jealousy of those scholars whose researches are balked by the absence here of those vast stores of literary works which aid the European inquirer. The only indemnity the private collector can offer for his exclusiveness is to die, and in dying to bequeath his treasures to some public institution, or leave them to be scattered at a public sale.

abstract: "Occasional," writing from Washington to the Philadelphia Press says: "The late Postmaster of New-York, ISAAC V. FOWLER, whose defalcation suggested so much discussion, has, as his friends inform me, determined to make every effort to redeem himself, and, if possible, to repay the losses which the Government has sustained at his hands. He has been living at Havana for several months past, and has awakened much interest by his excellent habits and his close attention to business. During the days of his prosperity, no man was more ready to serve than poor FOWLER. He was singularly popular in New-York, even when, in 1848, he joined the Van Burenites, and opposed Gen. CASS, because, at all times, he stood foremost in generous actions. It is creditable that many whom he aided while prosperous himself, have done, and are doing, their utmost to put him on his feet again. I am told that he started a few days ago to Mexico, and that he will there be a partner in a large and flourishing enterprise, with every prospect of speedy success. Our Consul at Havana, Mr. HELMS, now in this city, speaks of FOWLER very warmly, and has no doubt that if he is reasonably indulged, he will make every effort to vindicate his good name, and to prove that, although unfortunate, his disposition is to make good all deficiencies."

abstract: BOARD OF SUPERVISORS INTEREST ON WATER BONDS. An objourned meeting of the Kinds County Board of Supervisors, was held last evening. The first subject of interest which came up for consideration, was a report of the Committee on General and Local Taxes on communications from the Boards of Water and Sewer Commissioners.
lead_paragraph: BOARD OF SUPERVISORS INTEREST ON WATER BONDS. An objourned meeting of the Kinds County Board of Supervisors, was held last evening. The first subject of interest which came up for consideration, was a report of the Committee on General and Local Taxes on communications from the Boards of Water and Sewer Commissioners. The Water Commissioners say they have ascertained that the net income of the Water Works, after paying the annual expenses, will be insufficient by the sum of $60,000 to pay interest for the coming year on the bonds issued for the construction of the Water Works, and therefore ask that the deficiency be inserted in the tax list. The Sewers Commissioners ask $25,000 for anticipated repairs on sewers -- making a total of $85,000. The Committee report against raising the money asked for because the requisitions are founded upon "anticipated expenses" in the repairs of sewers, and "anticipated" deficiency in the receipts in the Water Commissioners' Department of Water Taxes to pay interest, and not upon any expense or deficiency of receipts actually occurred, and should any deficiency exist, the act has a provision for raising the money. A motion to amend the report by directing the amount to be inserted in the taxes, was lost by a vote of 5 Ayes to 16 Noes. The report was adopted by a vote of 18 to 3. It was stated during the discussion of this matter that the receipts of the Water department up to the present time amounted to about $400,000, and that 140 miles of pipe had been laid. Supervisor CROOK, of the Committee to inquire as to what disposition the Excise Commissioners had made of the money received by them during the last year, reported that the money -- about $13,000 -- was in the Central Bank to the credit of the Commissioners. That Commissioner MURPHY was ready to sign a check at any time for the amount, but one of his associates entertained an opinion that the Supervisors had nothing to do with the money, and would not sign the check until the spirit moved him. A resolution was adopted directing the County Treasurer to obtain the money. F.S. STALLKENCHT complained to the Board that he had been compelled to pay a fee of $6 for the privilege of bailing a boy who was locked up in jail awaiting trial. The matter was referred to the Law Committee to investigate. The question as to selecting a site for the proposed County Courthouse was laid over till Nov. 7, to which time the Board adjourned.

abstract: The humane and truly heroic conduct of Capt. JOHN WILSON and the officers and crew of the brig Mennie Schiffer, in rescuing five hundred persons from the burning wreck of the steamer Connaught, it seems is not to go unrewarded. The Humane Society of Boston have already presented its first-class.
lead_paragraph: The humane and truly heroic conduct of Capt. JOHN WILSON and the officers and crew of the brig Mennie Schiffer, in rescuing five hundred persons from the burning wreck of the steamer Connaught, it seems is not to go unrewarded. The Humane Society of Boston have already presented its first-class gold medal to Capt. WILSON, a silver medal to Mr. THOB. H. CONNAUT[???]N, the mate, and $10 to each of the crew of that vessel. The work thus worthily begun has been taken up by the merchants and Life Insurers of this City, under the le[???]d of Messrs. HOWLAND & ASPINWALL, the consignees of the Galway line, and a handsome sum has been subscribed. There was an impromptu meeting yesterday at the Chamber of Commerce Buildings in the office of the Manhattan Company, many of the leading Life Insurance Companies having representatives present. They resolved to recommend a testimonial to Capt. WILSON, and appointed a Committee with power to confer with, and convene a general meeting of all the Companies. WM. HURRY, Esq., of this City, who, with his daughter, was saved from the burning wreck, was present by invitation, and related the particulars of the terrible scene through which they passed after the fire broke out on board. The narrative deeply moved every one who listend to it. The heroic self-possession of Capt. LEITCH, of the Connaught, was only equaled by the generous and humane spirit of the noble-hearted Captain of the Minnie Schiffer. Captain WILSON is soon expected in this City.

abstract: SALE OF R.K. HAIGHT'S PICTURES,  C. One of the most elegant mansions in Fifth-avenue that of RICHARD K. HAIGHT, Esq., on the corner of Fifteenthstreet has for the past two days been converted into a salesroom, and its myriad houehold gods knocked.
lead_paragraph: SALE OF R.K. HAIGHT'S PICTURES, C. One of the most elegant mansions in Fifth-avenue that of RICHARD K. HAIGHT, Esq., on the corner of Fifteenthstreet has for the past two days been converted into a salesroom, and its myriad houehold gods knocked from their pedestals by the profane hammer of the auctioneer. The family of its owner being about to spend several years in Europe, the whole contents of the mansion, comprising over 100 paintings, a large collection of statuary, curiosities, and articles of vertu without number -- the accumulated treasures of years of lavish expenditure -- have been remorselessly surrendered to the great Toodles public, and, together with the upholstery of the establishment, knocked off to the highest bidder. The auction commenced on Wednesday with the sale of the paintings, of which there were 117 pieces. The attendance was not large, being confined principally to connoisseurs, who regulated their bids so as not to permit any very fearful sacrifice of the Old Masters. Among the chief bidders were MARLEY, the dealer; Mr. NIBLO and Dr. PETERS. "The Magdalen," a fine picture, pronounced by the catalogue to be an "original," from CORREGGIO, was knocked off to MARLEY at $1,025, and was the highest on the list. The same gentleman also took the following: "St. John," original from JULIO ROMANO, $410; "Ecce Homo," by ANNIBAL CARRACHI, $100; "Guard-room Scene in Flanders," by C.O. MARN, (1646,) $100. Mr. NIBLO purchased the "Flight into Egypt" (artist unknown) for $215; two copies of "Murillo's Beggars" for $275 each, and several other minor pictures. The "Marriage of Peasants," a beautiful picture, by PHILIP SPRUYT, was sold to Dr. SNELLING for $205; "The Last Supper," an old picture, by CARLO DOLCI, to Mr. IRVING for $165; "Country Inn Yard," "Flemish Fair," "Dutch Inn," and several others, to Dr. PETERS, at prices varying from $35 to $100. The second day's sales (yesterday) comprised marble statuary, bronzes, vases, figures in terra cotta, &c., &c. A beautiful marble group -- "The Three Graces" -- was knocked down to Mr. NIBLO at $505. "Venus at the Bath" went to Mrs. ABBOT for $210. MARLEY took a bronze lion at $55; the "Death of the Stag" (bronze) at $50, four antique stone Roman ruins, at $25 each, a "Vase de Medicis" at $190, a "Vase de Borghese" at $200, a Chinese dish and punch bowl, with table, at $350, etc. A magnificent set of porcelain ware was purchased for $185 by Mr. MANNEES, who also made other purchases amounting to nearly $2,000. A marble vase, antique Roman, with rude antique base, was sold to Mr. SANDS for $95; two vases (FRATIN's bronze) to Mr. MARSH for $125; "Crouching Lion" (bronze) to Mr. TAYLOR for $62 50. The bidding was quite spirited on the second day, although the number of bidders was small. To-day the sale of the furniture will commence, when the throng of bidders will undoubtedly be much larger. The mansion from which the sale takes place has been leased for ten years to the "New-York Club," who will take possession immediately.

abstract: The People ex rel. John Kelly vs. Robert T. Haws. -- The relator, who is the Sheriff of the City and County of New-York, seeks to obtain from the Comptroller his fees for service of process in the cases commenced by the Excise Commissioners against the host of delinquents charged with the violation of the Excise law. The average fee in these cases is $1 18 in each, and the number of cases are estimated at 30,000. By this estimate the amount of costs on the part of the Sheriff alone would be but a few dollars short of the snug sum of $40,000. Of that total the sum of about $6,000 has been already demanded by the Sheriff, it having been incorporated in his quarterly bills for the present year, being audited and allowed by the Board of Supervisors.

abstract: Pennoyer vs. Brennan. -- The plaintiff kept the Stryker's Bay Hotel, to which led a lane or road. The defendant, claiming to own both the hotel and lane, caused the same to be fenced up. The plaintiff obtained an injunction to restrain the defendant from obstructing the way to his hotel. The defendant moved that the injunction be dissolved, alleging that it was originally run through private property by the owner thereof, and was never regarded as a public highway. Motion was now granted. The case was full stated in the TIMES of the 25th September.

lead_paragraph: We obtain from the Arabia's mails some further European details of interest. The Pope, in his allocution delivered to the College of Cardinals on the 28th ult., is extremely bitter against King VICTOR EMANUEL, and stigmatizes his conduct as guilty, detestable and sacrilegious. There is, in the document, an indirect complaint that the Emperor NAPOLEON failed to fulfill his promise when he permitted "the authors and abettors of the invasion to advance as far as the walls of Rome as though they had the assurance that no one would oppose them." Count CAVOUR had declared in the Sardidian Chambers that no Power had ever made proposals involving the session of a single inch of Italian soil, and that there existed no public or private Convention stipulating such a cession. The Count's message to the Chambers is exceedingly interesting and develops the policy of the King with regard to Rome and Venice. It is alleged that GARIBALDI, wearied and harassed by complaints and recriminations, has requested VICTOR EMANUEL to come and relieve him from all authority. The French Cabinet is supposed to favor a reference of the Roman question to a Congress of all the Great Powers.

abstract: Yesterday morning Judge OGDEN charged the Jury in the case of the above-named parties, charged with the murder of Major KOPPER, of the Weehawken Ferry. The law respecting murder and manslaughter was fully explained and the evidence thoroughly reviewed. The Judge occupied over an hour in delivering the charge. The Jury retired shortly before 12 o'clock and were out until 6 o'clock P.M., when they brought in a verdict of guilty of murder in the second degree.

abstract: The latest phase of the Italian Question, profoundly interesting as it is, presents one aspect almost ludicrous in the eyes of grave and dispassionate men at this distance from the scene of operations. We all rejoice sincerely and manfully in the conquest which GARIBALDI seems to have won over his own prejudices and the passions of the foolish partisans who have been surrounding him in victory
lead_paragraph: The latest phase of the Italian Question, profoundly interesting as it is, presents one aspect almost ludicrous in the eyes of grave and dispassionate men at this distance from the scene of operations. We all rejoice sincerely and manfully in the conquest which GARIBALDI seems to have won over his own prejudices and the passions of the foolish partisans who have been surrounding him in victory with counsels pregnant with defeat. It is a glorious and hopeful thing for Italy and for human freedom that the triumphant liberator of Naples and Sicily should have sense, judgment, self-distrust and patriotism enough to abdicate political pretensions out of all proportion to his powers, and to leave the organization of the Italian freedom which his sword has won, to hands more skillful than his own in the manipulations of State-craft. Our faith in this result of the temporary imbroglio between GARIBALDI and VICTOR EMANUEL has never faltered, and it seems now about to be crowned with a splendid fruition.

abstract: A woman named Anna M. Baunan, was yesterday committed to prison on a charge of having stolen, at various times, the following articles from the persons named: A cloth cloak from Miss Haggett, of No. 103 Bayard-street; a frock coat from Mathew Ryan; a silver watch and two gold chains, valued in the aggregate at $35, from James McQuade, of No. 58 Mulberry-street; a gold chain, worth $15, from officer Riley, of the Sixth Ward; a case of pistols from Dr. Carpenter, of No. 103 Bayard-street, which were disposed of for a small sum to a man in the street. Officer Golden, of the Sixth Ward, who arrested Anna, also recovered most of the stolen property from pawnshops in Pearl and Division streets.

abstract: The opening of the past week gave little prospect for the yet outstanding corn. Monday night's tempest has been followed by heavy rains, and there seems little hope that the remainder of the grain, if sound, will be in fair condition. Some quantity of wheat even in the south and midland counties remains to be carried, and the bulk of all grain is yet jeopardized in the north, though Scotland is better off. Ireland, too, is in great peril, with much to be gathered. The agricultural districts of that country show a decrease in the growth of cereals this season of 15,223 acres, which, as this consists of Spring corn, taken at six, while the growth of potatoes is 28,510 acres less. This consideration upon the diseased state of the crop, which extends over 1,171,837 acres shows a heavy void to be filled up, supposing Great Britain is sad to hear that heavy rains in Southern Europe are beginning to threaten this important grain, which keeps continually advancing. With such weather, the markets here could not fail to rise, the average of the week being about 3s. per qr. There has been an unusual demand for dry foreign red of low quality to help off our own damp new by mixture; and as our own stock of old is nearly used up, it seems doubtful whether we shall have enough old foreign to meet our necessities. Throughout the continent very little is left, and much is waited here, while American is quite exhausted, and the shipments lately made are nearly all new, with condition of some not well reported. Prices there have moderately given way, as they have in Spain and Italy and on the Danube, but there has been some reaction at Odessa, as well as in Northern Germany, the Baltic, Holland, Belgium and France. It may be well, in our estimation of the possible shipments of the United States, to remember that for the last fourteen years the largest shipments thence were in 1846 and 1847, when, with an accumulation of old corn, they reached to 17,157,659 bushels of wheat and 3,156,245 barrels of flour, equal to 3,700,000 qrs.; but this season they had little to begin with.

abstract: As there are crimes which the laws cannot reach, so there are follies which the Press cannot punish. The blatant extravagances of personal vanity belong to this category; and the story of the visit of the Prince of Wales to New-York is a crying illustration alike of their disastrous absurdity and of their practical immunity from condign and wholesome chastisement. One only penalty attaches to them by that irreversible decree of a beneficent Providence, to which the Preacher did justice when he coupled vanity with vexation of spirit. To the operation of this wholesome natural law we were at first inclined to leave the two "clergymen in charge of Trinity Church," who yesterday obliged us with a singulariy peremptory communication in reply to certain strictures of ours upon what we felt constrained, in common with nine-tenths of the rational inhabitants of New-York, to regard as the discreditable and impertinent features of the "Cathedral services" performed under their auspices nominally in honor of the Almighty, but really in praise of the Prince of Wales and to the glory of their own ecclesiastical office. It seemed to us perfectly clear that men who could regard the presentation of a gorgeous prayer-book, inscribed with their own names, to a scion of royalty, as a becoming incident of Divine worship, and who could threaten to punish what they described as "editorial errors," with a formal exclusion of all newspaper men from the "means of grace" in a house of Christian worship, must be beyond the reach of mortal criticism, and might well be handed over to the moral discipline of wounded vanity and humiliated pride. But we owe something to the venerable Corporation of Trinity Church, and to the dignified position of its high-minded Christian Rector; and the following letter, therefore, compels us to revive a subject which we should gladly have consigned to oblivion, together with the indifferent temper and the more than indifferent manners of our clerical correspondents of yesterday:

lead_paragraph: The Norfolk Argus of Saturday says: The exam- ination of negroes suspected of insurrectionary designs will take place on the 5th of November. We are indebted to a gentleman who arrived from Princes Anne last evening for the following information: It has been ascertained that the extent of the conspiracy extends from Currituck, N.C., through Gibbs' Woods, Blackwater, Great Bridge and all the district Southwest of North-River, and the Chesapeake and Albermarle canal Every kind of instruments that could be procured was to be used on the occasion, such as pickaxes, pitchforks, &c. One of the magistrates issued a warrant yesterday for a white man named THOMAS CARROLL, suspected of inciting the negroes to insurrection. There are about 21 negroes in jail, their ages running from 20 to 70. The surrounding country is under patrol day and night, and a strict guard is kept on the jail. The free negroes it is thought will be required to leave the country at short notice.

abstract: The People ex rel. John Magin vs. The Board of Pilot Commissioners. -- This was a motion to quash a writ of prohibition obtained by the relator against the defendants, restraining them from proceeding against him to revoke his license as a pilot. The relator piloted a ship out of port which he did not bring in, thus violating the 28th section of the by-laws of the Board of Pilot Commissioners, which provided that the pilot bringing a vessel in should be entitled to take her out.

abstract: The adjourned meeting of the Church of the Puritans, having under consideration the trial of Mr. CHARLES ABERNETHY, one of the anti-Cheever members, took place last evening in the Lecture-room of the Church. There was a very full attendance of members at an early hour, and quite a delegation of persons not connected with the Church. Mr. RICHARD WARREN, and several other friends of Dr. CHEEVER, posted themselves at the door, and by standing in the way, pushing, pulling, crowding, and otherwise impeding the passage-way, endeavored to prevent all but members of the Church from entering the room -- reporters being the object of their special attention. A number of the opponents of Dr. CHEEVER were likewise on the spot, urging all who wished, to enter, declaring that it was an open court, and that no one member had a right to say who should or should not enter the room. Some of the members who wished to go out were impeded, and a number of disputes took place as to who were or were not members. Several scuffles took place on the occasion of non-members forcing an entrance, and loud calls were made on the policemen in attendance to arrest this or that person, according to the wish of the parties making the request. The policemen, however, so far as our reporter learned, declined to interfere to decide who should enter, taking the ground that they were there merely to preserve the peace. The greatest confusion took place, and many of the ladies, in the greatest trepidation, desired to be taken home. Mr. C.J. WARREN, the Chairman, informed those at the door that the meeting was for members, and that all not members were desired to leave. Upon his authority being questioned, he stated that this was not a new meeting, but the continuation of one already begun. In the midst of the discussion and confusion Mr. C.J. WARREN took the Chair, and for several minutes vainly called for the meeting to come to order.

abstract: On Wednesday night a great Anti-Slavery meeting was held at Leeds, under the auspices of the Leeds Young Men's Anti-Slavery Society. Mr. EDWARD BAINES, M.P., occupied the Chair, and paid a very high tribute to the labors of Dr. CHEEVER. He said that to destroy Dr. CHEEVER would be the highest achievement of the Pro-Slavery Party, and it was to strengthen his position that he came to seek their sympathy and support. Dr. CHEEVER, who was received with great applause, then addressed the meeting at considerable length, and with much eloquence. He expressed his conviction that if the churches and the ministry would unite evangelically against Slavery, trusting in God, they would sweep it from the whole land in twenty years. [Applause.] Rev. G.W. CONDER briefly moved, and Rev. F. EDWARDS seconded, the following resolution, which was unanimously adopted: "That this meeting, in tendering a hearty welcome to Rev. GEORGE B. CHEEVER, D.D., pastor of the Church of the Puritans, New-York, United States, takes this opportunity of assuring him of its sympathy and esteem. Feeling deeply interested in the result of the great conflict in which he is engaged, and concurring with the principles he has so boldly proclaimed and maintained; admiring his devotion and self-sacrifice, we honor him for his fidelity, and pledge ourselves to render him support; praying that Almighty God may crown his labors with success, and bless every instrumentality which has for its object the abolition of American Slavery." Among the speakers were Mr. GEORGE THOMPSON and Rev. Dr. BREWER.

abstract: W.B. Bull vs. Melliss & Ayers. -- The plaintiff is an attorney at Newport Pagnell, England. The defendants, in 1857, carried on business as Melliss & Ayers in New-York, and as Ayers & Melliss in Nottingham, England. The plaintiff caused $3,821 to be deposited with Melliss & Ayers in New-York, Aug. 24, 1857, to be forwarded to him in England. The defendants sent to the plaintiff their draft on Ayers & Melliss, of Nottingham, for the amount, at 60 days after sight, and which was accepted by them and forwarded to the plaintiff, and which was presented for payment at maturity and protested, the defendants having in the meantime stopped payment.

abstract: Observing the promise I made never to write unless topics of interest presented themselves, I have suffered several opportunities to pass without forwarding a letter. Affairs here have been very dull since the close of the general elections, but those to whose existence the excitement of politics is necessary, have a prospect of early breathing the air adapted to their constitutions the Legislature is to meet in the course of six weeks.

abstract: The annual inspection and review of the Seventh Regiment, Col. MARSHALL LEFFERTS, took place at Hamilton-square, yesterday, and attracted crowds of spectators, male and female, senile, mature and juvenile, in carriages, on foot and on horseback. During the morning the Regiment was exercised in the evolutions prescribed by the Adjutant-General, for 1860.
lead_paragraph: The annual inspection and review of the Seventh Regiment, Col. MARSHALL LEFFERTS, took place at Hamilton-square, yesterday, and attracted crowds of spectators, male and female, senile, mature and juvenile, in carriages, on foot and on horseback. During the morning the Regiment was exercised in the evolutions prescribed by the Adjutant-General, for 1860. The drill was worthy of the reputation of the Regiment. In the afternoon the inspection took place. There were 903 men on the ground -- five more than were present at the inspection of 1859. The absentees numbered about 150. The largest number in the ranks of any one company was 110, constituting the second company, Capt. SHALER. This company also has an enviable discipline for excellent drill; for that matter which company of the entire command has not? After the inspection Brigadier-General HALL reviewed the troops, greatly to the regret of many of the men, who were thus detained so long that their anticipated parade by daylight in Fifth-avenue and Broadway was prevented. This over, the men were conveyed in Third-avenue cars to Twenty-seventh-street, where they alighted, formed, and thence marched by gaslight and crescent moonlight through Fifth-avenue, Fourteenth-street, Broadway, Grand-street, the Bowery and Fourth-street to Lafayette-place, where they were dismissed. The route was lined with spectators.

abstract: It appears that Virginia has finally made up her mind to defend herself in the approaching crisis of our national affairs, with Northern arms. The Adjutant-General of that chivalric Sate a now in this City, charged with a credit of half a million of dollars, and with orders to purchase a complete armament for the Old Dominion. What the motives are which
lead_paragraph: It appears that Virginia has finally made up her mind to defend herself in the approaching crisis of our national affairs, with Northern arms. The Adjutant-General of that chivalric Sate a now in this City, charged with a credit of half a million of dollars, and with orders to purchase a complete armament for the Old Dominion. What the motives are which have impelled so calm and conservative a man as Gov. LETCHER to this extraordinary demonstration does not yet appear. It is, however, rumored that the Executive of Virginia has resolved to call a meeting of Southern Governors at Richmond, very shortly, for the purpose of concerting measures, defensive and offensive, to be taken in the now imminent event of Mr. LINCOLN's election. We do not believe that manifestations of this kind are destined to pass unrebuked by the more sober public sentiment of the Southern States, but it is much to be desired, for the sake of the general peace of the country, and of the public confidence which insures that peace, that the conservative South should lose no time in making head against a torrent of sectional excitement and alarm which appears to be growing formidable precisely in proportion to the groundlessness of the causes by which it is fed.

abstract: Mr. Whi. F. Howe, counsel for James Massey--the novel pugilist, indicted for felonious assault on Officer Patterson, of the Fourteenth Precinet, with intent to kill--applied to the Court, upon affidavits, to postpone the trial, assigning, as his reason, the absence of material witnesses. lead_paragraph: THE AMERICAN TICKET. -- The American Bell and Everett General Committee held a meeting on Wednesday evening, when they made the following nominations: For Congress -- Second District -- Moses F. Odell, Douglas Dem.; Fifth District -- D.D. Winant, Douglas Dem. For Sheriff -- Hugh McLaughlin, Douglas Dem. For City Judge -- C.C. Eagan, K.N. For Police Justice -- James A. Cornwell, Breckinridge Dem. For Justices of the Peace -- Jacob C. Blatchly, Douglas Dem., and Zachariah Voorhies, Douglas Dem. For Superintendents of the Poor -- James Boyle, Douglas Dem., and Caspar Urban, Breckinridge Dem. For Justice of the Sessions -- John A. Emmons Breckinridge Dem. For School Commissioner -- Chas. W. Church, Douglas Dem. The above can tidates are all taken from the two Democratic local tickets, except Mr. EAGAN, for City Judge.

abstract: All the humane efforts which have been made on this side of the Atlantic, and more especially by the State of New-York, to secure European immigrants from extortion and injustice on their arrival here, would now appear to be in great part neutralized by the adoption of that "booking-system" which Mr. JELLINGHAUS, on behalf of the German Society,
lead_paragraph: All the humane efforts which have been made on this side of the Atlantic, and more especially by the State of New-York, to secure European immigrants from extortion and injustice on their arrival here, would now appear to be in great part neutralized by the adoption of that "booking-system" which Mr. JELLINGHAUS, on behalf of the German Society, explained and denounced before the Commissioners of Immigration at their meeting on last Wednesday. This new development of the art which "takes the stranger in," completely sets at defiance all local laws designed for its restraint, and may require an additional clause to be added to all our extradition treaties before we can secure justice to the hosts of Europeans who annually seek our shores with the intention of making this country their home.

abstract: In accordance with the order issued by Coroner SOHIRMER, the remains of Mrs. JANE AUGUSTA BLANKMEN were on Wednesday exhumed, after they had remained for three days at Greenwood Cemetery, and taken to the dead-house at Bellevue Hospital, where yesterday a second autopsy was conducted. The notoriety which formerly attached to the deceased ...
lead_paragraph: In accordance with the order issued by Coroner SOHIRMER, the remains of Mrs. JANE AUGUSTA BLANKMEN were on Wednesday exhumed, after they had remained for three days at Greenwood Cemetery, and taken to the dead-house at Bellevue Hospital, where yesterday a second autopsy was conducted. The notoriety which formerly attached to the deceased, when, as FANNY WHITE, she was the proprietress of several houses of ill-fame in this City, in connection with the suddenness of her decease, has served to excite a great deal of interest in the case. This interest was manifested yesterday by the attendance of a large number of the medical fraternity to witness the proceedings connected with the examination. Among the distinguished physicians and surgeons present were Profs. CARNOCHAN, DOREMUS, J.C. BRONSON and GARDNER, and the investigation was conducted by the two first-mentioned gentlemen, assisted by Dr. GEO. B. BOUTON, the Deputy of Coroner SCHIRMER. The autopsy was very thorough, and we herewith present an outline of its result:

abstract: The lovers of Italian opera will be delighted to learn that this charming institution is to be revived under a strictly German dynasty. There is no reason, certainly, why a German should not give us Italian opera, especially when that German is CABL FORMES, and when he is assisted by another German, in the person of Madame MULDER-FABBRI, a name at least as Italian as PATTI-STRAKOSCH.

abstract: At 4 o'clock this morning, the Prince of Wales, a tired and used-up man, retired to his couch, where he remained until 10 o'clock, shortly after which breakfast was served, and the business of the day began. The entire party was so completely fagged out by the unusual exertions of the day previous, that they felt great, indisposition to accept the kindly-proffered services of the entertaining Committee.

abstract: THE AMERICAN vs. SATELLITE The first match of the American Club against the Satellite Club of Williamsburgh, was played Thursday, and ended in a victory for the Americans. Some compliments were exchanged on presenting the ball to the Americans. Mr. Dakin, who is President of his Club, saying that they were organized for the purpose of making the game popular among Americans, by making
lead_paragraph: THE AMERICAN vs. SATELLITE The first match of the American Club against the Satellite Club of Williamsburgh, was played Thursday, and ended in a victory for the Americans. Some compliments were exchanged on presenting the ball to the Americans. Mr. Dakin, who is President of his Club, saying that they were organized for the purpose of making the game popular among Americans, by making it a quicker game as they had proved to-day, by being punctual and sending their men in without delay, They also intended to conduct the game without many of the objectionable features which had made it unpopular with Americans.

abstract: The President has followed good examples in forwarding to the gallant and magnanimous ABD-EL-KADER a public token of the respect which he has won from all right-minded Christian men by his heroic and successful interference to mitigate the horrors of the Moslem massacres in Syria. The Sacred Crosses of the Legion of Honor and of St. Manuel and St. Lazarus already sparkle on the breast of the bold Emir, to bear witness to the esteem in which NAPOLEON and VICTOR EMANUEL hold the fearless protector of defenceless men and women in the streets of Damascus. America owes even a more absolute debt to this illustrious son of the desert. For the Americans in Syria owe all that they have saved from the storm which so lately swept with fiery breath from the Lebanon to the Levant, not to the terror of the American name or the vigor of American policy, but to just such humane and fearless action as that of the exiled chieftain of Algiers.
lead_paragraph: The President has followed good examples in forwarding to the gallant and magnanimous ABD-EL-KADER a public token of the respect which he has won from all right-minded Christian men by his heroic and successful interference to mitigate the horrors of the Moslem massacres in Syria. America owes even a more absolute debt to this illustrious son of the desert. abstract: There have been so many inquiries in relation to the Prince's present to Capt. It is a watch of the chronometer pattern, with the so-called magic case, enabling the wearer to use it with an open face or in hunting style. It is very heavy and perfectly plain. abstract: The stated meeting of the Academy was held at the University on Wednesday evening, Dr. JOHN WATSON in the Chair. After the usual order of business, the President read a valuable paper on Tetanus. The paper led to a discussion. Dr. A.H. STEVENS reviewed the paper, differing from the views of the author in some points. Dr. J.M. SIMS referred to the tetanus of young children. Dr. J. MCNULTY dissented from the views of the author as to the true cause of tetanus. He does not believe that local injury is the cause, per se, of tetanus, but that it is due to a morbific principle circulating in the blood, producing a tetanic diathesis. When such diathesis exists, then, and then only will tetanus follow local injury. He showed that tetanus did not follow local injuries more frequently than one case to thirty thousand such injuries. The discussion was continued until a late hour, and participated in by Drs. Bulkly, Clark, Foster, Porter, Lovel, and others. Dr. J.G. ADAMS presented some memoirs from Dr. SPERANDA, of Turin, on "Syphilization." On motion of Dr. A.H. STEVENS a committee was appointed to investigate a new method of using cow's milk as food for infants. The meetings of the Academy are the first and third Wednesday of each month.
lead_paragraph: The stated meeting of the Academy was held at the University on Wednesday evening, Dr. JOHN WATSON in the Chair. When such diathesis exists, then, and then only will tetanus follow local injury. He showed that tetanus did not follow local injuries more frequently than one case to thirty thousand such injuries. The discussion was continued until a late hour, and participated in by Drs. Bulkly, Clark, Foster, Porter, Lovel, and others. Dr. J.G. ADAMS presented some memoirs from Dr. SPERANDA, of Turin, on "Syphilization." On motion of Dr. A.H. abstract: A doughty son of Esculapius sends us a letter, which will be found in another column, indignantly controverting the statements made in the TIMES of Thursday last, in regard to the velocity of medical education in the Colleges of this City, and averring that if what we stated were true, "the medical students themselves would burn down the Colleges and dissect the Professors!" Now, though we would
lead_paragraph: A doughty son of Esculapius sends us a letter, which will be found in another column, indignantly controverting the statements made in the TIMES of Thursday last, in regard to the velocity of medical education in the Colleges of this City, and averring that if what we stated were true, "the medical students themselves would burn down the Colleges and dissect the Professors!" Now, though we would not, for the whole TIMES' establishment, contribute a single faggot, nor even the ivory of a scalpel, to forward the crematic and postmortem spectacle so vivaciously prophesied, and notwithstanding the categorical denials of our correspondent, the facts in the case compel us to reiterate every statement in the article referred to; and we once more emphasize the assertion that M.D.'s are now manufactured out of raw material by the leading medical schools of this City, (Brooklyn included,) in the brief period elapsing between October and July -- the Professors and records of the schools themselves being witnesses. It is evident that both this correspondent and the writers of the other communications sent us on the same subject, have not kept abreast of the late rapid march of events in the medical world. He does not seem to know (to take him also categorically) that the very authority he himself defers to (Prof. REESE) affirms that the qualifications demanded for a medical diploma in this country, at the present time, are less now than at the commencement of the century -- that young men have, this very year, and within the last half of it too, received their diplomas from chartered orthodox medical schools, within eight or nine months from the time they first entered the walls of a medical institution -- that if, during this period, the matriculants did not acquire a scientific knowledge of the entire curriculum of medicine, they did acquire all that was demanded of them as a preliminary to its practice -- that this was accomplished in the brief period of eight or nine months -- and finally that all these things have been done just as stated, and yet not a rafter of any of the colleges has been offered up a burnt sacrifice to the shade of the insulted Father of Medicine, nor has the scalpel (so far as we know) invaded the dry and lean anatomy of a single Professor!

abstract: EXTENSIVE FIRE IN PLATT-STREET LOSS ABOUT 835,000. Between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday morning a fire was discovered in the building No. 32 Plattstreet, occupied by GOUDELET  GOURE, dealers in  patent medicines, and S.J. PARDESSUS, manufacturer of glass-ware. The firemen quickly repaired to the place, but in spite of their earnest efforts to extinguish the flames, owing to the combustible character of the medicine stock,a large amount of damage was done.
lead_paragraph: EXTENSIVE FIRE IN PLATT-STREET LOSS ABOUT 835,000. Between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday morning a fire was discovered in the building No. 32 Plattstreet, occupied by GOUDELET GOURE, dealers in patent medicines, and S.J. PARDESSUS, manufacturer of glass-ware. The firemen quickly repaired to the place, but in spite of their earnest efforts to extinguish the flames, owing to the combustible character of the medicine stock,a large amount of damage was done. The fire is supposed to have originated from a defective flue in the premises of Messrs. GOUDELET & GOURE, and these gentlemen estimate their loss at $10,000, which is fully met by insurance in the Excelsior, Gallatin and Commercial Companies for $5,000 each. The damage to the stock of Mr. PARDESSUS is said to be $15,000. He had effected a full insurance upon it in the Excelsior, Lafayette Harmony and Stuyvesant Insurance Companies. The flames extended to that part of the adjoining building, No. 34 Platt-street, occupied by E. MULLER, porcelain dealer, and by the Sullivan Blacking Company. The former suffered a loss of $1,000, insured for $3,000 in City Companies, but only slight injury resulted to the stock of the Blacking Company, who are insured for $2,000 in the Home Insurance Company. ATTERBURY & CO., dealers in anvils, and the New-England Nut Company, both of whom are located at No. 30, were sufferers to some extent. Mr. ATTERBURY's loss is covered by an insurance of $1,000 in the Home, and the Nut Company, who estimate their loss at $1,500have policies upon their stock from Providence Companies. The building in which the fire originated is owned by THOS. PATON. It is damaged to the extent of $3,000, and is insured for $4,500 in the Niagara.

abstract: Some weeks since the Common Council passed a resolution permitting GEORGE LAW to erect, at his own expense, a sea wall at the foot of State-street, Pier No. 1 East River, which should correspond with the exterior line of the Battery, as authorized by the extension which had been ordered. In consideration of the enormous expense which the construction of this bulkhead would necessarily entail upon Mr. LAW, the resolution granted him permission to use the space between the bulkhead and the opposite pier for the landing and departure of boats owned by him. In the Board of Councilmen, where it last appeared, the measure was denounced by Mr. PINCKNEY and others in the most unqualified terms, as a perfect swindle upon the public, and as being nothing less than a perpetual ferry franchise to Mr. LAW without the payment of a farthing of rent. The TIMES called attention to the matter editorially, warning tax-payers of the certain consequences which such a permission would entail upon them, and especially upon those who were compelled to use his ferry-boats to convey them to Staten Island. For over four years Mr. LAW has enjoyed a ferry franchise without the payment of any rent.

abstract: The Tammany Judicial Convention met at the Wigwam last evening for the purpose of nominating a candidate for the Superior Court Judgeship, to fill the vacancy occasioned by the resignation of Judge PIERREPONT. Of the 154 members of the Convention, there were but 130 present, and loud complaints were made by certain parties of the failure to give due notice of the meeting. Several attempts to postpone and adjourn the meeting were made by a small but determined minority, who were anxious for the nomination of Mr. J.T. HOFFMAN to the Superior Court vacancy, and the indorsement of the Mozart nomination of ABRAHAM D. RUSSELL for the Recordership. These attempts proved unavailing, and after a vote which showed the strength of the majority, Judge ULLSHOEFFER was nominated by acclamation, and then the Convention adjourned sine die.

abstract: ATTORNEY. -- It has been erroneously stated that there is an understanding among the members of the Bar to vote for the Democratic candidate for District-Attorney. We are assured of this fact by leading members of the profession. Republican and Democratic lawyers will vote their respective tickets, while a few will be influenced by personal considerations irrespective of politics. Of the different candidates in the field, Mr. THOMAS B. VAN BUREN, the Republican nominee, has decidedly the best chance of success. He is a lawyer of good standing and ability, and is popular among his confreres.
lead_paragraph: ATTORNEY. -- It has been erroneously stated that there is an understanding among the members of the Bar to vote for the Democratic candidate for District-Attorney. abstract: About two weeks ago a woman named BURNS passed a number of counterfeit $3 bills on the Bank of Kokomo, Wisconsin, upon various shopkeepers in Louisville. Information was given of the circumstances at the time, but the woman eluded the most vigilant search. On Tuesday last, however, she, in company with a man, called at Mr. HOGAN's wig factory, Louisville, where she had her hair cut short, ordering a wig to be made of it for her own use. The man gave his name as BUCKLEY. The wig was to be completed on Saturday last, at which time she called for it, offering a counterfeit $10 bill on the Merchants' Bank of St. Louis in payment. Mr. HOGAN gave information of the affair to the police, together with an accurate description of the parties. They ascertained that BUCKLEY had gone to this city, but that he would return some time during Sunday night. An officer was stationed in BUCKLEY's room, confronted him upon his arrival and searched him. About $1,600 in counterfeit bills and coin was found in his possession. Among the bogus stuff were found fives on the Bank of Lafayette, Ill.; tens on the Merchants' Bank of St. Louis, twenties and tens on the Bank of Ashland, threes on the Bank of Kokomo, Wis.; threes on the Southern Bank of Kentucky, twenties on the Bank of Louisville, tens on the Citizens' Bank of New-Orleans ones and tens on the State Bank of Ohio, and counterfeit gold dollars. "BUCKLEY is in jail, together with his confederate, awaiting examination. -- Cincinnati Gazette.

abstract: An impromptu procession of Wide-Awakes from the Fourth, Ninth, Tenth, Seventeenth, Eighteenth and other Wards -- in all about 1,000 men -- formed in the vicinity of Cooper Institute on Thursday evening, while Hon. CARL SCHURZ was addressing the Germans within, and, after the meeting adjourned, marched down through the eastern part of the City and up the Bowery. Mr. SCHURZ appead on the balcony of HEIL's Hotel, on the Bowery, and was loudly cheered by them as they passed. A club from the Fourth Ward countermarched after passing this point, and was proceeding homeward, when in front of the hotel a link-boy in the rear rank was struck by one of the number of rough fellows who were gathered near. The blow was returned, the word was passed to those in front, and they returned to the assistance of their comrades. For a moment a battle seemed pending, but the police promptly interfered, and arrested the assailant. The Wide-Awakes then continued their march.
lead_paragraph: An impromptu procession of Wide-Awakes from the Fourth, Ninth, Tenth, Seventeenth, Eighteenth and other Wards -- in all about 1,000 men -- formed in the vicinity of Cooper Institute on Thursday evening, while Hon. abstract: A MAN CHARGED WITH ATTEMPTING TO MURDER HIS WIFE. -- About 1 1/2 o'clock yesterday (Friday) morning, as Officers VALADE and CARROLL were standing at the corner of Sussex and Essex streets, Jersey City, they heard the quick and repeated cries of "Watch," at a house near by in Essex-street. Upon entering the rear basement room they found a man named THOMAS KELLY, armed with a large carving-knife, and apparently very much excited, while his wife was sitting in a chair exhausted, and her night  clothes covered with blood, which was flowing profusely from a number of severe wounds about the head and face. KELLY was disarmed and conveyed to the Station-house, where he was locked up. It appears that KELLY had been spending the evening with a party of friends, drinking and carousing. About 12 o'clock at night Mrs. KELLY went after and endeavored to pursuade her husband to return home, but he refused to leave, and she accordingly went home alone. About an hour afterwards KELLY came in, and a quarrel occurred between them. Finally, becoming enraged, he dragged her from the bed, and seizing a heavy boot beat her in a most brutal manner over the head with the heel of it. The first blow stunned her, but soon after, recovering a little, she begged of her husband not to kill her, when he replied, "Yes, I will." The timely arrival of the officers probably saved the woman's life, as he had armed himself as above stated, and apparently intended to carry his threat into execution. Dr. QUIDOR, City Physician, was called in and pronounced the injuries of a dangerous nature. Mrs. KELLY was removed to the Hospital, and Recorder TILDEN committed the accused to the County Jail to await the result of the injuries.

Mrs. KELLY was removed to the Hospital, and Recorder TILDEN committed the accused to the County Jail to await the result of the injuries.

abstract: Our Old Public Functionary really seems to be bent on doing his utmost to go down to posterity as the last President of the United States. He has expended upon fanning the flames of Disunion at the South an amount of time, patience, patronage and influence which would have more than sufficed to consolidate the political power of the country for years in
lead_paragraph: Our Old Public Functionary really seems to be bent on doing his utmost to go down to posterity as the last President of the United States. He has expended upon fanning the flames of Disunion at the South an amount of time, patience, patronage and influence which would have more than sufficed to consolidate the political power of the country for years in the hands of the party which elected him. It is not his fault that the Kansas fever is not now raging throughout the country to madden both sections into irrepressible hostility. So far as in him lies, the President has labored to close with the name of BUCHANAN, that glorious list of rulers which begins with the name of WASHINGTON. Could we suspect him of possessing one gleam of artistic feeling, it might be supposed that the would-be Augustulus of our Western Empire has felt the full splendor and completeness of this antithesis; and that we recognize the impossibility of achieving any historical contrast so close at once to the sublime and the ridiculous, as a sunset of BUCHANAN answering to a sunrise of WASHINGTON.

abstract: We have, by the California mail, some particulars of the defeat of Major THOMAS' command of the Second Cavalry by Comanche Indians. The troops and red skins met on the 25th of August, and after a sharp fight of some hours the former had to retreat, several of the men being wounded. The gallant Major was badly, but not seriously hurt. No lives were lost on the soldiers' side; but the Indian casualties are not reported.
lead_paragraph: We have, by the California mail, some particulars of the defeat of Major THOMAS' command of the Second Cavalry by Comanche Indians. abstract: We learn through a private source that the evidence of the insurrectionary plot in Alabama, which we alluded to some days ago, was extorted from a slave by the application of eight hundred lashes to his back. After this gentle manifestation his memory was entirely restored and he was able to verify every suspicion of his tormentors. It was evidence obtained by this process on which the preachers were hung in Texas, and on which most of the cruel punishments inflicted on Northern travelers in the South are grounded. It is a well known fact, that the States in which these ingenious methods of acquring knowledge are in vogue, are the most ardent in their devotion to the Democratic Party; and it is marvelous, if we revert to the history of the reign of the late King BOMBA, to witness the similarity of means and instruments used in keeping up an intense Democracy and an intense Despotism.

abstract: There is too frequent reason to complain of the carelessness of Post-office clerks. Even in cases where their interests would seem to be identified with punctilious accuracy in the discharge of their duties, painful evidence of negligence offers itself, and proves that the disorder is chronic, if not incurable. An illustration lies before us. It is a letter marked "private," and bearing the signature of CHARLES O'CONOR
lead_paragraph: There is too frequent reason to complain of the carelessness of Post-office clerks. Even in cases where their interests would seem to be identified with punctilious accuracy in the discharge of their duties, painful evidence of negligence offers itself, and proves that the disorder is chronic, if not incurable. An illustration lies before us. It is a letter marked "private," and bearing the signature of CHARLES O'CONOR and others, Committee, and of JOSHUA J. HENRY, Chairman; a letter evidently destined for some other recipient; and yet, through some woful mistake, here it lies broadly divulged to a very different "Dear Sir" from him for whom it was intended. There may be no inexcusable breach of confidence if, under pledge of the profoundest secrecy, we inform the reader, that it is a begging letter, curiously signed by a half-dozen millionaires and their associates, soliciting money for the purpose of defeating the election of ABRAHAM LINCOLN. Contributors are invited to meet the Committee daily at the Merchants' Exchange, Wall-street, with admonition to seek "entrance by the front steps," the back stairs no doubt being required for the feet of those engaged in the disbursement of this politico-evangelical fund. You, respected and generous reader, tremulous of the fate of the country in the event of Mr. LINCOLN's election, are solicited to pour into the general fund "such a sum as you are willing to contribute to the cause of the Union." And various motives to the action are tendered by the Committee.

abstract: -- Judging from the tone of the Southern Press, the entire population of that region would appear to be at present divided into two classes -- those who think they may be able to obtain office under Mr. LINCOLN's Administration, and those who have no such hope. These latter gentry are very athletic in their vows to burst up the Union rather than see the marble porch of the White House invaded by a Black Republican. The former, however, are in a large majority, "hope springing eternally in the human breast," and they are just as resolved, on the other side, to wait for the justification of some "overt act of treason," -- which may be interpreted to mean any refusal on, Mr. LINCOLN's part to give them such share of patronage as they consider due for the "moral support" which they are now lending to the Union.

abstract: Later advices from Mexico are received by the arrival of an English steamer at Mobile. Vera Cruz dates are to the 2d inst. The expedition of the Liberals against Guadalajara arrived before that city on the 21st of September, but at last advices operations had not yet commenced. A division of the Church forces, commanded by Generals ROBLES and PEZUELA, in attempting to march out of the capital, had been defeated with a loss of four hundred men.

abstract: The sale of the household property of Mr. R. K. HAIGHT was continued yesterday at the mansion, corner of Fifth-avenue and Fifteenth-street. The catalogue, being confined to the general furniture of the house, drew together a much larger and more money gathering than attended the two previous days' sales of works of art. The rush of crinoline and broadcloth that pervaded the parlors,_the anterooms, the halls, the boudoirs, the saloons, and the
lead_paragraph: The sale of the household property of Mr. R. K. HAIGHT was continued yesterday at the mansion, corner of Fifth-avenue and Fifteenth-street. The catalogue, being confined to the general furniture of the house, drew together a much larger and more money gathering than attended the two previous days' sales of works of art. The rush of crinoline and broadcloth that pervaded the parlors,_the anterooms, the halls, the boudoirs, the saloons, and the various apartments, large and small, that opened to view in that princely establishment, was scarcely equaled by the grand crush in honor of Baron RENREW at the Academy of Music. As the Baron on that occasion was the "cynosure of all eyes," so was Mr. EDWARD SCHENCK, the auctioneer, on this. Fair bidders thronged around him, with anxiety in their faces and porte-monnaies in their hands; followed him to this room and to that, and were only too happy if, after the last "going," "going," "gone," they heard the announcement -- "Sold to Mrs. _____" Mr. SHENCK, it must be allowed, deported himself like a true "prince of the blood," and dispensed "bargains" with a rapidity and profusion only equaled by the liberality of his Royal prototype. The sale was admirably conducted and with a dispatch rarely equaled. Nearly $10,000 worth of furniture was disposed of between 10 and 2 o'clock. The following are some of the "bargains" secured, not a few of which, it may be safely asserted, were as much a bargain to the seller as to the buyer: Suite of ancient Milan steel armor, $335; black marble mantle-clock, mounted by a group of bronze, $205; six black walnut chairs, Paris make, $120; four carved oak bookcases, $140; four sets brocatel door curtains, $136; one set centre curtains, $100; set of ebony chairs and sofas, fourteen pieces, $300; one ebony, bronze and ormolu side meuble, $340; four French plate mirrors, $135, $125, $145 and $140; pair of equestrian bronze groups, $270; two sevres blue porcelain and ormolu vases, $160; suite of Bois deRose and ormolu furniture covered in gobelin tapestry, four chairs and a sofa, $200; two Bois deRose, ormolu and antique sevres cabinets, $320; bronze and ormolu fire irons, $102; pair of Dresden statuettes, $100; magnificent bronze; and marble clock, $185, and other articles without number at prices to match. The sale closes to-day with the disposal of the bedroom furniture on the third and fourth stories. The total amount of sales thus far exceeds $25,000.

abstract: In consequence of the informal and unauthorized announcement that Gen. LESLIE COOMBS, of Kentucky, would address the Young Men's National Union Club last evening, there was but a small attendance at Mozart Hall. Gen. COOMBS was present, however, and after briefly felicitating the meeting on the success of the Kentucky Opposition in August last, vigorously denouncing seecession, and predicting the victory of the Union Party, invited his hearers to listen to him on Wednesday evening. He said he would not speak to a corporal's guard, as he was in the habit of addressing corps de armee. He wanted to see half a million before him. He indulged in a number of patriotic reminiscences of his visit to the field of Yorktown and WASHINGTON's Head-quarters, and was particularly severe upon the Abolitionists. What the d -- l, he said, had the people of the North to do with Slavery, any how? Let them rest quiet -- the Trontier States had protected them against savage-dom, and they would protect them against Abolitionism.

abstract: At an early hour yesterday morning, William Mulligan and Patrick Mathews met at a public house in Prince-street. Each had with him several friends; and they had not long been together ere Mulligan commenced disputing with Mathews, upon whom he finally drew a pistol, with which he struck him several blows upon his sconce. This violence he accompanied by daring Mathews to fight him in any way that he liked, warning him at the same time to produce his pistol, as he intended to "blaze away." In reply, Mathews, who had meantime attempted to shield his person behind a table, called upon his friends for a pistol, stating that he was unarmed and consequently unable to defend himself, but they thought it better to prevent the fight, and the two fire-eaters were not permitted to gratify their fierce appetites. The police did not hear of the fracas, and both parties went their ways, probably with an intention to fight it out at some more convenient opportunity.

abstract: GRAND FIREMEN's RECEPTION AT POUGHKEEPSIE -- TORCHLIGHT PROCESSION, &c.. -- The firemen of Poughkeepsie have been very busy this week receiving and entertaining Lady Washington Hose Company No. 7, of New-Haven, Conn. The latter started from Hew-Haven on Tuesday morning, and arrived in New-York in time to take the steamboat Thomas Powell for Poughkeepsie. On board the boat was a new engine for Young America Engine Co. No. 6, of Poughkeepsie. On arriving at that city they were  met at the dock by the entire Fire Department, and escorted up town and through the principal streets, each fireman bearing a torch. The hose carriage of the visiting firemen is the handsomest that has ever been seen in Poughkeepsie, and attracted far more attention than the new engine. After parading, the guests were escorted to Firemen's Hall, where a splendid supper was served, after partaking of which they retired. On Wednesday morning the guests, preceded by Young America Engine Co. No. 6, with engine, paraded through the city, and returned in time to dine at the Forbus House, where the Common Council and several invited guests were ready to receive them. The afternoon was spent like the morning. On Thursday night the guests were escorted to the river by the Fire Department, when they took the boat for home, apparently well satisfied with their trip. The torchlight procession on Tuesday night was far ahead of anything of the kind ever witnessed in that city. The different houses belonging to the Department were illuminated.

On board the boat was a new engine for Young America Engine Co. No. 6, of Poughkeepsie. On arriving at that city they were met at the dock by the entire Fire Department, and escorted up town and through the principal streets, each fireman bearing a torch. The hose carriage of the visiting firemen is the handsomest that has ever been seen in Poughkeepsie, and attracted far more attention than the new engine. After parading, the guests were escorted to Firemen's Hall, where a splendid supper was served, after partaking of which they retired. On Wednesday morning the guests, preceded by Young America Engine Co. No. 6, with engine, paraded through the city, and returned in time to dine at the Forbus House, where the Common Council and several invited guests were ready to receive them. The afternoon was spent like the morning. On Thursday night the guests were escorted to the river by the Fire Department, when they took the boat for home, apparently well satisfied with their trip. The torchlight procession on Tuesday night was far ahead of anything of the kind ever witnessed in that city. The different houses belonging to the Department were illuminated.
