abstract: A meeting of the members of the Wide-Awake Central Committee was held last evening at the Republican head-quarters, No. 618 Broadway. Mr. SILAS B. DUTCHER presided. Owing to the paucity of members present, a resolution was passed directing the advertising of future meetings in additional papers to those advertised in heretofore. Several communications were received from Wide-Awake organizations in other cities, setting forth the result of their organizations. From Baltimore was received a letter announcing the establishment of a Club there and asking the transmission of a Constitution and details of uniform. The Secretary was directed to answer the letter and send on a copy of the Constitution and a sample uniform. The letter was the text of two or three spirited speeches on the growth of Republicanism in Baltimore. From the Committee of Arrangements of the recent Wide-Awake parade a verbal report was made. No further light, it was stated, had been obtained on the subject of the missing fifty barrels of oil. The financial indebtedness, it was added, was growing beautifully less. After transacting some minor business, the Committee adjourned for one week.

abstract: -- Maj.-Gen. SANFORD, of Georgia, has made a report to the Commander-in-Chief, in which he states that his command is in a state of complete disorganization, -- and he thinks that the same is true of the entire militia force of the State. This is a bad state of things for a disunion movement. He urges the Legislature to provide at once for organizing and drilling a force of at least ten thousand men. If they are in earnest in their menaces of secession, they ought by all means to act at once upon this advice.

abstract: LAYING OF A CORNER-STONE. The corner-stone of the new St. Anne's Church was laid with imposing ceremonies in the presence of 10,000 people, at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, at the corner of Front and Gold streets. Bishop McLAUGHLIN delivered the address, and there were present, assisting in the ceremonies, Rev. Father CASSIDY, KEEGAN, O'NEIL, MCGUIRE, MOICE and GLEESON, Mr. GLEESON, who is...
lead_paragraph: LAYING OF A CORNER-STONE. The corner-stone of the new St. Anne's Church was laid with imposing ceremonies in the presence of 10,000 people, at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, at the corner of Front and Gold streets. Bishop McLAUGHLIN delivered the address, and there were present, assisting in the ceremonies, Rev. Father CASSIDY, KEEGAN, O'NEIL, MCGUIRE, MOICE and GLEESON, Mr. GLEESON, who is now located at Flatbush, will take charge of the new Church. The building will be of the Gothic style of architecture of the Thirteenth Century -- basement story of blue stone with brown stone trimmings and the main walls brick. Ground size, 126 feet deep by 60 feet front on Front-street. Height to the top of the tower and spire, 135 feet; to apex of roof, 62 feet, and to the eaves 40 feet. The front of the Church will contain three doors -- the centre or the main door leading through the tower to the main aisle of the Church, and the two other doors leading each to a separate vestibule or porch. There will be no galleries except for the organ choir, which will be located in the tower. The altar will be fifteen feet long and four feet three inches wide. On each side of the main altar, and within the sanctuary rails, there will be two smaller altars or chaplains, and at the rear two rooms, one for the use of the attendants and the other for the clergymen. The land cost $15,000, and the building will cost about $22,000 more -- one half of which has already been raised, and a considerable sum was added to that yesterday. The architect is P.C. KEELEY; carpenter, MICHAEL O'BRIEN; builder, STEPHEN MARTIN.

abstract: THE WEATHER ON THE COAST. Arrivals at this port yesterday report the late northeast gale along the ceast as very heavy. The steamship Quaker City, from Havana on the 15th, reports that it blew almost a hurricane from the time she left Havana, varying from East to E.N.E. The steamer Marion, from Charleston, experienced a continuous gale, and had portions of her wheel-house and bulwarks carried away by the sea.
lead_paragraph: THE WEATHER ON THE COAST. Arrivals at this port yesterday report the late northeast gale along the ceast as very heavy. The steamship Quaker City, from Havana on the 15th, reports that it blew almost a hurricane from the time she left Havana, varying from East to E.N.E. The steamer Marion, from Charleston, experienced a continuous gale, and had portions of her wheel-house and bulwarks carried away by the sea. The ships arriving from the Eastward report the gale as the heaviest of the season. The steamers from the South, mentioned as overdue have arrived, and all make the same report of the gale along the coast. The Plymouth Rock, Connecticut, and Elm City, anchored in Cow Bay, where they remained at 6 o'clock yesterday morning. The other Sound steamers from the East arrived in due season. The steamer Montgomery, from Savannah, and Jamestown, from Norfolk, had not arrived last evening. At sunset last night a dense fog set in below with considerable rain. The steamships Vanderbilt for Havre, Parkersburg, for Wilmington N.C., Monticello, for Washington D.C., and Georges Creek, for Baltimore, all proceeded to sea from Quarantine at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. The City of Baltimore sailed from S.W. Spit at noon.

abstract: There was a large gathering of Republicans last Friday evening in Mills' Hall, Washington Heights, to listen to addresses from Hon. WILLIAM CURTIS NOYES and Hon. ABRAM WAKEMAN. The speeches were long and able, and called out the enthusiasm of those present in a remarkable degree. Mr. SHEPHERD KNAPP, one of the oldest and most influential residents on Washington Heights, was called for, and in a few words declared his intention to vote for Mr. LINCOLN and Mr. WAKEMAN. Songs were sung by the Rocky Mountain Glee Club, and the citizens dispersed, well pleased.

abstract: The Prince of Wales on Saturday finished his tour in America, and embarked for home. The Royal party left Boston in the forenoon in a special train for Portland, accompanied by Gov. BANKS, Mayor LINCOLN, Hon. CHARLES SUMNER, Hon. HENRY WILSON, Hon. ANSON BURNINGAME, and other distinguished personages.
lead_paragraph: The Prince of Wales on Saturday finished his tour in America, and embarked for home. The Royal party left Boston in the forenoon in a special train for Portland, accompanied by Gov. BANKS, Mayor LINCOLN, Hon. CHARLES SUMNER, Hon. HENRY WILSON, Hon. ANSON BURNINGAME, and other distinguished personages. They reached Portland about 2 o'clock P.M., after receiving the heartiest ovations of Salem, Newburyport, Portsmouth, and other places along the route, and were received by the Mayor and Councils of the City, and escorted by the military through the principal streets of the City to the wharf built for the accommodation of the Great Eastern, when they embarked amid salvos of artillery and bursts of martial music. The Prince and his suite before their departure expressed themselves in terms of the highest gratification at the manner in which they were treated in the United States.

abstract: Our enterprising Mayor is in constant danger of burning his fingers from the number of irons which he will persist in attempting to keep hot at the same time. But we have now to notice an iron of great length and size which he has been fully successful in heating, and which is soon to be applied as a hissing cautery to the most sensitive part of our body politic.
lead_paragraph: Our enterprising Mayor is in constant danger of burning his fingers from the number of irons which he will persist in attempting to keep hot at the same time. But we have now to notice an iron of great length and size which he has been fully successful in heating, and which is soon to be applied as a hissing cautery to the most sensitive part of our body politic. In this enterprise the Mayor acts in concert with two new partners -- verdant countrymen from Westchester -- who may little suspect the purpose to which they are lending themselves. But in the background of the scene, the usual cohort of City operators may be recognized, and the scheme, if successful, must result in the illegal extortion from the public treasury of a sum not less than five hundred thousand dollars.

abstract: Messrs. PHELAN & COLLENDER have offered for competition among the professional billiard players of the United States, a splendid gold-mounted billiard cue, to be played for on the following terms: Each player will contend against each other player in a four-ball carom game of 250 points; and he that wins the greatest number of games wins the prize cue, and afterwards plays a game of 500 points with Mr. PHELAN. For this tournament, Messrs. KAVANAGH, LYNCH, WHITE and CLEVELAND, of New-York, and BIRD of Philadelphia, and TIEMAN of Cincinnati, have entered their names. Several other celebrities are expected, among whom may be GEORGE SERREITER. The games will occupy eight days, and will be played in some convenient place, yet to be selected. Admission will only be attainable by complimentary tickets.

abstract: In the township of Goshen, N.Y., -- a land "flowing with milk and honey," -- where the Republicans have had hard work to cope with a Democratic majority in town and county, (though not in the Congressional District,) a splendid demonstration was planned for Saturday last, including speeches by Ex-Governor, and newly chosen United States Senator, SALMON P. CHASE, of Ohio, WM. CURTIS NOYES, Esq., and an extensive parade of the Wide-Awake Clubs of the county. As a jubilant Democrat remarked,"Providence didn't seem to favor the movement," as the rain poured down all day. As a Republican retorted, however, "Pennsylvania, Ohio and Indiana are in favor of the movement," so that the interruption of this one manifestation may be excused. The contemplated open-air meeting was abandoned, and the Town Hall was substituted as the place for the speaking.

abstract: Rogues are prolific in devices wherewith to accomplish their dishonest plans. On Tuesday night last one of the fraternity named Thomas Devoy alias Watson, called at the basement door of the residence...
lead_paragraph: Rogues are prolific in devices wherewith to accomplish their dishonest plans. On Tuesday night last one of the fraternity named Thomas Devoy alias Watson, called at the basement door of the residence of Mr. George Kenny, No. 119 Second-avenue, and asked to see Maria Reardon, the servant girl, stating that he had a letter for her which required an answer. He was ushered by the wondering damsel into the back kitchen, where, being unable to read herself, she invited her visitor to decipher the epistle. To do this was just what he desired, as he left the door unsecured that a confederate might enter and plunder the house, while he engaged her attention. The noise made by rogue No. 2 in prosecuting his search of the beaufet excited the young woman's suspicions, and, in spite of Devoy's efforts to prevent her, she got into the front basement in time to see the thief "bag" a lot of silver-ware and run out of the door. She pursued him and seized him by the leg as he was passing through the area gate, and he endeavored to make her release her hold by striking her a heavy blow in the face with his bag of silver-ware. He did not succeed in this, however, and he only escaped by slipping out of his coat, the collar of which garment Maria had meantime tenaciously grasped. The other rogue came up while the contest was raging, and also attempted to run past the girl into the street. This, like his confederate, he succeeded in doing, leaving his coat as a trophy in the hands of the courageous young woman, who, having gathered the spoils, including the bag of silver-ware, straightway went to the office of the Detective Police, and gave a description of the thieves. On Saturday night Detectives Farley and Slowey effected the arrest of both the accused -- the name of Devoy's companion in the robbery being William Beatty alias Thompson. Yesterday the prisoners were taken before Justice QUACKENBUSH, who committed them for trial.

abstract: The Breckinridge Democrats in this State are playing rather a shrewd game in the pending canvass. Mr. JAMES T. BRADY, who is stumping the State, ostensibly for the Fusion ticket, is very careful to let it be distinctly understood on what grounds his support of that ticket is based. We give in another column a report of his speech at Binghamton, in which he denounces DOUGLAS as a traitor to the principles of the Democratic Party, and sets forth the Breckinridge platform as the only one on which the Democratic Party can stand hereafter. Supporting the Fusion ticket, he says, cannot help DOUGLAS, while it will keep the organization of the party in the hands of the Breckinridge men and give them control of the National Democracy in 1864. The Breckinridge State ticket, says Mr. BRADY, is to be kept in the field at all hazards: -- and being its candidate for Governor, he ought to know.

abstract: On Saturday forenoon, Col. THOMAS, of the head-quarters of the Army in this City, accompanied by Brevet-Maj. Porter, visited Governor's Island for the purpose of inspecting a large detachment of United States troops, destined to leave in the California steamer to-day. The men, numbering about 230, were...
lead_paragraph: On Saturday forenoon, Col. THOMAS, of the head-quarters of the Army in this City, accompanied by Brevet-Maj. Porter, visited Governor's Island for the purpose of inspecting a large detachment of United States troops, destined to leave in the California steamer to-day. The men, numbering about 230, were drawn up in front of the barracks, and seemed to be a fine, healthy set of fellows, nearly all being above the middle height. They were minutely examined by the Colonel, who subsequently proceeded to inspect the baggage, equipment, &c. The officers ordered to accompany the detachment were on the ground, and the final preparations for departure were completed. This forenoon they will be marched to the steamer that is to carry them to their destination. These troops are for short companies of the Sixth Infantry. Their officers are Capt. WALLEN, Capt. HENDRICKSON, Lieuts. HARVEY, LINEILAR, LANDERS, FOSTER, ANDREWS, MARTIN, MARSH and VANDERBILT. On reporting to the Commandant of the Presideo, at San Francisco, they will be supplied with such fresh stores as may be required, the Department providing the necessaries for the journey. One hundred additional soldiers for Companies A, B, K and F, of the First Dragoons, now stationed at Forts Tegon, Crook and Churchill, will be dispatched on the 11th of next month. All the officers to accompany them are not yet detailed. The Island will be very dull after the exit of these recruits.

lead_paragraph: The army of Song has broken into two divisions. The first, or German division, under the command of CARL FORMES, takes the field on Wednesday, and opens in "Robert le Diable. This corps contains STIGELLI, FABERI, VAN BERKEL, and, it is said, ADELAIDE PHILLIPS. Mr. ULLMAN lends the dignity of his name, but takes no pecuniary interest in the enterprise, beyond the agreeable one of receiving his rent, and reposing in a condition of lucrative taciturnity for a time.

abstract: -- THE PRINCE OF WALES AND Mr. BROWN's PICTURE. -- All true amateurs of American art will be at once pleased and pained to learn that Mr. GEO. L. BROWN's striking and beautiful picture of the "Bay and City of New-York," of which we have already spoken in these columns as its excellence deserves, has been purchased for the Prince of Wales, and that it will be exhibited in this City but a short time longer before its final departure to grace the walls of Buckingham Palace with a vision not more brilliant than accurate of our own imperial City. A more appropriate souvenir of the visit of England's heir to the great City of the West could not be imagined, and American art may justly pride itself on a painting which will prove to England and Englishmen not only that New-York is one of the most picturesque and glorious capitals of civilization, but also that the material prosperity of the New World has given birth to aesthetic genius not less remarkable than the other qualities which all the world unites in according us, and abundantly able to do justice to the ideal beauty of the land.

abstract: On Friday evening, PATRICK DONOHUE, a laboring man, residing in the upper part of the City, while on his way home from work, in company with a fellow-laborer named McKENNA, went into the porterhouse at the corner of Hudson and Thirteenth streets, kept by JAMES McCAULEY. After having partaken of...
lead_paragraph: On Friday evening, PATRICK DONOHUE, a laboring man, residing in the upper part of the City, while on his way home from work, in company with a fellow-laborer named McKENNA, went into the porterhouse at the corner of Hudson and Thirteenth streets, kept by JAMES McCAULEY. After having partaken of refreshments, one of the men challenged his companion to a wrestling match, and the gauntlet was accepted. A scuffle of some moments' duration resulted in MCKENNA's fall, with considerable violence, to the floor, and his defeat irritated him so much that he made an attempt to gouge out an eye of his opponent. The bystanders, however, prevented further violent demonstrations, and the proprietor of the saloon insisted that both men should go away from his place, and this they finally did. Presently, however, DONOHUE came back, and, after the lapse of a short interval, MCKENNA also returned. He immediately went towards DONOHUE, remarking that it was foolish to indulge in feelings of animosity for so trivial a cause; that he was wrong in giving way to his temper, and he desired to make up and be friends again. While making these professions, however, he was possessed with the purpose of an assassin, for as soon as he had approached near enough to reach DONOHUE, he pulled a knife from beneath his coat-sleeve and made a lunge at his throat. The blade entered the neck of the unsuspecting man, who fell bleeding profusely from the wound. His assailant immediately made his way towards a side door, brandishing his weapon, and threatening to murder any person who attempted to prevent his escape. DONOHUE was taken by the witnesses of the assault to a neighboring drug store, where his wound was staunched, and afterwards he was removed to his residence. The police of the Ninth Precinct were notified of the occurrence, and a pursuit for MCKENNA was at once entered upon, but so far it has not resulted in his arrest. It subsequently transpired that during the time MCKENNA was absent from the porter-house, he had gone into a grocery store near by and stolen the knife with which he attempted the assassination of his victim.

abstract: -- The following paragraph in the Charleston Mercury of the 17th, gives the probable denouement of the excitement which disturbed the citizens in the interior of South Carolina a few days since: "From Cheraw we learn that the two HITCHINGS, concerning whose arrest and trial as Abolition incendiaries a full account was published in the Mercury of Saturday, had been duly convicted and sentenced to be hung on Friday next. Additional and crushing evidence had been adduced to prove their complicity in an insurrectionary plot, and this sealed their doom. At last accounts, 'Minute-Men' were actively forming in Cheraw and the vicinity."

abstract: In presenting some practical difficulties in the way of a successful attempt at disunion, the other day, we assumed that only six Southern States, viz.: South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi Florida and Texas, would attempt to secede.
lead_paragraph: In presenting some practical difficulties in the way of a successful attempt at disunion, the other day, we assumed that only six Southern States, viz.: South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi Florida and Texas, would attempt to secede. We feel warranted in this assumption by the fact that the leading politicians of the Northern Slave States have taken decided ground in favor of adhering to the Union until "an overt act" of invading Southern rights is committed by a Republican President. There is nothing in this position inconsistent with the sincerest devotion to the Union; for who will be so unreasonable, and so faithless to the principles of Republican liberty, as to maintain that the States must submit to the overthrow of their constitutional rights by the Federal Government? It is true that men may differ as to what will be "an overt act" of invasion, but an agreement in advance to remain in the Union until the Federal Government transcends its constitutional power, is all that any fair-minded Republican could ask of the South or the North. Whether peaceful secession, or simple revolution, be the "rightful remedy" of the States, is a question involving constitutional niceties which we will not now attempt to settle; but certainly no sound Republican will maintain that the States must remain passive while their local sovereignty is being overthrown, and the Confederacy converted into a consolidated despotism.

abstract: Our correspondent, writing from Havana on the 15th inst., denies that Spain is making any hostile preparations for the invasion of Mexico. A rumor, as our readers know, has been in circulation for some time, to the effect that Spain is organizing a corps d'armee at Havana, and that her very obvious design is to interfere in behalf of despotism between the belligerent factions of the Mexican Republic. Our correspondent denies the truth of this rumor most emphatically, and as he has every facility to make himself acquainted with the fact, if fact it be, we take it for granted that no such hostile demonstration as the one alluded to is actively going on.

abstract: The earthquake was very violent here, in fact more so than any which has occurred in Canada since 1863, when mountains were displaced, river courses changed, waters discolored, and the trees so shaken that the Indians, seeing their strange motions, said the forests were drunk and the trees at war. Yesterday's quaking commenced at five minutes to 6 A.M.

abstract: -- We are pained to learn that on Wednesday evening, when near the forty-mile station, the locomotive Cherokee exploded, seriously and perhaps fatally injuring Mr. BROWN, a conductor; Mr. GEO. FOX, the engineer, and a fireman whose name we could not ascertain. The locomotive was attached to a freight-train, and when near the station alluded to the engineer discovered that there was not sufficient water in the tender to last until the next tank was reached. The engine and tender were uncoupled, and Mr. BROWN mounting the locomotive, it started. It had proceeded but a short distance when the explosion occurred, shattering the locomotive to fragments, and throwing some portions of it a great distance. Only the wheels were left whole. The unfortunate persons upon the car were severely injured, as before stated, and it is singular that they were not instantly killed. -- Charleston Mercury.
lead_paragraph: -- We are pained to learn that on Wednesday evening, when near the forty-mile station, the locomotive Cherokee exploded, seriously and perhaps fatally injuring Mr. BROWN, a conductor; Mr. GEO. abstract: -- A correspondent urges upon us an elaborate explanation of the absolute denial given by two "clergymen in charge of Trinity Church," to our statement that a fulsome puff of a singing boy was put forward in the programme of services prepared at that Church for the occasion of the Prince of Wales' visit. It seems that the puff and the programme in question were written out in full by some authority of the Church, for the benefit not of the Prince in his pew, but of the whole public. They were furnished to the Reporters of the Press, of course, for the express purpose of improving the opportunity to make known to all mankind that a particular boy in the choir of Trinity possesses a voice of "extraordinary power and splendor." This explanation, while it relieves the "clergymen in charge of Trinity Church" from the serious imputation of flatly contradicting us upon absolutely insufficient grounds, perfectly bears out our original statement, and warrants the general criticism passed by public opinion upon the general spirit and temper of the "religious ovation" offered to our Royal English visitor upon the occasion in question. This criticism has nowhere been more curtly or sharply expressed than in the columns of our Anglican cotemporary, the Albion. It is indeed the criticism of common sense as well as of true religious feeling, and it is idle to discuss in detail a matter about which in the main very little difference of opinion is to be looked for in any quarter.

abstract: To the Editor of the Constitution:  Your paper for a few days past has forcibly re-  minded me of the days of President JACKSON, when AMOS KENDALL was the theme of a thousand scribblers. Circumstances, however, have somewhat changed. Then he was abused by the enemies of the Old Hero and of his Administration; now by the organ of an Administration which claims to be his friends. Who has changed? Is it AMOS KENDALL,
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, October, 1860.

abstract: -- The Sandusky (Ohio) papers give some further particulars of the kidnapping of six negroes in that place. The Register says: "The following were the persons kidnapped: HENRY BURNS, wife and one child. It is claimed here that the woman was free. THOS. MARSHALL, wife and one child. The children were each about six months old, and were born in Ohio. They first came here in December last, as we are told, and some time during the Winter rented thirty acres of wild land for five years, put up cabins, and moved on to it in March last. In the Spring they cleared seven acres and put out crops, and the cultivated land is now covered with a fine crop of corn, &c., sufficient for their Winter's supply. Several of our citizens have visited the place, and they report that everything looks as though they had been industrious and were very comfortably situated. There fare other negro cabins in the neighborhood -- none close by -- and no whites living near. The colored man who heard Mrs. BURNS crying as she was being dragged over the fence and who shot at the kidnapper, was probably the first one of the neighbors aroused, and the first to give the alarm.

abstract: It is now quite clear to the intelligent observer of passing events that Mr. DOUGLAS will not receive an electoral vote. The lugubrious tone of his domestic organ, the Chicago Times, in its appeals for succor to the adherents of BRECKINRIDGE and BELL, would alone satisfy us that his hopes of carrying his own State are faint indeed. But we have a positive as-
lead_paragraph: It is now quite clear to the intelligent observer of passing events that Mr. DOUGLAS will not receive an electoral vote. The lugubrious tone of his domestic organ, the Chicago Times, in its appeals for succor to the adherents of BRECKINRIDGE and BELL, would alone satisfy us that his hopes of carrying his own State are faint indeed. But we have a positive assurance from intelligent sources that the Republican majority in Illinois will be overwhelming. Prior to the October elections the Republicans in that State anticipated a handsome victory; but the impetus given to the cause in all the free States, by the splendid examples set by Pennsylvania, Ohio, and Indiana, induces the least sanguine to anticipate a majority of fifteen or twenty thousand, and some go much higher in their estimates.

abstract: The grand torch-light procession of the Anti-Lincoln men takes place to-night. There is promise of a very imposing display. Forming in the lower part of the City, the procession, at a signal to be given by "the Empire Pocket-Piece," will march in eight divisions from the City Hall through Broadway, Fourteenth-street, Fifth-avenue, Twenty-sixth-street, Madison-avenue, Twenty-third-street, Fourth-avenue, the Bowery and Chatham-street, to the Park, where it will be dismissed. If the evening is unpleasant the affair will be postponed. The expenses of the pageant have been large, and the indications are that Capt. RYNDERS will be compelled to bear them all. He certainly deserves well of those whose cause he serves for the efforts which he has put forth in behalf of the demonstration of to-night.

abstract: The census is furnishing another impressive lesson to the South on the ruinous effects of Slavery upon her commercial and manufacturing enterprises; and if the most prejudiced or the least intelligent votary of the peculiar institution can cherish the hope of seeing Southern cities rival those of the North in wealth and importance, after the results of this enumeration are made known, the fact will prove that the Pro-Slavery mania is as benumbing to the understanding as the most degrading form of religious superstition. Our attention has been drawn to this subject by statements which we meet with in Southern newspapers, of the ascertained population of Richmond and Charleston, and more particularly the latter. The career of these places furnishes the best test of the effects of Slavery upon the population and wealth of commercial and manufacturing cities, for the reason that they are located in communities which make Slavery the predominant interest.
lead_paragraph: The census is furnishing another impressive lesson to the South on the ruinous effects of Slavery upon her commercial and manufacturing enterprises; and if the most prejudiced or the least intelligent votary of the peculiar institution can cherish the hope of seeing Southern cities rival those of the North in wealth and importance, after the results of this enumeration are made known, the fact will prove that the Pro-Slavery mania is as benumbing to the understanding as the most degrading form of religious superstition. abstract: This Board met last evening, the President in the Chair, and transacted a large amount of routine business. Among the reports from the Board of Aldermen concurred in, was one in favor of paving East Broadway from Chatham-square to Grand-street with Belgian pavement, and one for paving Broadway from Seventeenth-street to Madison-square with trap-block pavement. A resolution to furnish Hose Company No. 16 with a new carriage was adopted. The Board adjourned to Thursday next.

abstract: The return game between these two Clubs was played yesterday on the Atlantic's ground, Bedford, and resulted in a victory for the Eckfords, as follows: Atlantic, 15; Eckford, 20. The game and field were conducted in the most friendly manner, and the conquering game will be played next Monday on the Putnam's ground. Threatening as the weather was, between three and four thousand persons were present.

abstract: ORDINANCES. -- Some years ago, during the Mayoralty of Mr. KINGSLAND, an ordinance was passed imposing a penalty of $250 on the interment of any party in any vault or cemetery below Forty-second-street, and many respectable families who own vaults in Trinity, St. Paul's, or St. John's, as well as in other burial grounds, readily paid the amount for the privilege. Last evening, the Aldermen passed a resolution authorizing the Pastor of the Catholic Church in Twenty-eighth-street to open the receiving-vault attached to that edifice, and in so doing the Board openly violated the ordinance referred to. The resolution was doubtless passed for political effect; but we trust that, if the Councilmen are as reckless as their Aldermanic confreres in defying City ordinances, the measure will be peremptorily vetoed by the Mayor as contrary to law.

The resolution was doubtless passed for political effect; but we trust that, if the Councilmen are as reckless as their Aldermanic confreres in defying City ordinances, the measure will be peremptorily vetoed by the Mayor as contrary to law.

abstract: None of the political meetings, for which Cooper Institute has of late become famous, have attracted larger gatherings than assembled there last evening. It was the occasion of the eighth anniversary celebration of Metropolitan (Masonic) Lodge No. 273. The...
lead_paragraph: None of the political meetings, for which Cooper Institute has of late become famous, have attracted larger gatherings than assembled there last evening. It was the occasion of the eighth anniversary celebration of Metropolitan (Masonic) Lodge No. 273. The ladies constituted more than half the audience, and the majority of those of the sterner sex who succeeded in gaining admission were unable to obtain seats. At 7 1/2 o'clock the Grand Lodge of the Most Ancient and Honorable Fraternity of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New-York, under the escort of Columbian, Morton, Clinton, Palestine, Coeur de Lion, and De Witt Clinton Commanderies Knights Templar, entered the Hall in the following order: Columbian Commandery, No. 1, Eminent Sir R.B. Atterbury, Commander; Morton Commandery, No. 4, Eminent Sir N.O. Benjamin, Commander; Clinton Commandery, No. 14. Eminent Sir Bradley Parker, Commander; Palestine Commandery, No. 18, Eminent Sir E.P. Breed, Commander; Coeur de Lion Commandery, No. 23, Eminent Sir H.F.L. Bunting, Commander; De Witt Clinton Commandery, No. 27, Eminent Sir Thos. T. May, Commander. As the Grand Lodge entered, Dodworth's Band, which in full force was stationed on the platform, performed a grand march. The members of the Lodge, who were clad in their regalias, took seats on the platform where already were stationed the choir of the Cooper Union ranged near one of CHICKERING's grand pianos. The decorations of the stage were simply a scroll formed of gas jets, with the words, "Sit Lux et Lux Fuit," suspended midway between the ceiling and the platform, and the banners of the Lodge.

abstract: POLITICAL. -- A Republican meeting was held last evening in the Fulton-street Wigwam, when addresses were made by Hon. JAMES DUNN, of Elmira, STEWART L. WOODFORD, Esq., of New-York, and others. A meeting was also held in Front-street by the Second Ward Republican Club, when addresses were made by Col. JESSE C. SMITH, and Col. C.J. JACK. On Saturday evening a large Republican meeting was held at the Bath House, Gravesend, when addresses were made by JOSEPH HOXIE and the Hon. J.A. BRIGGS.

abstract: The ship Black Hawk, of Newburyport, Capt. THURLOW, which sailed from Calcutta April 1 for Boston, and which has been overdue for some time was undoubtedly lost in a heavy gale in Bengal Bay April 5, and all on board perished. The only information in regard to her fate is furnished by a seaman named JOHN LALOR, who arrived at this port in the ship Mattapan, from Calcutta, although a similar statement was received here some months since from Calcutta. He states that he was on board the British ship Geologist. from London for Calcutta, and when in the Bay of Bengal on the 4th of April last, they signalized the American ship Black Hawk, from Calcutta for Boston.

abstract: -- We understand that J.P. O'SULLIVAN, Esq., Consul for the United States at Singapore, is about to leave us for his own country, having taken his passage for Boston in the ship Boruco. Mr. O'SULLIVAN will carry home with him the best wishes of this community. During his residence among us he has succeeded in gaining the respect and esteem of all classes, not only from the efficient discharge of his official duties, but also his uniform courtesy and urbanity in his social relations. -- Singapore Journal of Commerce.

abstract: A meeting of the National Union Convention was held last evening at Thorpe's Hotel, corner of Broadway and Eighth-street. The principal business of the meeting was to hear the report of the Committee appointed to confer with Committees from the Tammany and Mozart Conventions, with a view to the harmonious action of the three bodies, and also to nominate a Judge for the Superior Court. Mr. W.T. JENNINGS, chairman of the Conference Committee, reported that both the Mozart and Tammany Conventions had adjourned sine die without appointing committees to confer with that from the Union body.

abstract: Last evening thee was a special meeting of the Board of Representatives of the New-York Fire Department, held at Fireman's Hall, in Mercer-street, for the purpose of making arrangements for the concert and dramatic performance to be given for the benefit of the widow and Orphan Fund. There...
lead_paragraph: Last evening thee was a special meeting of the Board of Representatives of the New-York Fire Department, held at Fireman's Hall, in Mercer-street, for the purpose of making arrangements for the concert and dramatic performance to be given for the benefit of the widow and Orphan Fund. There were 2,110 tickets distributed among the representatives of the Department. Resolutions were offered by Judge PHILIPS, of Engine Co. No. 40, to the effect that as the funds of the widow and orphan were getting low and needed an increase, a Committee of Three be appointed by the President for the purpose of procuring a lecturer to deliver a course of lectures in the Hall of the Department during the Winter, the proceeds to be appropriated to the Fund of said Department. It is thought that the lectures will be delivered by Hon. EDWARD EVERETT and JAMES T. BRADY. Another resolution, by Mr. JOHN C. SMITH, to the effect that fifteen members of the Board of Representatives be appointed by the President, consisting of six from engine companies, five from hose companies, and four from hook and ladder companies, to report to the Board, at their earliest convenience, such alterations as may be deemed necessary to submit to the State Legislature for the better regulation and government of the Fire Department. Both resolutions were adopted.

abstract: Among the first papers adopted was a resolution allowing the pastor of St. Stephen's Catholic Church in Twenty-eighth-street, to deposit the bodies of parties, whose friends might desire to have them placed there, in the receiving vault of that Church. There is an ordinance prohibiting the...
lead_paragraph: Among the first papers adopted was a resolution allowing the pastor of St. Stephen's Catholic Church in Twenty-eighth-street, to deposit the bodies of parties, whose friends might desire to have them placed there, in the receiving vault of that Church. There is an ordinance prohibiting the opening of any vault or the digging of any grave, for the purposes of interment, below Forty-second-street, the penalty being $250, which has been often paid by the friends of deceased parties, whom they desired to have interred in family vaults. This resolution, however, gives to the pastor of this Church the privilege of interment, there being no provision as to the time during which bodies may be allowed to repose there.

abstract: The measure of the civilization of a people is said to be "the interest which the powerful take in the weak". When the upper classes of a community are found providing for the benefit of the lower classes, affording them education or opportunities of improvement, and even putting themselves to trouble for the sake of those less fortunate, we at once know what degree of culture and humanity those things indicate.
lead_paragraph: The measure of the civilization of a people is said to be "the interest which the powerful take in the weak". abstract: There is a good deal of talk about these days of the importance of preserving the integrity of the judiciary by nominating and electing honest and capable men as judges. Nor is too much importance likely to be attached to this, or too much care and labor likely to be bestowed upon it in the coming election. But...
lead_paragraph: There is a good deal of talk about these days of the importance of preserving the integrity of the judiciary by nominating and electing honest and capable men as judges. Nor is too much importance likely to be attached to this, or too much care and labor likely to be bestowed upon it in the coming election. But even if the exertions which are being made should be successful, and none but honest and capable judges chosen, the people must not think that they thereby insure honesty and justice in the business of the Courts. The jury is still an important element in them, and that too will need watching. We have not found it entirely free from suspicion heretofore. Fraud and rascality have infinite variety, and when driven from one place, are sure to appear elsewhere. Eternal vigilance is the price of honesty as well as of liberty.

abstract: Judge CROSBY arrived in this city, from the East, last Saturday, at midnight. The Judge came by the mail carriage as far as Echo Canon, where it is reported the mail driver managed somehow to get half seas over, and so far quarrelsome as to delay the  mail, and stab an emigrant, wounding him severely,  but not fatally. The Judge completed his journey in company with Mr. G.W. MYERS, a mail station employe.

abstract: The French Theatre in Broadway was last night filled with a cordial and good-natured audience assembled to surrender up their senses to a fair enchantress. To the "natural magic" of a graceful person, bright eyes, and an eloquent smile, Mlle. VICTORIA, the "Queen of Black Arts," unites all the skill in artificial witchcraft which ROBERT HOUDIN could communicate to an apt pupil. The programme of Mile. VICTORIA was full of the most agreeable tours de force, which were executed with a pretty ease and received with hearty applause. She emptied cannon-balls out of hats, turned empty air into fragrant flowers and toothsome bon-bons, distributed flags, fans, and bouquets, and made herself generally demonological and entertaining. If she could but perform the stupendous trick of infusing a little vivacity and activity into her assistants, she might take her place unchallenged at the head of her art. As it is, her performances and herself are both well worth the seeing.

abstract: -- We have already alluded to the diplomatic rupture between Spain and Venezuela, and this morning furnish, through our Havana correspondence, full particulars of the dispute. The Spanish demands were, in the first place, that the assassins of Spanish subjects should be delivered to the tribunals for trial, and, in the second, that they should be indemnified for all losses sustained during the civil commotions. The first demand was readily granted, but, to the second, the Venezuelan Government replied that civil war was a calamity for the results of which it could not be held responsible. Venezuela, it seems, did all she could consistent with her honor and independence to bring about a peaceable adjustment of the dispute; but the Spanish Minister, under positive instructions from home, demanded his passports and left the country. The peremptory attitude of Spain in this Venezuelan affair, added to her Mexican schemes and interference in San Domingo, strengthens the belief that she is making great efforts to reestablish an ascendancy in the American continent, and perhaps reconquer some of her lost possessions.
lead_paragraph: -- We have already alluded to the diplomatic rupture between Spain and Venezuela, and this morning furnish, through our Havana correspondence, full particulars of the dispute. abstract: GEORGE SENECA, of Princess Anne County, Va., was arrested in New-Orleans a few days since charged with swindling Capt. F.W.O. BROWN, of this City, out of $2,000. On the 20th of March last Capt. BROWN was in Cardenas, Island of Cuba, with his brig Emily, where he made the acquaintance of a Virginian calling himself SAMUEL M. BROCK, a tall, good-looking man, with a long, heavy, dark beard, sprucely dressed, and of agreeable, insinuating address. BROCK represented himself to have been engaged in the African Slave-trade, but having lost his vessel and cargo by capture, was remaining in Cardenas awaiting remittances from L.H. CHANDLER & Co., of Norfolk, who he said were his merchants. BROCK won the confidence of Capt. BROWN completely, and pretending that he was possessed of ample means, he induced the Captain to foot his rather extensive bills in Cardenas, furnish him with a handsome outfit of clothing, and give him a passage home. On the voyage home the brig Emily was wrecked, and they got into Nassau, where Capt. BROWN furnished BROCK with another outfit. They could not get a passage North, but took passage on a ship to this city. Here they boarded at the St. Louis Hotel, Mrs. JENKINS' boarding-house, and at the Verandah Hotel, the generous Captain footing all the bills, as usual, while BROCK showed him letters pretending to be from Virginia merchants, in which they promised remittances. Capt. BROWN's suspicions were finally arroused, and he started North to make inquiries about his friend. Arriving at Norfolk he found some persons who had had a slight and exceedingly unfortunate acquaintance with an individual answering to the description of BROCK, whose real name they said was GEORGE SENECA. Capt. BROWN immediately returned to New-Orleans, found SENECA and had him arrested, but whether he will recover any of his money remains to be seen.

abstract: -- Our Havana correspondent transmits information that proves how utterly futile are the attempts to extinguish the Slave trade under the present regulations. Though a large American, English, and Spanish fleet is keeping constant watch upon the movements of the traders, and the Captain-General has undertaken in earnest to punish the Spanish authorities in Cuba who connive at the traffic, yet it flourishes more than ever. It is estimated that, during nine months of the current year, 30,000 Africans have been landed on the Island and even steamships are now engaged in the prosecution of the business. Every year more capital and more energy are employed in the Slave-trade, and the more vessels that are captured the more would seem to be started on this barbarous and inhuman venture. Our correspondent affirms that the names of highly respectable merchants, both in the United States and in Europe, are mentioned in connection with the Cuban Slave-trade, and he presents such a picture of its prosperous condition as to make the philanthropist despair of ever seeing it abandoned. It certainly never will be abandoned as long as its control remains with the Spanish Government. If Spain ever had any serious determination to enforce her own laws against the Slave-trade it would not now be the blot on her civilization that it is. Experience has proved that a blockade of the Coast of Africa is an impossibility, and as English or American cruisers cannot follow slavers into Spanish waters, their presence in the vicinity of Cuba and Porto Rico is almost useless. The only means by which the Slave-trade can be arrested has been often pointed out. A rigorous and faithful execution of the laws against the Slave-trade in the Island of Cuba would soon render its prosecution impossible; but Spain shirks this responsibility, and will never carry out measures that may check the prosperity of her dependency unless compelled to do so by more powerful reasoning than the moral suasion of England or the United States.

abstract: The books for personal taxes were opened yesterday at the office of Receiver of Taxes, and although it was only personal property on which taxes were to be paid, the amount received was beyond the average of any previous year, reaching the sum of $184,961 40. The books of taxation on real estate will not be ready until next Saturday, when of course, the daily amount of receipts will be largely increased. The increase of valuation in the real and personal property of the City for 1860, amounts to the sum of $25,207,934 97, which reduces the apparent taxation, but in reality increases it, for those who pay taxes only on the valuation of last year escape the imposition of the increase which must be made up by those who are so unfortunate as to own property which is considered as having increased in value. The decrease in real estate is confined to the First, Second and Ninth Wards, amounting to $825,018 -- while the increase in the other Wards amounts to $20,307,107. On personal estate, the only increase is on that of non-residents, which has advanced from $163,575,875 in 1859, to $173,697,037 97 in 1860, being an increase of $5,725,845.

abstract: A fire broke out between 3 and 4 o'clock yesterday morning, in the centre of the group of structures, known as "Townsend's Block," located between Broadway and Sixth-avenue, and Thirty-fifth and Thirty-sixth streets. The flames were first seen issu-
lead_paragraph: A fire broke out between 3 and 4 o'clock yesterday morning, in the centre of the group of structures, known as "Townsend's Block," located between Broadway and Sixth-avenue, and Thirty-fifth and Thirty-sixth streets. The flames were first seen issuing from the furniture-store, No. 605 Sixth-avenue, situated in the centre of the block, and occupied by GEORGE KARNER. Notwithstanding the fact that the firemen soon commenced operations, the fire could not be checked, and the buildings on either side were quickly in a blaze, while in less than half-an-hour after the discovery of the flames the whole of the middle part of the block, extending through from Sixth-avenue to Broadway, was burned down. It was only through the extraordinary exertions of the firemen that the tenements fronting on Thirty-fifth and Thirty-sixth streets were saved, and thus a great deal of misery spared the poor people who live in them. As it was, however, more than twenty poor families were rendered homeless, and in some instances penniless, having had barely time enough to leave their beds and escape in their night-clothes, the fire sweeping along so rapidly. The entire loss will probably not exceed $10,000, the buildings being considered of comparatively little value. They were erected by Mr. D.F. MAURICE soon after the opening of the Crystal Palace, and soon afterwards leased to Mr. SAMUEL P. TOWNSEND, who has since retained control of them. It is probable that the owner will now raze what remains of the block, and erect on the site of the present structures houses which will prove better paying property. How the fire originated has not been ascertained, but the Fire Marshal will prosecute an investigation.

abstract: A week or two ago Michael Geraty, a pilot, of St. Johns, Newfoundland, while taking a vessel to sea, passed his station boat, and had no alternative but to go on to Boston, whither the craft was bound.
lead_paragraph: A week or two ago Michael Geraty, a pilot, of St. Johns, Newfoundland, while taking a vessel to sea, passed his station boat, and had no alternative but to go on to Boston, whither the craft was bound. On Thursday last he came to this City to take passage on a vessel about to depart to St. Johns, and in the interval before she sailed he took board at the sailor's boarding-house kept by Thomas Hadden, to which he had been recommended. On Friday, it is said, Hadden induced the unwary pilot to accompany him on board a ship which lay in the stream, and then told him to consider himself shipped for the voyage. Geraty protested that he did not want to go, but Hadden gave the Captain the usual shipping papers, with his name forged to them, and he was required to go to work. The man was powerless, and probably would have been taken to sea had not a friend, on Saturday, learned of the trap in which he had been caught and taken measures which resulted in his release. A complaint was subsequently lodged against Hadden for attempting to kidnap Geraty, and having been arrested by Officer Connell, of the Harbor Police, Justice WELSH committed him for examination. The object HADDEN had in view in the commission of the outrage was to secure the sum given as advance wages.

abstract: CITY MORTALITY According to the City Inspector's report, there were 414 deaths in the City for the week ending Saturday last, Oct. 20 viz.: 86 men 103 women, 118 boys and 107 girls. Of the whole number, 196 were under 5 years of age. The princi-
lead_paragraph: CITY MORTALITY. -- According to the City Inspector's report, there were 414 deaths in the City for the week ending Saturday last, Oct. 20 viz.: 86 men 103 women, 118 boys and 107 girls. Of the whole number, 196 were under 5 years of age. The principal diseases were: Apoplexy, 4; bronchitis, 6; cholera infantum, 8; congestion of brain, 12; congestion of lungs, 5; convulsions, infantile, 18; croup, 16; disease of kidneys, 9; consumption, 50; infantile debility, 11; dropsy, 10; dropsy in head, 15; diarrhoea, 15; diphtherite, 4; dysentery, 8; epilepsy, 4; fever, scarlet, 18; do. typhoid, 6; do. typhus, 9; hooping-cough, 5; disease of heart, 6; inflammation of bowels, 9; do. brain, 9; do. liver,5; do. lungs, 28; do. stomach, 2; do. throat, 4; marasmus, infantile, 29; small-pox, 5; teething, 4; palsy, 7; burned or scalded, 4; casualties, 4; delirium tremens, 4; drowned, 2; old age, 5; premature birth, 13; accidental suffocation, 3. Particulars were for
lead_paragraph: So far back as last June, and previous to the nominations of DOUGLAS and BRECKIN- RIDGE at Baltimore by rival Democratic Conventions, there were rumors and reports in constant circulation to the effect, that Mr. YANCEY, of Alabama, would accept the VicePresidency on the Douglas ticket, as the price for withdrawing his opposition to the Little Giant's nomination. Particulars were forwarded by telegraph, of a secret interview said to have taken place between the high contracting parties, and many were the winks given by ardent Douglas men as they prophesied the speedy and unanimous nomination of their political favorite.

abstract: The bears of Wall-street are evidently a variety undescribed by naturalists. The bear of fable and the books is a stolid brute of honest proclivities, and of wit too clumsy to be expert in contests with those Solomons of the forest, the fox and the wolf. The bear of
lead_paragraph: The bears of Wall-street are evidently a variety undescribed by naturalists. The bear of fable and the books is a stolid brute of honest proclivities, and of wit too clumsy to be expert in contests with those Solomons of the forest, the fox and the wolf. The bear of the Street is on the contrary the summation of all that is ingenious and acute in animal life. He not only reads the present with superhuman sagacity, but penetrating the future, lays before our amazed vision vistas of events to come, which but for their uniform gloom and sadness, might well gratify the attentive spectator, and prepare him for long tissues of calamity. There is, indeed, much reason to identify the prophets who disgusted the king, and the bears who avenged the prophet of Israel, as mere representatives of this despondent type of humanity, the most striking realizations of which frequent the dens and recesses of our financial thoroughfare, and impress upon the unaccustomed visitors of that realm, horrors such as reigned in the Halls of Eblis.

abstract: The Society of St. Vincent de Paul is now holding its Fourth Annual Festival at the City Assembly Rooms, No. 426 Broadway. This Association exists under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church, and is purely charitable in its objects. It was first or-
lead_paragraph: The Society of St. Vincent de Paul is now holding its Fourth Annual Festival at the City Assembly Rooms, No. 426 Broadway. This Association exists under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church, and is purely charitable in its objects. It was first organized in France, in the year 1833, and its present President, ADOLPH BADAUN, is now resident in Paris. The existence of the Society in this City dates back to 1844, though the practice of holding annual festivals was not inaugurated until 1856. It numbers about 600 members, who hold weekly meetings, and pay weekly visits among the poor, for whose benefit they make weekly disbursements. The funds of the Society are mainly supplied by these annual festivals or fairs, to which the price of admittance is 50 cents per caput, while the goods disposed of, being donations from the charitably disposed, yield a net profit, of course.

abstract: -- It is rumored in Montreal that Hon. abstract: Charles Hume vs. James Gordon Bennett. The plaintiff claims that he has been injured in reputation and ruined in business by a publication made in the Herald, on the 3d and 4th of March, 1859. The article
lead_paragraph: Charles Hume vs. James Gordon Bennett. The plaintiff claims that he has been injured in reputation and ruined in business by a publication made in the Herald, on the 3d and 4th of March, 1859. The article referred to intimates that the plaintiff was concerned in the robbery of a guest of the Constantine Hotel, No. 218 William-street, of some $8,000 in money and jewelry. The plaintiff was then proprietor of the Hotel, and avers that the business is ruined, his boarders having all left him in consequence of the publication.

abstract: Important intelligence reaches us from the Pacific side, by the arrival of the Pony Express at St. Joseph last night, with advices from San Francisco to the 10th inst., and from Oregon to the 7th.
lead_paragraph: Important intelligence reaches us from the Pacific side, by the arrival of the Pony Express at St. Joseph last night, with advices from San Francisco to the 10th inst., and from Oregon to the 7th. The difficulties in the Oregon Legislature had been so far overcome that on the 2d the election for United Senators took place in legal form and resulted in the choice of J.W. NESMITH, Douglas Democrat, for the long term, and E.D. BAKER, Republican, for the short term of five years. The arrangement was, of course, effected by a fusion. This news created the greatest excitement among the California Republicans, many of whom thought their chances in that State by no means so desperate as had been feared. Efforts were to be made to get Mr. BAKER to stump the State for LINCOLN. The Broderick will had at last been admitted to probate. A dreadful massacre of an entire emigrant train by the Snake Indians took place about fifty miles west of Salmon Falls, on the Columbia River, on the 9th of September. Only one person escaped out of a party of forty-six -- a man named SCHEIBER. Nineteen of these massacred were men, and the rest were women and children. The details of this horrible affair are given in our dispatch.

abstract: DEMOCRATIC COUNTY CONVENTION. The delegates to the Democratic County Convention, for nominating a candidate for Sheriff and three Coroners met yesterday afternoon at the National Hotel, in Hudson City, Hon, SAMUEL A. FRENCH was Chairman, and JAMES LYNCH Secretary. There were two
lead_paragraph: DEMOCRATIC COUNTY CONVENTION. The delegates to the Democratic County Convention, for nominating a candidate for Sheriff and three Coroners met yesterday afternoon at the National Hotel, in Hudson City, Hon, SAMUEL A. FRENCH was Chairman, and JAMES LYNCH Secretary. There were two sets of delegates present from Harrison Township, and, in consequence of no regular call having been issued for a primary in that township, both delegations were allowed to participate. On motion, JOHN M. FRANCIS was unanimously renominated for Sheriff. Coroner GAFFNEY, of Jersey City, was also unanimously renominated by acclamation. Mr. HOFF, of Hoboken, here offered a resolution indorsing the Democratic National Electors, as selected by the State Convention at Trenton, and against nominating of supporting any candidate opposed to the regular Electoral ticket. The resolution was unanimously rejected, with the exception of the gentleman who offered it Mr. F.H. BOHNSTEDT, of Hoboken, and JAMES H. DONNELLY, of Hudson City, were then nominated for the office of Coroners, after which the Convention adjourned.

abstract: The Teachers' Association of this City Held its regular monthly meeting on Saturday evening, in the Hall of the Board of Education, the President, HENRY W. DUNSHEE, Esq., in the Chair, and Mr. S.M. PERKINS Secretary. Mr. JOHN H. FANNING, Principal of Ward School No. 12, read a paper on "Our City School System its History and Utility." He com-
lead_paragraph: The Teachers' Association of this City Held its regular monthly meeting on Saturday evening, in the Hall of the Board of Education, the President, HENRY W. DUNSHEE, Esq., in the Chair, and Mr. S.M. PERKINS Secretary. Mr. JOHN H. FANNING, Principal of Ward School No. 12, read a paper on "Our City School System its History and Utility." He commenced with the formation of the free-school system in this City, under DEWITT CLINTON, in 1805, and traced its progress, under different corporate names, down to the present time. The "Free School Society" had the control of educational matters to the year 1826, at which time its title was changed to the "Public School Society." Previous to the year 1830 such parents as were able to pay for the tuition of their children did so, but, as the number of those paying became "small by degrees and beautifully less," the receiving of pay was soon entirely abolished by the Society. In furnishing gratuitous education to all classes of children in our City, and in firmly laying the foundations of our present school system, he considered the Public School Society as justly entitled to the appellation of the "Pioneer" Society. He commended it for its integrity and general faithfulness in the discharge of its responsible duties; alluded to the fact that it was the founder of our City Normal Schools; remarked that thousands of our citizens can point to its schools as one points to his Alma Mater; and that nearly half of the present Principals of our large schools obtained the basis of their education or professional training in its schools. Still that Society had its faults, but as a general thing they were on the right side, so to speak. After giving a sketch of the method of discipline and course of instruction prevailing under the old system, he next adverted to the more popular establishment of the "Board of Education," and of local Ward Boards, in 1842. From this time till 1853, two parallel systems of schools -- the Public and the Ward Schools were in existence; but the Board of Education had the supervisory control of both. A new impetus was now given to public education. New school-houses sprung up, as if by magic, and were as rapidly filled with youthful seekers after knowledge, and about this time the Free Academy was ushered into existence. For a time the Public and Ward schools moved onward in a spirit of healthful rivalry; but the necessity of two systems began to be questioned, and the Public School Society voluntarily terminated its labors in 1853. At that time the Public and Ward Schools were merged into one system -- the system of to-day. Our school system is now in the hands of local Ward Boards and of the Board of Education -- men fresh from the ranks of the people, and understanding their wants. In conclusion, Mr. FANNING showed that the Common School system of our City has now a strong hold of the public mind, possesses great vitality, and that, if properly administered, its prospective influence for good is almost unbounded. Mr. WM.J. KENNARD also read a brief paper on "Errors in Teaching." Both of the papers elicited remarks from several of the teachers present, after which the Association adjourned, to meet the 14th of next month, at which time a lecture is expected from Rev. Dr. BELLOWS.
headline: {'main': "Teachers' Association.; RISE AND PROGRESS OF THE PRESENT SCHOOL SYSTEM.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Teachers' Association.; RISE AND PROGRESS OF THE PRESENT SCHOOL SYSTEM.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: This was a proceeding, by mandamus, to compel the defendants White and Smith, who were Inspectors at an election for Trustees, held at the Church of the Puritans on the 12th of March last, to give certificates of election to the relators, Hartt, Hall and Whiting, who were duly elected. It appears that there were
lead_paragraph: This was a proceeding, by mandamus, to compel the defendants White and Smith, who were Inspectors at an election for Trustees, held at the Church of the Puritans on the 12th of March last, to give certificates of election to the relators, Hartt, Hall and Whiting, who were duly elected. It appears that there were two sets of candidates to fill three vacancies in the Board of Trustees. According to the count of the defendants, Inspectors, and their declaration made at the time in the presence of the said Society, Messrs. Hartt, Hall and Whiting had 33 votes each; Messrs. Harvey and Tompkins, 31 each; and James O. Bennett, 27; there being also some 3 or 4 votes for Thomas Roundy. Eleven days after the election, however, the defendants, on the plea that illegal votes were cast for the relators, gave certificates of election to Messrs. Harvey and Tompkins, the defeated candidates. The relators then instituted a suit for damages and also this proceeding. The defendants thereupon made an evasive and insufficient return. The Court, on motion, then ordered the defendants to make a further return setting forth the defects in the former one. The defendant then made a second return, which, being deemed evasive and defective like the first motion, was made by the relator to quash the second return, and that a peremptory mandamus issue.

abstract: Mr. THOMAS D'ARCY McGEE, one of the Irish patriots of 1848, has written a letter to a paper published in Montreal, condemning the refusal of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, N. Y.S.M., to parade in honor of the Prince of  Wales, as "a silly proceeding." At the same...
lead_paragraph: Mr. THOMAS D'ARCY McGEE, one of the Irish patriots of 1848, has written a letter to a paper published in Montreal, condemning the refusal of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, N. Y.S.M., to parade in honor of the Prince of Wales, as "a silly proceeding." At the same time he calls attention to the fact, that our adopted citizens of Irish birth throughout the United States conducted themselves otherwise with commendable propriety -- the exception in the case noted being simply a negative one, but with no affirmatively hostile action towards our Royal visitor. According to Mr. T.D. MAGEE, we should be grateful that the "one hundred and fifty thousand" Irishmen of Philadelphia, and the "three hundred thousand" of the same race inhabiting this City, and the "sixty-three thousand" native Milesians of Boston did not all turn out en masse to avenge the wrongs of their country on our late illustrious visitor and those in his train.

abstract: The statement in the Charleston Courier that the two HITCHINGS who were arrested at Clio, (S.C.) some days since on suspicion of being Abolitionists, had been hung, proves to be incorrect. A letter to the Mercury, dated at Cheraw on the 18th, says that they are safely lodged in the Bennettsvile Jail, and that the most conclusive proof of their guilt will be needed to secure their conviction.

abstract: -- A frightful collision, entailing a loss of three lives, and the injury of of several others, occurred on the Detroit and Milwaukee Railway, about two miles west of Birmington, yesterday, morning. The mail train, which ought to have left this city for the West at 7:30 A.M., was detained twenty minutes in starting, and again about ten minutes at Birmingham in passing the Fentonville accommodation bound East, making it about thirty minutes late in leaving Birmingham. The train was running at high speed, probably not less than forty miles per hour, to overcome this loss of time, when, in turning a curve in a deep cut, the through freight train from Grand Haven, which was also under extra speed to make up time, was discovered just ahead. The two engineers had barely time to reverse their engines, whistle the signal for the brakes to be applied, and jump, when the trains collided with a fearful crash, tearing and crushing the engines and cars in a fearful manner.
lead_paragraph: -- A frightful collision, entailing a loss of three lives, and the injury of of several others, occurred on the Detroit and Milwaukee Railway, about two miles west of Birmington, yesterday, morning. The two engineers had barely time to reverse their engines, whistle the signal for the brakes to be applied, and jump, when the trains collided with a fearful crash, tearing and crushing the engines and cars in a fearful manner.

abstract: PROBABLY FATAL AFFRAY. -- About 8 1/2 o'clock last evening, a young Irishman, named MICHAEL [???]VANAH, residing in City Hall-place, near Pearl-street, went into the grocery and liquor-store at the corner of those thoroughfares, and quarreled with JOHN SHOCK, the clerk. After the two men had abused each other for a short time SHOCK ordered KAVANAGH to leave the place, but the latter positively refused to go, and an attempt was made to forcibly eject him. The clerk, however, found himself unable to effect his object, and he therefore caught up a cleaver from the meat-table and struck KAVANAGH a heavy blow upon the head, causing a fracture of the skull. As soon as he realized the nature of the injury he had inflicted SHOCK ran away, and up to a late hour the Police had not effected his arrest. The sufferer was removed to the New-York Hospital, and placed under the care of Dr. WEIR, who pronounced the wound of a character which he would not be likely to survive.

abstract: Early last evening, a Police Telegraph pole, at the corner of Prince and Greene streets, was knocked down by a large tree, which, drawn upon a truck, was to have formed one of the embellishments of the Union procession. The mishap makes the telegraph line unavailable for the present. The banners of a portion of the procession, which passed up Centre-street, also caused an entanglement of the wires in that locality, and messages could neither be received nor transmitton with any degree of certainty.

abstract: Regular semi-monthly mail service will hereafter be performed by the steamship Isabel, between Charleston, S.C., Savannah, Georgia, Key West, Florida and Havana, Cuba, the schedule days of sailing being as follows, viz.: the Isabel will leave Charleston, S. C., on the 1st, 12th and 25th of November next, and return from Havana on the 6th and 17th of November and 1st of December next. Subsequently she will perform two trips per month, leaving Charleston on the 10th and 25th, and Havana on the 1st and 16th of each month.

abstract: The excitement occasioned by the procession was nowhere greater than at the Metropolitan Hotel, which is crowded with guests, among whom are a large number of Southerners. Of these, some of the more enthusiastic had decorated their windows with Chinese variegated lanterns, while the balconies were thronged with gentlemen, and the windows, everywhere fronting Broadway, were radiant with the eyes and jewels, that sparkled in the light of fireworks and torches, of fair ladies.
lead_paragraph: The excitement occasioned by the procession was nowhere greater than at the Metropolitan Hotel, which is crowded with guests, among whom are a large number of Southerners. Of these, some of the more enthusiastic had decorated their windows with Chinese variegated lanterns, while the balconies were thronged with gentlemen, and the windows, everywhere fronting Broadway, were radiant with the eyes and jewels, that sparkled in the light of fireworks and torches, of fair ladies. As soon as the head of the procession reached the hotel a temporary halt was made, when the cheering commenced, the gentlemen shouting, and the ladies waving their handkerchiefs. Roman candles from the steps of the various entrances were let off by the score, and sentiments of Samsonian strength in reference to the perpetuity of the Union, the defeat of LINCOLN, the utter crushing out and perfectly overwhelming annihilation of the Black Republicans, were freely, but not obtrusively or offensively indulged in. One gentleman, between the intervals of taking a whiff at his segar, shouted so loud that his friend counseled moderation lest he should lose his voice, or break a blood-vessel. With true patriotism, he replied: "A man must 'holler' for his country." And for two hours he "hollered," always between the whiffs of a segar, and when last heard from was "hollering" still.

abstract: DEATH FROM HYDROPHOBIA. -- A middle-aged woman, named MARY DIETRICH, died on Thursday last at the Almshouse, of hydrophobia. She was a German woman, and earned her living by washing. While hanging out clothes about a month ago, she was bitten on the arm by a pet dog. The wound was cauterized by a physician, but it seems without success, for on Wednesday last, the womaa was seized with spasms at the sight of water. She continued to get worse, and was taken to the Almshouse, where she lingered in agony for about twelve hours, when she died. In her paroxysms, she bit the flesh from her fingers to the bone, before death put an end to her sufferings. The case was a most distressing one throughout. -- Philadelphia Press, Oct. 23.
lead_paragraph: DEATH FROM HYDROPHOBIA. -- A middle-aged woman, named MARY DIETRICH, died on Thursday last at the Almshouse, of hydrophobia. She was a German woman, and earned her living by washing. abstract: man, who gave his name as JO WILDER, came here about the 26th or 27th of September, called on several of the free colored people here, and wished to hire them to go to Des Moines City, where he and his brother had a hotel and farm--some to work on the farm and the others in the hotel.
lead_paragraph: man, who gave his name as JO WILDER, came here about the 26th or 27th of September, called on several of the free colored people here, and wished to hire them to go to Des Moines City, where he and his brother had a hotel and farm--some to work on the farm and the others in the hotel. On the 27th he engaged JERRY BOYD and wife, two men, JACOBS and DRYDEN, who had been running on the river, to go. JERRY had a colored girl about 14 years old, and a white child two years old, living with him. The white man had a covered wagon, in which JERRY, his wife, and the two girls started off on the 28th. The two men were to meet them at Dyersville, on the D. & P.R.R., but waited a day or two without seeing them, and returned. We heard no more of JERRY and family, till the 13th of October, when Mr. HOWARD, our Postmaster, received a letter from WARREN SPURRIER, of the town of Solon, Johnson County, Iowa, saying that on the 30th of September a wagon-answering to the description of the one in which JERRY was, passed there, going up the Iowa River, with two white men, a colored man, and woman and girl, about 16 years of age, and a small girl; that they had stayed over night in an untenanted building near there; that on the 3d a boy saw a man lying on the side of the road where the wagon passed, and supposed he was drunk. On the 8th, another boy saw the same man, and found he was dead. An inquest was held on the 10th of October, and found that he had been murdered by a blow on the head; clothed as JERRY BOYD generally was; had several articles in his pocket which he was known to have, and a receipt signed by JAS. W. BAILEY, of this place, to JERRY BOYD, for $20 -- showing plainly that there could be no mistake about the identity. JERRY, his wife and colored girl were all free, and have lived in Galena a number of years, (the two former 15 or 20 years,) and bore irreproachable characters. There is no doubt here that the white men were kidnappers, and that the colored people, as well as the white girl, may be sold into Slavery. -- St. Louis News.

abstract: The brig Delicia, as will be remembered, was captured off the coast of Africa some weeks since, on a charge of being engaged in the Slave-trade. A libel was filed asking her condemnation and forfeiture, and subsequently a claim was filed in behalf of her owners, who were alleged to be subjects of Spain. Some time since a motion was made for an order directing her to be sold, which was denied by the Court, upon the ground that an order for sale could not be made unless the Court had rightful jurisdiction of the subject matter, and that it could not have jurisdiction if the vessel was a Spanish vessel. A few days since, from the Spanish Minister at Washington, through the Department of State, the evidence of her national character was produced; and immediately thereupon the libel was dismissed and the vessel restored. The Charleston Courier publishes the opinion delivered by Judge MAGRATH. After reviewing the testimony of JOSE VASQUEZ, third mate of the Delicia, who swore that the vessel had never displayed any but Spanish colors, and that they were thrown overboard by the mate, when the vessel was captured, by the order of the boarding-officer of the U.S. steamer Falcon, Judge MAGRATH states that the power of the Court to order a sale of property was given not alone to preserve property, but to preserve that of which it has jurisdiction. Taking the evidence submitted, he was obliged to suppose that the vessel had not discarded her national character. The Judge concluded as follows:

abstract: Matters at the different Navy-Yards, notwithstanding the number of vessels ordered for sea, are comparatively dull. This arises from the small appropriations made by Congress for purely yard work. At New-York, (the sum granted for which was $20,000,) there is hardly anything doing except on ships.
lead_paragraph: Matters at the different Navy-Yards, notwithstanding the number of vessels ordered for sea, are comparatively dull. This arises from the small appropriations made by Congress for purely yard work. At New-York, (the sum granted for which was $20,000,) there is hardly anything doing except on ships. The launching-ways are receiving a few finishing touches, a sewer is being sunk, and a small shot-rack is building behind the marine barracks. The Vandalia occupies a large gang, and so does the Wabash, which is still in dock. The Roanoke, North Carolina, Perry, Brandywine and Potomac are in statu quo.
