abstract: Joseph Burnett and another vs. Edward Phalon and another.--In this case the plaintiffs obtained a judgment at Special Term enjoining the defendants from using the word "Cocoine" in the sale of their article of hair oil, upon the ground that it was an innovation of the word "Cocoaine," which the plaintiffs ...
lead_paragraph: Joseph Burnett and another vs. Edward Phalon and another.--In this case the plaintiffs obtained a judgment at Special Term enjoining the defendants from using the word "Cocoine" in the sale of their article of hair oil, upon the ground that it was an innovation of the word "Cocoaine," which the plaintiffs claimed they had adopted as a trade mark. The plaintiffs claimed damages, and to ascertain such damages, a reference to H.W. Robinson, Esq., was ordered. Upon the examination before the Referee, Joseph Burnett, one of the plaintiffs, was called as a witness in his own behalf, and endeavored to show a diminution of the sales of this article, and a consequent loss of profits. That the plaintiffs' profits were $1 40 per dozen bottles "Cocoaine" sold by them. Upon his cross-examination the witness stated that he got at the profits by estimating the cost of the materials, bottles, labor, &c., and deducting such gross amount from the sum realized upon a sale of the article. The witness was then asked what materials he calculated the costs upon? The witness refused to answer this question on the ground that it compelled him to divulge the component parts of which "Cocoaine" was made, which was a secret of considerable value to his firm. The Referee decided that the question was a proper one and required the witness to answer. And upon his refusal so to do, and as a penalty for such contempt, struck out so much of the plaintiff's claim for damages as was predicated upon a loss of profits upon sales made by them, and, after hearing further proofs, the Referee made his report, granting the plaintiff 6 cents damages. The plaintiff excepted to the report, and, upon argument, at Special Term, before Justice Pierrepont, the case was remanded to the Referee, the Justice allowing two exceptions made, that the Referee erred in deciding the plaintiff not bound to answer the question put to him, and also the exercise of the right of punishment for contempt in refusing to answer the question. From this decision the defendants appealed to the General Term, and in an elaborate opinion by Justice Hoffman, the Court held that the question put to the plaintiff was pertinent, and that he was bound to answer it, as the plaintiff sought to establish his claim by proving his loss of profits. That in such cases there was no exemption nor privilege allowed the witness, and in this respect the Referee was right in his decision. That the practice in such cases was to strike out the whole evidence of the witness for the refusal to answer a proper question, or upon the certificate of the Referee to apply to the Court to punish the witness if the party desired the evidence, and not for the Referee to strike out the plaintiff's claim for damages. The order made at Special Term, which allowed the exception to the punishment imposed by the Referee, was affirmed, but in other respects the order was reversed, without costs.

abstract: One of the largest political meetings of the campaign was held, last evening, in the Fulton-street Wigwam, to listen to a speech from Gov. CHASE, of Ohio. There were not less than 5,000 people present, and as all could not get inside of the Wigwam, an outside meeting was organized, where addresses were made by Mr. NORTHROP, of Connecticut, WM.H. BURLEIGH, and Mr. CONCH, of Brooklyn. Hon. J.S.T. STRANAHAN presided at the meeting inside of the Wigwam, and the stand was occupied by Hon. JAMES HUMPHREY, EDWARDS FISK, Elector, and other distinguished citizens. Gov. CHASE's speech was mainly devoted to exposing the "humbug" of Douglas Popular Sovereignly, and he kept the audience interested for nearly three hours.

abstract: The Union Demonstration last night was an immense affair in point of the numbers parading, and the amount of fireworks consumed. The whole City was alive with bands of music, colored lamps, Democratic transparencies, thousands of Bell-Everett men with cow-bells, and myriads of little oily boys carrying oil-dropping torches almost as long as themselves.
lead_paragraph: The Union Demonstration last night was an immense affair in point of the numbers parading, and the amount of fireworks consumed. The whole City was alive with bands of music, colored lamps, Democratic transparencies, thousands of Bell-Everett men with cow-bells, and myriads of little oily boys carrying oil-dropping torches almost as long as themselves. The air blazed with rockets, and unoffending house-fronts were peppered dangerously with the small shot of Roman candles. The bales of red flannel, contributed by the Committee of Fifteen, did goodly service. The same may also be said of the white muslin for banners, contributed by the same assotiation. Everything that could be done towards raising a crowd was effected. Some little trouble was created here and there by the refusal of different bands of music to ply their vocation at the head of expectant brigades until they had been paid in advance. These unpleasant interruptions, however, were in time overcome by the liberal disbursements made by Marshal RYNDERS, who is rumored to have expended over seventeen thousand dollars for the purposes of the procession.

abstract: SAN FRANCISCO, Monday, Oct. 1, 1860. As we near election, all parties grow more mod  erate, and excitement dies out. No movement has been made within the week that alters the relative position of the contending forces. The big bell paraded through the street one night, and the whole Union Party went over to Oakland in a ferryboat discharging rockets, without regard to expense, as they sailed.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Monday, Oct. 1, 1860.

abstract: The cattle-dealers were loud in their complaints of the market yesterday. Many of them were certainly losing money, having paid too much for their cattle, as the market proved. It was emphatically one of the dullest Tuesdays of the season, and there was little prospect of a better trade to-day, for, in addition to over 4,100 beeves already yarded, a few hundred more are expected this morning from a delayed train upon the Erie Road. The cattle were of fair quality -- some of them very nice, fat steers, but excepting a few isolated cases, 9c. lb., net weight, was all that could be obtained. Taking the actual allowance of weight conceded to butchers, the market shows a decline of 1/4c.@1/2c. lb. The fact is, we are having too many cattle for the present season. Vegetables are abundant and cheap, poultry is beginning to come in, and mutton and pork are sought after, so that the 5,500 beeves per week received for six weeks past, proves to be more than can easily be disposed of, even at low rates.
lead_paragraph: The cattle-dealers were loud in their complaints of the market yesterday. Many of them were certainly losing money, having paid too much for their cattle, as the market proved. abstract: German, was arrested yesterday by Officer ULTER, of the Fourth Precinct, on a charge of fatally injuring PHILLIP SCHUTZ by stabbing him with a knife. The injured man keeps a bakery at No. 383 Hudson-avenue, and the accused has been in his employ. On Monday night, WELLER came into the house intoxicated and commenced abusing the inmates. He was ordered away, when he drew a dirk-knife and stabbed Mr. SCHUTZ several times -- twice in the region of the heart. The wounds are considered dangerous, and the accused was committed to await the result of the injuries.

abstract: The moon was as bright, the stars as numerous and the sky as cloudless, last night, as on the occasion of the great Wide-Awake parade. The clerk of the weather, assuredly, is no partisan. The monster procession of the combined Douglas, Breckinridge and Bell-Everett forces which marched through our streets last night, had no need of torches, calcium lights and variegated pyrotechnics. Yet they were displayed in profusion.
lead_paragraph: The moon was as bright, the stars as numerous and the sky as cloudless, last night, as on the occasion of the great Wide-Awake parade. The clerk of the weather, assuredly, is no partisan. The monster procession of the combined Douglas, Breckinridge and Bell-Everett forces which marched through our streets last night, had no need of torches, calcium lights and variegated pyrotechnics. Yet they were displayed in profusion. The pageant was gotten up regardless of expense, and was a decided success. The thoroughfares through which it passed were again rivers of flame rolling between black banks of packed humanity. The women that were in the streets -- and their name was many myriads -- received a sparking from the hundreds of Roman candles, that was much more ardent than agreeable. The whole town seemed on fire for Fusion, just as one night, a few weeks ago, it seemed redolent of Republican resin.

abstract: That no Government can be strong whose people are oppressed and disaffected, is a truth of which the world has had a fresh and striking illustration in the facility with which an ancient Italian monarchy has been overthrown, and the monarch driven out a fugitive and a wanderer, over the earth. That he might have retained his crown, and transmitted it to his posterity, if he had listened to the ...
lead_paragraph: That no Government can be strong whose people are oppressed and disaffected, is a truth of which the world has had a fresh and striking illustration in the facility with which an ancient Italian monarchy has been overthrown, and the monarch driven out a fugitive and a wanderer, over the earth. That he might have retained his crown, and transmitted it to his posterity, if he had listened to the remonstrances of the civilized world, and the timely warnings and advice of friendly Governments, is equally apparent to every intelligent man in Europe and America. But fatuity seems� to be the evil genius of those who wield arbitrary power; and instances of voluntary concessions of privileges to the masses, by despots or oligarchs, to which they are moved by a sense of justice, or by wise foresight, are among the rarest, as well as the most precious events of history. It was this judicial blindness which cost CHARLES I. his head, and his son JAMES his throne, which precipitated the horrors of the French Revolution, and severed the American Colonies from the British Crown.

abstract: -- The steamer New World got aground on the bar at Castleton this morning, and while lying there her condition was noticed by the officers of the steamer Knickerbocker, which had previously passed over the bar. With a view of hauling the New World off, the Knickerbocker backen down to the New World and came in collision with her, striking her at the forward gangway, on the larboard side, and fearing away all the wood on that side of the latter boat as far aft as the wheel. The collision was accompanied by a terrible crash which caused considerable consternation among those on board both boats. Fortunately no person was injured, although the passengers were greatly alarmed. -- Albany Statesman, last evening.
lead_paragraph: -- The steamer New World got aground on the bar at Castleton this morning, and while lying there her condition was noticed by the officers of the steamer Knickerbocker, which had previously passed over the bar. abstract: -- The Chicago Zouave Cadets have resolved to form a whole regiment of their style of military, to consist of eight companies, Col. ELLSWORTH to be the chief officer. The old company will be Company A, and the rest B,C, &c., in the order of their organization. We learn that the work of organizing the new companies is progressing steadily, and that in a few months the regiment, which is to be known as the "Independent Regiment of Illinois Light Infantry," will be full.

abstract: -- In New-Orleans, on Monday last, a young man, 18 years of age, named RICHARD SWAN, on returning home from his day's work, was seized by his step-father, FRANK WILSON, who struck him three blows. A fearful struggle ensued, when RICHARD, who was almost helpless in the grasp of WILSON, drew a pistol and dirk-knife, which he habitually carried, shot his assailant through the neck, and stabbed him eight or nine times. WILSON fell to the floor and almost instantly expired. The young man immediately delivered himself up to a policeman and now awaits an investigation. The Delta says young SWAN is of good reputation, but that his step-father was of a violent temper, and had inflicted numerous causeless brutalities upon his wife's children.

abstract: VALPARAISO, Tuesday, Sept. 17, 1860. Tomorrow will be the anniversary of Chilian  Independence, and the festivities, beginning to-day, generally last three or four days. We were awakened this morning at sunrise by a salute from the fort, and we have another now at midday from the man-of-war. Good-bye to business of all kinds unlesss it be the business of diversion.
lead_paragraph: VALPARAISO, Tuesday, Sept. 17, 1860.

abstract: The crowd in the vicinity of the New-York Hotel was more dense than in any other part of Broadway,-- partly on account of its location opposite the headquarters of the Republican Campaign Club, and partly from the fact that a rumor had gained circulation that an attack was contemplated upon the aforesaid headquarters by some of the roughs of the Empire Club.
lead_paragraph: The crowd in the vicinity of the New-York Hotel was more dense than in any other part of Broadway,-- partly on account of its location opposite the headquarters of the Republican Campaign Club, and partly from the fact that a rumor had gained circulation that an attack was contemplated upon the aforesaid headquarters by some of the roughs of the Empire Club. No such attack, however, was made, or attempted. Nevertheless, an unusual display of policemen was made at this point, who, not having occasion to be useful were regarded as ornamental. The rooms of the Campaign Clubs were lighted up, and their outside transparency brilliantly illuminated in the forepart of the evening, but long before the procession arrived, the lights were all extinguished, the doors closed, and the banner which hangs across the street hauled in. This proceeding was strenuously opposed by some members of the Club, who regarded it as a cowardly relinquishment of their rights, but on the advice of the General Superintendent of Police, who visited the rooms about 8 o'clock, it was finally acquiesced in as being a measure which the Republicans could amply afford in view of the victory which awaits them, and as being the easiest and cheapest way to prevent the possibility of a disturbance. The crowd on the New-York Hotel side indulged in a variety of taunting insinuations about the courage of the Lincolnites, when they saw their flag hauled in and their rooms darkened, but the Republicans pocketed the insults and preserved the peace. Every window of the hotel, from the sidewalk to the cornice, was filled with the fair faces of the lady inmates, who vied with each other in the enthusiasm of their greetings to the various clubs as they passed under the windows. The head of the procession, with its cavalcade, led by the redoubtable Capt. RYNDERS, mounted on a swift charger, arrived in front of the hotel at precisely 9 1/2 o'clock, and was received with the most enthusiastic cheering and the waving of innumerable handkerchiefs. Capt. RYNDERS acknowledged the honor by ordering a halt, and proposing three cheers for the "New-York Hotel," three for the "Union," and three for the success of the Fusion ticket. They were all given with a will, and the crowd on the walk added three supplementary groans for the Republican Central Campaign Club opposite. Each club, as it passed, received a similar greeting, though not quite so boisterous, and every transparency or device, deserving, from its originality or comicality, any special notice, received its due meed of applause. It was the unanimous opinion of all the Hotel people, that the procession far exceeded, in every respect, the Wide-Awake display, and not a few, in the height of their enthusiasm, declared it as their opinion, that Old ABE LINCOLN was, then and there, and forever hereafter, "sent higher than a kite." The Republicans themselves, when appealed to in the comparisons that were constantly being made, admitted that the procession was more varied in its character than that of the Wide-Awakes; that it had more horses, more transparencies, and more mottoes, (many of the latter, however, they considered vulgar,) and that altogether it was a great demonstration. But as to numbers, they could tell better when it had all passed. There was one point that the Republicans claimed beyond cavil, and that was that their procession was made up of more genteel looking men. This point was bluffly knocked in the head, however, by a burly Democrat, who declared that "it wasn't genteel lookin' men who did the votin' in this 'ere country; the old Whig Party allers thought that and they found theirselves mistaken."

abstract: A respectably-dressed man, named Richard Arbuthnot, was arrested at the Metropolitan Hotel by Officer McArthur, of the Broadway Squad, on suspicion of having broken into one of the rooms of the establishment and stolen various articles of value. The prisoner stated that he was a lawyer by profession, and that the charge against him was unfounded. Justice STEERS committed him until the matter shall have been inquired into....Aaron Isaacs, a clothes dealer, was arrested yesterday on a charge of having stolen twelve coats, valued at $40, from David Finn, of No. 105 Payard-street. The garments had been intrusted to the prisoner to clean, and after he had freshened them up, he pawned the lot for $9. Justice KELLY committed him to answer.

abstract: European advices four days later are received by the City of Washington, via Cape Race, which point she passed last evening. She left Liverpool on the 10th and Queenstown on the 11th. Our full dispatch, however, is not received, owing to an interruption in telegraphic connection. No new movements are reported from Italy. Since the battle of Caserta--or Volturno, as it is called ...
lead_paragraph: European advices four days later are received by the City of Washington, via Cape Race, which point she passed last evening. She left Liverpool on the 10th and Queenstown on the 11th. Our full dispatch, however, is not received, owing to an interruption in telegraphic connection. No new movements are reported from Italy. Since the battle of Caserta--or Volturno, as it is called -- the position of the belligerents had remained unchanged. Details of the battle received render i[???] certain that it was one of the most bloody and protracted struggles that has taken place in modern warfare. The Neapolitan army fought with desperation, as they probably thought it their last chance to retrieve the fortunes of the ex-King, but they were finally driven back in great disorder to the fortress of Capua, with an estimated loss of over three thousand men killed and five thousand taken prisoners. GARIBALDI's losses are estimated at from 1,200 to 2,000 men. The position of affairs in the Papal States remained as before reported The Liverpool Cotton market is reported firm, with an advancing tendency, and Breadstuffs were down.

abstract: The District-Attorney, yesterday, at the opening of Court, moved on the case of Patrick Hennessey, indicted for arson in the first degree. The defendant, it appeared, had purchased, during the Fall of 1859, the grocery business carried on at No.33 Goerckstreet by Charles McKenna, who had insured his stock and fixtures in the National Fire Insurance Company, ...
lead_paragraph: The District-Attorney, yesterday, at the opening of Court, moved on the case of Patrick Hennessey, indicted for arson in the first degree. The defendant, it appeared, had purchased, during the Fall of 1859, the grocery business carried on at No.33 Goerckstreet by Charles McKenna, who had insured his stock and fixtures in the National Fire Insurance Company, No. 52 Wall-street, for $600. Towards the end of February last, the defendant called at that Insurance office and asked for a transfer of the policy from McKenna's name to his own, and wished an increase of insurance. The Surveyor of the Company visited his premises, viewed his stock, found it less than the stock insured by McKenna, and declined to accede to the increase, but consented to insure the household furniture for $200. On Monday morning, about 2 o'clock, on the 26th of March, Policeman Poillon found the premises on fire, under circumstances which left no doubt that arson had been committed, and which tended strongly to inculpate the prisoner. The facts connected therewith were shown as follows, oh the evidence:

abstract: The presence, in this City, of Gen. LESLIE COOMBS, of Kentucky, appears to have awakened the patriotic reminiscences of his old companions in arms, the veterans of 1812. A military display of these venerable defenders of their country took place yesterday in front of the City Hall, at which Gen. ...
lead_paragraph: The presence, in this City, of Gen. LESLIE COOMBS, of Kentucky, appears to have awakened the patriotic reminiscences of his old companions in arms, the veterans of 1812. A military display of these venerable defenders of their country took place yesterday in front of the City Hall, at which Gen. COOMBS had been specially invited to attend. They numbered in all about thirty-seven men, rank and file, and finding that their compatriot, COOMBS, had, from come cause or other, failed to come up to time, loitered through the corridors of the City Hall from one o'clock until nearly three, when, being at last summoned to muster by the orderly sergeant, they formed in line in front of the Hall, and went through a series of manoeuvres.

abstract: At 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon the candle factory, owned by O.P. MENCCI, near Vanderbilt's Landing, Staten Island, was destroyed by fire, together with the adjoining buildings, known as MCCARTY's coach factory, ROBINSON & MOLFORD's carpenter shop, and several small dwellings and out-houses. The candle factory was owned by MATHEW CARROLL, Esq., and occupied by Mr. MENCCI, who was formerly a partner in the same establishment with GARIBALDI. Mr. CARROLL's loss is about $3,000. He was insured for $2,000.

abstract: Shortly before 7 o'clock P.M. a delegation of sixty "Minute Men of 56," from Philadelphia, in uniform, bearing torches and led by an effective band, marched up Broadway. At this hour there was no crowd below Canal-street to impede locomotion. At this point, however, the sidewalks began to be filled by spectators, who had evidently taken their positions for the evening. The "Minute Men" were favorably greeted ...
lead_paragraph: Shortly before 7 o'clock P.M. a delegation of sixty "Minute Men of 56," from Philadelphia, in uniform, bearing torches and led by an effective band, marched up Broadway. At this hour there was no crowd below Canal-street to impede locomotion. At this point, however, the sidewalks began to be filled by spectators, who had evidently taken their positions for the evening. The "Minute Men" were favorably greeted as they passed along. From Canal-street to the St. Nicholas Hotel Broadway was well filled by 7 3/2 o'clock, every available spot being occupied, both in the street and at the windows, from which a view of the procession could be obtained. The balcony of the St. Nicholas, as well as all the windows, were closely packed mostly by ladies, while crowds of sympathizers blocked up the entrance to the hotel, and rendered ingress and egress quite difficult. Despite this blockade, however, the multitude thronged the large bar-room in the rear almost to suffocation. The more determined clung to their uncertain foothold about the pillars of the doorway, or clambered upon the window sills and other elevated places, in order to see the procession over intervening heads. On the opposite side the Union Democratic Head-quarters were brilliantly lighted up, their transparency, having upon it two clasped hands, showing to good advantage. Here also most of the windows were filled with ladies, with kerchiefs in hand prepared to do all possible honor to the procession when it should begin to move. At 9 o'clock Grand Marshal RYNDERS, at the head of the column, and supported by some twenty mounted men; passed the hotel. His appearance was the signal for a moderate burst of applause from the spectators, in response to which the Marshal raised his hat and bowed his thanks to the applauding multitude. The crowd about the door of the St. Nicholas, though evidently in full sympathy with the demonstration, manifested very little enthusiasm. The cheering generally began and ended in the passing ranks, with an occasional response from the. lookers on. The only exception to this was when the delegations from Jersey City, Newark, Perth Amboy and New-Brunswick passed. These delegations made a fine appearance, and elicited marked applause, which was manifested by clapping of hands and cheering from all sides, while the ladies enthusiastically waved their white handkerchiefs from the windows. The St. Nicholas appeared to be especially favored by the discharge of an extra quantity of fire-works and other demonstrations. The six-pounder which was carried in the procession was fired in front of the hotel, with a stunning report, which broke the windows, and brought a shower of shattered glass upon the heads of the people beneath.

abstract: It would now appear certain that the United States must fail to recover any portion of the sum abstracted from the public treasury by the late Postmaster of this City. Mr. FOWLER has made a deposition evidently intended to shield his sureties, GEORGE LAW and GUSTAVUS ...
lead_paragraph: It would now appear certain that the United States must fail to recover any portion of the sum abstracted from the public treasury by the late Postmaster of this City. Mr. FOWLER has made a deposition evidently intended to shield his sureties, GEORGE LAW and GUSTAVUS A. CONOVER, from the penalties of their bond. The point of his evidence is, that he represented to both gentlemen that a third surety in the person of Mr. OLIVER CHARLICK, would join them; and his whole statement goes to suggest the inference that, but for these delusive representations, Messrs. LAW and CONOVER would not have consented to become responsible for his official faith.

abstract: United States Commissioner MORELL, yesterday, resumed the examination of the case of the slaver Erie, Mr. Joachimssen appearing for the defendants, and the District-Attorney conducting the case for the Government. Wm.M.E. Warren, the mate of the vessel, was cross-examined by the District-Attorney, during which it appeared that the hail of the American steamer was answered in English; ...
lead_paragraph: United States Commissioner MORELL, yesterday, resumed the examination of the case of the slaver Erie, Mr. Joachimssen appearing for the defendants, and the District-Attorney conducting the case for the Government. Wm.M.E. Warren, the mate of the vessel, was cross-examined by the District-Attorney, during which it appeared that the hail of the American steamer was answered in English; he did not know what was done with the ship's papers; Capt. Gordon did not say they were destroyed; witness kept the log-book on the outward passage; thirty-six pipes of rum were discharged in the Congo, and one hundred tons of ballast taken in; the negroes were not on board on the 6th of August; they sailed on the 7th; they were only twenty-four hours at sea when they were hailed by the Mohican; witness made no entries after the 6th, as he had nothing to do with the matter after that date; he did not haul out the flag; was on deck at the time it was done. Another book was presented, which was claimed by the witness as his private property. It contained essays and odes on all subjects, and eulogies in rhyme and blank verse on Washington, Jackson and Henry Clay, and religious dissertations. Describing a launch, the writer goes on to remark that "when a vessel is first launched into the water, it is impossible for any one to tell in what business she will be engaged." Witness said he did not belong to the United States.

abstract: A very large audience listened to M. DE CORDOVA's lecture on "the Past and Present condition of the Jews," delivered in Clinton Hall last evening. Commencing with the Biblical renown of the Israelites, the lecturer traced the distinction of that nation in the field of letters of arms, of medicine, and, in fact, of all the arts and sciences, demonstrating that they are well worthy a place in history. He cited the popular idea of a Jew as that of a man with a very protuberant proboscis, engaged in buying old clo', renovating them by same mysterious and secret process, and selling them for eight times their value to unsuspecting countrymen. He accounted for the degraded condition of the lower class of Israelites from the fact of the relentless persecutions to which the race has been subjected in Austria, Spain, Germany and other countries, where they have been obliged to withstand the most terrible pains and penalties in their adherence to the religion of their fathers. He read official correspondence from Holland to show the good effect of emancipation the Jewish nation in that country, and from the increasing liberality manifested in all countries -- taking example by America -- he foretold a glorious future for Israel. As to the politics of this country he knew many Jews who would vote for LINCOLN. [Loud applause and a few hisses.] Some who would vote for DOUGLAS. [Faint applause.] Some who would go for BRECKENRIGDE, [slight applause -- the Breckinridge men being probably in the torch-light procession,] and two or three who were Know-Nothings. [Laughter.] In conclusion, M. DE CORDOVA paid a glowing tribute of admiration to our free institutions, which alike honor and protect the Jew and the Gentile.
lead_paragraph: A very large audience listened to M. DE CORDOVA's lecture on "the Past and Present condition of the Jews," delivered in Clinton Hall last evening. Commencing with the Biblical renown of the Israelites, the lecturer traced the distinction of that nation in the field of letters of arms, of medicine, and, in fact, of all the arts and sciences, demonstrating that they are well worthy a place in history. He cited the popular idea of a Jew as that of a man with a very protuberant proboscis, engaged in buying old clo', renovating them by same mysterious and secret process, and selling them for eight times their value to unsuspecting countrymen. He accounted for the degraded condition of the lower class of Israelites from the fact of the relentless persecutions to which the race has been subjected in Austria, Spain, Germany and other countries, where they have been obliged to withstand the most terrible pains and penalties in their adherence to the religion of their fathers. He read official correspondence from Holland to show the good effect of emancipation the Jewish nation in that country, and from the increasing liberality manifested in all countries -- taking example by America -- he foretold a glorious future for Israel. As to the politics of this country he knew many Jews who would vote for LINCOLN. [Loud applause and a few hisses.] Some who would vote for DOUGLAS. [Faint applause.] Some who would go for BRECKENRIGDE, [slight applause -- the Breckinridge men being probably in the torch-light procession,] and two or three who were Know-Nothings. [Laughter.] In conclusion, M. DE CORDOVA paid a glowing tribute of admiration to our free institutions, which alike honor and protect the Jew and the Gentile.

abstract: Mr. W.L. YANCEY has produced a very favorable impression upon the Northern audiences he has recently addressed by the apparent candor and fairness which he has brought to the discussion of political topics. Upon one or two points of his speeches we are compelled to doubt whether he deserves ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. W.L. YANCEY has produced a very favorable impression upon the Northern audiences he has recently addressed by the apparent candor and fairness which he has brought to the discussion of political topics. Upon one or two points of his speeches we are compelled to doubt whether he deserves the credit for fair dealing which he has received. There are one or two points of history on which it would be presumptuous to suppose him ignorant, and on which it is yet impossible to believe him well informed without impeaching his integrity. The relations of the North to the Slave-trade, at the time the Constitution was formed, is one of them.

What possible contingency can provoke further displays, it is difficult to conceive. The military and the firemen, Wide-Awakes, Minute Men and Little Giants have had their ...
lead_paragraph: It may not be entirely rash to assume that, with the really dazzling and melodramatic display which last night demonstrated the devotion of Capt. RYNDERS to the Union and to three parties of irreconcileable politics, the season of parades has been brought to a close. What possible contingency can provoke further displays, it is difficult to conceive. The military and the firemen, Wide-Awakes, Minute Men and Little Giants have had their turn; we have done honor to the Prince of Wales, to our partisan convictions and to ourselves, by the splendor and force of our Autumnal demonstrations; and unless there be some grand jubilee by party or parties unknown over the result of the Presidential election, there is no visible excuse for more of this pretty and highly respectable child's play.

abstract: The Fusion demonstration in this City, last evening, was undoubtedly a success, in regard  to the extent of the procession, and the general display throughout the almost interminable line. In fact, it was all that those who created it had promised, in point of numbers and variety of embellishments. At an early hour in the evening the various Douglas, Breckinridge and Bell and Everett ...
lead_paragraph: The Fusion demonstration in this City, last evening, was undoubtedly a success, in regard to the extent of the procession, and the general display throughout the almost interminable line. In fact, it was all that those who created it had promised, in point of numbers and variety of embellishments. At an early hour in the evening the various Douglas, Breckinridge and Bell and Everett delegations from Kings County, Queens County and Richmond County; from Jersey City, Hoboken, Patterson, New-Brunswick, Perth Amboy, Newark, Philadelphia, and elsewhere, began to pour into the City, and make their way to their several rendezvous; and soon afterwards the Ward Associations of the City were under way, carrying banners with strange devices, and most of them preceded by at least a fife and drum. At 9 o'clock the City was ablaze with burning torches, and the air was burdened with rockets, Roman candles, lamp-smoke, and "I wish I was in Dixy." There were in the several divisions at this time, probably, about 25,000 persons -- some arrayed in red shirts, some in white, some in uniform coats, many in their every-day apparel, and all, together with their banners, transparencies, temples of Liberty, boats on wheels, and torches in hand, forming an exciting spectacle. The procession, however, though immense and imposing, showed none of the marks of discipline, such as regularity of step and line, which marked the parade of their better drilled opponents, the Wide-Awakes, on the occasion of their recent evening display. The gathering of the people upon the sidewalks, and at the doors and windows, along the line of the procession, was very great -- it could not well have been greater -- and the enthusiasm with which the companies were received, as they passed along, was all that could have been desired. There was one peculiarity about it, however, which was occasioned by the peculiar character of the procession.

abstract: A trotting-match was to have taken place yesterday, on the Union Course, between two fast horses, a roan gelding, Red Robin, driven by Mr. PEIPER, and a bay stallion, driven by Mr. DOTY, mile heats, in wagons, best three in five, for $1,000; but coming to the scratch, the stallion broke up into a run three times on starting, and a fresh attempt was ordered in each case by the Judges. The owners of the delinquent horse finally withdrew him, and paid, half forfeit; and the money was returned to the disappointed spectators, about 200 in number.

abstract: We have just been favored in New-York with an artistic revival more interesting than the exhumation of any Egyptian belle of the Court of the Pharaohs. ...
lead_paragraph: We have just been favored in New-York with an artistic revival more interesting than the exhumation of any Egyptian belle of the Court of the Pharaohs. CLEOPATRA herself, disinterred in the shape of a monotonous mummy, would hardly charm the most imaginative of antiquarians; but the "Danae" of WERTMULLER has flashed out upon New-York after forty years of seclusion in the cabinet of a jealous virtuoso at Philadelphia, as fresh and bright and irresistible a vision of loveliness as she was when she turned the heads of our respectable grandfathers in the days before Waterloo. The name of WERTMULLER is an artistic tradition in America. Born a Swede, and bred a Frenchman, this exiled court-painter of LOUIS XVI, is chiefly known to us by his not very edifying or inspiring portrait of WASHINGTON. This portrait is a popular household image of the Father of his Country, but it conveys to the aesthetic student the very faintest notion of the artistic ability of the painter. To pass from the contemplation of this rigid, estimable, but rather dreary figure of a stately citizen to the glaring beauty and delicate fascination of the same artist's "Danae," is hardly less of a surprise than it would be to take a quiet supper with Lord JOHN RUSSELL, and find TITIAN's "Venus" presiding at the teapot.

abstract: A large and enthusiastic meeting was held, last evening, at the Republican Head-quarters, No. 178 Prince-street, Mr. W.F.T. CHAPMAN presiding. After an introductory song from "Old Abe's Choir," the chairman introduced Mr. EMAN ALLIN as the "young American orator," who was greeted with enthusiastic applause. He proceeded to deliver an eloquent and telling speech, which fully justified the title given him by the chairman, and drew forth frequent and unanimous plaudits form his hearers. He quoted JEFFERSON, CLAY and WEESTER as the authors and enunciators of Anti-Slavery sentiments, such as are now advanced by the Republican Party. At the close of Mr. ALLEN's speech, Mr. G.F. TEFT was introduced, and entertained the audience for a half-hour or more, at the close of which another song was sung by "Old Abe's Choir," and the meeting adjourned.

abstract: We observe, with much pleasure, that earnest efforts are being made to place before our citizens, at the next election, a fusion Judiciary ticket, which shall be composed of the best men put in nomination by both our great...
lead_paragraph: We observe, with much pleasure, that earnest efforts are being made to place before our citizens, at the next election, a fusion Judiciary ticket, which shall be composed of the best men put in nomination by both our great political parties. The Bench is our last refuge for the defence of free institutions, and against any machinery which seeks to elevate bad men to judicial rank, the honest voters of all parties should combine.

abstract: The annual course of Clinical Lectures, at Bellevue Hospital, was inaugurated yesterday afternoon. The introductory was delivered by the President of the Medical Board of the Hospital, Dr. JOHN W. FRANCIS. The Board of Commissioners of Public Charities and Correction was present, as were about 200 students. Mr. S. DRAPER, President of the Board of Commissioners, presided. On taking the Chair, he alluded briefly to the duties of those connected with the institution, and spoke favorably of the manner in which the duties had been discharged. He believed the government of the Hospital had been such as to commend it to the people of New-York, and place it on a footing with any other similar institution in the country. He stated that the Board had spent $15,000 within the past six months in perfecting arrangements whereby to facilitate its future operations, which would tend to crown them with stiff greater success than ever. When Mr. DRAPER had concluded, Dr. VALENTINE MOTT arose, and was warmly greeted. He said he appeared before the students as a representative of the Medical Board, simply to urge upon them the necessity of giving earnest heed to the instruction, they would there receive. He then introduced Dr. FRANCIS, who said he appeared before them again as an instructor only at the earnest solicitation of the Medical Faculty connected with the Hospital. In some respects, he stud, the old administration had been changed for a new one, which he had no doubt would further the interests of the institution. The Bellevue Hospital was now considered, for many reasons, the first in the land. An improved code of laws had been added which rendered its operations more than ever effective. He would not then attempt to lecture upon any specific disease, but rather point out to the students the facilities now offered them for the acquisition of that practical knowledge which could be obtained in the example daily affered at this institution. And he trusted they would see the necessity of making the most of the opportunity offorded them. Dr. FRANCIS was several times applauded in the course of his address, and concluded with an earnest appeal to the students to be diligent in the labor assigned to their hands, recommending this as being the very best method by which they could advance to ultimate perfection in medical science. The following gentlemen compose the Medical Board for the ensuing year; Drs. J.W. Francis, Valentine Mott, Green, Loomis, A.B. Mott, Jas. R. Wood, Taylor, Church and McCready.

abstract: The denizens of Broadway were startled last evening by the sudden appearance of a Wide-Awake Torchlight Procession. ...
lead_paragraph: The denizens of Broadway were startled last evening by the sudden appearance of a Wide-Awake Torchlight Procession. Quiet people possibly hoped that the monster demonstration of Tuesday night was the climax to torchlight parades for the present season, but they were destined to be disappointed. The Wide-Awakes were no doubt inspired by a lofty ambition to impress upon the minds of the public the contrast between their demonstrations and those of their opponents; and though all must concede to the latter superiority in numbers, few will be prepared to deny that as a respectable representation, nothing of the kind ever attempted in New-York can approach a Wide-Awake parade. They swept past the TIMES Office last night like well-disciplined regiments, to the number of 3,000 or more, with bands of music and characteristic banners and insignia. Their torches were as steady upon the march as the bayonets of the Seventh Regiment, and they wheeled into the Park to the order of "right shoulder, forward," with the military precision of that unrivaled corps.

abstract: The Republicans of Queens County gathered in great force yesterday in a beautiful grove near Brush- ville, L.I.; devoured an ox, which had been roasted whole; listened to speeches from distinguished men in a beautifully decorated wigwarn and out doors; had...
lead_paragraph: The Republicans of Queens County gathered in great force yesterday in a beautiful grove near Brush- ville, L.I.; devoured an ox, which had been roasted whole; listened to speeches from distinguished men in a beautifully decorated wigwarn and out doors; had an old-fashioned clam-bake, and made a day and a night of it generally. In the morning, companies of Wide-Awakes from Astoria, Flushing, Hempstead, Jamaica, Smithville, Glen Cove, Minncola, and the Ashland Artillery -- numbering about 500 men altogether -- marched in procession to the grove. There thousands of people were assembled around the inclosure in which the ox, weighing 890 pounds, was spitted. At 1 o'clock, its demolition commenced, and an hour later it would have been difficult to find a vestige of it. Its devouring, however, was conducted with excellent order; and when it was completed, as many as could squeeze themselves in assembled in the Wigwam, where, at 3 o'clock, R.L. MEEKS, Esq., called the meeting to order, and Vice-Chancellor WM.T. MACOMB was called to the Chair. He briefly addressed the meeting, predicting a Republican triumph.

abstract: We can scarcely credit the statements made in the China papers, that an American ship-of-war had called at Shanghai, and had refused protection to the persons and property of American citizens. Two journals, however, the China Mail and the Hong Kong Press, corroborate the report that the United States ship Hartford, bearing the flag of Commodore STRIBLING, arrived at Shanghai, during the invasion panic, and left port almost immediately, though urgent remonstrances against her departure were made by the American residents of the place. The mere report of a proceeding like this calls for satisfactory explanation, and we trust that, for his own sake, Commodore STRIBLING will be able to give it. American interests, not only in China but in every foreign country where we have any interests at stake, have been so shamefully neglected by the present Administration that we do not look for much in that quarter. But we can hardly believe that an officer in the American Naval service would so far neglect his duty towards his fellow-citizens, in their time of need, as to refuse them the protection and assistance they demanded. The Hong Kong papers are circumstantial in their statements, but we hope to hear them contradicted by later intelligence.

abstract: Last evening the so-called Union Nominating Convention, called under the auspicies of the National Democratic Volunteers, met at Head-quarters, No.751 Broadway, Mr. SOLOMONS in the chair. ...
lead_paragraph: Last evening the so-called Union Nominating Convention, called under the auspicies of the National Democratic Volunteers, met at Head-quarters, No.751 Broadway, Mr. SOLOMONS in the chair. After the transaction of routine business, the Committee appointed to make selections of candidates from those already nominated by the Democratic Parties, of which Gen. LLOYD was chairman, reported that they had finished their labors, and had agreed upon all candidates with the exception of Register. On this candidate he was sorry to say the entire Committee had not agreed. The majority of the Committee had agreed upon Mr. LYNCH. [Hisses and applause.]

abstract: The investigations of Professor PUGH, of Pennsylvania, on the assimilation of gaseous nitrogen by plants, presented before the Scientific Convention at its late meeting, were reported at the time in these columns.
lead_paragraph: -- The investigations of Professor PUGH, of Pennsylvania, on the assimilation of gaseous nitrogen by plants, presented before the Scientific Convention at its late meeting, were reported at the time in these columns. It may be remembered that his conclusions went to show decisively that no assimilation of the free nitrogen of the atmosphere takes place. This result is confirmed by a recent communication to the Chemical News, ("On the Sources of the Nitrogen of Plants,") by Dr. CHARLES CAMERON, who is satisfied from numerous carefully conducted experiments, that neither the gaseous nitrogen of the atmosphere nor the combined nitrogen of humus can be assimilated by plants and that the nutriment of plants can only be supplied by substances of a purely inorganic nature. In addition to the list of substances capable of furnisning nitrogen to plants (as urea, soda, cyanurates of potash, etc.,) he is, from some new experiments, able to add two, viz.: nitrate of potash and ferrocyanide of potash. These investigations are of high theoretical and practical value.

abstract: The chances of Brigadier LANE continuing to serve his country in that august body the United States Senate grow daily less. ...
lead_paragraph: The chances of Brigadier LANE continuing to serve his country in that august body the United States Senate grow daily less. Oregon has ungratefully repudiated his distinguished services, replacing him by Mr. JAMES W. NESMITH, who will take his seat on the 5th of March next; while for the chair formerly filled by DFLAZON SMITH, Col. E.D. BAKER has been selected. Mr. NESMITH is an adherent of Popular Sovereignty, and of the fortunes of Mr. DOUGLAS; Col. BAKER is represented as being favorable to the opinions of Mr. ELI THAYER, regarding the political efficacy of colonization as the antagonist of Slavery; and, therefore, agrees with so much of his colleague's platform as denies the necessity of Congressional intervention for the discomfiture of servile labor. Evidently, therefore, Oregon has turned its back upon the Administration. None of the several phases of persuasion to which Mr. BUCHANAN has in turn addicted himself finds favor with these sturdy settlers of the Northwest; who, in deserting LANE after his ten years of diligent service as delegate and Senator, sufficiently indicate that the fatal fault lies in his recent and obtrusive devotion to the interests of the Slavery propagandists. Because he is willing to appear on the Presidential ticket nominated by the Secessionists, he is dismissed by his immediate constituents. The story is an old one; LANE is only its latest illustration.

abstract: On the twelfth day of next month the official term of our present Street Commissioner expires, and it will become the duty of the Mayor to name his successor. ...
lead_paragraph: On the twelfth day of next month the official term of our present Street Commissioner expires, and it will become the duty of the Mayor to name his successor. The Street Department is one of the most important branches of our City Government, its annual disbursements exceeding three millions of dollars, and the peculiar nature of its work making it the largest field for peculative jobbery. Under it is one bureau having charge of all the wharves, piers, and slips around Manhattan Island; to another is assigned the care of all streets, roads, and avenues; a third has supervision of public lighting; a fourth of lands, parks, and public squares; a fifth of repairs and supplies; and lastly, there is that most important bureau for the "collection of assessments," which should certainly be attached to the Comptroller's office -- its duties having direct connection with the public funds, and but very little with the Street Department proper.
headline: {'main': 'The Street Department.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Street Department.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: On Tuesday night, while the procession was passing through Broadway, Officer Barry, of the Fifth Ward, observed the front door of building No. 283 partly open. He went into the hallway and listened, but had not waited long before he heard a noise as if some person was breaking open a door on the second floor. Going up stairs he saw a young man named James Smith attempting to force open the door of Mme. Sinnot's ladies' head-dress manufactory, but at sight of the policeman the thief sought to escape arrest by concealing himself in the attic, whither he ran. He was followed, however, and captured, after which, upon searching him, a quantity of glaziers' diamonds, picture frames and daguerreotypist's materials were found. These articles were subsequently identified by Mr. Charles Worms us having been stolen from his gallery, which was in the building. Justice KELLY yesterday fully committed the prisoner for trial on a charge of burglary. Mme. Sinnot's rooms have been visited by burglars three times within the past eight months, and over $700 worth of property has been stolen from her.

abstract: We receive additional European news by the City of Washington, whose arrival off Cape Race was announced in yesterday's TIMES. Fuller par- ticulars are given of the battle of volturno. ...
lead_paragraph: We receive additional European news by the City of Washington, whose arrival off Cape Race was announced in yesterday's TIMES. Fuller par- ticulars are given of the battle of volturno. The Neapolitans, after a well contested fight, were thoroughly beaten, and lost 5,000 prisoners and 3,000 in killed and wounded. The King of Naples was present at the battle. There was a rumor current that Capua had surrendered, but it lacks confirmation. The Sardinian troops had entered Neapolitan territory, and several of the Great Powers had protested against the step. The Pope, according to the latest accounts, remained at Rome. A number of places around the Eternal City had been occupied by French troops, and the statement that an additional division would be sent from France indicates that the Emperor is determined to protect the Holy Father from his Sardinian or Garibaldian enemies. Military movements on a large scale are reported in Austria.

abstract: The present year of Grace, when bound and shelved, will be a perfect wonder-book. It will read very much like one of the fairy tales, loved of children, where every page is embroidered with surprises and punctuated with princes. As a record of royal pilgrimages it should be bound in purple, and studded with coronets. The summer months were as prolific of princes as of roses. ...
lead_paragraph: The present year of Grace, when bound and shelved, will be a perfect wonder-book. It will read very much like one of the fairy tales, loved of children, where every page is embroidered with surprises and punctuated with princes. As a record of royal pilgrimages it should be bound in purple, and studded with coronets. The summer months were as prolific of princes as of roses. First came the swart Mongolians, from the distant Isle of Niphon, with their paper fans, and loose trowsers and unpronounceable names. Having feted and feasted them we sent them back to the land of their Tycoon, rejoicing and laden with presents. Scarcely had their footsteps become inaudible, as they went their watery way, before the eldest son of our beloved BUCHANAN's "good friend" crossed our threshold, and to him we extended the friendly hand of greeting. Mindful of his morals and of the mild request of his most excellent mother, we preserved him from contact with BOOLE and from association with FARLEY. We threw open the doors of our ball-rooms to him as Prince of the Dance, and hailed him in Trinity as Lord of the Aisles. On our Atlantic threshold we bade him a hearty God-speed, and now his waving plume, with its Bohemian legend, is dancing over the waves. But scarcely has one Prince bowed himself out of our Eastern portals than another comes knocking at our Goldon Gate on the Pacific -- the Prince of Hawaii craves audience of our Republic. Exit ALBERT EDWARD -- enter Prince LOT.
headline: {'main': 'And Yet Another Prince.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'And Yet Another Prince.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We have fallen into the comfortable habit of denouncing the Slave-trade, as though it was an iniquity that could not possibly be laid at our own door; but recent revelations have gone far to prove that a very considerable...
lead_paragraph: We have fallen into the comfortable habit of denouncing the Slave-trade, as though it was an iniquity that could not possibly be laid at our own door; but recent revelations have gone far to prove that a very considerable portion of the capital embarked in this iniquitous business is obtained in New-York. The open encouragement given by Spain to the Slave-trade cannot be too heavily denounced. Her course has drawn upon her the odium of the whole world, and her flagrant violation of treaty stipulations has been sufficient to exclude her from the councils of European nations. Even Brazil has given to Spain an example that she would do well to imitate; for Brazil, taking a higher view of the subject than a purely mercernary one, has made the abandonment of a traffic -- condemned as piracy by all great and enlightened nations, and, in every respect, diametrically opposed to the spirit of the age, -- a point of national honor and pride.

abstract: The Long Island Farmer publishes a correspondence between the editor of that paper and Mr. Richard Busteed. ...
lead_paragraph: -- The Long Island Farmer publishes a correspondence between the editor of that paper and Mr. Richard Busteed, Mr. Busteed, it seems, attempted to enlighten the Democracy of Jamaica on Mr. Douglas' qualifications for the Presidency, and Welling, the editor of the Farmer, made, charges which Mr. Busteed thus sums up: "Your article suggests that in my life and conduct I publicly invade the sanctity of the Subbath; that I am of intemperate habits; that my practices and pursuits are opposed to the prosperity of the schools and churches in our midst, and to the advancement of learning and the maintenance of good order in the community in which we dwell." Mr. Welling admitted that he was the author of the article in question, and Mr. Busteed addressed him as follows: "Come, Sir, toe the mark -- enter a retraxit; or make proof of your accusations; or stand convicted in the judgment of liberal men, and in foro conscientae of a scandalous violation of truth and decency." To this demand Mr. Welling responded by asking Mr. Busteed to point out the offensive expressions in the editorial complained of, but he declined to do more than he had already done, so the difficulty stands unadjusted.

abstract: A BAD TRADE. -- A New-York merchant, who does a little farming in a small way, in the Eighteenth Ward, had a few barrels of very choice apples on his trees, this Fall. Last week a man who was passing by made him a tempting offer for the apples, which was accepted, and the purchaser agreed to gather them the next morning. Our City farmer waited some time for his customer the following morning, and finally proceeded to his business without seeing him. Upon returning home in the evining, he found the purchaser had been there and gathered the apples, but left without paying for them. The City farmer has not seen him since.
lead_paragraph: A BAD TRADE. -- A New-York merchant, who does a little farming in a small way, in the Eighteenth Ward, had a few barrels of very choice apples on his trees, this Fall. abstract: A portion of the subscribers to the fund for the benefit of Capt. JOHN WILSON, his officers and crew, of the brig Minnie Schiffer, for their humane efforts in rescuing the passengers of the steamer Connaught, met yesterday at the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce, for the purpose of making the proper...
lead_paragraph: A portion of the subscribers to the fund for the benefit of Capt. JOHN WILSON, his officers and crew, of the brig Minnie Schiffer, for their humane efforts in rescuing the passengers of the steamer Connaught, met yesterday at the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce, for the purpose of making the proper. disposition of the fund already subscribed. Mr. PELATIAH PERIT, President of the Chamber of Commerce, Capt. C.H. MARSHALL, Mr. LATHROP, SAMUEL SCHIFFER, the owner of the brig, and other prominent merchants, attended. Mr. WM. HURRY, Mr. Fox, and two or three other passengers of the ill-fated steamer, were also present, testifying their deep interest in the objects of the meeting. After some informal conversation between the members of the Committee, Mr. P. PERIT was elected Chairman, and G.G. HOWLAND, of the firm of HOWLAND & ASPINWALL, Secretary of the meeting. Mr. SCHIFFER, on being introduced, rose and stated to the meeting that he, in common with his partners, the owners of the Minnie Schiffer, felt great satisfaction that their little vessel had been instrumental, in the hands of her noble Captain, in rescuing from a dreadful fate so large a number of their fellow-creatures, and this feeling was the only reward which they coveted for the service she had rendered. He desired that the donations of the merchants which had already been made, as well as those which should hereafter be subscribed, should be appropriated wholly to the generous seamen, who deserved so well of their follow-citizens.

abstract: Byron Lafllin et al. vs. Benjamin Hoagland et al. This was an action brought to recover the balance due for rent of part of premises No. 298 Green  wich-street, from the defendants, alleged to be partners. ...
lead_paragraph: Byron Lafllin et al. vs. Benjamin Hoagland et al. This was an action brought to recover the balance due for rent of part of premises No. 298 Green wich-street, from the defendants, alleged to be partners. The defendant, Hoagland, answered, and defended upon the ground, first, that there was no partnership between the defendants, and that the premises were let to defendant. Mason; second, that he had been discharged pursuant to the provisions of the statute for the discharge of an insolvent from his debts.

abstract: The formal opening and dedication of the new building lately purchased by the Rutgers Female Institute in Fifth-avenue, opposite the Reservoir, took place in the chapel of the institute last evening. The chapel, together with the lobbies and adjacent rooms, was crowded to excess, the larger portion of the audience being ladies. The exercises were opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. SPRING. Prof. HENRY M. PIEECE, the Principal of the Institute, then addressed the audience, and gave a brief sketch of the history of the Institution. It was founded twenty-one years ago, and took the name of Rutgers Female Institute, in compliment to Col. RUTGER, who gave the land on which the institute was built in Madison-street. Prof. PIERCE spoke of the progress and prosperity of the Institution from that time to the present, and of the change in its location, made necessary by the upward movement of population. Since 1853 there had been a falling off in the number of pupils, owing to the Institution being located so far down town; but the prospects of the school were now brighter than ever. The term opened in the new building on the 13th of September, with 75 pupils, which number had been increased in little more than a month to upwards of 200. He alluded to the excellent accommodations of the new building, to the large library, and extensive philosophical apparatus belonging to the Institution, &c., &c.

Since 1853 there had been a falling off in the number of pupils, owing to the Institution being located so far down town; but the prospects of the school were now brighter than ever. The term opened in the new building on the 13th of September, with 75 pupils, which number had been increased in little more than a month to upwards of 200. He alluded to the excellent accommodations of the new building, to the large library, and extensive philosophical apparatus belonging to the Institution, &c., &c.

abstract: This Society held their first anniversary last evening in St. George's Church, Stuyvesant-square. The attendance was fair, though the church was by no means crowded. ...
lead_paragraph: This Society held their first anniversary last evening in St. George's Church, Stuyvesant-square. The attendance was fair, though the church was by no means crowded. Rev. JOHN S. STONE, D.D., of Massachusetts, Vice-President of the Society, presided in the absence of the President, Hon. PHILLIP WILLIAMS, of Virginia. After the singing of a hymn, prayer was offered by Rev. THEO. IRVING, of Staten Island. The address of the President was then road by Dr. H. DYER, followed by the reading of the annual report by Rev. Dr. TYNG.

abstract: In our exposure yesterday of Mr. YANCEY'S ignorance or recklessness of historical truth, we had barely room, within the appropriate limits of an editorial, to rebut his misrepre-
lead_paragraph: In our exposure yesterday of Mr. YANCEY'S ignorance or recklessness of historical truth, we had barely room, within the appropriate limits of an editorial, to rebut his misrepresentations of the Northern members of the Convention which framed the Constitution, by brief citations from their speeches. It may be shown with equal clearness, that nearly all of the States had already abolished the slave-trade, and that this fact was strongly pressed upon the attention of the Convention, by way of inducing the majority to yield their objections to the clause providing for the toleration of the traffic for a brief period. All the Northern States together with Maryland and Virginia had irrevocably abolished the slave-trade long before the Convention met. North Carolina imposed a tax of five pounds per head upon Africans imported directly, and ten pounds if brought in from other States. The Legislature of South Carolina, the year before the Convention met, passed an act prohibiting the importation of Slaves for one year, and renewed it for three years. Indeed this prohibition was continued for fifteen years, and the State denied herself the real or supposed advantages of the traffic in slaves for more than three-fourths of the period of twenty years during which Congress was withheld from its final abolition.

abstract: -- A blunder, very characteristic of the administration of criminal justice in New-York, will be found noticed in our Law reports to-day. It appears that on a motion in the Court of Oyer and Terminer to arraign FRANCIS ENRIGHT for the manslaughter of one DANIEL HORRIGAN, counsel for the prisoner moved to have the trial postponed under plea that an important witness for the defence was "absent in Europe." The Court, to guard against imposition, directed that an affidavit supporting the plea should be made; whereupon an affidavit was drawn, averring that the witness in question "had left New-York only three weeks ago in the steamer Connaught, hound for Ireland" -- that unfortunate vessel, as we all know, having been burned within a day's sail of Boston, on her voyage from Galway to that port, about the time indicated. Nevertheless, the venerable Judge of the Oyer and Terminer accepted the affidavit as satisfactory, and the order for postponement was made!
lead_paragraph: -- A blunder, very characteristic of the administration of criminal justice in New-York, will be found noticed in our Law reports to-day. Nevertheless, the venerable Judge of the Oyer and Terminer accepted the affidavit as satisfactory, and the order for postponement was made!

abstract: As a gentleman's horse, next to his wife, dog or yacht, is the object which is dearest to his heart, and in which he takes most pride, it can well be imagined what are the motives which have induced a number of gentlemen to associate themselves together for the purpose of trying the speed of their road horses on the Fashion Course to-morrow. As a general thing it has been the custom with gentlemen who delight in owning fast horses, to have a brush with one another on the road, the trotting on the race courses being confined to men who have made it a business to get up trots, the results of which -- it is said -- are generally known before hand to the initated, and thus the public often get led, by sham bets, to wager their money to a considerable extent on the losing horse. Mr. MCNNOT, a gentleman who has devoted some years, and a large amount of money, to improving the breed of horses, has taken the initiative in getting up the present trot, which is exclusively for gentlemen's horses, -- entirely excluding the hippodromes, -- and for which he has offend a prize of $500, to be contended for in mile beats, best three in five. For this trial of speed there are entered already Mr. MCNNOT's favorite bay gelding, Tartar; Mr. FULTER, another associate, has entered his bay gelding, Putnam; and another gentleman has entered the bay mare Belle Brandon, which won in a similar trial of speed lately on the Union Course, against Mystery, Tycoon and Boney Young, when four heats were trotted in 2:39 [???], 2:59 1/2, 2:42 1/4, 2:41 1/4. The great object in getting up the present trot, by the gentlemen concerned, is to get rid of many objectionable features which have prevailed to a great extent, and which have prevented great numbers of gentlemen from giving countenance to a pastime which might be made a respectable one, if conducted properly.

abstract: Shortly after nine o'clock last evening a young sailor, named JOHN MCGUIRE, accompanied by one of his companions, went into the dance-house, No. 275 Water-street, kept by JOHN GREENE, and behaved in a disorderly manner. The bar-keeper, WM. P. GREENE, brother of the keeper of the place, and a man named FOGARTY, who happened to be present, endeavored to prevail upon MCGUIRE to leave, as he was threatening to break the furniture and fixtures, and eventually they succeeded, without having had occasion to use violence. When MCGUIRE got into the street he commenced to abuse the occupants of the saloon, and drawing a sheath-knife, threatened to murder every person within the building. His noise and threats attracted a crowd, and WM. GREENE finally became so much incensed that he ran towards the ruffian and said that he would thrash him unless he speedily departed. Scarcely had he uttered the words, however, ere MCGUIRE sprang upon him, and thrust his knife into his abdomen, causing a shocking wound, from which the entrails protruded to such an extent that they filled a wash bowl, and remained in the vessel until Drs. ROONEY and CHAMBERLIN came to replace them. As soon as he had inflicted the violence. MCGUIRE ran off down Water-street, pursued by the crowd, who called "Murder! Watch!" and on reaching the corner of Beekman-street he was arrested by Officer SIMONSON, of the Second Precinct, and conducted to the Station-house. The physicians in attendance upon GREENE stated that the probability of his surviving the terrible injury was very slight, consequently Sergeant BRACKETT deemed it advisable to give the sufferer an opportunity to identify the prisoner, who was handcuffed and taken back to the scene of the affray. Upon being confronted with GREENE, the latter at once asserted that he was the person who had stabbed him, and several persons who witnessed the occurrence were positive in a similar statement.

abstract: DISTURBANCE AMONG EXCURSIONISTS PROBABLY FATAL ASSAULT. On Monday last a number of young men, belonging to Engine Co. No. 39, under the name of the Tradesmen's Guards, went to Tomlinson's Woods, near High Bridge, for target practice.
lead_paragraph: DISTURBANCE AMONG EXCURSIONISTS PROBABLY FATAL ASSAULT. On Monday last a number of young men, belonging to Engine Co. No. 39, under the name of the Tradesmen's Guards, went to Tomlinson's Woods, near High Bridge, for target practice. While there, a fight occurred between two of the party, named GEORGE MCCOMB and MICHAEL CLARE, and the jaw of the latter was broken in the encounter. After the excursionists had reached Fifty-ninth-street in the cars, on their way back to the City, and while forming into company to march down town, CLARE, it is said, ran behind Mr. WM.H. WARD, one of the spectators, and felled him to the ground by a blow on the head with the butt of his musket, supposing at the time that he was attacking MCCOMB. CLARE was immediately arrested by the Nineteenth Ward Police, and subsequently discharged, as Mr. WARD refused to make a complaint against him, Yesterday, however, the condition of the injured man became so critical from the effects of his wound that CLARE was rearrested, and held to await the result of the violence he had inflicted. The prisoner expresses much regret at having made such a serious mistake.

abstract: We have additional advices (to Sept. 11) from the Brazil squadron. The United States steam gunboat Dacotah, which turns out satisfactorily, arrived at Rib Janeiro on the 2d ult. from Madeira, where she stopped to coal and deliver mails for the naval, vessels on the African station. The Dacotah is one of the new gunboats, and is on her way to reinforce our East India squadron. She would sail from Rio for Hong Kong on the 18th ult. The intelligence obtained at Madeira from the African fleet reported the ships' companies in good health generally. The brig-of-war Bainbridge entered Rio on the 8th ult., and on the following day commenced taking in stores for her homeward-bound voyage. She would sail before the 20th; her arrival at Boston, which has been expected for weeks, may therefore take place very soon. The Dolphin had arrived at Buenos Ayres from Montevideo, so that the news, via England, announcing her departure for home was premature. She is ordered to return, however, which may account for the mistake. The Seminole was to proceed up the La Plata, but the whereabouts of the Congress and Pulaski are not known.
lead_paragraph: We have additional advices (to Sept. 11) from the Brazil squadron. The United States steam gunboat Dacotah, which turns out satisfactorily, arrived at Rib Janeiro on the 2d ult. from Madeira, where she stopped to coal and deliver mails for the naval, vessels on the African station. The Dacotah is one of the new gunboats, and is on her way to reinforce our East India squadron. She would sail from Rio for Hong Kong on the 18th ult. The intelligence obtained at Madeira from the African fleet reported the ships' companies in good health generally. The brig-of-war Bainbridge entered Rio on the 8th ult., and on the following day commenced taking in stores for her homeward-bound voyage. She would sail before the 20th; her arrival at Boston, which has been expected for weeks, may therefore take place very soon. The Dolphin had arrived at Buenos Ayres from Montevideo, so that the news, via England, announcing her departure for home was premature. She is ordered to return, however, which may account for the mistake. The Seminole was to proceed up the La Plata, but the whereabouts of the Congress and Pulaski are not known.

abstract: If the Bears of the Stock  Exchange fail to reward the President's organ at Washington for its services in beating down the value of Government credit preparatory to the late loan, it will be for the reason that  they are an ungrateful race of animals, or that they set no high value upon the influence of the organ aforesaid.
lead_paragraph: If the Bears of the Stock Exchange fail to reward the President's organ at Washington for its services in beating down the value of Government credit preparatory to the late loan, it will be for the reason that they are an ungrateful race of animals, or that they set no high value upon the influence of the organ aforesaid. That journal (we mean the Constitution) has for months labored assiduously to demonstrate that the Union should be, and will be dissolved, in the event of Mr. LINCOLN's election to the Presidency; and if these warnings from the head of the Government failed to bring down the premium which it would otherwise have received upon its stocks, the Old Public Functionary must have fallen very low indeed in the public estimation.

abstract: -Ex-President ROBERTS, of Liberia writing from Monrovia on Aug. 30, says: "You will have heard, before this reaches you, of the capture of two slave ships off Congo, and brought into this port, with some fourteen hundred slaves on board. Fortunately, the captives are mostly young persons -- boys and girls -- just such as, from their tender years, may be easily trained to habits of industry and civilization, and will no doubt readily adopt the principles of Christianity. Rev. Mr. SEYS, U.S. Agent for captured Africans, is judiciously, I think, distributing them in the families of citizens, who will attend to their proper training. I do hope that in time they will turn out good citizens, and will themselves be the means of advancing more rapidly the cause of civilization and Christianity in his heaten land. You will, of course, hear, through the Government and Rev. Mr. SEYS, all that relates to the landing and disposal of these people -- aside from which there appears' to be no news here worth communicating."
lead_paragraph: -Ex-President ROBERTS, of Liberia writing from Monrovia on Aug. 30, says: "You will have heard, before this reaches you, of the capture of two slave ships off Congo, and brought into this port, with some fourteen hundred slaves on board. abstract: We are  informed that a very distinguished merchant of this City, prominent hitherto in every Union movement, and a zealous Anti-Republican in principle, has declared his purpose to vote for LINCOLN, as a business operation. He wants this Presidential contest ended the sooner the better. If Mr. LINCOLN is elected, we shall know the worst at once, and can be prepared to meet it.
lead_paragraph: We are informed that a very distinguished merchant of this City, prominent hitherto in every Union movement, and a zealous Anti-Republican in principle, has declared his purpose to vote for LINCOLN, as a business operation. He wants this Presidential contest ended the sooner the better. If Mr. LINCOLN is elected, we shall know the worst at once, and can be prepared to meet it. But if the controversy is to be carried to the House of Representatives, it will engross public attention for at least four months, and will paralyze the business of the country for the whole season. He says he cannot afford to have his business stand still so long.

abstract: Ex-Recorder Smith appeared in Court yesterday morning, and before the regular proceedings were commenced addressed Judge GOULD, stating that he wished to correct an apparent discrepancy in the affidavit presented by him on the day previous, and sworn to by the defendant. Francis Enright, charged with the manslaughter of Daniel Horrigan. In that affaidavit it was stated that a principal witness for the defence, John Welsh by name, had sailed, three weeks since, from this port in the steamship Connaught for Ireland. That unfortunate vessel was burned within a few miles of Boston, about three weeks ago, on her return from Ireland. What the defendant meant to have stated in his affidavit was that the witness had sailed in some ship, (name not mentioned) for Connaught.

abstract: Senator COLLAMER, of Vermont, who has just been reelected by the General Assembly of that State, on Thursday last, addressed the members of the two branches, in accordance with a resolution inviting him to do so. After some allusions purely personal in their character, he touched upon the question of Slavery.
lead_paragraph: Senator COLLAMER, of Vermont, who has just been reelected by the General Assembly of that State, on Thursday last, addressed the members of the two branches, in accordance with a resolution inviting him to do so. After some allusions purely personal in their character, he touched upon the question of Slavery. Vermont, he said, could justly apply Paul's language to herself, "I was free born, I never was in bondage to any man," for she had never been a colony or in a condition of Territorial dependence. The Free Press, of Burlington, thus reports the concluding portion of Senator COLLAMER's speech:
