abstract: A strong pressure is being brought to bear upon the various Democratic organizations of our City in favor of having but one Anti-Republican candidate for Congress in each of the six Districts comprised with- in Manhattan Island. In obedience to this feeling, ANSON HERRICK, the Tammany Hall nominee for Congress in the Eighth District, consisting to the Twelfth, Eighteenth, Nineteenth, Twenty-first and Twentysecond Wards, called a meeting on last Monday even-...
lead_paragraph: A strong pressure is being brought to bear upon the various Democratic organizations of our City in favor of having but one Anti-Republican candidate for Congress in each of the six Districts comprised with- in Manhattan Island. In obedience to this feeling, ANSON HERRICK, the Tammany Hall nominee for Congress in the Eighth District, consisting to the Twelfth, Eighteenth, Nineteenth, Twenty-first and Twentysecond Wards, called a meeting on last Monday evening of all the leading Democrats in his District for the purpose of consulting them as to the best means for concentrating the Anti-Republican vote on some one candidate. Mr. HERRICK then submitted a letter, setting forth the certainty of ABRAHAM WAKEMAN's election, and professing his own willingness to withdraw, if by so doing, he could injure a concentration of the Democratic vote upon some other candidate not yet named.

abstract: A curious commentary on social life in this metropolis may be gathered from a fact which Rev. Dr. TYNG exhumed from the reminiscent rubbish of the great Ball, and gave to an audience in his own church the other evening. According to the reverend gentleman's statement, an eminent jeweler's house of this City cleared, from diamonds rented to ladies to glitter in the presence of Royalty, a sufficient sum to pay the rent of their store for a year. This is a most interesting and instructive fact. In Paris, and on the continent, as is pretty generally known, it has long been the custom for ladies to hire the jewelry which they coveted for special occasions, when their husbands were unable to buy it; but we believe the practice has not heretofore prevailed in this country. That it should now obtain is a good illustration of the ease with which our women can adopt all customs which are French and bad. Its exposure may go far to check that growing extravagance in gauds which brings many a family from trafficking with the house which displays one Ball on its sign to dealing with those which expose three. For a wealth of diamonds will come to be looked upon as suspiciously as an inordinate wealth of hair or unusually fine teeth. Dr. TYNG deserves thanks for giving this interesting information in regard to borrowed finery to the public. It is well sometimes to have a watchman in the pulpit whose thoughts and eyes are below the moon.

abstract: The mail contract between the Colonial authorities of Jamaica and ALFRED HOLT, of Liverpool, for carrying the mails between New-York and Kingston monthly, was to have gone into effect on the 5th of October -- to leave Kingston on that day and New-York on the 22d; the same days to be observed for the first two months, and afterwards (beginning with December) the 20th to be the day of leaving New-York. The contract is for five years, determinable at the discretion of either party at the end of three years. The steamers, according to contract, are to perform each passage in ten days. The forfeitures are fixed as follows: For delaying departure for forty-eight hours, £160; for seventy-two hours, £450; if any mail is not duly delivered after November, £125; no larger sum to be forfeited in one month than £700, (which, by the way, is £250 more than the monthly subsidy.) Payments are to be made quarterly, two months' instalments to be reserved in the first six months, and afterwards one month's instalment to be always in arrears. If the vessel is lost and the mails saved, they are to be transmitted at the expense of the contractor. The public may terminate the contract at one month's notice for repeated failure to fulfill contract. Under this contract the screw steamer Saladin, 530 tons, left Kingston on the 6th of October, midday, and reached New York on the night of the 17th. The screw steamer Zulu, 278 tons, was advertised to leave New-York on the 22d of October, but as yet, (the 25th,) she has not arrived from Liverpool, It is stated that the Zulu is to perform the service between Kingston and New-York under the contract, in connection with a similar steamer -- the Cleator, in reserve at Kingston.

abstract: The Albany Evening Journal states that Gov. MORGAN has recently received a large number of letters from different persons, urging him to inquire into the truth of statements made by the Independent regarding the alleged cruel punishment of TOM KELLY at Sing Sing. In compliance with these requests the Governor wrote to the Warden of the prison, alluding to the case of JELLY, and stating that the allegations were of so grave and serious a nature, and were so specifically stated, that he could not let them pass without due inquiry; and therefore requested to be informed if the mode of punishment known as the "shower bath" is resorted to at Sing Sing, to what extent, and what had been its effects, physically, upon the convicts.

abstract: -- AN EDITOR TERRIBLY BEATEN AND A RUFFIAN SHOT. -- The Louisville Courier, of Monday, says: "An oyster saloon on Market-street, between Third and Fourth, was the scene of a desperate and perhaps, fatal fight, yesterday morning at an early hour. Col. J. RUCKSTUHL, local editor of the Anzeiger, went into the place and took some refreshments, at a table where several Germans were eating. When he had finished he called for the bill, and MARTIN MILLER, the proprietor, told him he must pay for the whole party. RUCKSTUHL refused, and MILLER then locked the door and warned him if he did not comply with the demand he would assault him. The editor told him if he did he would shoot him. MILLER then struck him, and his brother and four or five others took part in the affray. They got RUCKSTUHL down, and were beating him terribly, when he drew a small revolver and shot MARTIN MILLER, the ball entering near the left nipple, and inflicted a fatal wound in all probability. The crowd then fled, leaving RUCKSTUHL the victor of the field, but covered with his own blood, and very badly injured. The Colonel was one of the braves who fought at Buena Vista, in the Kentucky cavalry, and he bears to this day the scars of the many wounds he received in that bloody fight. The ruffians who assaulted him are in jail.

abstract: The City of Norfolk sailed from the port of New-York on the 5th day of June last for the purpose, as we were informed, of entering the service of the Government of Venezuela as a transport. The steamer arrived at St. Thomas, the passage occupying ten days, where we remained six days, and discharged a part of the cargo, consisting of tobacco and packages of merchandise, apparently, the contents of which were unknown to us. While lying at this port we received on board the steamer two hundred tons of coal and eighteen large casks, the contents of which were not known to us at the time.
lead_paragraph: The City of Norfolk sailed from the port of New-York on the 5th day of June last for the purpose, as we were informed, of entering the service of the Government of Venezuela as a transport. abstract: Next in excellence to the virtue and wisdom which resist temptation and avoid error is the ingenuousness of free and frank confession of sin. The last is the merit of Ex-Senator BADGER, of North Carolina. Carried away by the storm of Pro-Slavery fanaticism which swept over the country in 1854, he forgot his old conservative instincts, the large and liberal...
lead_paragraph: Next in excellence to the virtue and wisdom which resist temptation and avoid error is the ingenuousness of free and frank confession of sin. The last is the merit of Ex-Senator BADGER, of North Carolina. Carried away by the storm of Pro-Slavery fanaticism which swept over the country in 1854, he forgot his old conservative instincts, the large and liberal maxims of Government which he had learned from WEBSTER and CLAY, as well as the plighted faith, of the South, and in an evil hour voted for the repeal of the Missouri Compromise. His best friends were deeply mortified at the fatal mistake he made, and they have never doubted that he himself deplored it as the weakest and worst act of his public life. We are gratified to perceive that Mr. BADGER has had the manliness at length to come forward voluntarily, and make a clean breast by an open confession of his grievous fault. In a speech at Raleigh, the seat of Government of North Carolina, he took occasion, a few days ago, to say that his vote for the Nebraska bill was "the worst vote he ever gave in his life," while he applauded the opposite course pursued by Mr. BELL, of Tennessee. This frank confession, by a very proud, as well as a very able man, was received by his audience, we are told, with wild enthusiasm -- a clear proof that North Carolina, like Mr. BADGER, has been dragged into Pro-Slavery ultraisms, against her better judgment, by the evil example and the arrogant leadership of her more pretentious neighbors, Virginia and South Carolina.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen last evening, a resolution to increase the salary of JOSEPH MURPHY, Deputy Superintendent of Lands and Places, to $1,500, was laid over. Pier No. 20, East river, was ordered to be repaired. A report in favor of paying Lexington-avenue, from Forty-second to Fifty-second steel, one-half the expense to be borne by the owners, was laid over.
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen last evening, a resolution to increase the salary of JOSEPH MURPHY, Deputy Superintendent of Lands and Places, to $1,500, was laid over. Pier No. 20, East river, was ordered to be repaired. A report in favor of paying Lexington-avenue, from Forty-second to Fifty-second steel, one-half the expense to be borne by the owners, was laid over. A large number of assessments for work completed were confirmed, as were several contracts heretofore awarded by the various departments. A report in favor of increasing the salaries of the general clerks in the Street Commissioner's office elicited some discussion, Alderman OWENS opposing it, and for one among other reasons, that it was contemplated to date the increase back to January, 1860.

abstract: The position of the Post-office Department is this: The public demands facilities like those of London and Paris. The Department, anxious to grant them, claims that it can be done only by having a monopoly of the business, which it is now endeavoring to secure by the enforcement of the laws against private expresses. The opposition with which it meets occasions much embarrassment.

abstract: For several years past, a few property-owners upon the line of Atlantic-street labored to secure the passage of an ordinance prohibiting the use of steam power on the Long Island Railroad, within the City limits. Time and again resolutions were passed by the Common Council, giving notice to the Company to desist from using steam; and time and again, when the objects of the speculators who had secured the passage of such a resolution had been attained by its mere adoption, the Railroad Company was permitted to continue the use of steam, until another opportunity for speculation occurred. Finally the Company, becoming tired of the continual annoyance to which it was in this way subjected, determined upon a change of terminus to a point where business men in the neighborhood would appreciate the advantages for business which a railroad almost always brings with it. The place selected was Hunter's Point, and since that was decided upon, preparations for the change have been progressing rapidly, under the general direction of Mr. MORRIS, the very efficient President of the Company. By the proposed arrangement the road will branch off at Jamaica for Hunter's Point, and passengers will be conveyed to New-York on the Hunter's Point Ferry boats. It is expected that the new road and extensive depot will be ready for use about the 1st of January next. It is stated that the Company intends to run three ferry-boats to James-slip, and two to Thirty-fourth-street, East River, for the accommodation of the business of the road. When the extension of Chambers-street is made, a direct route across the City, in connection with all the great arteries of traffic, will be opened up to the public traveling by the Long Island Railroad. The saving in the distance, to say nothing of the additional convenience to travelers, will be about two miles in the run from Jamaica. The depot is 500 feet long by 60 feet wide, and, when completed, will have cost $25,000. This change, by which a great proportion of the business of the road will be brought to Hunter's Point, instead of to Brooklyn, cannot but prove vastly beneficial to that place. The people there are delighted with the prospect, and are free in the expression of their thanks to the President and agents of the road, for the very liberal manner in which they have prepared for the change. The business men in South Brooklyn, now that the new arrangement has been decided upon, begin to express fears that they may possibly lose their Long Island customers, and regret the annoyance to the Company, which caused it.

abstract: -- A correspondent of the Lexington Dispatch, writing from Decaturville, Tenn., under date of the 14th inst., gives the following particulars of a terrible calamity: "As some negroes were passing the road leading from this place to Perryville, this morning, near Rushing Creek, they were attracted by the cries of a female, and upon examination with her husband, both confined by a long across them. It appears that they were traveling, and had stooped to camp, and had built their fire near a dead tree, which caught fire, (after they had fallen asleep), and burning off near the ground, fell angling across them breaking both the woman's legs, just below the knee, and killing the man almost instantly. When interrogating the woman we learned that the tree had fallen across them several hours before day, and that her husband lived long enough to tell her what to do after he was dead. She said she called till she could call no longer, for some one to come to her relief after her husband died, (not being able to extricate herself.) She also stated that her maiden name was WATTS, and that her husband's name was JEFFERSON KELLY; that they had been married about three months, and were going across Tennessee River, where corn was cheaper. When we reached the place where the unfortunate persons were, the scene was most horrifying, and the cries of the poor woman when taken away from her husband were enough to melt the most obdurate heart."

When interrogating the woman we learned that the tree had fallen across them several hours before day, and that her husband lived long enough to tell her what to do after he was dead. She said she called till she could call no longer, for some one to come to her relief after her husband died, (not being able to extricate herself.) abstract: The trial of speed for road horses, best 3 in 5, for Mr. MONNOT's prize of $500, took place yesterday on the fashion Course, and was a complete success About a thousand spectators were on the stands -- a larger proportion than common from among well-known and respectable citizens. The odds were slightly in favor of Putnam against the field, previous to the first heat. Three to one was bet on Tartar previous to the second heat, but it turned the other way previous to the third heat.

abstract: The day of long as well as expensive ocean trips has gone by. The time was when our fathers parted slowly with the land, after seeing the sun set thrice behind the dear heights of Nevasink. Now, in the same time, their children trace the cost line of half the Atlantic States and sleep on the third night within sound of the guns of Fort Moultrie.
lead_paragraph: MONTGOMERY, Ala., October.

abstract: -- The body of Mr. F.A. LUMSDEN, having at last been recovered on the shore of Lake Michigan, near the scene of the appalling disaster to the Lady Elgin, and brought to the city friends for interment, was entombed last evening by fitting honors. The funeral took place from the late residence of the deceased, on Rampart-street. The high dignitaries and many members of the Masonic and Odd Fellows orders, the Continental Guards, and the New-Orleans Typographical Union, (the latter in strong force,) all attended the funeral; the deceased having been long a member of the two orders and the military company, and an honorary member of the Typographical Union. Besides these, officers of the other military companies, and a large concourse of the personal friends of the deceased were present. The office of the Picayune newspaper, with which the deceased was so long and honorably connected as proprietor and Editor, was closed during the day. The Masons having precedence, took charge of the funeral. Their solemn mortuary ceremonies being duly performed at the residence, the coffin was put into the hearse and the procession formed, the Continental Guards leading the way, to the slow measure of the funeral dirge by their band. The procession was both long and imposing. The body was followed to and laid away in the Girod-street Cemetery, the Masons there performing the last and most solemn ceremonies of sepulture. The ceremonies over, the Continentals ranged themselves near the tomb and paid the last salute to their late and well-beloved comrade -- three volleys of musketry, after which all quietly retired. -- New-Orleans Crescent, Oct. 19.
lead_paragraph: -- The body of Mr. F.A. The procession was both long and imposing. The body was followed to and laid away in the Girod-street Cemetery, the Masons there performing the last and most solemn ceremonies of sepulture. abstract: Capt. Brown, of the brig Rainbow, (of New-Haven,) from Turks Island for New-Haven, reports that on the 22d inst., spoke schr. E.H. Conkling, of Brooklyn, Bogart, master; being short of provisions, lowered a boat to board her, when the E.H.C. set her gaff topsail to avoid the boat, but the wind being light did not succeed. Capt. Bogart refused at first to part with any stores, but was eventually prevailed on to sell 15 pounds of flour for $1. Afterwards spoke schr. W.F. Roe, of Boston, from Philadelphia for Boston who very generously furnished what was wanted.

abstract: DISTRESSING CASUALTY. -- On Wednesday afternoon Mrs. ELIZA FARE, of No. 170 West Thirty-fourth-street, who is well known as one of the Directresses of the Ladies' Union of the Episcopal Church, met with an accident which, in all probability, will prove fatal, while attempting to cross Eighth-avenue, not far from her residence. A horse, attached to a wagon, had been left by its owner, Mr. R.T. AUCHMUTZ, of No. 54 West Twenty-fifth-street, in front of a house in Thirty-fourth-street, while he transacted some business in the neighborhood. Something caused the animal to take fright, and, breaking loose from a tree to which he had been fastened, he dashed off, coming in contact with the unfortunate lady, and knocking her down. Officer BULMER, of the Twentieth Precinct, ran to her assistance, and, finding that she had been rendered insensible, he conveyed her to Bellevue Hospital. It was then ascertained that her skull had been fractured in two places, and scarcely a possibility of her recovery exists.

Officer BULMER, of the Twentieth Precinct, ran to her assistance, and, finding that she had been rendered insensible, he conveyed her to Bellevue Hospital. abstract: An ingenuous but irascible correspondent writes to us in a highly deprecatory frame of mind, that he regards himself as having been victimized by somebody, because on going to a recent sale of pictures at a splendid mansion in the Fifth-avenue, expressly to see, and if possible to buy, two "original" paintings the one by CORREGGIO and the other by GIULIO ROMANO he found himself put face to face with a couple of ordinary copies.

abstract: The parties belonging to  this department of the public service, under the superintendence of Capt. GEORGE G. MEADE, T.E., have returned from the past season's field of operations to  their head-quarters in this city. Their field-notes show that a very large amount of work has been ac- complished, the entire region of Grand Traverse Bay, including the Manitou and Fox Islands, having been obtained with extreme accuracy.
lead_paragraph: -- The parties belonging to this department of the public service, under the superintendence of Capt. GEORGE G. MEADE, T.E., have returned from the past season's field of operations to their head-quarters in this city. Their field-notes show that a very large amount of work has been ac- complished, the entire region of Grand Traverse Bay, including the Manitou and Fox Islands, having been obtained with extreme accuracy. The efficient management of the able and accomplished superintendent, has mainly contributed to this result. Besides the fulfillment of the onerous duties of his position, included in the general direction and supervision of this great work, the execution of a large portion of the main triangulation, and of the off-shore hydrography devolved upon him. In this he was assisted by Lieut. W.P. SMITH, T.E., who also had charge of the magnetic department.

abstract: The Pacific Mail Steamship Company have just entered into a contract with WM.H. WEBB for the construction of a large steamer to be placed on the San Francisco and Panama route. Her dimensions will be as follows: Length on deck 340 feet; breadth of beam, outside, 45 feet, 44 feet moulded, and depth of hold 32 feet. She will be one thousand tons larger than the John L. Stevens. Her engine, which will be furnished by the Novelty Works, is to be of the single beam variety, with a cylinder of 9.5 inches diameter and 12 feet stroke, and having extra capacity of boilers. She is to be constructed of the very best materials, with diagonal iron straps -- her construction to be under the superintendence of Capt. SKIDDY. The internal arrangements of the ship will be such as the long experience of the Company has discovered to be best adapted to the increasing trade with California. The increased size of this steamer over the other vessels of the line is rendered necessary on account of the demand for freight-room, so that the new steamer, while she will be better provided for the accommodation of passengers, having her two upper decks devoted to that purpose, the whole lower deck will be used for freight-room. She will have water-tight compartments; and special attention is to be paid to the ventilation of the passenger's department, the state-rooms and steerage excelling, in their commodiousness, any passenger steamer yet placed on the route. In model the new steamer is intended to be one of the most approved of Capt. SKIDDY's, combining great buoyancy and carrying capacity with rapid sailing. It is intended that she shall make the Pacific trip in ten days.

It is intended that she shall make the Pacific trip in ten days.

abstract: According, to the theory of an eminent English jurist, it is not only the privilege but the duty of a lawyer to avail himself of every advantage, fair or unfair, which may come within grasp, for his clients' benefit. This theory has never found recognition among the better portions of the legal fraternity; but we think the author of the doctrine may rest secure in the belief that ex-Recorder JAMES M. SMITH, of this City, has not only taken the full sanction of the laxative theory to his conscience, but also its practical license to the ends of his pen and tongue.

abstract: By the New-Orleans Picayune of the 19th inst., we learn that the intelligence of the loss of the steamer Connaught, in connection with the heroic conduct of Capt. WILSON, who is well known in that city, created a deep sensation. All the papers express unbounded admiration of the disinterested and noble conduct of the Captain of the Minnie Schiffer, not unmixed with expressions of pride, that Capt. WILSON was recognized as a New-Orleans commander, who was widely known there, and as widely respected among the merchants and shippers for his generous and manly qualities. Biographies, more or less extended, appeared in most of the papers; photographs of the now celebrated little brig and of her commander were displayed in the Exchange, and great satisfaction was expressed that the merchants of New-York were subscribing to a fund to make some suitable testimonial to the deserving seaman. It should perhaps be mentiond that after the very proper distribution to the other officers, and to the crew of their share of the fund, a little over $3,000 remains to Capt. WILSON. As the subscription is still open at Messrs. HOWLAND & ASPINWALL'S, there is no doubt that the amount will be considerably increased.

abstract: Our Washington correspondent discloses the scheme of the Disunionists at Washington, for the accomplishment of their traitorous designs. He asserts that it has its headquarters in the Treasury Department, and that high officials of the Federal Administration are parties to it. It is proposed that the Legislatures of the seceding States meet immediately after the election of LINCOLN, de- clare the Union dissolved, and proclaim Mr. BRECKINRIDGE President.
lead_paragraph: Our Washington correspondent discloses the scheme of the Disunionists at Washington, for the accomplishment of their traitorous designs. He asserts that it has its headquarters in the Treasury Department, and that high officials of the Federal Administration are parties to it. It is proposed that the Legislatures of the seceding States meet immediately after the election of LINCOLN, de- clare the Union dissolved, and proclaim Mr. BRECKINRIDGE President.

abstract: Our town was thrown into excitement yesterday about 10 o'clock, by the circulation of a report that the body of a man had been found on the hill, about a mile from town, hanging to the limb of a tree. I immediately repaired to the spot, and found that a desperate character, known as PHIL MAGUIRE, had been there summarily executed; but at what time, or by whom, is unknown.
lead_paragraph: Correspondence of the New York Times.

abstract: A correspondent writes, asking us to ask the District-Attorney what has become of the several indictments found against one J. BRYANT SMITH, formerly a clerk in the Comptroller's office under AZARIAH C. FLAGG, for the enormous peculations and frauds upon the public treasury, in which Mr. SMITH was supposed and alleged to have been implicated? This alleged malfeasant, it will be remembered, was a clerk under Mr. FLAGG, drawing only an ostensible remuneration of $1,200 a year, while at the same time indulging in such modest luxuries as a yacht, with a crew of some half-dozen sailors, a stable with half a score or score of fast horses, a magnificent mansion at the north end of this island, with outhouses, conservatories, and all other appurtenances proper to one who could afford to spend twenty-five or thirty thousand dollars a year; several other very expensive indulgences, and last, but not least, a taste for high official company, which made his house and yacht perpetual scenes of champagne festivities and pate de foic gras feasts.
lead_paragraph: A correspondent writes, asking us to ask the District-Attorney what has become of the several indictments found against one J. abstract: ASSAULT WITH A HAMMER. A man named CHRISTIAN PEROTIN, keeper of a lager beer saloon at No. 70 Railroad-avenue, Jersey City, was arrested last evening by officer SCOTT, charged with committing an atrocious assault upon Constable HAYBECK, while in the discharge of his duty.
lead_paragraph: ASSAULT WITH A HAMMER. A man named CHRISTIAN PEROTIN, keeper of a lager beer saloon at No. 70 Railroad-avenue, Jersey City, was arrested last evening by officer SCOTT, charged with committing an atrocious assault upon Constable HAYBECK, while in the discharge of his duty. The officer had made a levy upon some property during the absence of PEROTIN, who, upon returning, as is alleged, attacked the officer with a hammer, and after using considerable violence, thrust him into the street. The accused was held in $500 bonds to appear for examination.

abstract: Nothing more pointedly indicates the utter demoralization of the Democratic Party than the exhibitions of rowdyism rampant and ruffians in the ascendency, which have recently been made in the nominating conventions of that party in this City, the last stronghold of Democracy north of Mason and Dixon's line. Conventions of all kinds, except the respect able, have sprung up with the rapidity of mushrooms on a sheep-walk after a night of autumnal rain.
lead_paragraph: Nothing more pointedly indicates the utter demoralization of the Democratic Party than the exhibitions of rowdyism rampant and ruffians in the ascendency, which have recently been made in the nominating conventions of that party in this City, the last stronghold of Democracy north of Mason and Dixon's line. Conventions of all kinds, except the respect able, have sprung up with the rapidity of mushrooms on a sheep-walk after a night of autumnal rain. Each candidate would seem to think that he can be elected merely by the number of his Conventional indorsements, quite overlooking or ignoring the fact that very many of those who figure in one of these mushroom assemblages are also actors in nearly all the others; so that after receiving the nominations of a score of different organizations, it will be found at the end that not more than fifty or sixty men were represented, and that all these were moved as puppets under one controlling hand. All discipline seems lost in the Democratic Party; all those traditions which pointed to constituencies as the only source of representative power, would appear to have vanished. Every man seems to regard himself as at liberty to seize what he can lay hands upon before quitting the sinking ship; and every little clique of such intriguers rise to importance and authority in their own estimation, just in proportion as the general cause of their party becomes hopeless.
headline: {'main': 'Settling Down of the Democratic Ship.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Settling Down of the Democratic Ship.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The American Geographical and Statistical Society held a meeting last evening, at their rooms, in Clinton Hall, Rev. Dr. HAWKS, the President, in the chair. There was a full attendance. Before proceeding to the regular business of the meeting, Mr. RUSSEL arose and announced in appropriate terms the death of Rev. Dr. SCHROEDER, a warm friend and patron of the Society, whereupon resolutions were read and adopted expressing respect for deceased, and condolence with his family, which were directed to be engrossed upon the records of the meeting.

On the 1lth, the Golden Age, with the mails, passengers and treasure for the Aspinwall steamer, left San Francisco for Panama. She had on board $1,353,000, of which $1,240,000 were for this port.
lead_paragraph: Advices from the Pacific Coast three days later reach us by the Pony Express, which arrived at St. Joseph yesterday morning, having left San Francisco on the 13th inst. On the 1lth, the Golden Age, with the mails, passengers and treasure for the Aspinwall steamer, left San Francisco for Panama. She had on board $1,353,000, of which $1,240,000 were for this port. The political canvass engrossed the greatest attention, and there was the utmost anxiety to hear the result of the elections in Pennsylvania, Ohio and Indiana. Concerning the result of the Senatorial election the Douglas papers in Oregon are very bitter. The President of the Senate had been burnt in effigy. It was thought, however, that this course is resorted to only to counteract the bad effects which might otherwise result from the temporary coalition. Trade at San Francisco was rather more active than at last advices, and money continued easy.

abstract: About 7 o'clock last evening a fire was discovered in the fourth story of the large marble-front building, No. 8 Warren-street, the four upper floors of which are occupied by STEINBERG  LICHTENSTADT, importers of English and French hosiery, gloves,
lead_paragraph: About 7 o'clock last evening a fire was discovered in the fourth story of the large marble-front building, No. 8 Warren-street, the four upper floors of which are occupied by STEINBERG LICHTENSTADT, importers of English and French hosiery, gloves, &c. An alarm was rung for the Eighth district, and the firemen speedily responded, their prompt operations serving to extinguish the flames in a very brief period. The amount of loss upon the stock, which is mainly damaged by water, is estimated at from $30,000 to $70,000 -- the former figures probably being nearest the truth -- and it is fully covered by insurance as follows:

abstract: In the report of the attempt to incite a riot on Wednesday evening, on the occasion of the reception of the Philadelphia Wide-Awakes, it was inadvertently stated that the disturbance occurred opposite the New-York Hotel. Such was not the case. The trouble originated opposite the Stuyvesant Institute, in which building are the head-quarters of the Young Men's Republican Club, and thence spread to the corner of Bleecker-street, where the fighting and tumult raged fiercest. The police at this point made the arrests. The prisoners, however, six in number, were yesterday discharged from custody by Justice CONNOLLY, who administered a severe reprimand to each of them.
lead_paragraph: In the report of the attempt to incite a riot on Wednesday evening, on the occasion of the reception of the Philadelphia Wide-Awakes, it was inadvertently stated that the disturbance occurred opposite the New-York Hotel. abstract: -- The New-York correspondent of the Boston Journal tells the following story: "Quite a scene took place in one of our city cars, in which a well-known lawyer of New-York and a man from the South were the parties. The Southerner called on the lawyer for advice and placed papers in his hands. As the case was not what was represented, the lawyer wrote to the client that he had no case and notified him to call and get his papers. The laws of New-York allow the attorney to hold papers in the hands as a lien till the counsel fees are paid. And the fee in this case was $24, a small one under any circumstances. The client called in the absence of the lawyer and asked for his papers. He was told by the clerk that he could have them on the payment of the fee. He refused to do this and 'went away in a rage.' But he soon came back, and finding only a boy in the office, he clandestinely took the papers and decamped. The next time the parties met were in the cars. The lawyer -- celebrated for that trait of character that enables a legal gentleman to fight his way onward in his practice -- went up to the client and said, 'Sir, I demand the papers you stole from my office.' The man of the South was in a great rage at the public accusation of theft, and threatened all sorts of things. But the lawyer was firm, and with a loud and decided tone demanded the papers. After a time of altercation the client offered to compromise the matter by paying the bill. This the lawyer would not do till the papers were put back into his hands. And as the lawyer would not trust his client to go for them, he sent an agent with him, amid the merriment of the crowd, who applauded the cool courage of the civilian, put ever against the bravado of the Southern man, who completely cowed down, handed over the papers, and promised to come down with the amount due."
lead_paragraph: -- The New-York correspondent of the Boston Journal tells the following story: "Quite a scene took place in one of our city cars, in which a well-known lawyer of New-York and a man from the South were the parties. The client called in the absence of the lawyer and asked for his papers. He was told by the clerk that he could have them on the payment of the fee. He refused to do this and 'went away in a rage.' But he soon came back, and finding only a boy in the office, he clandestinely took the papers and decamped. The next time the parties met were in the cars. The man of the South was in a great rage at the public accusation of theft, and threatened all sorts of things. But the lawyer was firm, and with a loud and decided tone demanded the papers. After a time of altercation the client offered to compromise the matter by paying the bill. This the lawyer would not do till the papers were put back into his hands. And as the lawyer would not trust his client to go for them, he sent an agent with him, amid the merriment of the crowd, who applauded the cool courage of the civilian, put ever against the bravado of the Southern man, who completely cowed down, handed over the papers, and promised to come down with the amount due."

abstract: WILLIAM P. GREEN, bar-keeper at the dancehouse, No. 275 Water-street, who was stabbed on Wednesday night by a sailor named JOHN McGUIRE, died at 5 o'clock yesterday morning from the effects of the wound. Coroner SCHIEMER was summoned to hold an inquest upon the body, and the proceedings...
lead_paragraph: WILLIAM P. GREEN, bar-keeper at the dancehouse, No. 275 Water-street, who was stabbed on Wednesday night by a sailor named JOHN McGUIRE, died at 5 o'clock yesterday morning from the effects of the wound. Coroner SCHIEMER was summoned to hold an inquest upon the body, and the proceedings were conducted at the Fourth Ward Ponce Station. It was shown by the testimony that the place in question is kept by JOHN GREEN, a brother of the deceased, and that MCGUIRE, who is a hand on beard the schooner Sunny South, lying at the Atlantic Basin, went there, accompanied by another sailor named JAMES E. HORTON, bent on having some fun. Both men drank several times at the bar and talked with the women, after which they went away. A short interval only elapsed ere they returned to the saloon, when they commenced jostling about as if they desired to create a disturbance -- the prisoner, MCGUIRE, being the more boisterous of the two. Fearing that the man would break a looking-glass that hung against the wall, GREENE bade him leave the premises, but he did not immediately comply with the request, and angry words followed. Finally, however, the prisoner was induced to go out of the place and after he had reached the sidewalk, he drew a sheath-knife from his belt, and brandished it, threatening to kill any person who should approach him. These threats he accompanied with taunting language, addressed to deceased, who at last came out of the dance-house, and asked him to go away from the door, and not make a disturbance there. MCGUIRE made no reply, but at once sprang toward deceased, and thrust the knife into him. The wound thus inflicted was two inches in length, the knife having entered the lower part of the abdomen of deceased, severed the smaller intestines and caused the bowels to fall out. The occurrence was witnessed by a large number of person 5 who had been attracted to the place by the noise, and when the prisoner ran away, which had did as soon as the mischief had been done, he was pursued and overtaken in Water-street, between Fulton and Beekman. Before his arrest was effected, however, he made an attempt to stab another man who sought to bar his flight, but who fortunately warded the blow with a dinner kettle which he had in his hand. Officer SIMONSON, of the Second Precinct, heard the hallooing of the crowd in pursuit of the fugitive, and he succeeded in stopping him. For a second MCGUIRE seemed inclined to resist, but thinking better of it, he gave up his knife and said he was willing to surrender. His face at this time was covered with blood, his nose was bleeding, and his left hand was badly cut. He said that he had been struck on the head with a club, and what he had done was done in self-defence. He did not appear to be drunk and he was very much exited. The officer took him to the Second Ward Station-house, and afterwards conducted him to the scene of the affray in Water-street, where he was fully identified by the deceased as the person who had stabbed him. After GREENE received his wound he walked unassisted into the house and his friends immediately summoned medical aid, but nothing could be done for his relief. Dr. GEO P. BOUTON made a post-mortem examination of the body, finding a wound in the abdomen about two and a half inches in length. Several of the intestines had been cut into, the knife having been nearly driven through the body. The case was submitted to the Jury, and they immediately rendered a verdict of death from stabs at the hands of JOHN MCGUIRE. The prisoner was then committed to prison by the Coroner to await his trial for the deed.

abstract: There's nothing like pluck, after all. And the more desperate the emergency, the more admirable the courage with which plucky men are apt to meet it. Senator DOUGLAS affords an excellent instance of this quality, exhibited under most discouraging circumstances.
lead_paragraph: There's nothing like pluck, after all. And the more desperate the emergency, the more admirable the courage with which plucky men are apt to meet it. Senator DOUGLAS affords an excellent instance of this quality, exhibited under most discouraging circumstances. Dame Partington, invented and immortalized by SIDNEY SMITH, affords a still more striking example of sublime pluck under great discouragements. When the Atlantic rose and deluged her domicil, instead of running away, as other housekeepers did, she seized her mop and gave battle to the rising tide. Since her day no equal exploit has been witnessed, until our Fusion Committee robbed the good Dame of her laurels, and made her performance appear common-place and respectable by the side of their own.

abstract: On Friday last DANIEL CLIFFORD was hung in the jail yard at Dubuque, Iowa, for murdering a man named WOOD, whom he robbed of $27. CLIFFORD was but 22 years of age, yet the murder was so unprovoked that hardly any sympathy has been manifested for him. He refused to eat any breakfast on the morning of his execution and had to be supported while on the way to the gallows. Arrived there, he had to be lifted up the steps, and when kneeling in prayer with the priests, he kept constantly repeating, "Oh, Lord, receive my soul!" "Oh, Lord, receive my soul!" Although the body fell about seven feet when the rope was cut, the wretched man died from suffocation.
lead_paragraph: On Friday last DANIEL CLIFFORD was hung in the jail yard at Dubuque, Iowa, for murdering a man named WOOD, whom he robbed of $27. CLIFFORD was but 22 years of age, yet the murder was so unprovoked that hardly any sympathy has been manifested for him. He refused to eat any breakfast on the morning of his execution and had to be supported while on the way to the gallows. Arrived there, he had to be lifted up the steps, and when kneeling in prayer with the priests, he kept constantly repeating, "Oh, Lord, receive my soul!" "Oh, Lord, receive my soul!" Although the body fell about seven feet when the rope was cut, the wretched man died from suffocation.

abstract: -- The Key West correspondent of the New-Orleans Picayune, in a letter dated Oct. 11, writes: "The United States steamer Wyandotte, STANLY, came in on the 8th inst., with her First Lieutenant sick. She was ordered into Quarantine, and received coal by means of a lighter. The Crusader arrived from a cruise on the 8th inst. She brings news of the capture of the City of Norfolk steamer, as well as her slaves, by a Spanish man-of-war; as, also, the Crusader brings over the crew of the steamer as "distressed American seamen." The steamer was under Portuguese colors, and, therefore, not subject to capture by an American man-of-war, had she have been fallen in with; but she cruised off an island on the south side of Cuba, discharged her cargo, and set the steamer off under a full head of steam, and holes in her bottom to go down into the deep "bosom of the ocean." By some strange mismanagement she changed her course and came ashore under a full head of steam, when she was discovered by a Spanish man-of-war, thus leading to her capture, as well as that of her slaves landed; about 130 had changed hands by sale. A little incident giving rise to considerable feeling, has taken place between the Crusader and a Spanish war steamer. Both vessels were approach, bows on, as the sailors say, when the Spanish ship threw a shot across the bow of the Crusader, which Capt. MAFFIT immediately returned, hoisted his ensign, and bore down upon him, demanding what he meant? The explanation was that the Crusader was taken for the City of Norfolk, who the Spaniard was particularly in quest of, and which vessel was said to bear a close resemblance to Capt. MAFFIT's ship. I understand that the Spanish officer has made a formal complaint to his admiral of the "menacing manner in which the Crusader approached him, the men at quarters," &c. "There is much feeling in Havana on this subject but it is to be hoped that these little ebullitions of nationality will lead to no serious complications of our affairs with Spain."
lead_paragraph: -- The Key West correspondent of the New-Orleans Picayune, in a letter dated Oct. 11, writes: "The United States steamer Wyandotte, STANLY, came in on the 8th inst., with her First Lieutenant sick. She was ordered into Quarantine, and received coal by means of a lighter. The Crusader arrived from a cruise on the 8th inst. She brings news of the capture of the City of Norfolk steamer, as well as her slaves, by a Spanish man-of-war; as, also, the Crusader brings over the crew of the steamer as "distressed American seamen." The steamer was under Portuguese colors, and, therefore, not subject to capture by an American man-of-war, had she have been fallen in with; but she cruised off an island on the south side of Cuba, discharged her cargo, and set the steamer off under a full head of steam, and holes in her bottom to go down into the deep "bosom of the ocean." By some strange mismanagement she changed her course and came ashore under a full head of steam, when she was discovered by a Spanish man-of-war, thus leading to her capture, as well as that of her slaves landed; about 130 had changed hands by sale. A little incident giving rise to considerable feeling, has taken place between the Crusader and a Spanish war steamer. Both vessels were approach, bows on, as the sailors say, when the Spanish ship threw a shot across the bow of the Crusader, which Capt. MAFFIT immediately returned, hoisted his ensign, and bore down upon him, demanding what he meant? The explanation was that the Crusader was taken for the City of Norfolk, who the Spaniard was particularly in quest of, and which vessel was said to bear a close resemblance to Capt. MAFFIT's ship. I understand that the Spanish officer has made a formal complaint to his admiral of the "menacing manner in which the Crusader approached him, the men at quarters," &c. "There is much feeling in Havana on this subject but it is to be hoped that these little ebullitions of nationality will lead to no serious complications of our affairs with Spain."

abstract: To-night we are to be favored at the Academy of Music with a truly German performance of that truly German opera, the "Martha" of FLOTOW. The Teutonic Parliament of 1848 asserted, rather in the teeth of principles and of facts, that Italy belongs of right to the German frontiers; and Herr FORMES, who was a Teuton of the Teutons in 1848, and abdicated the lyric stage at Vienna to enact a more sounding part upon the platform of imperial affairs, seems to be still of one mind with the sages of Frankfort. In conjunction with the Signora FABBRI who, hides a German origin under an Italian cognomen, and the Signori STIGELLI and QUINTO, who commit the same act of lese-patrie, the great baritone has deliberately undertaken to annex the Italian opera in New-York. On Wednesday night he made his first attempt upon this beautiful province. Oddly enough, however, he attacked a French opera, we suppose, by way of experiment, and brought out "Robert le Diable," in a more or less successful fashion. Herr FORMES' Bertram is one of the destined traditions of the present age in lyric drama. Always more than equal to the demands of the role so far as mere volume and force of voice are concerned, and perfectly master of its dramatic aspects, Herr FORMES has never condescended to interpret the music of this singular and striking partition with the musical accuracy which every partition deserves, if it is to be rendered at all. He gives it to us new, with all the merits and all the defects of his established theory and practice in regard to it. Signora FABBRI was an Alice of more than ordinary merit, passionate, pathetic and effective in a very high degree; and Signor STIGELLI did only too much justice to the susceptible role of Robert. In the character of Plunkett, which he will fill to-night, Herr FORMES is without an equal; and if Mme. FABBRI and Signor STIGELLI impart into the graceful and tender music of FLOTOW the really solid lyric qualities which they have never hitherto failed to display, the representation of "Martha" at the Academy this evening will be deservedly remembered as a great musical event.

abstract: This road, running from Hunter's Point to Flushing, receiving and landing passengers at Fulton Ferry, by making almost hourly connections with the steamer Mattano, is about to increase its importance and usefulness by extending its track on the north shore of Long Island, first to Glen Cove and then to Huntington, making in all a distance from New-York...
lead_paragraph: This road, running from Hunter's Point to Flushing, receiving and landing passengers at Fulton Ferry, by making almost hourly connections with the steamer Mattano, is about to increase its importance and usefulness by extending its track on the north shore of Long Island, first to Glen Cove and then to Huntington, making in all a distance from New-York of about 25 or 30 miles. The proposed extension finds a warm response with the citizens on the proposed route. Heretofore they have been compelled, as they still are, to rely chiefly on small steamboats for the means of communication with New-York, which have not only been too slow for convenience and interest, but comparatively useless during the Winter months. The residents of this part of Long Island plainly see that, by bringing them nearer the metropolis by the reduction of the time of travel, it will add corresponding value to their property.

abstract: We had occasion to speak, in our issue of yesterday morning, of the African Slave-trade and the "respectable merchants" engaged in it, and to express the hope that some of them might be brought to punishment for their participation in that piratical traffic.
lead_paragraph: We had occasion to speak, in our issue of yesterday morning, of the African Slave-trade and the "respectable merchants" engaged in it, and to express the hope that some of them might be brought to punishment for their participation in that piratical traffic. We are aware of the great difficulty of accomplishing that result with our present laws, which are drawn with such looseness that a lawyer of ordinary ability, before a judge of the average tendencies in favor of Slavery, can almost surely get off any one charged with offences against those laws, before a New-York jury, if not in any part of the country. Public sentiment has changed somewhat since those laws were passed -- has become in a measure debauched. Is it to be supposed that fifty years ago resolutions against the Slave-trade would have been so unceremoniously disposed of as were those presented by Mr. JAY to the Episcopal Convention a few days ago? Is it to be supposed that in a political convention of gentlemen from all parts of the country, fifty years ago, the announcement of one of them, that he "represented the slave-trading interest," and that he "considered the African slave-trader to be a true Missionary and a true Christian," would have been greeted with applause?

abstract: -- A large number of Insurance Companies of the North have established agencies in this city, and throughout the South, which, for years past, have been doing a large business. We are pleased to learn that some of our leading mercantile houses have determined to change their insurers. On yesterday a firm that has $25,000 insured in four companies located at Hartford, Conn, one of the policies having expired, took out a new policy in a Southern Insurance Company. They have determined, as soon as their policies expire, which will be within a few days, to insure altogether in Southern companies. We understand there are agencies of six or seven reliable Southern Insurance Companies in this city, and one English company, so that there will be no necessity for continuing to enrich the enemies of our institutions. The Hartford companies have become wealthy by doing an immense Southern business. -- Columbia (S.C.) Guardian.

abstract: The case of HENRY TAYLOR vs. Bank of Mutual Redemption, was tried in the Superior Court, yesterday. The plaintiff was a depositor in the Eliot Bank, which did business with the defendant corporation. He deposited, in a package separately done up, $214, which he showed was counted by himself and another, and put in the Eliot Bank, himself. It was returned "short $100" by the defendant corporation of the Eliot Bank. The plaintiff now seeks to recover the deficit $100. To hold the defendants, the plaintiffs introduced the regulation on the depositors' books of the Eliot Bank as evidence of a contract rendering them liable directly to all depositors of banks dealing with the defendants, for such sums as should be sent to the defendants. But the Court ruled, that it could not be construed to hold them in any way liable directly to the plaintiff, for such deficit, or to account with him, but only with the Eliot Bank, to whom, and to whom alone, the plaintiff must look for any deficit Verdict was taken for defendant WM. BRIGHAM for plaintiff; B.F. BUTLER for defendants. -- Boston Traveller, Tuesday.

abstract: Staats Zeiung of yesterday contains a manifesto from the Association for resisting the Sunday-Theatre law, calling for more money to pay the lawyers. It is stated that $1,050 has already been expended on Messrs. BRADY, CLINTON and STALLENECHT, the counselors of the Association, who need $500 more! We give these gentlemen the benefit of a gratuitous notice of their necessities; but, if our private opinion were asked as to the expediency of a general contribution to aid in filling the pockets of a few men, who insist on keeping open their drinking, dancing and play-giving establishments seven days in a week, it would probably favor a less selfish and more hopeful direction of public charities. There is about as much likelihood of repealing the law against Sunday threatricals, or of having it declared unconstitutional, as there is of the election of Mr. BRADY to the office of Governor. Money given or expended for either object will be money wasted.

abstract: CHURCH IMPROVEMENTS IN BALTIMORE.  In Baltimore, Md., a number of churches are in process of erection by the different denominations, and various edifices have lately been extensively  improved. A building for the accommodation of the Methodist Protestant Mission is going up at the northeast corner of Broadway and Monumentstreet upon a lot measuring 55 by 120 feet.
lead_paragraph: CHURCH IMPROVEMENTS IN BALTIMORE. In Baltimore, Md., a number of churches are in process of erection by the different denominations, and various edifices have lately been extensively improved. A building for the accommodation of the Methodist Protestant Mission is going up at the northeast corner of Broadway and Monumentstreet upon a lot measuring 55 by 120 feet. It will have a front of 50 feet and a depth of 72, and will afford sitting room for 900 persons. The Fourth Presbyterian Congregation which has been worshipping in a small building on Baltimore-street, has taken the preliminary steps towards removing to the corner of Fayette and Cary streets, where it will erect an edifice 66 by 90 feet, which will accommodate about 700 persons, at a probable expense of $30,000. Of this sum $10,000 has already been subscribed by the widow of the late GEORGE BROWN, and $5,000 by a successor of the distinguished Dr. NEVINS. No difficulty is anticipated in raising the balance of the sum named. The Huntingdon Methodist Episcopal Church is about to erect a new building, 50 feet by 75, on the corner of Decker-street and Huntingdon-avenue; the congregation of St. John's Independent Methodist Protestant Church is making extensive improvements in the building which it now occupies; a new church for the Sharp-street M.E. Congregation will speedily be completed; the Memorial (P.E.) Church is rapidly pushing forward the erection of a new building, and among the other congregations which are moving actively in the same direction maybe mentioned those of the First Universalist Church, of the United Presbyterian Church, of the New-Jerusalem or New Christian Church, and of the St. James Catholic Church. This last edifice, whon completed, will afford sittings for several thousand persons. When such of these church edifices as are within the city limits shall be finished the total number in Baltimore will be as follows: Roman Catholic, 21; Protestant Episcapal, 21; Presbyterian, 16; Methodist Episcopal, 50; Methodist Protestant, 6; African Methodist Episcopal, 5; German Reformed, 4: Baptist, 10; Christian Church, 1; Lutheran, 9; Evangelical Association, 2; Independent Churches, 2; Seamen's Union Bethel, 2; Friends, 3; Universalist, 1; Unitarian, 2; Swedenborgian, 3; Jewish Synagogues, 6; United Brethren in Christ, 1; Otterbine Church, 1; St. Peter's Evangelical Lutheran Congregation of the Unaltered Congregation, 1 -- making an aggregate of 167.

abstract: The issues raised in the United States Courts at Philadelphia, respecting the City Postal delivery, involve a highly desirable adjustment of an important question. The General Post-office disputes the right, of Messrs. D.O. BLOOD  CO., of that city, to carry letters within the city limits. The streets it declares to be post roads within the
lead_paragraph: The issues raised in the United States Courts at Philadelphia, respecting the City Postal delivery, involve a highly desirable adjustment of an important question. The General Post-office disputes the right, of Messrs. D.O. BLOOD CO., of that city, to carry letters within the city limits. The streets it declares to be post roads within the meaning of the act of Congress, and as such to be exclusively in the enjoyment of the United States for the purposes of mail transportation. Any corporation or individual entering upon or persisting in that business to the prejudice of Federal rights, is therefore subject to well-defined penalties announced in the act; and should at once be arrested by the intervention of the Judiciary. The Department accordingly demands an injunction upon the Messrs. BLOOD & CO. The reply of the latter mainly controverts the assumption that city streets are legally post routes, and opposes the injunction for reasons of public policy. And the injunction has not been granted. The grounds upon which the Court founded its opinion are unfortunately not stated, but we are to assume that technical rather than essential reasons have governed it for the terms of the act admit of no doubtful interpretation.

abstract: HUDSON COUNT COURT. -- DAVID J. SWAIN, JOHN FAULHNER and FREDERICK H. TURNER were on trial Thursday on an indictment for assault and battery with guns upon a number of residents of Scacaucus, growing out of an alleged assault upon a colored woman. From the evidence, it appears that in August last the accused parties, while out gunning, entered a small house at Scacaucus, occupied by a colored woman named MARY THOMPSON, and demanded something to drink. The woman told them they had just passed a lager-bier place, and that there was the proper place to procure it. Some words followed, when, it is alleged, SWAIN struck the woman in the face, after which the party left and went into a field. An alarm was given, and a number of men followed the accused parties, and a desperate fight resulted, during which the guns were used for clubs, and the combatants were all more or less injured. The young men were finally overpowered, disarmed and conveyed to the county jail, and while being conveyed there bound, were subjected to ill-treatment at the hands of their captors. Gen. WRIGHT and C.H. WINFEILD appeared for the defence, and District-Attorney SCUDDER conducted the case for the State. SWAIN was previously tried for assault and battery on Mrs. THOMPSON, and was found guilty.
lead_paragraph: HUDSON COUNT COURT. -- DAVID J. SWAIN, JOHN FAULHNER and FREDERICK H. TURNER were on trial Thursday on an indictment for assault and battery with guns upon a number of residents of Scacaucus, growing out of an alleged assault upon a colored woman. From the evidence, it appears that in August last the accused parties, while out gunning, entered a small house at Scacaucus, occupied by a colored woman named MARY THOMPSON, and demanded something to drink. The woman told them they had just passed a lager-bier place, and that there was the proper place to procure it. Some words followed, when, it is alleged, SWAIN struck the woman in the face, after which the party left and went into a field. An alarm was given, and a number of men followed the accused parties, and a desperate fight resulted, during which the guns were used for clubs, and the combatants were all more or less injured. The young men were finally overpowered, disarmed and conveyed to the county jail, and while being conveyed there bound, were subjected to ill-treatment at the hands of their captors. Gen. WRIGHT and C.H. WINFEILD appeared for the defence, and District-Attorney SCUDDER conducted the case for the State. SWAIN was previously tried for assault and battery on Mrs. THOMPSON, and was found guilty.

abstract: By the arrival of the Canadian off Father Point we receive one day's later news from Europe. It is reported that the French garrison in Rome will shortly be increased to 60,000 men. Rumors are again current that negotiations are on foot for the annexation of the Island of Sardinia to France, but they are not traced to any very reliable source. The Piedmontese troops under General CIALDINI had received orders to cross the Neapolitan frontier, and would probably be before Capua on the 15th inst. It was generally believed that the Neapolitans would evacuate the town and retire to Gaeta. There is a report current that Russia was about to recall her Ambassador from Turin, but, according to the London Post, no protest, in a diplomatic sense, has been made by either Russia or Austria against the entry of Sardinian troops into Neapolitan territory. The departure of FUAD PASHA from Syria had been the signal for the recommencement of Christian massacres. The life of the Russian Consul had been threatened.

abstract: We give place, with pleasure, to the following communications referring to some editorial comments in yesterday's TIMES, on borowed jewelry for the Prince of Wales' Ball. lead_paragraph: We give place, with pleasure, to the following communications referring to some editorial comments in yesterday's TIMES, on borowed jewelry for the Prince of Wales' Ball. Those comments, as our correspondents know, were founded on positive, statements made by Dr. TYNG an authority which no citizen of New-York would think of discrediting. It would appear, however, from the communications appended, that the Reverend Doctor was mistaken or misinformed, as far as two leading establishments are concerned, for they indignantly deny such a practice as that of hiring out jewelry. We really think, however, that the indignation of Messrs. BALL, BLACK & CO., and TIFFANY & CO., is rather more violent than the occasion warrants, for very high precedents may be found for the deed they repudiate. When GEORGE IV. was crowned King of England, the jewels in his coronet, borrowed expressly for the occasion, were valued at a million and a half of pounds sterling, and the fortunate London jeweler received $200,000 as interest for their use. In a moral point of view, there is certainly very little difference between lending jewels for the coronation of one Prince of Wales, or lending jewels for a ball given in honor of another. We condemned the wretched taste and extravagance of those New-York women who appeared in borrowed finery at the Prince's Ball; but unless Messrs. TIFFANY & CO., and Messrs. BALL, BLACK & CO., are prepared to answer for all other jewelers in the metropolis, we do not see that their interference, except in so far as they are personally concerned, is at all pertinent. Their communications are as follows:

abstract: A desperate fight recently occurred in Gates, N.C., between two men named DAVIS and JACKSON, about some hogs. DAVIS and his wife armed themselves with guns, axes and knives, and presented themselves at JACKSON's house, where a general fight ensued, in which both men, women and children participated. They shot until their ammunition gave out, and then closed in with axes, knives and gun-barrels. During the shooting a son of JACKSON, a mere boy, was killed by a son of DAVIS, also a lad. Seven of the party were dangerously wounded, one of the women having received a broken arm, and, it is said, fifty buckshot! From all accounts, they fought as long as they could, and quit with mutual consent. The surviving parties have been arrested and placed in the county jail to await trial.

abstract: The news which reached us yesterday from Europe is of no ordinary interest. So far as the question of Italy is concerned it cannot be truly said that any marked and decisive change has taken place in the relative positions of the leading parties in the grand secular conflict of old diplomatic Europe with the modern life of the Peninsula.

abstract: THE FURMAN-STREET RAILROAD ROUTE The special Committee of the Common Council, of which Alderman VAN BRUNT is Chairman, appointed to see if some arrangement could not be made between the Central and City Railroad Companies, so as to have the Railroad on Furman-street, between Fulton and Atlantic streets, operated, held a meeting in the City Hall last evening. lead_paragraph: THE FURMAN-STREET RAILROAD ROUTE The special Committee of the Common Council, of which Alderman VAN BRUNT is Chairman, appointed to see if some arrangement could not be made between the Central and City Railroad Companies, so as to have the Railroad on Furman-street, between Fulton and Atlantic streets, operated, held a meeting in the City Hall last evening. Mr. PIERSON, President of the City Company, made a detailed statement as to the claims, rights and existing difficulties, and was followed by Mr. LITCHFIELD, President of the Central Company, and Messrs. KELSEY and STANTON, of the Board of Directors. After some two hours' time had been used up in presenting the subject in detail, the Committee decided that they were only authorized I to see whether there was any possibility of a temporary arrangement being made so as to have the route operated immediately, and until such time as the Courts decided the rights of the respective Companies. Mr. LITCHFIELD renewed the propositions which he said had been made the day before, when Committees of the two Companies were in consultation: 1. To perfect the original agreement between the Companies, the Central Company to operate the route and pay 6 per cent. for the use of the City Company's track. 2. To leave the matter to the decision of three disinterested Presidents of railroads. 3. To leave it to any three persons -- one to be selected by each Company and the third by the two referees thus selected. 4. To the Mayor. Another proposition was, to operate the road under proposition No. 1, temporarily. The reference in each case to be considered binding, -- all of which the City Company's Committee, Mr. LITCHFIELD said, the day before had declined. The Chairman of the Committee asked if Mr. PIERSON was authorized to accept either of these propositions. He said he was not able to say that the Company would accept either, but said that he would call a meeting of the Board of Directors and consider any propositions the Common Council Committee might see fit to make. The only proposition he was authorized to make was, that the City Company would run as many cars over the Furman-street route as the public accommodation might require, at two cents one way and one cent the other, or one and one-half cent for each passenger, until such time as the suit now pending should be determined. This the Central Company refused to accept, and that Company would accept of no proposition which did not give the Central Company the right to operate the road. The Committee adjourned with a view to prepare propositions to be presented to the City Company. Mr. PIERSON asked Mr. LITCHFIELD if the Central Company would consent to let the City Company cross Atlantic-street under any circumstances. To which Mr. LITCHFIELD replied, that when they were satisfied that they were dealing with men who would carry out their agreements, they would give the Central Company the use of their road on Atlantic-street. Mr. KELSEY desired it to be particularly understood that in tearing up the City Company's Railroad track on Atlantic-street on Thursday, he had acted as a citizen, and not as a Director of the Central Railroad Company.

abstract: The friends of this enterprise will be gratified to learn that it is meeting with a degree of success which far exceeds the most sanguine expectations of its projectors. The room, are filled every day with women who desire to avail themselves of its advantages, or with those who feel interested in its success and wish to lend it their aid. Among the former are a large number of the teachers in our public schools, who find in this Library precisely the opportunities for reading of which they have long felt the need There are also a very good proportion of girls employed in book-binding, in sewing and kindred avocations, among the regular patrons of the Library, and four-fifths of the books which they take from its shelves are histories, memoirs, travels, &c., almost to the entire exclusion of light literature, which many have predicted they would alone require.

abstract: -- On Tuesday night of last week, Dr. BACHMAN, of Rock Grove, was stabbed by one CONRAD BAKER, it is thought fatally, under the following circumstances: BAKER had been working the farm belonging to widow SPANGLER, and was living, it seems, upon terms of improper intimacy with the widow. He had for some time had suspicions and jealousies of a certain neighbor, who paid, he thought, too much attention to the widow. On Tuesday last, BAKER, who slept up stairs, heard some one down stairs with the widow, and, supposing it to be the person alluded to, rushed down, and finding a man with her in a position which admitted of no explanation, at once commenced an attack. The person attacked, who proved to be Dr. BACHMAN, defended himself with a chair, but BAKER stabbed him in several places, one of the stabs severing one of his kidneys. This, it is thought, must prove fatal. BAKER was arrested and lodged in jail, and on Thursday night tore up one of the sheets to his bed, and hung himself from the gratings over his cell door. He was found dead by Sheriff TAGGART in the morning, and an inquest which was held resulted in a verdict in accordance with the facts. -- Freeport (Ill.) Journal, Oct. 24.

abstract: Hon. abstract: The death of Dr. GEORGE SHRORTER, which occurred at Paterson, N.J., on Thursday morning, has already been announced by telegraph. Dr. SHRORTER was a native of Prussia, and graduated at the Universities of Konigsberg and Berlin, making philology and the natural sciences his principal studies. For some rears after leaving the University, he acted as Private Secretary to the Prince Regent of Prussia, traveling with him through a large part of Europe, and enjoying remarkable opportunities for becoming acquainted with the working of its various Governments. Immediately upon the breaking out of the Revolutions of 1818 Dr. SHRORTER, sided with the Liberals and resigned all connection with his royal patron, whose sympathies were with the reactionists. In company with many other patriots he found himself obliged to leave his country and take refuge in the United States, in 1849. Dr. SHRORTER immediately applied himself to the geography of this Continent, and in connection with the Geographical and Statistical Society, his abilties soon began to attract notice. In 1856 he completed a map of the United States from ocean to ocean, on a canvas thirty feet by seventeen. After remaining several weeks at the Merchants' Exchange of this City for exhibition, this was sent to its destination, the Stock Exchange of London. The map contained every railroad and canal in the country, completed or in progress. Since then he has executed models of this country in war, showing the elevations and depressions of its surface. His labors have by no means received the appreciation which they so richly deserved. At the time of his death Dr. SHRORTER was but 43 years of age. He removed to Paterson four or five years ago, hoping to be able to pursue his studies there with less interruption, and on the 17th was taken with inflammation of the lungs. The severity of his mental labors doubtless favored the progress of the disease, which terminated fatally on the 25th. It is understood that the family of Dr. SHRORTER is left in straitened circumstances.

abstract: During the past few days considerable excitement has been created among the politicians in Poughkeepsie, by a ruffianly interference with the Wide-Awakes while they were parading the city, in consequence of which Mayor SWIFT has offered a reward of $200 for the discovery and conviction of the offenders. The particulars are as follows: On Friday night, the Wide-Awakcs of Poughkeepsie and surrounding towns had a grand torchlight procession, and while parading through Main-street, a stone was thrown which struck a young man named HENRY SEYMOUR on the head. He was taken up badly hurt and insensible. At the same time another person in the procession was knocked down by some one of the spectators, who instantly dodged back and was out of sight. The greatest confusion was the consequence. On Saturday evening effort was made to discover the offender, but without success. The Mayor has offered a reward of $200 for the arrest and conviction of the guilty parties. Several other citizens also offered additional rewards, from $50 downwards, in all amounting to about $500. The consequence was that a person was arrested and locked in jail, but as yet no direct proof has been brought forward to convict him.

abstract: As a body the fireman of this City have ever received from us the commendations which they have so often merited, for the cheerful and ready manner in which their arduous duties, so voluntarily assumed, are ever discharged; but they have been so petted, so indulged, and so courted, they have grown into a great political power, for that their four thousand votes are counted is but too palpable, as facts will show.

abstract: In an article upon the policy of the South, we have already pointed out what seems to is to be the imperative need of the present moment, viz.: the creation in the sable breasts of her four millions of slaves of an amor patrioe, on which reliance may be placed in the event of foreign war. This cannot be done except by ameliorating the condition of the slaves, and conceding to them certain rights, privileges and immunities which are now denied them. We have admitted the impracticability of immediate emancipation, and hence the reforms which strike us as needful, leave untouched the leading feature of the system, which is compulsory and unpaid labor. What we maintain is, that the law of Slavery is needlessly harsh and cruel. This is admitted by the friends and apologists of the system, who exclaim against having it judged by the letter of the law, and insist that the practice [???]nder it is mild and humane. But if Slavery in practice is so much better than its legal definitions, why retain these? Is it not clear that the system is made to present, an odious and revolting aspect by what its friends would have us believe to be a mere dead letter?

abstract: THE CASE OF WM. HURRY, JR. -- COMPLAINTS AGAINST GAMBLERS. -- The Case of WM. HURRY, Jr., the young man who was arrested on Thursday evening, charged with having defrauded the firm of QUICK & L'HOMMEDIEU, exchange brokers in Pine-street, out of a note for $1,958 36 which they intrusted to him to sell, was called yesterday at the Lower Police Court, for investigation, but was postponed. HORRY it appears, has been rather a fast man for some time, and the victim of sundry keepers of "faro banks," -- several of whom he yesterday made complaints against. He makes affidavit that on the 19th inst. he went into the gambling-house of JAMES STEWART, corner of Broadway and Fulton-street, where he lost, at "faro," $3,000, which was won and taken by the card dealer, in the presence of STEWART. On the same day, he makes oath, he lost $1,200 at "faro" in the gambling-house of CHAS. HANSOM, corner of Prince and Mercer streets. On the following day he lost $250 at the gambling-house of CHAS. HILMAN, Broadway, next door to the corner of Eighth-street. The same day he lost $500 at JOHN COLTON's gambling-house. No. 828 Broadway; also, $200 at FRED's W. BLACKMAN's place, No. 1 Ann-street. Warrants for the arrest of all the above-named parties were issued by Justice KELLY and given so Detective HOGAN on Thursday, but up to yesterday afternoon he had not made his appearance with any of them, Yesterday afternoon, Justice KELLY received an intimation that the gamblers would wait upon him at their leisure some day next week. Another singular circumstance in connected with the affair, and that is, the. gamblers, the complainant, and HURRY have all employed the same person as counsel.
