abstract: If the Union could be dissolved in twenty-four hours by a Southern Convention, there would be great danger of its accomplishment; but luckily some months would have to elapse before the formalities could be settled, even supposing that no obstacles should be thrown in the way; and in the meantime the people and the politicians would be compelled to look the consequences full in the face. Long discussions must necessarily take place on the various new wants and exigencies of the Southern Confederacy, in which the dangers to be met, and the ways and means to meet them, must be fully brought out. For instance, in providing for an army and navy, it would be a most discouraging reflection that establishments no larger than those possessed by the present Federal Union would cost nearly forty millions per annum, although our army consists of only about sixteen or seventeen thousand men, and the navy, on the same economical scale. Would the South feel secure with so small a standing army as we now find sufficient to protect the whole Union? Would twice, or thrice such an army suffice for the protection of a slaveholding Republic? Then there is the civil list, including the Post-office. By all means, let there be a Southern Convenvention called to discuss these questions.

abstract: DELIBERATE ATTEMPT AT MURDER. About 9 o'clock Saturday morning a young sailor, giving the name of CHARLES L. KELLING, went to the grocery store No. 252 Houston-street and attempted to take the life of WILLIAM KOENIG, the proprietor of the establishment,...
lead_paragraph: DELIBERATE ATTEMPT AT MURDER. About 9 o'clock Saturday morning a young sailor, giving the name of CHARLES L. KELLING, went to the grocery store No. 252 Houston-street and attempted to take the life of WILLIAM KOENIG, the proprietor of the establishment, by stabbing him with a bowie-knife. KELLING recently arrived at the port of Boston, where information came to him that KOENIG had circulated a report reflecting upon the reputation of a young woman to whom he was attached. He at once determined to avenge the assumed injury by murdering the alleged calumniator. With this purpose in view he purchased a bowie-knife, had it sharpened, and left Boston on Friday evening to put his intention into execution. As soon as he reached this City, he went to KOENIG's store and characterized him as a scoundrel and a liar, at the same time attempting to cut his throat. In this, however, he failed, but he nevertheless inflicted a terrible wound, the blade having entered KOENIG's mouth, breaking the jawbone, and extending to a point behind the right ear. Before the assailant could escape, Officer C. BROWN came up and took him into custody. He was taken before Justice CONNOLLY, at Jefferson Market Court, to whom he made a statement of the affray similar to that above narrated, and added that he was sorry for having failed to kill the object of his wrath. Under these circumstances he was fully committed on a charge of assault with intent to kill.

abstract: We publish this morning copious extracts from our Southern exchanges upon the question of disunion. Our selections have been made partly with a view to show our readers that rampant disunionism does not engross the entire Southern Press even now but that very many vigorous and influential journals denounce it as utterly ruinous as a remedy, and as highly disastrous when used merely as a menace.

abstract: The interior of this structure is being rapidly completed. The workmen labor on it night and day. The wood-work of the house, we believe, is entirely of oak, and will be, when finished, as solid and enduring as it can be made. Workmen at work in the light, report that during the severest storms thus far, only a slight trembling is felt. Capt. ALEXANDER, who superintended the construction of the light house, dined within its granite walls, one day last week, with his entire family. Report says that one man who recently spent a night in the building could not be induced to try the experiment again. Airy phantoms disturbed his quiet,-visions, apparitions, fantastic shapes flitted around him, and among the rest, the veritable ghosts of the two brave but unfortunate men who perished when the iron light-house yielded to the stormy waves. Now, those men, it is true, went down alive into the remorseless deep, with none, to tell the dismal story of their end; but as for their ghosts coming back and haunting the new structure, to terrify and torment their successors, we don't believe one single word of it. It is a libel on the dead. The sympathizing ghosts of those men, full of pity and compassion for their successors, would be the very last ghosts in the universe to haunt the brave man who should fearlessly step into their shoes. -- Hingham Journal.

abstract: Unless the magnates of the Union and Democratic parties make haste to unite on some one candidate in each of the six Congressional Districts embraced within our City, there would appear every...
lead_paragraph: Unless the magnates of the Union and Democratic parties make haste to unite on some one candidate in each of the six Congressional Districts embraced within our City, there would appear every certainty that four if not five of such Districts will return Republican representatives to Congress. Indeed, it would not in the least surprise those who know the influences which are at work, to see a clean sweep of the Congressional slate made by the Republicans on the sixth of next November. All the portents lie in this direction, and so far embittered by personal hatreds and rivalries are the various factions of the Democracy, that it may well be doubted whether the rebellious rank and file can be induced to ratify by their votes any bargains in the making of which they have not been personally consulted. The leaders may coalesce as much as they please, but the masses will not suffer their suffrages to be huckstered hither and thither without any voice in the final selection of their candidates. This insurrectionary spirit is one of the portents announcing the breaking up of the Democratic Party; and of its probable operation in the various Districts, the following summary will give an outline.

abstract: -- The bold and patriotic stand taken by the Opposition to the sham Democracy in these States, in favor of the Union, is worthy of all praise. The Alexandria (Va.) Gazette of the 24th inst. contains an elaborate speech by one of the ablest lawyers in the State, ROBERT E. SCOTT, Esq., of Fauquier, in which he presents with great force the ruinous policy of disunion as a remedy for real or supposed grievances. He declares that the South "ought not to think of secession," on account of the election of Mr. LINCOLN. After recounting the vicissitudes of parties in the country, and the quiet submission of the defeated to the triumphant, he says:

abstract: - A most heart-rending accident occurred at Norfolk, Va., on Wednesday evening. Mr. JESSE T. NEWELL went home from business about sunset, and finding his little son playing in the yard with a pistol, not supposed to be loaded, took it from him, and while examining it. It was accidentally discharged. LAURA, (Mr. NEWELL's daughter,) a beautiful and interesting little girl of nine Summers, was seated on the step getting her lesson, when the pistol went off, and instantly jumping up, she exclaimed, "Oh! pa, you have killed me!." As she said this, the blood (burst from her nose and mouth. She fell forward and instantly expired. The pistol had been charged with two buckshot, both of which had entered her right breast and perforated her right lung. The great shock, together with the internal hemorrhage, produced almost instant death. Drs. GALT and BRIGHT were almost instantly called, and reached the scene of casualty in a very short time, but too late. The little girl had breathed her last, and a worthy family were overwhelmed with grief. The unhappy father, almost bereft of reason by the distressing and heart-rending accident, sought, in his frenzy to take his own life. He seized a knife, and made a desperate effort to cut his throat, but was prevented from steeping his family in still deeper grief by some of his friends.

abstract: The Richmond Whig, the Raleigh (N.C.) Register, and other influential Southern journals, charge that the object of the seceders from the Charleston Convention was, by breaking up the Democratic Party, "to dissolve the Union, in order to open the African...
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Whig, the Raleigh (N.C.) Register, and other influential Southern journals, charge that the object of the seceders from the Charleston Convention was, by breaking up the Democratic Party, "to dissolve the Union, in order to open the African Slave-trade, and bring down the value of negroes, that the profits upon cotton might be higher." This is a very grave imputation upon the honor, humanity and patriotism of the Fire-eaters, but it is fully sustained by their own declarations, or those of their newspapers and orators. Despairing of reopening the Slave-trade, and of enjoying the luxury of cheap negroes while the Union lasts, this deprivation has been a favorite argument with the Southern Democratic leaders for a dissolution of the Federal compact. The fact charged upon the Cotton State Democracy by the Virginia journals is by no means new to us; but we call attention to their recognition of it as a sign of progress. No more disastrous event to the slave interest of Virginia and other old Slave States, where negro labor is already superabundant, could occur, than the revival of the African Slave-trade. That piratical traffic is repugnant to the moral sense of Northern men, but its revival would be to the slaveholders north of the thirty-fifth parallel of latitude, simple pecuniary ruin, to say nothing of the fearful addition it would make to that dangerous class of population. It is surprising that this truth has not been recognized in all its appalling proportions before now.

abstract: As usual, Plymouth Church was crowded to excess yesterday morning. Before the text was given out, Mr. BEECHER announced that a collection would be taken up for the "American Board of Home and Foreign Missions." He read a statement of the re-...
lead_paragraph: As usual, Plymouth Church was crowded to excess yesterday morning. Before the text was given out, Mr. BEECHER announced that a collection would be taken up for the "American Board of Home and Foreign Missions." He read a statement of the results of the past year in the mission field, one item of which was that 36,000,000 printed pages of the Bible had been circulated among the heathen. Mr. BEECHER remarked that gold and silver were conversant with all the spoken languages, and a man had only to be munificent in his contributions to the cause of Christ and his gold and silver would need no interpreters. It will be remembered that on the last Sabbath Mr. BEECHER expressed himself as very favorably disposed toward the American "Board," while he emphatically disclaimed any want of Christian sympathy with the "Association." He loved not that the less but this the more. A debt of $13,000 had already been paid for the "Board" by Plymouth Church, and the "Board" now presented itself with perfect confidence for an annual contribution. A liberal collection was taken up.

abstract: A correspondent of the National Intelligencer writes as follows: "In your issue of the 22d inst. I read an account of the discovery of a cave in Florida, in which was found a Latin inscription certifying that it was inhabited or visited by Europeans in the eleventh century. Of this now there can be no doubt, if this discovery is true; and, consequently, our Continent was known to the people of Europe before its discovery by COLUMBUS. But that is not the only point which I want to notice in this connection. My object is to direct the attention of American historians or antiquarians to a similar statement in Cardinal WISEMAN's treatise on 'The Connection between Science and Revealed Religion,' in which that accomplished scholar and archaeologist states it for a fact, when speaking of the aborigines of America, that there are manuscripts in the Vatican library at Rome which say that this country was known to Missionaries of the Eternal City in the tenth century and concludes his remarks on the subject by asking the question, 'Who can enlighten us on the subject?' or words to that effect. (I have not the work now before me.) The records found in the Danish archives since this work was written (30 or 40 years since) prove that this continent was known to the Nortamen before it was discovered by COLUMBUS; but this last development, if true, as I have above said, removes all doubt of that interesting fact."

abstract: We learn that various efforts have been made to interest Mr. BUCHANAN'S Secretary of the Treasury, Hon. HOWELL COBB, in the election of Democratic Congressman from this City, but to all applications for interference he has returned a steady and contemptuous negative. Imitating the Mr. Augustus Toots, immortalized...
lead_paragraph: We learn that various efforts have been made to interest Mr. BUCHANAN'S Secretary of the Treasury, Hon. HOWELL COBB, in the election of Democratic Congressman from this City, but to all applications for interference he has returned a steady and contemptuous negative. Imitating the Mr. Augustus Toots, immortalized by DICKENS, the Secretary of the Treasury declares in all companies and on all occasions, that Congressmen are "not of the slightest consequence;" he does not believe that "a Congress of the United States will ever again assemble," and for this reason is quite willing that the Republicans should "elect all the representatives they can" -- a gracious permission of which the people of the free States appear likely to avail themselves to the full.

abstract: The anniversary of the dedication of the John-street M.E. Church, in this City, which was the first Church of that denomination erected in America, is the 30th of October, -- the event having occurred in 1768, ninety-two years ago. The edifice now stands surrounded wholly by business establishments. The Society has, for several years past, observed the day as a religious anniversary, partly for the quickening of the Church, and also with the view to raising the necessary means to defray the current expenses of the year. Yesterday was, accordingly, devoted to the yearly services which were of unusual interest. At 9 o'clock in the morning, a love-feast was held, which was conducted by the pastor, Rev. E.L. JANES. Several of the old members, who were converted in this church, were present, and spoke, relating their experiences, and calling up interesting reminiscences of past days. The meeting was one of deep interest. Rev. Dr. THOMPSON, editor of the Christian Advocate and Journal, preached at 10 1/2 o'clock, from the 15th Chapter of Job, 11th verse -- "Are the Consolations of God small with thee? Is there any secret thing with thee?" A reunion meeting was held at 2 P.M., at which brief addresses were made by the former pastors, and old members. A general prayer meeting was held in the evening, which was conducted by L.B. LODER, and at 7 1/2 P.M., Rev. CHARLES E. HARRIS, the pastor of the Green-street Church, preached to a very full house from the Epistle of James, 2d Chapter, 23d verse -- Another scripture was fulfilled, which saith: Abraham believed God, and it was imputed unto him for righteousness; and he was called the friend of God," the subject being the trials and triumphs of heroic faith. About one thousand dollars were raised during the day for the expenses of the Society.

abstract: Commander JOHN L. SANDERS, of the Navy, another officer who served in the War of 1812, died on Friday at Norfolk, Va., his native State. Capt. SANDERS had been placed on the retired list by the famous Naval Board, although it was believed by many that he was able to perform several years' service when the order to drop him from the active list came first. He began his naval life exactly fifty-one...
lead_paragraph: Commander JOHN L. SANDERS, of the Navy, another officer who served in the War of 1812, died on Friday at Norfolk, Va., his native State. Capt. SANDERS had been placed on the retired list by the famous Naval Board, although it was believed by many that he was able to perform several years' service when the order to drop him from the active list came first. He began his naval life exactly fifty-one years ago, receiving his appointment from Virginia, and performed since then nearly fifteen years of sea service and fourteen years five months shore duty. He was nineteen years and nine months unemployed. Capt. SANDERS' death makes no change in the Register. He was fifth in rank among his retired cotemporaries.

abstract: ARREST OF COUNTERFEITERS. Jersey City was visited by a gang of counterfeiters on Friday night, who succeeded in passing quite a number of counterfeit five dollar bills of the East River Bank, of the City of New-York. The Chief of Police dispatched officers to notify store-keepers and others of their doings, and to arrest the operators. Between 10 and 11...
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF COUNTERFEITERS. Jersey City was visited by a gang of counterfeiters on Friday night, who succeeded in passing quite a number of counterfeit five dollar bills of the East River Bank, of the City of New-York. The Chief of Police dispatched officers to notify store-keepers and others of their doings, and to arrest the operators. Between 10 and 11 o'clock, Officers BRADLEY, BENNETT, CARROLL and KIPP, succeeded in arresting three men, apparently canal boatmen, who gave their names as JOHN WILLIAMS, MATTHEW BEARS and JACOB MILLER, who were committed to the cells. On Saturday morning, the prisoners being brought before Recorder TILDEN, they were identified by a dozen or more persons. Two of the gang, a man and woman, succeeded in making their escape. The prisoners were committed to await trial.

abstract: -A letter from St. Simon, in Lower Canada, states that the earthquake was severely felt there. "Persons driving along the road found their horses struck with terror, so that they would not proceed, and the upheaving of the ground was such that they expected to be thrown out of the carriage. The houses shook and the floors and roofs creaked awfully. Men working on the road, could hardly keep on their legs, and the fence-posts were shaken by the phenomenon."

abstract: The funds are stationary to-day at the closing prices of yesterday, with very little business. The changes shown in the Bank return are regarded more with satisfaction than otherwise, but it has transpired that a further large amount of gold, rumored to be between 25,000 and 30,000, has been taken this day from the Bank of England for exportation. The Railway share market is dull, preparations for the fortnightly settlement attract attention.
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Saturday Evening, Oct. 13.

abstract: The screw-steamship City of Washington, from Liverpool on the 10th inst., and the Cunard steamship Asia, from Liverpool on the 13th and Queenstown on the 14th inst., have arrived at this port. Their mails are one week later than those received by the last arrival, but the City of Washington's advices were partly anticipated by a brief telegraphic summary from Cape Race.
lead_paragraph: The screw-steamship City of Washington, from Liverpool on the 10th inst., and the Cunard steamship Asia, from Liverpool on the 13th and Queenstown on the 14th inst., have arrived at this port. Their mails are one week later than those received by the last arrival, but the City of Washington's advices were partly anticipated by a brief telegraphic summary from Cape Race. By the Asia we learn that tremendous military preparations are being made by Austria in Venetia, and a rumor was current that a large force had crossed the Po and the Mincio. The rumor was not generally credited, but the London Times lends encouragement to the belief that this important step was really contemplated by the Emperor FRANCIS JOSEPH, and would be carried out. Some authorities deny, and others state positively, that Russia, Austria and Prussia had protested against the entry of the Sardinian troops into Neapolitan territory. However this may be, a semi-official article in the Constitutionnel alleges that the act, as well as the invasion of the Papal States, are flagrant violations of the principles of neutrality and non-intervention invoked by Piedmont herself. The French army in Rome, it is reported, will be increased to 60,000 men. Our foreign files furnish us with interesting details of the great struggle at Volturno, in which GARIBALDI achieved so signal a victory and displayed such undaunted heroism. Telegrams dated the 13th inst. say that the Dictators troops had succeeded in occupying fresh positions under the walls of Capua. Severe cannonading had been kept up during the 11th, 12th and 13th. GARIBALDI had issued a decree ordaining that on the 21st inst. the Neapolitans should vote on the question, "Do you wish Italy to be indivisably united with VICTOR EMANUEL, as constitutional King, and his legitimate descendants?" The bill empowering VICTOR EMANUEL to incorporate the Two Sicilies and the Papal States with his kingdom has passed the Sardinian Chambers by a vote of 296 to 6. Count DE CAVOUR delivered an important speech on the occasion.

abstract: Saturday was the second day of the Billiard Tournament at Lynch's Billiard Rooms in Union-square, which were crowded with interested visitors, who frequently applauded when any brilliant shots were made. M. Berger, who, with his son and an interpreter, are constant visitors to the Tournament, remarked to a French gentleman, at the conclusion of the first day's tournament, that he had very much underrated American billiard players. Kavanagh and Geary were the first contestants on Saturday. The latter, although beaten, made some excellent play, which, albeit at times it was not successful, brought him considerable applause, in which M. Berger joined. Kavanagh's highest runs were as follows: 27, 42, 111, 31, 68, 53, 29, 29 -- total, 500. Geary made the following runs in his 211: 51, 22, 18, 16, 16, 12, 12.
lead_paragraph: Saturday was the second day of the Billiard Tournament at Lynch's Billiard Rooms in Union-square, which were crowded with interested visitors, who frequently applauded when any brilliant shots were made. abstract: For three weeks in the very flush of the season there had been no opera, and we firmly believe that on last Wednesday evening, when by 8 o'clock, a huge audience, yielding $1,900, filled the Academy of Music, a feeling of general satisfaction was diffused over the whole assemblage before the orchestra had...
lead_paragraph: For three weeks in the very flush of the season there had been no opera, and we firmly believe that on last Wednesday evening, when by 8 o'clock, a huge audience, yielding $1,900, filled the Academy of Music, a feeling of general satisfaction was diffused over the whole assemblage before the orchestra had struck the first chord. We have heard that in England, when the old style was changed into new by act of Parliament, declaring that the day immediately following the 2d of December, 1852, should be reckoned as the fourteenth, an indignant mob gathered together shouting "Give us back our eleven days." Could we not, with this story in our memory, almost imagine that the elegant multitude of Wednesday evening, finding about the best bit of their season shriveled up was inclined to ejaculate in the little ears of Mr. ULLMAN, "Give us back our three weeks." Not to dwell on the past, Mr. FORMES has with his giant arm fairly lifted up the dethroned and suppliant goddess of song and placed her once more for a time upon her pedestal.

abstract: On Friday last Mr. Edward P. Hudson, of Troy, arrived in this City, and on Saturday evening he passed several hours at a disreputable establishment in Houston-street, kept by one Mrs. Wise. Before he left the place, Hudson discovered that his watch, worth $55, had been stolen from him, conse-...
lead_paragraph: On Friday last Mr. Edward P. Hudson, of Troy, arrived in this City, and on Saturday evening he passed several hours at a disreputable establishment in Houston-street, kept by one Mrs. Wise. Before he left the place, Hudson discovered that his watch, worth $55, had been stolen from him, consequently, he summoned Officer Lyng to arrest Kate Brockway, one of the boarders, supposed to be the thief. Instead of detaining the complainant, as is usually the custom in a case where he is a non-resident, he was permitted to go his ways, and yesterday morning, when the prisoner was taken before Judge CONNOLLY, there was no person to make an affidavit against her. The magistrate, to the delight of her friends, of whom there were many present, was about to discharge her from custody, when he suddenly became indignant at the remissness of the police in the matter, and Officer Lyng was dispatched to find the loser of the property. After some time had elapsed, he returned to Court with that individual, and, in spite of the efforts which had been made to the contrary, the charge against the woman Brockway was pressed, and she was held to answer. It is said that many a notorious rogue goes unwhipt of justice because of collusion on the part of the policemen, who take cure to keep complainants out of the way until after the accused have been arraigned before a magistrate, and discharged for lack of evidence.

abstract: Travelers in the express trains recently placed on this route experience sundry advantages, not to say refinements of railway transit, as compared with the general standard of car traveling in this country. After a short journey (three-quarters of a mile) by horse-power, through clean streets, from the Central station, at Twenty-sixth-street and Fourth-avenue, in cars which, as to cleanliness and plentifulness of upholstery, are far above the average, they are taken by first-class engines, over as smooth a track as leads out of any American city, (the Camden and Amboy excepted,) and landed in Albany in five hours, by arrangements as regular as clock work. The new baggage and mail cars are provided with luxurious smoking rooms, well warmed and ventilated -- an attraction which needs no further comment. The running gear of all the cars is boxed in, and the chasm between the adjacent platforms is bridged -- attachments which deaden noise and prevent the entrance of dust. The. line is peculiarly free from reverberating rock-cuttings. The upper part of the road runs mostly through a country of natural gravel ballast, which much improves the condition of the track. The road has no trestle-work, not much bridging, and easy grades and alignment. It is but about six miles longer, to Albany, than the river route. The scenery on the upper part of the road is peculiarly fine -an extensive view of the river, valley, and the Catskills, in the distance. There are two five hour trains daily -- at 7 A.M. and 5 P.M., and a through accommodation train at 10 A.M. Through tickets and cheeks are issued to the West and Northwest.

abstract: Hon. Peter Boyle de Blazmere, who died suddenly in Yorkville, near Toronto, C.W., on Tuesday night, was born in Dublin on the 26th of April, 1783. Independent of his position as member of the Legislative Council, Mr. De Blazmere held the title of "honorable" in his own right, being the youngest son...
lead_paragraph: -- Hon. Peter Boyle de Blazmere, who died suddenly in Yorkville, near Toronto, C.W., on Tuesday night, was born in Dublin on the 26th of April, 1783. Independent of his position as member of the Legislative Council, Mr. De Blazmere held the title of "honorable" in his own right, being the youngest son of Lord John de Blazmere, of Ardkill county, Londonderry. When very young, he entered the Navy and served as a Midshipman under the celebrated Captain Bligh, of the Bounty, at the battle of Camperdown. He was also present at the mutiny of the Nore. Leaving the navy, however, at an early age he devoted himself to more peaceful pursuits, and emigrated to Canada in 1837. Here he soon attained to the highest honours. In 1858 he was selected as a fit person for a seat in the Legislative Council, which he continued to hold until the time of his death. On the remodeling of the Toronto University, he was appointed to the honorable office of Chancellor, but subsequently resigned. He was also a member of the Anglican Synod, where he commanded great respect. By that body his loss will be severely felt.

abstract: It is eminently desirable that the returns from the State at large on election night should be as reliable and succinct as possible, and in order to prevent the wires from being incumbered with a mass of useless matter, it will be well that the following ideas should be borne in mind: As far as practicable the Press desire to obtain the vote by counties for Presidential Electors and Governor; but where it is impossible to give the full or a near approximation of the result by counties, the scattering returns which may come to hand will be acceptable. The vote of all the large cities is of course desirable, but that of fractional parts of cities or townships should not be allowed to pass over the wires to the hindrance of more important matters. As to members of Congress and the Legislature, the name and politics of the parties chosen, or probably elected, is all that need be telegraphed. The vote for other officers on the State ticket is not required.

abstract: -- Two of the volunteers who were attached to the unfortunate expedition of Gen. Walke in Honduras, -- E.H. Harper and B. Hand -- were in Augusta (Geo.) a few days ago. The Dispatch thus speaks of them: "They arrived here from Charleston in a destitute condition, and have been taken in charge by Wm. E. Evans, our worthy Mayor pro tern., who has generously relieved their pressing necessities at his own expense. Both of them are very intelligent men, and give most thrilling accounts of the death of Walker, and of the condition of Col. Rudler. The latter is loaded with chains and imprisoned in a mine one hundred feet under ground. Messrs. Harper and Hand are on their way to their homes in Tennessee, and we hope they will meet with sympathy and all necessary assistance from all whom they meet."

abstract: The merchants of our City who are so busy in the Fusion movement, will do well to give some little heed to an article which we copy from the Charleston Mercury. It will probably come home somewhat closely to their "business and bosoms." It discusses the ad-...
lead_paragraph: The merchants of our City who are so busy in the Fusion movement, will do well to give some little heed to an article which we copy from the Charleston Mercury. It will probably come home somewhat closely to their "business and bosoms." It discusses the advantages. to the South of secession, -- and foremost among them it places the Repudiation of all their Northern debts. If they can only get rid of the Federal Constitution, they will obliterate their indebtedness to Northern merchants forever. Disunion is to operate, therefore, as an enormous sponge -- to wipe off all their obligations, and release them from the payment of all their dues.
headline: {'main': 'Repudiation and Disunion.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Repudiation and Disunion.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Advices from the Third Assembly District of Westchester County represent a fierce contest going on in the Republican Party with reference to the nomination of Mr. BENJAMIN F. CAMP as member of Assembly from that District. Strong movements are being made to reconsider Mr. CAMP's nomination and to place in the field some Republican who undoubtedly resides within the District. All this trouble arises from an allegation that Mr. CAMP made oath to being a resident of New-York City when he applied a few weeks ago to Judge LEONARD for the Receivership of the Artisans' Bank. Mr. C. has a house in Madison-avenue and a country residence in the town of Somers, which latter place is within the district he seeks to represent. His predecessor in the Republican nomination was Mr. GAYLORD B. HUBBELL, who made a faithful Representative last winter, but failed to acquiesce in the legislation of the majority. Mr. CAMP's Democratic rival is WM. MARSHALL, Jr., also a resident of Somers, and supported through the District by such men as Calvin Frost and Frost Horton, Horace Bailey, Charles Wright, John D. Haines and Isaac Hart Purdy. The contest is one of peculiar closeness and interest, the majority for the Republicans last year having been but three hundred. There can be no doubt but that, if the question of CAMP's residence can be established satisfactorily, or if he be withdrawn, failing this, and another Republican candidate put up in his place, this majority can be augmented, otherwise Mr. MARSHALL would seem to have the inside track.

abstract: An immense turn-out of the Wide-Awakes took place last evening at Newark. From an early hour the streets were filled with people from the city and the neighboring towns, all anxious to secure desirable positions along the line of march. As great pains had been taken by the leaders in the movement to have the affair pass off with eclat, there was an unusual curiosity on the part of all parties to see the demonstration, and amply were they repaid for any amount of trouble they may have encountered in the struggle for place.
lead_paragraph: An immense turn-out of the Wide-Awakes took place last evening at Newark. abstract: Mr. SAMUEL HOTALING, a prominent merchant of this City, formerly a Henry-Clay Whig, more recently a Fillmore man, but now a Republican, addressed the Young Men's Republican Union at their head-quarters, in Stuyvesant Institute, last evening, upon the issues of the campaign.
lead_paragraph: Mr. SAMUEL HOTALING, a prominent merchant of this City, formerly a Henry-Clay Whig, more recently a Fillmore man, but now a Republican, addressed the Young Men's Republican Union at their head-quarters, in Stuyvesant Institute, last evening, upon the issues of the campaign. After alluding to the fact that he had been for 25 years a merchant in this City, doing business with men from all sections of the country; that he had traveled over all the Northern and most of the Southern States, and had made careful observations of the commercial, mechanical, and agricultural resources of both sections, he proceeded to consider at length the question of Slavery, and its relations to the Republican Party and to the country at large. While admitting that Slavery, as it existed in the Southern States, was not a barbarous institution, but was destined under Providence, to work out the ultimate good of the African race, he yet opposed its extension on the ground that the area of Slave Territory was already nearly double that of free territory, and that more territory was not, and would not be for one hundred years to come, needed for Slavery, while it would be needed for Freedom. If all the slaves of all the Southern States were transported to the State of Missouri, and added to the population already there, the State, even then, would not be as thickly populated as the State of New-York now is. And yet a great portion even of New-York was at this day a wilderness. The Slave States, with a population of about 9,000,000, black and white, had an area of nearly 1,000,000 square miles; while the Free States, with a population of 13,000,000 and over, had an area of only 454,000 square miles. In view of these facts there was no necessity, even in the interest of Slavery, for an extension of the institution into new territory, while the rapid increase of free population required that the remaining territory should be reserved for its occupation. The African race, Mr. HOTALING believed, were destined eventually to be restored to their native country, and that their temporary servitude here was the means under God of working out their ultimate salvation and that of their race. To show the improved condition of an American slave over a native African, he related the following: A gentleman, a merchant in this City, with whom I am well acquainted, informed me last year that he had just then received a letter from his own brother, then living in Western Africa, just south of the Guinea Coast, and that he had just attended a large funeral at the residence of one of the Kings there; and that 1,400 persons of their own African blood and kindred were, in cold blood, slaughtered there to celebrate that funeral. And also, that it is a common circumstance, on the occasion of making a dinner party or feast, to slaughter from twenty to fifty living human beings to show their zeal or friendship for their guests. This, gentlemen, is the state and national condition of that portion of Africa now. Revolting as it may seem to you, and untruthful as it may appear to the African population of the United States, it is nevertheless true. And much more might be added to this story of inhumanity practiced there in that land of the fathers of our African people. After alluding to the position of the other candidates upon this all-absorbing question of Slavery, he thus spoke of the stand occupied by Mr. LINCOLN:

abstract: Great attention has been attracted in the political circles of London to an article on the United States under the Presidentship of Mr. BUCHANAN, in the new number of the Edinburgh Review, which was issued on the day before the departure of the mail.
lead_paragraph: Great attention has been attracted in the political circles of London to an article on the United States under the Presidentship of Mr. BUCHANAN, in the new number of the Edinburgh Review, which was issued on the day before the departure of the mail. The text of the article is furnished by HELPER's Impending Crisis, SHEAHAN's Life of Stephen A. Douglas, Mr. SUMNER's speech on the admission of Kansas as a Free State, Mr. EVERETT's Fourth of July Oration at Boston, and Mr. GRATTAN's work on America, published last year in London. The approaching Presidential election has evidently been the impulse to this article, which is written with much vigor of style, and shows a larger share of knowledge of American politics than is usually found on that side of the Atlantic. The writer does not present an analysis of our parties, the nomenclature of which is so perplexing and unintelligible to foreigners, but confines himself to noticing the principal events of Mr. BUCHANAN's Administration, and the state of affairs to which the new President will succeed.
headline: {'main': 'AMERICAN POLITICS ABROAD.; The Edinburgh Review on the Presidency of Mr. Buchanan.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'AMERICAN POLITICS ABROAD.; The Edinburgh Review on the Presidency of Mr. Buchanan.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Last evening His Honor the Mayor transmitted to the Common Council a statement of the expenses incurred by him in the reception and entertainment of His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales. The bills,...
lead_paragraph: Last evening His Honor the Mayor transmitted to the Common Council a statement of the expenses incurred by him in the reception and entertainment of His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales. The bills, taking all things into account, are commendably moderate, their total being but $4,400, of which sum nearly one-half was expended for music in the military and Fire-department parades. These bills are now before the Common Council for approval, and it remains to be seen what action our City Fathers will take in reference to expenditures which, for the most part, were incurred without their sanction, and from any voice in the disposal of which they were rigorously debarred. Perhaps a sense of the obligations due to hospitality may get the better of their wounded pride, but there are other considerations only too likely to deter them from doing justice to the generosity of the Mayor, in this particular case.

abstract: To detect the secret antagonism that exists between the eternal principles of Christianity and the evanescent smoke that curls from the good man's pipe, might puzzle an Oriental mystagogue or confound the metaphysics of AQUINAS himself.
lead_paragraph: To detect the secret antagonism that exists between the eternal principles of Christianity and the evanescent smoke that curls from the good man's pipe, might puzzle an Oriental mystagogue or confound the metaphysics of AQUINAS himself. But it has been discovered in our own epoch, and is now authoritatively announced, in this, the fourth year of BUCHANAN, by the General Conference of the M.E. Church of the State of Ohio. The faith of the Ohio Church and the fumes of the Virginia weed are authentically proclaimed to be mutually destructive. The Athanasian creed and the Book of Discipline are the acids in antagonism with the alkali of the Nicotiana Tabacum; and "full communion" is consequently henceforth incompatible with regalias, maccaboy, or fine-cut cavendish. At the session of the Conference held in Gallipolis a few weeks ago, the following action was taken upon this subject:

abstract: We have already published the meagre extracts of a letter from Mr. BRECKINRIDGE to a gentleman in North Carolina, in which he defines his position upon the question of disunion. We have no hesitation in declaring that it places him in a far worse position than he occupied while refusing to answer. His silence was suspicious, and left room for the inference that he might be tinctured with the treasonable sentiments which all the more distinguished leaders of his party own; but his oracular utterance leaves us little room to doubt that he is only for the Union so long as his party holds power.

abstract: Our Washington correspondent transmits further intelligence concerning the plans of Disunion traitors to break up the Confederation in the event of their being unable to retain the power they have so long wielded to the country's injury and disgrace. The Disunionists know well that the in-...
lead_paragraph: Our Washington correspondent transmits further intelligence concerning the plans of Disunion traitors to break up the Confederation in the event of their being unable to retain the power they have so long wielded to the country's injury and disgrace. The Disunionists know well that the intelligent masses of the South are opposed to their schemes, and their purpose is not to consult them at all, but to have a Convention elected by the Legislatures of the Seceding States, and to confer upon this body full powers to dissolve the Union and elect Mr. BRECKINRIDGE to the Presidency of a Southern Confederacy. It is also reasserted that the Emperor NAPOLEON has been consulted on the subject, and has given promise of protection whenever intervention shall become necessary. However criminal these designs may be, they can only be regarded, in a practical point of view, as the insane and desperate efforts of men whose ruin is already certain. The success of these schemes does not come within the range of possibility, and their, revelation is so far opportune that it will dissuade many voters, North and South, from supporting men so disloyal to their country and a cause so utterly reckless and unworthy.

abstract: The vicinity of the liberty-pole at the junction of Hudson, Franklin and Varick streets, was the scene of a rousing demonstration by the Republicans of the Third Congressional District, to ratify the nomination of AMOR J. WILLIAMSON. The exhilarating music from several bands, the fierce flames of burning tar-barrels, the hissing of pyrotechnics, the glare of Wide-Awake torches, the singing of campaign songs, and the speaking from three stands in English, German, French and Italian, combined to render the occasion interesting and exciting to the thousands collected to witness the demonstration.

abstract: Christ, Jay & Hess vs. Augustus Schell. -- This was an action brought against the defendant, to recover an excess of duties imposed by him as Collector upon some goods imported by the plaintiffs, called in the invoice and the entry gentian blankets. By the Tariff Act of 1846, "blankets of all kinds came in Schedule E., and were liable to a duty of twenty per cent., while "manufactures of wool, not otherwise provided for," were placed in Schedule C., and charged with thirty per cent. duty. These duties were reduced by the Act of 1857 to twenty-four per cent. instead of thirty, and fifteen per cent. instead of twenty.
lead_paragraph: Christ, Jay & Hess vs. Augustus Schell. -- This was an action brought against the defendant, to recover an excess of duties imposed by him as Collector upon some goods imported by the plaintiffs, called in the invoice and the entry gentian blankets. abstract: THE BILLIARD TOURNAMENT The Billiard Tournament continues to excite great interest, and the room of Mr. LYNCH, in Fourteenth-street, where it is held, is daily crowded to its utmost capacity by gentlemen who feel an interest in the game.
lead_paragraph: THE BILLIARD TOURNAMENT The Billiard Tournament continues to excite great interest, and the room of Mr. LYNCH, in Fourteenth-street, where it is held, is daily crowded to its utmost capacity by gentlemen who feel an interest in the game. The games yesterday were first between Messrs. KAVANAGH & WHITE, and did not excite as much interest as was anticipated, The scores made by either were far inferior to their ordinary play. Mr. WHITE was beaten by 132 points, the highest run in the game being 53, which was made by Mr. KAVANAGH, who is a cool and graceful player, but who was evidently nursing himself for the grand contest of Wednesday. The second game between Messrs. TIERNAN and LYNCH, was one of the closest and best-contested of any thus far played. Mr. PHELAN, before the game commenced made an apology for Mr. LYNCH on account of ill-health, which was borne out by his appearance, and on account of the damp atmosphere which affected the tables and balls. The game was then commenced and Mr. LYNCH led off hi some splendid runs, ranging from 74 to 16, but towards the close of the frame his lusty but good-natured antagonist was shined up, and when the game was even within a single point, made a splendid run of 85, and was proclaimed the victor. On Wednesday Messrs. KAVANAGH and TIEMAN will play, and as the prize cue undoubtedly lies between them, much interest is felt as to the result. On Thursday Mr. PHELAN will play a game of 500 points with the winner, on which occasion ladies will be admitted.

abstract: There can be no doubt that German New-York, which ranks third or fourth in size among the Teutonic capitals of the world, is just as devotedly musical as any of its sisters over the sea. However precarious and meagre may be the life of Italian opera among us when Italians sing it to American audiences, the Italian Opera of a German company, addressed to a German house, always prospers exceedingly. Herr FORMES and Madame FABBRI are in the way of agreeably appreciating this fact at the present time. Last night, though the temperature of the world and of the Academy was decidedly oriental, the opera of the "Huguenots" was sung to a tremendous audience, the first thorough and unquestionable crowd of the season.

abstract: The euphonious strains of "Dixy's Land" and "Aint I glad Uncle Abe's going to the White House," as sung by the stentorian as well as harmonious City Wide-Awake Club, attracted a great deal of attention last night, at about 11 o'clock, in front of the TIMES' Building. About fifty members of the Club were present in uniforms, bearing torches and transparencies, and headed by a band. After singing several songs, giving a variety of Wide-Awake cheers, and three old-fashioned huzzas for the TIMES, they marched off in fine style -- refraining from noticing the cheers for the "Union ticket" and a few for DOUGLAS, proceeding from a crowd in the vicinity -- except by giving counter-cheers for LINCOLN.

abstract: Hon. W.H. HOOPER, member of Congress, and lady, left this city, last Saturday, for Washington. With Mr. HOOPER, started the remnants of the company of Mormon Missionaries for the States and Europe. These missionaries appeared to be well fitted out for their journey across the plains, doubtless owing to the liberal contributions of the faithful, instigated by the fatherly BRIGHAM.

abstract: On Friday last a broken rail on the Fall River line turned over a car containing thirtyfive passengers, many of whom were thereby severely, and at least three, seriously injured.
lead_paragraph: On Friday last a broken rail on the Fall River line turned over a car containing thirtyfive passengers, many of whom were thereby severely, and at least three, seriously injured. Although this is an occurrence of considerable importance to these people who are maimed for life, it so far pales before the grander works of cheap engineering that we read about every few months, as to be quite indistinct to the general public. The fact is, however, that those untiring riflemen -- broken rails, axles and wheels, misplaced switches, loose rail-joints, rotten sleepers, all the evils of bad drainage, cattle and rocks on the track, and the absence of a thorough system of brakes and signals -- these steady riflemen slaughter quite as many innocents in a decade as the spasmodic artillery which now and then sweeps them down by companies as at Norwalk, Hamilton and Burlington.

abstract: The NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, a large folio double-sheet, issued this morning, contains an extended and comprehensive summing-up of the great Political Cause about to be submitted to the Country. The Progress of the Secessionist Movement, and the active and patriotic opposition offered to it by friends of the whole Union at the South; the alleged complicity of members of the Federal Cabinet in the conspiracy; the conflict in this State between Republicanism and Cash-Conservatism; and the general aspects of the battle-ground, are among the topics illustrated and discussed in this number.
lead_paragraph: The NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, a large folio double-sheet, issued this morning, contains an extended and comprehensive summing-up of the great Political Cause about to be submitted to the Country. abstract: We are in receipt of papers and correspondence from the City of Mexico to the 17th inst. We obtain some particulars of the capture of Guadalajara by the Liberal forces, and the extent is generally regarded as the turning point of the civil war. It would appear that the suffering of the people in...
lead_paragraph: We are in receipt of papers and correspondence from the City of Mexico to the 17th inst. We obtain some particulars of the capture of Guadalajara by the Liberal forces, and the extent is generally regarded as the turning point of the civil war. It would appear that the suffering of the people in the city while the siege lasted was very great -- so great that the bombardment had to be suspended for about three hours, in order that women and children might leave the town. The Mexican papers do not contain an account of the fall of Guadalajara, but the passengers who left the capital on the 17th report that the city was taken on the 11th inst. Next to this great Liberal victory, the most important feature of the news is the withdrawal of the British Minister from the capital -- he having received instructions from his Government to hold no further intercourse with the Church authorities. The condition of the city of Mexico is described as a complete reign of terror, and the triumph of the Liberal cause is earnestly looked for by all classes of the Mexican people. There is every reason to hope that this triumph will not now be long delayed.

abstract: The Republicans of the Eleventh, Fifteenth and Seventeenth Wards, met last evening at the Cooper Institute, to ratify the nomination of Hon. FREDERICK A. CONKLING, for Congressman from the Sixth District. The hall was crowded. Mr. ROBERT H. McCURDY
lead_paragraph: The Republicans of the Eleventh, Fifteenth and Seventeenth Wards, met last evening at the Cooper Institute, to ratify the nomination of Hon. FREDERICK A. CONKLING, for Congressman from the Sixth District. The hall was crowded. Mr. ROBERT H. McCURDY called the meeting to order, expressed his gratification that so large a number were present in spite of the unpleasant weather, announced the object of the meeting, and dwelt upon the importance of sending Republican Congressmen to Washington, to support the Administration of Mr. LINCOLN. He alluded to the idle clamor about disunion, and predicted that as soon as the objects of the Republican Party were rightly understood, their Southern brethren would rally to its support. For the City of New-York he wanted to say a word. She had been too long ruled by demagogues, and she owed it to herself, to the nation, and to LINCOLN and HAMLIN [applause] to send representatives to Washington who would serve her ably and faithfully. Such an one was FREDERICK A. CONKLING, who was presented for their suffrages in this District. [Applause.]

abstract: It is a well known fact that the Democrats of the South are not the only slaveholders. On the contrary, we believe that in proportion to numbers, the Opposition own more slaves than the Democracy. It is also a fact that the...
lead_paragraph: It is a well known fact that the Democrats of the South are not the only slaveholders. On the contrary, we believe that in proportion to numbers, the Opposition own more slaves than the Democracy. It is also a fact that the largest slaveholders among the Democrats are the most conservative, and least prone to indulge in threats of disunion. Why is it, then, that all Southern patriotism is monopolized by Democrats, as they choose to call themselves, and that all threats of resistance or secession, on the event of LINCOLN's election, come from what party? Nearly or quite half the popular vote of the South will be given for Mr. BELL and Mr. DOUGLAS, yet not one of these voters or their political leaders avows disunion sentiments, although they are deeply interested in slavery. Is not this a strange state of things? Are these men destitute of the patriotism, the courage, and the intelligence which actuate the supporters of BRECKINRIDGE? If they be not wanting in these virtues, how comes it that they never menace the North with disunion, in the event of defeat?
headline: {'main': 'Who Threatened Disunion, and Why.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Who Threatened Disunion, and Why.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The months of this Autumn do not bring us a very rich bibliothical harvest. Granary floors seem destined to groan beneath a greater burden than library shelves. This, however, is the fault of people and of politics more than of publishers. Presidential seasons are provervially dull ones for...
lead_paragraph: The months of this Autumn do not bring us a very rich bibliothical harvest. Granary floors seem destined to groan beneath a greater burden than library shelves. This, however, is the fault of people and of politics more than of publishers. Presidential seasons are provervially dull ones for the book trade. Buried in the somewhat difficult work of making Presidents, the public have no time for reading books, and this fact is very well understood and appreciated by our publishers, who, during these exciting seasons muzzle, or at least, muffle, their presses. Still, the winds of Autumn have not alone been employed scattering leaves through the land -- our enterprising publishers have rivaled them in a small degree. It is worthy of note, too, that the Autumn books have caught the prevailing hue of the season, and come to us clad in brown, in russet, and in gold. Tinted paper is fast becoming, rather the rule than the exception; and the quaint old English typography is becoming so general a favorite that we open each new volume in the expectation of finding an illuminated title-page, and in the body of the book, "A rivulet of text meandering through a meadow of margin," quite in the olden style. Those who think that the cutting and color of a book's dress is a matter of no moment, are very much mistaken. Ideas are judged by their outward covering quite as much as individuals, and a book out of fashion would be quite as much out of fashion as a beauty.

abstract: The best informed of our Southern correspondents begin to assure us that the extreme excitement which has for some time past reigned throughout the Southern States, in anticipation of the election of Mr. LINCOLN, already exhibits symptoms of decline.
lead_paragraph: The best informed of our Southern correspondents begin to assure us that the extreme excitement which has for some time past reigned throughout the Southern States, in anticipation of the election of Mr. LINCOLN, already exhibits symptoms of decline. It is more than probable, now, that the State of South Carolina must be regarded as the sole pivot of the Southern revolution, and that the rest of the slaveholding Sovereignties will defer the resumption of their supreme attributes, and the open defiance of the constitutional authorities of the Union, until the Palmetto State shall act in the premises. Whether the Palmetto State will or will not act at all in the premises is another question, upon which we have not yet sufficient grounds for pronouncing a decisive opinion. South Carolina is a very peculiar State, and occupies a quite exceptional position in the Republic. Nowhere else have the ideas of the permanence of Slavery, and of the capacity of the South for independence, struck root so deeply as in the Commonwealth of CALHOUN. Yet, at the same time, it must be remembered that the society of South Carolina is singularly well organized, and therefore essentially conservative, and that the influence of property in that State is more direct and more openly recognized than in any other part of the Confederation.

abstract: It is now privately conceded by all intelligent Democrats that the Republican Electoral ticket will sweep the State of New-York by a majority variously estimated at between fifty and seventy thousand. For this result the original Douglas men are anxious to hold the Albany Regency responsible, the charge being...
lead_paragraph: It is now privately conceded by all intelligent Democrats that the Republican Electoral ticket will sweep the State of New-York by a majority variously estimated at between fifty and seventy thousand. For this result the original Douglas men are anxious to hold the Albany Regency responsible, the charge being that but for "fusion," Mr. LINCOLN could have stood no chance of carrying the State. Of course, such criminations are but natural in view of certain defeat, all men attempting to evade the consequences of their own share in the general ruin, and to fix it on the shoulders of those to whom they stand opposed. As the controlling power of the Democracy of our State, Messrs. RICHMOND, CAGGER and CHURCH will find it difficult to clear their skirts of blame. It was on their sole motion that the original fusion with the Native Americans was made last August at Syracuse, and it was upon this entering wedge in the Douglas ranks that those blows were struck home which have already split the Democratic Party into a mass of incoherent fragments, without either candidate, principle or rallying-cry.

abstract: There was a large and enthusiastic meeting at the Republican Wigwam at Greenpoint, last evening, at which Hon. GALUSHA A. GROW, of Pennsylvania, was the principal speaker. Every vacant seat and all the standing-room inside of the building was occupied, and large numbers congregated outside to listen to the address. Mr. GROW, on being introduced,...
lead_paragraph: There was a large and enthusiastic meeting at the Republican Wigwam at Greenpoint, last evening, at which Hon. GALUSHA A. GROW, of Pennsylvania, was the principal speaker. Every vacant seat and all the standing-room inside of the building was occupied, and large numbers congregated outside to listen to the address. Mr. GROW, on being introduced, was received with enthusiastic cheers. He said, it could hardly be expected of him, after speaking for the last eight weeks, as TOM CORWIN has said, 36 hours out of 24, that he should detain them with a lengthy speech. The Presidential election might be considered as settled, and nothing remained but for the people to meet, express their preferences and count the votes. It was not necessary, therefore, that he should detain them with arguments in favor of placing ABE LINCOLN of Illinois in the Presidential chair. But there was another and very unfortunate question for them to settle -- a Congress was to be elected, on which would devolve the work of sustaining his Administration, and from which must emanate the bills which would affect, for all time to come, the interests of the country. Mr. GROW then passed to a definition of the features of the Homestead bill, and the advantages which it secured to the actual settlers upon the unoccupied lands of the West; the efforts of the last Congress to pass such a bill; the opposition of Democratic members; and the final veto of the "Old Public Functionary;" of the half-way measure which they were finally obliged 10 accept. The bill was intended to close forever the doors of the public land offices against the land monopolist -- the deadliest curse which had ever been inflicted upon the country. He demanded that in this New World the seeds of the giant wrong should not be planted, to bring forth the harvest of misery for the poor man who should seek a refuge for himself and family from the tyranny of capital. By what right, he asked, does the Government seize upon this common bounty to the race, and turn it into a source of revenue? As well might they dam up the springs which the Creator had caused to "run among the hills" to quench the thirst of God's children, and set them apart for the benefit of speculators. The poor man, under the present system, was compelled to purchase these lands of speculators at $5 and $10 per acre, and spend the best part of his days in paying the first cost and interest upon the purchase, and then, broken down and exhausted by his hard labors, surrender his improvements to some non-resident speculator. The Government was asked to extend its protection to the families and firesides of these poor men, and make their homes comfortable, by forbidding the speculator to come in and rob them of the fruits of their honest toil. The Homestead bill was framed for this purpose. The deprivations and dangers to which the present system exposed the pioneers, by isolating them from each other, and compelling them to carry the sword in one hand, and the implements of husbandry in the other, was eloquently set forth by the speaker. He referred to the action of the Democratic members of the House of Representatives upon the Homestead bill, the action of the Senate, and the final veto of the President. The policy of the Republican Party had always been that those who had been driven from their homes in Europe, by a necessity as dire as death, should find a free home in the great West, and the protection of the Government for themselves and their families; that they should thus become attached to the Government which afforded them an asylum, and gave them a home and country to love. Yet every member from the Slaveholding States except two, voted against this beneficent measure.

abstract: THE CASE OF HURRY AND THE GAMBLERS. In accordance with a previous arrangement the four men named JAMES STEWART, CHARLES RANSOM, JOHN COLTON and FREDERICK BLACKMAN, who are charged with keeping gambling houses, yesterday were brought before Justice KELLY for examination. It will be recollected that the complaints against these men were...
lead_paragraph: THE CASE OF HURRY AND THE GAMBLERS. In accordance with a previous arrangement the four men named JAMES STEWART, CHARLES RANSOM, JOHN COLTON and FREDERICK BLACKMAN, who are charged with keeping gambling houses, yesterday were brought before Justice KELLY for examination. It will be recollected that the complaints against these men were preferred by WM. HURRY, jr., who, at the time they, were made, was in the custody of detective HOGAN, charged with having embezzled about $5,000 from the firm of QUICK & L'HOMMEDIEU, brokers at No. 42 Pine-street. HURRY stated to the officer that he had lost a portion of the money in question at the faro banks kept by the above-named persons, and he was taken before Justice KELLY, before; whom he lodged the complaints, but at that time the magistrate was not aware of the fact that HURRY was a prisoner on a criminal charge. Warrants for the arrest of the accused parties were accordingly issued and given to Detective HOOAN, who took his own time to serve them, and it was not till after the lapse of two days or more that the prisoners were brought before the magistrate. Even then the officer had taken no pains to secure additional evidence against them, not even the implements with which they pursue their avocation. Yesterday, when all the parties were in Court, the counsel for QUICK & L'HOMMEDIEU begged to withdraw the complaint against HURRY, alleging that as it failed to charge any intent to defraud it was incomplete. HURRY was therefore discharged, but he was directed to find bail in the sum of $500 to appear, and prosecute at the Court of Special Sessions on the 15th of November. The alleged gamblers were also held in $500 each to answer. It is not probable that the trial will result in the conviction of the accused, as the affidavit of the complainant will be looked upon with suspicion, and the officer failed to secure any other evidence to substantiate the charge.

abstract: The new Hall of the Brooklyn Athenaeum was opened to the public, last evening, and the introductory lecture of the season delivered by JAMES T. BRADY: The Hall has undergone so many and so important changes in its interior arrangements as to merit its descriptive term, "new." Scarce a vestige of the old time square barn of a room remains.
lead_paragraph: The new Hall of the Brooklyn Athenaeum was opened to the public, last evening, and the introductory lecture of the season delivered by JAMES T. BRADY: The Hall has undergone so many and so important changes in its interior arrangements as to merit its descriptive term, "new." Scarce a vestige of the old time square barn of a room remains. In its place the Brooklynites have a commodious and well-arranged hall, in every respect worthy of their city. And to honor its initiation, the beauty and intelligence of Brooklyn came out in goodly numbers last evening, in spite of the muddy condition of the pavements, and the prevailing dampness of the evening. Perhaps, too, they were moved by a laudable desire to assist Mr. BRADY in solving the self-proposed question embodied in the subject-title of his lecture, "Who are we?"

abstract: In another column will be found a very interesting letter from the District-Attorney, addressed to Mr. JELLINGHAUS, President of the Board of Immigrant and Benevolent Societies, in reference to the extraordinary decision delivered by Judge RUSSELL, on the trial of two alleged ticket-swindlers, named WARD and...
lead_paragraph: In another column will be found a very interesting letter from the District-Attorney, addressed to Mr. JELLINGHAUS, President of the Board of Immigrant and Benevolent Societies, in reference to the extraordinary decision delivered by Judge RUSSELL, on the trial of two alleged ticket-swindlers, named WARD and GILBERT, under the act passed last Winter to prevent frauds in the sale of passenger tickets. On that occasion the prosecution proved that one of the prisoners had sold tickets for a line of packet ships of which he was not the agent, this being contrary to the law, and entailing penalties for ticket-swindling. The theory of defence was that the prisoner had been appointed sub-agent by a third party; but no attempt was made to prove that the latter was himself a duly authorized agent, or had any power to transfer his authority.

abstract: That portion of the Democracy of the Third Congressional District favoring the election of Mr. BENJAMIN WOOD, met in full force last evening, at the junction of Hudson, Varick and Franklin streets. There were several bands of music in attendance, and throughout the evening delegations arrived from the First, Second, Third, Fifth and Eight Wards, bearing manifold torches, transparencies, banners, fireworks and other insignia of enthusiasm.
lead_paragraph: That portion of the Democracy of the Third Congressional District favoring the election of Mr. BENJAMIN WOOD, met in full force last evening, at the junction of Hudson, Varick and Franklin streets. There were several bands of music in attendance, and throughout the evening delegations arrived from the First, Second, Third, Fifth and Eight Wards, bearing manifold torches, transparencies, banners, fireworks and other insignia of enthusiasm. With the tar barrels, torches, pyrotechnics and bonfires, the square was brilliantly illuminated. Early in the evening the crowd began to collect, and by 8 o'clock there were several thousand persons collected in the vicinity of the two stands erected for the speakers. The meeting at the main stand fronting on Hudson-street having been duly organized, a series of resolutions were adopted -- among which was the following, proclaiming the irrepressible conflict:
